name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on the presentation of the annual report of the European Court of Auditors - 2014 (2015/2852 (RSP)). I would like to warmly welcome Mr Vitor Caldeira, President of the Court of Auditors.

name: Vítor Manuel da Silva Caldeira
text: President of the Court of Auditors. – Madam President, I am honoured to present the Court’s annual report to this plenary session of the European Parliament. This year it comes at a particularly difficult time. On behalf of all of us at the Court, I would like to express our deepest condolences to the French people and to the families of the victims of the recent terrorist attacks in Paris. Those who attack European values are actually attacking our democracy. We must all stand firm against them. This is a time for European solidarity, to defend the fundamental values in our Treaty. It is a time when the European Union and Member States must also address other major challenges: generating jobs and growth; meeting energy needs while achieving climate goals; and managing asylum and migration flows. In our view, the European budget could be invested better and more quickly to meet the many challenges Europe faces. Taken together, our audit results over recent years point to a need for a wholly new approach: decision-makers must align the budget better with the European Union’s long-term strategic priorities and make it more capable of responding in a crisis; legislators need to ensure that spending schemes are clear about the results to be achieved and the risk it is acceptable to take; financial managers have to ensure that the money spent complies with the rules and achieves the intended results. Next year’s mid-term review of the Multiannual Financial Framework provides a crucial opportunity to rethink our priorities and the design of some spending schemes. In the meantime, more must be done with the tools already in place. Our report identifies long-standing financial management issues that need to be addressed. But before I go through them, I would like to be absolutely clear that the 2014 European Union accounts have been signed off. They are reliable and we have issued a clean audit opinion to that effect. That said, let me highlight four areas of European Union financial management requiring attention. First, too much money is still not spent in accordance with the European Union’s financial rules. There is a persistently high level of payment errors. The overall estimated error rate for payments in 2014 was 4.4%, and it has been stable for the last three years. The Commission and Member States have made progress in recent years in preventing and correcting errors, but more errors could have been corrected if all the available information had been used. Our analysis shows that there is scope to design spending schemes that are less error—prone, in particular by simplifying payment conditions and procedures. Second, the performance of the budget. The European Union must invest the budget better. We found that the Multiannual Financial Framework could be better aligned with the EU’s strategy, both in terms of periods and priorities. We also highlight the fact that the high level of European Union targets and political aims is not translated into clear operational objectives, which is fundamental for effective management and reporting on performance. Third, the European Union needs to deal with a number of financial backlogs that have built up, not least to free up funds so that they can be used where they are needed most. In particular, some Member States are struggling to absorb the EU funds they have been allocated, and there continues to be a high level of unused funds in financial instruments. Finally, European Union financial management would strongly benefit from improved transparency, because this is crucial to ensuring citizens’ trust. We have recommended the action the Commission should take to improve transparency about long—term cash flow needs, payment errors and corrections made, as well as the results of spending the European Union budget. But it is equally important to ensure transparency for European Union policies not directly funded from the European Union budget. New ways of funding European Union policies should not put financial risks beyond public scrutiny and audit. To conclude, the European Union must invest its money better. It must act to ensure that its investments better match the European Union’s priorities; that simpler rules are framed to achieve results; and that financial resources are managed more efficiently. Taken together, all this would indeed represent a wholly new approach. The Court of Auditors stands alongside Parliament and the other European institutions at this very difficult time. Defending our democracy and ensuring the well—being of our citizens will place a great burden on our common resources. Helping to ensure that those resources are used to their best effect will continue to be the principal task of the European Court of Auditors. (Applause)

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, President Caldeira, members of the Court, on behalf of the Commission I would like to express our deepest gratitude to the Court for the work you do. It helps us to use our taxpayers’ money better. I fully agree with the call by President Caldeira for a new approach, and it is what we have embraced in the Commission with our strategy on a results-focused budget. We have made progress on financial management, and the Court has recognised that our accounts are in order by signing them for an eighth year in a row. They are modern, they are up to standard, and we thank the Court for the work it has done that helped us to stabilise the error rate and, indeed, to reduce it slightly. That is a trend that we must pursue in the future. However, we also recognise there is more work to be done, and I would like to focus my response on the four points that President Caldeira made. Firstly, we have work to do on bringing the error rate down further by improving the quality of first-level checks, by continuing our simplification efforts – simpler rules mean fewer errors – and by further deepening work on the cost-effectiveness of checks. The Court tells us that we have a higher level in respect of schemes that reimburse costs, and a lower level in respect of entitlement programmes. We have to take this into account. Secondly, we fully agree with the Court about the importance of focusing on performance. We are in a very difficult time for the European Union, and every single euro matters. The Union has to work better for our people, and this is at the heart of the work we are doing on a results-focused budget. We will also continue combining performance and compliance. We believe that work we have started already on preventive and corrective action in relation to errors is bringing positive results: EUR 3.5 billion has been returned to the budget thanks to corrective action and preventive action that we have taken. We believe that, if we take into account the calculated residual error rate, we would be very close to the 2% that we strive to achieve. Thirdly, on financial backlogs. This was a priority issue in the discussion on the 2016 budget, and we are committed to bringing the backlog down to EUR 2 billion by the end of 2016 – to a sustainable level. And of course, work has to concentrate on the new programmes so we do not end up with the same problem three years down the road. Last but definitely not least: transparency is our taxpayers’ best friend, and we are committed to continuing to improve it. We are grateful to Parliament for recognising that we have made progress over this last year in terms of the transparency of our work, and we absolutely commit here to continuing that effort in the future. In conclusion, President Caldeira said we must invest money better. We agree.

name: Claudia SCHMIDT
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The error rate for the 2014 financial year, estimated by the Court of Auditors, is 3.8% for the European Development Fund. In the previous financial year, we were still 3.4%.  As usual, we are again well above the 2% threshold. The sources of error also remain the same: procurement rules are disregarded, there is no evidence to support expenditure, and ineligible expenditure is incurred and so on. What interests me is that, as of 31.12.2014, the outstanding commitments amount to EUR 9 673 million, because we are still spending money from the 8th EDF, which was made available 20 years ago. This means that we are talking about a levy rate of 19.7%, that is, less than one fifth of the total budget. Do we know where this money is, what is to be done with it, why it is more or less frozen? Especially in this day and age, we cannot afford to leave almost EUR 10 billion simply behind. That is why, as rapporteur for the discharge, I expect enlightening answers.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, I would like to thank the President of the Court of Auditors, Mr Caldeira, and the entire Court, all its members, for the report they have presented to us for this year. Diagnosis remains a serious diagnosis, because the sick person, who is our budget, has undergone and continues to be subjected to great difficulties: ever smaller; increasingly financialized, through financial instruments that, as we see, have an implementation problem and also control; under great strains because of their own resources, which are european in nature, but from resources of intergovernmental origin, which means that those who consider themselves owners of the resources can decide in a conjunctural manner on their fate; and also subject to delays and serious risks of non-payment, as the Court tells us. But the Court also tells us that there is hope, that is, it tells Parliament, the institutions — also the Commission, of course - that we need a new approach and that in 2017, in this review of the financial perspective, it is when we will be able to improve, with everything we have learned in recent years, and to ensure that the European budget ceases to be subject to totally conjunctural changes. In a few months we have gone on to want to cure with it the economic crisis, youth unemployment, the refugee crisis and now the security crisis, and this series of elements cannot be financed improvised by the European budget, which was in principle intended to recover the Europe 2020 Strategy. However, there are new elements in the report that will help us: everything that the trend has changed; the mistakes of shared management and direct management have been further matched — then, Mrs Georgieva, Madam Vice-President, we are going to have to help us to improve the direct management of the Commission; and we also thank the Court of Auditors for pointing out the nature of the errors. I believe that it is precisely with all that information that we will be able to improve the configuration not only of the 2016 budget, which has just been adopted, and its control, but also the revision of next year.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank the European Court of Auditors for the report and the work which was done by it. I would like to recall that the indication of great importance here is that the European decision-makers must align the budget better with the European Union’s long-term strategic priorities. The budget has especially to be more responsive in a crisis. We have to ensure that spending schemes outline the results to be achieved. The EU should be a better manager of its budget and should invest better, and to make this possible, it should reconcile its priorities. The money spent should always achieve the intended result. The estimated error rate for expenditure is still high: 4.4%. Although some errors were corrected, this is still such a high rate.

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: on the alde group. – Madam President, Commissioner, President of the Court of Auditors, I thank all the members of the European Court of Auditors who, when presenting the 2014 accounts, called for the budget to be in tune with the Long-Term Strategic Priorities of the European Union, as well as for increasing the capacity of European funds to respond more flexibly to Europe's current needs. I consider this new approach to managing investment and expenditure to be very correct at European level. As rapporteur for the 2014 Discharge of the European Commission, I am heading in the same direction.  My first priority is to put emphasis on performance and on real economic effect, not just on the legal and formal accuracy of documents. We must strike a new balance between compliance with formalities and a stronger focus on results. I believe that the way European money is being managed should be viewed comprehensively and in context. After all, if this money is public, it must be subject to competent, objective and transparent scrutiny. The economy of the management of public resources is far from over by comparing the reality of the money spent with the rules formally adopted, on the contrary, it starts for me by finding out what each particular expenditure and its overall total has actually produced in a given period. My second priority is to help the Union meet its commitments and start presenting its achievements. We urgently need to stop just looking for missteps and shortcomings, but we also need to show examples of good practice that have high added value and can inspire us into the future.  My third priority is close cooperation with stakeholders across the Institutions of the European Union. The Annual Report of the European Court of Auditors talks in several places about the culture of performance as a quality necessary for the long-term sound financial management of public resources redistributed through the European Union budget. If we can achieve this culture of performance together and adopt its common understanding and understanding, I will consider my 2014 discharge target to be fulfilled. Finally, let me quote a Czech proverb that says, "Good accounts make good friends." I believe that the pursuit of economical management of European funds and the effort to avoid unnecessary losses unite us across member countries and across the political spectrum at this difficult time.

name: Dennis de JONG
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Thank you to Mr Caldera and the Court of Auditors for the report. It is, of course, a gloomy report, which still shows that the number of errors is too high. This will undoubtedly be discussed in the Committee on Budgetary Control next year, where pressure will be put on the Commission and the Member States.  I would like to concentrate on a few other points. We all agree that the citizens of Europe want to know the results of European Union spending, and I am very much in favour of performance and results-oriented budgeting. But there are also some risks. First, it should not get bogged down in a system of indicators that makes Democrats happy, but which in reality only increase costs.  Secondly, European added value must be made clear in ordinary human language. Let me give one example: in its annual anti-fraud report, the European Commission, as one of the most important results of the Hercules III programme, reports that 55 conferences and seminars are being organised. This is fun for civil servants and useful for getting to know each other, but it does not make citizens in Europe happy. They want to know what the real results of these meetings are now. How does cooperation really improve and how can we measure it? A result must also be compared to all costs incurred. Would projects without European funding have also been achieved? Is money simply spent because it is there or was there an acute need? How much is the cost for local regional authorities, for example, to rake in projects? In Brussels, they have almost all of them lobbying firms. They cost money, too. Do we include these costs in determining European added value? Then there's a whole other point. The Court of Auditors is right to distinguish between errors and fraud. But if the proportion of serious errors in procurement increases from 0.8% to 1.2% in one year, then I wonder if there is no longer any work to be done here. Of course, contracting is a separate profession. However, is there no deliberate malversation here and should serious errors not be treated as fraud?

name: Bart STAES
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. I thank you for the work done. We have a great deal of influence from the Court of Auditors. But this is the 17th time I have done this exercise and I have to say that there is absolutely little progress. I sigh deeply. The error rate remains high, 4.4 percent. In the debate earlier , and rejoicing in the debate, The Commissioner said that the error rate remains stable. But it also means that in almost one in 20 cases of audits, errors are discovered by the Court of Auditors! I know that is not fraud, but it is grist to the mill of Eurosceptics. We know that the basic problem lies with the Member States. Eighty percent of our resources are used in shared management and it is the Member States that usually knew or could have known that mistakes were made.  So, Commissioner, I ask you clearly and clearly: will you indicate which Member States are refusing to improve the situation here? Will you appoint them and will you also take action to effectively recover the funds that were paid out?

name: Marco VALLI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to thank the President of the Court of Auditors, because he does a very important job and helps us in the process of budgetary control of the Union. However, like my colleague Bart Staes, I have to note many and too many irregularities, especially in the management of the Structural Funds.  We have seen from your reports, which over the years always have the same indications, such as the Member States, in this opaque management of funds, especially of the European Social Fund and the European Regional Development Fund, those funds that should give added value in our territories, prove to be opaque: contracts awarded directly and failure to publish procurement documentation. It is a system that has been going on for too long and there are too many billions at stake. At a time of crisis, it is absolutely essential to act and impose, in a certain sense, transparency measures on those who are not transparent.  On the question of the European Investment Bank, it should be noted that often the lack of transparency of contracts and subcontracting relating to infrastructure investments. The documentation on subcontracting must always be clear and transparent, because the European Investment Bank – which manages european citizens' money – cannot guarantee a return to unclear companies, which may also have links to organised crime.  With regard to the subject of pre-accession funds, we absolutely want more transparency. Let us give a lot of billions to Turkey, which – as we have seen – occupies the seventh position among the beneficiaries of funds, including from the EIB: a country outside the European Union which, however, is the seventh beneficiary of these funds! We want transparency on the pre-accession funds. Nothing is known about the funds for refugees. These countries are being given billions of euros and, at this time of pressure in that very geographical area, it is important to know what is being financed in those countries with every single euro of our taxpayers.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as in 2012 and 2013, the European Court of Auditors is giving an unfavourable opinion on the legality and regularity of payments made by the Union, estimating the level of error at 4.4%, well above the 2% threshold. As such, I would like to draw your attention to the particularly high level of error in the allocation of European Structural Funds, with a rate that explodes to 5.7%.  As this report indicates, performance should be at the heart of public servants' priorities. Moreover, the complexity of administrative procedures and the crossover of the Europe 2020 strategy with the multi-year financial framework are the source of unbearable financial anomalies to the detriment of the European peoples. Therefore, it is not the tightening of controls or certain payment suspensions that will resolve anything.  All this, of course, is still very inadequate in view of the challenges ahead.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). Madam President, over the last five years the Court of Auditors' annual reports have unfortunately said that the error rate of European expenditure is constantly increasing. This practically translates into the fact that the accounts of the European Union are unreliable.  We must be more careful in the management and control of European funds. The practice of reckless spending needs to change, just to absorb funds. We need to focus more on results and compliance with the rules, so that in the medium to long term there are sufficient funds to be allocated to the Budget of the European Union.  In areas such as regional policy, energy, transport, the environment and fisheries, funds are managed jointly between the Commission and the Member States. As well-wishers as we are, high error rates in expenditure cannot be solely due to non-compliance with European directives.  We must control and penalise cases of fraud, inadequacy and waste. For example, if a small and medium-sized enterprise, while owning a larger one, receives payments from European resources as small and medium-sized enterprises, then we are talking about fraud and not inconsistency of rules.  Such practices must be stopped so that the European taxpayer is not burdened.

name: Markus PIEPER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Every year again - this year two clues. Firstly, on the area of expenditure 'Europe in the world': unfortunately, we have to accept drastically increasing errors in the areas of foreign policy, and the handling of crisis states is sensitive – now also under the heading of refugees. This makes it all the more difficult for us as the EU to assume direct responsibility and not just blindly trust the aid organisations. Secondly, on the Court's approach to investigation: yes, the approach of the Europe-wide qualitative sample is effective and brings things to the point. However, working with samples is also prone to tampering. Is it a coincidence that last year's outliers, Spain and Greece, are suddenly supposed to have a reliable administration? I stand by this: without accompanying country reports, the Court's general report does not get to the bottom of the real causes of fraud and error. Mr Caldeira, you are finally creating more trust and transparency by really scrutinising individual countries and not hiding behind the overall view!

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, President of the Court of Auditors, I wish to repeat that the accounts have been signed off and that errors, of course, are not fraud, although we should naturally keep trying to reduce them. Member States can play their part. Indeed, they already have the information to stop or correct many of the errors, and they should use that information. At EU level we should do more on simplification to help reduce errors. For the current cohesion policy programmes, some attempts have been made to reduce errors through simplification, for example through the introduction of cohesion flat-rate payments and having one set of common regulations for the five different funds, although each of the individual funds still has its own rules. Hopefully the High-Level Group established by the Commissioner will look at this particular issue and many others, because it is important that we reduce bureaucracy and make things as simple as possible for beneficiaries, for auditors, for Member States and for regions. Indeed, when we visit regions and projects, they continue to make the same plea for greater simplification. I also wanted to comment quickly on the issue of measuring performance. I think it is absolutely right that we should be looking to measure performance. The question is what we measure and how we measure it. Obviously, we need to do a lot more work on that, but it must surely be right for us to measure the results of spending of EU funds. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Madam President, dear colleague, you have spoken of simplification and it is something that everyone complains about in all countries, including the administration, not just private firms. I ask you: do you think there is a direct link between the complexity of writing programmes and the mistakes that are being made and the corruption that arises in attracting European funds? Do you think there is a direct link and what should be done?

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: blue-card answer. – I do not think that there is a link between simplification and corruption, but I think that there definitely is a link between simplification and reducing the number of errors. That is why I said in my contribution that whenever we visit Member States’ regions, businesses or anybody involved in projects, they plead for greater simplification. They believe that this is one of the best ways – probably the best way – to reduce errors.

name: Richard ASHWORTH
text: – Madam President, I would like to say to Mr Caldeira that there is a depressing familiarity to the Court of Auditors’ report. For far too many years it is the same areas of spend showing the same errors of spend. I agree with you, Mr Caldeira, that it is time for a fresh approach. Firstly, because Mr Vaughan is right: he was right when he said there is a direct relationship between the complexity of regulation and the consequent level of error. Secondly, because the high emphasis on compliance comes at the expense of evaluation of outcomes and quality of spend. To achieve those, we need greater levels of transparency and of accountability. Both of these we can only really achieve when the people elected by the taxpayers adopt responsibility and the scrutiny role for expenditure of the taxpayers’ money.

name: Nedzhmi ALI
text: – Madam President, we welcome the appeal for a wholly new approach to the management of EU investment and spending. Certainly the EU budget should be better aligned to the long-term strategic priorities. At the same time, it should be more agile and allow a higher degree of responsiveness to the changing parameters of the dynamic environment. In order to achieve the optimal outcome from the introduction of performance-based budgeting, not only should the intended results be clear, but the financial resources should also be spent lawfully and the intended result accomplished. In order to reduce the level of errors, it is of the utmost importance to undertake massive simplification of the procedures. Despite the positive steps taken by the Commission in introducing the ‘budget focused on results’, we should be aware of several issues. Firstly, this new approach should be introduced carefully and should take account of the impact of irregularities on added value. Secondly, there should be a precise timetable for its introduction, and lastly, we should achieve a common understanding among the EU institutions about the indicators that we will use to measure results.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – Mr President of the Court of Auditors, Commissioner, President-in-Office, greetings. The error rate found by the Court of Auditors this year is relatively high.  The Court of Auditors sets a mirror every year on the use of European money, but it is, of course, true that the European Court of Auditors cannot only review all transactions carried out with European money, and there is also a great role for national courts and, of course, the internal control system. Only through the cooperation of all these and together with the Commission can we also achieve better results in the analysis of errors, in the analysis of irregularities.  Many mistakes also go at the expense of public procurement and, as we know, legislation in this area is changing in all Member States, and this is also one window for improvement.  I am convinced that if we help the Member States here and improve the financial culture, the error rate will also be relatively lower in the future.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Madam President, you might expect that I would, as a Eurosceptic, give the same speech as last year. You might expect me to make much of the continuing high error rate in the EU’s accounts or the auditor’s adverse opinion on the legality and regularity of payment underlying the accounts. But actually, Commissioner Georgieva is doing one thing right in talking about performance-based budgeting, as it is not just about the high error rate that we see, it is also about whether money spent actually provides value for money. There is one example in the Court of Auditors’ report that I find particularly instructive, in which it describes a sewage system in Greece: they built the plant, they built the network, but nobody had connected the system to people’s homes, even though the project had been six years in the making from 2007 to 2013. EU funds – taxpayers’ money – achieve nothing if a system cannot actually be used. At the confirmation hearing over a year ago, before Commissioner Georgieva took office, I asked whether they had introduced failure criteria so that we would know whether a project was a success or a failure, in other words what it looked like. Well in my view it is 40 years too late, but the Commission is actually talking about doing something about the problem. Here is my question: is this actually going to be implemented in a way which will be critical when needed? Will we shine a light, not just on fraud or errors but on bad planning? And as the 4.4% error rate is a drop in the ocean, metaphorically as well as in reality, we need to clean out the sewer. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: "blue card" question. – Mr Arnott, I just wanted to tell you to read the error rates well, because you have not told the truth.  This year, the error rate has fallen from last year. Little, as always, because we always seek to improve, but it has descended. I mean, you can't say otherwise.  From last year to this, the error rate has declined and has not increased. It's not much, but still, at least you tell the truth.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: blue-card answer. – Classically, in this place, you are arguing against something that I did not say. I did not say that the error rate had gone up. It says in the report that it has gone from 4.5% to 4.4%, which is pretty much staying exactly the same, and that is only based on a statistical sample. We do not know whether it actually, overall, went up or went down. My point is that we have to look beyond just the error rate and actually look at the question of whether the money that is being spent is achieving its stated aim.

name: Olaf STUGER
text: – What happens to an entrepreneur who does not receive approval from his accountant? The next day, the IRS is on his doorstep. He'll be fined and given a warning. But not with the EU. The EU has been in power for 20 years without the approval of the auditor, the European Court of Auditors. That is now the EU in optima forma. She makes a lot of rules and a lot of laws, and everything and everyone has to abide by them. Except for the EU itself. Look, Robert Mugabe can learn from that. But the European citizen is aware of it all, and it is abandoning it en masse and saying it is confidence in this EU. That's a good thing. The EU is on its way back and we will keep it that way.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: – Madam President, Vice-President of the Commission, you have been talking about a performance-based budget. Absolutely agree. The EPP Group will develop a position paper on this subject in the coming weeks. Mr President, you mentioned a new approach focused on results. Unfortunately, reading the Court of Auditors' reports, at least for joint ventures, I have not noticed this at all. There is no talk of results, no talk, for example, of the assessment of the contribution in kind, there is even mention of audit reports that do not provide any clarification regarding errors. There is no talk of intellectual property rights relating to projects that are carried out with public money. Even more, if we compare with the 2013 reports, 10% are different, the rest of the text is identical. So the request would be that what you said apply in practice to future reports.

name: Georgi PIRINSKI
text: – Madam President, with this year’s 38th Annual Report, the Court is inviting us to start applying an updated approach to our discharge procedure for determining whether the Commission has satisfactorily carried out its responsibilities for implementing the budget. Thus the report represents a most timely and valuable input to discharge: designing and putting into practice results-oriented budgeting is an urgent necessity so that citizens recognise that their money is being put to the best possible use. In this regard, three features of the report deserve particular notice. The structuring of chapters to reflect the headings of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) which came into force in 2014 is a most valuable input towards the mid-term review of the MFF. Chapter 3 focuses on the extent to which the performance framework enables the Commission to monitor and steer progress towards Europe 2020. The stated purpose is that checking the legality and reliability of accounts is intended to assist in identifying risks affecting economy, efficiency and effectiveness. This is precisely the right focus for ever-better results-oriented budgeting, and it is here, I believe, that the Court deserves a particular word of thanks. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Olaf STUGER
text: "blue card" question. I would like to ask this colleague a question. He has given a small summary of the debate that has been going on here for 20 years and no improvement has been seen for 20 years. Why does my colleague think that this story is now being held for the 20th time in this House, will suddenly be better? What has changed in the last 20 years that suggests that things will be fine in the future?

name: Georgi PIRINSKI
text: blue-card answer. – In the briefest possible terms, I believe that the focus over the years has been a bit one-sided on error rates and observance of rules. This, of course, has to continue to be of particular concern. However, it should be used as an indicator to find sectors where programmes are not performing and there is an excessively high rate, and to reorientate the whole exercise of discharge towards results.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: – It's the same song year after year. The European Court of Auditors finds a high number of errors, more than double what is allowed, and the European Parliament will approve it. Twenty-one years in a row. At the same time, 60% of the European Court of Auditors' budget goes to this report, which is ignored by the revered Parliament anyway. Would it not be much more sensible to abolish the entire European Court of Auditors? However, it is completely useless. Now to the expense itself. There's not just a high level of error in that expenditure. There is also a huge amount of corruption. These expenditures often bring distortions of the economy. Commissioner, if you want to leave something behind, start cutting this expenditure. They don't really bring real growth. How many billions of euros have been spent fighting unemployment and what is unemployment? You only have to look at that. That's a completely unnecessary redistribution. I know that it will not be possible with Mr Juncker, because he would like to spend more and more, but maybe we will at least succeed. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Mr Sulík, if there is a great deal of corruption somewhere, what should a proper citizen do? He should go and report this corruption to the competent authorities.  If you know that the European Union is corrupt, why don't you go and report and present evidence of this corruption? I think that if one is not a populist, then he is able to present his evidence.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Mr Zdechovský, but you also come from a country where corruption is worthy, just as I come from such a country. I am not saying that the European Parliament or the European Court of Auditors is corrupt. Not even the European Commission. But in yours, in ours, mine and in many other countries, Bulgaria, Romania, however, there is up-to-the-point corruption. Because those people are betting on it, that money has fallen from the sky. You're asking why report it? Well, for example, we filed over 50 criminal complaints, you might as well have some. We know how it's going to turn out when we're talking about money that doesn't belong to anyone.

name: Joachim ZELLER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I am grateful to Mr Caldeira and the Court of Auditors for the report on the 2014 budget discharge. I do not think it is useless, quite the contrary. What bothers me, however, is that the Commission is represented, but the Council is not. Expenditure of 80% of the European budget is carried out through the paying agencies and the managers in the Member States. This is where the mistakes arise. I therefore think that the Council should also be interested in having this debate with us on how we could reduce the continuing high error rates, because we will only achieve this together. The other is that I am very grateful to the Court of Auditors for pointing out that there is a discrepancy between the payments that we made last year and again this year, which relate to the old funding period, while we would have to work long ago to achieve the Europe2020 target. I believe that this is also a debate that we should have in the coming days and months.

name: Jens GEIER
text: – Jens Geier (S&D). Madam President, Mr President Caldeira, Vice-President Georgieva, I would like to begin by thanking the Rapporteur on the work she has done on this report. First of all, I would like to thank you for the work of the European Court of Auditors, which is far from useless, but which always gives us new indications as to where we can continue to work. I would like to respond to two comments you made in your presentation. On the one hand, Member States do not use the information they have sufficiently to avoid errors. On the other hand, Member States cannot use all the resources that the EU makes available to them. My conclusion is that, in the context of the negotiations on the medium-term financial framework, some Member States are making every effort to bring as much money home as possible, and then they do not really know what to do with it. I think that one solution lies in the revision of the medium-term financial framework, because the EU budget is not only underfunded, it seems that its funds are misallocated. The second point I want to raise is the state of the national control authorities responsible for spending EU money. What will the Commission do to improve the situation here?

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: – Mr President, the overall level of error in payments has repeatedly, year after year, been at a high level. We need to improve the situation and make a real change. If this does not happen, the conditions for granting discharge must be assessed more critically. For 20 years now, the Court of Auditors has issued a negative opinion on the legality and regularity of payments. Consider what would happen in a private company if similar statements were made regularly and routinely about its operations every single year to the owners of the company. Quite quickly, the people in charge would be found, and the consequences would be severe.  There must be a new and thrifty attitude to the management of public sector funds, more rigidity and then responsibility. Public funds must be treated in the same way as an individual with care manages their own funds.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – The European Parliament and the European Court of Auditors have long drawn attention to the need for a comprehensive reflection of the European budget, which is not in line with the overall European Union strategy. The use of the budget lacks vision, perspective for the future and contextual thinking. Therefore, money is spent to be spent, and their added value is often limited. Ladies and gentlemen, I am therefore glad that the European Court of Auditors has sent a clear signal in its audit that there is a need for an overall rethink of the strategy for managing European Union funds. At the moment, it is clear that we must have long-term objectives that are based on the unity of European states. A common mindset and a resounding response to unexpected events, as was the case now in Paris. We need to invest money better, smarter and more efficiently. This will also lead to a more efficient use of the European budget.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab First of all, thank you very much for the honest and necessary report. May I refer to your speech, Mr Caldeira, namely where you write that the European Union should solve the accumulated financial backlog, which is a very important warning to the Commission and to the Council. Notabene pity that the Council does not have. The current year, 2015, will be the closing year of the previous perspective, but at the same time we are in the second year of the current perspective, so these payments can actually accumulate further, and that is what we need to take into account. Mr President, you have used three of these demands: transparency and simplification are the basis. Well, here I see a conflict, because we often complicate the rules in the name of transparency. How do you reconcile these two things? Lastly, I very much support this performance orientation.

name: Petri SARVAMAA
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank the Court for this interesting report and especially for twining together budget efficiency and budgetary control, because they go hand in hand. Value for money is an essential phrase for both. For the first time the Court put at least some emphasis on the performance of the budget, instead of mainly pointing to errors. This is what we have been asking for: more transparency in the use of money and finding systematic weaknesses in different areas of spending. But this is only the beginning. So I encourage the Court to continue on the path it has chosen and to go much further next year. We need total transparency and country-specific information. That would be the way forward in achieving a budget focused on results and, not just that, to be able to justify to our citizens how we are dealing with our finances.

name: Ingeborg GRÄSSLE
text: Madam President, Mr Caldeira, I would like to thank the President for his work and for the work he has For some of the things that have come from Parliament's side here, one would almost have to apologise. All I can say is that, thank God, these people are not members of the Committee on Budgetary Control, and perhaps that is why they do not know what they are talking about. I would like to thank you most warmly for the very useful report. Personally, I would like to see more recommendations, even more recommendations, so that we can continue and follow them. We are dealing with many well-known problems. Madam Vice-President, I would like to recommend one thing to you, namely the difference in the error rate in the Structural Funds between the Commission and the Court of Auditors. Although the Court of Auditors has moved towards the Commission with its figures, there is still a considerable difference, which can no longer be explained by methodological differences, which raises lasting doubts about the whole control system and, above all, about the will to control. I would like to thank the Court of Auditors very much for the performance chapter. If we have a quarter of the Structural Funds projects that do not achieve any of the policy objectives, we must already think about it. Thank you very much for this chapter and your work!

name: Verónica LOPE FONTAGNÉ
text: – Madam President, the European budget is a complex and constantly evolving instrument, and 2014, the first year of the current financial framework, shows this: new rules, new spending orientation aimed at the objectives of the 2020 Strategy and performance-oriented budgeting. The budget should be geared towards generating added value of expenditure, and that is why we need to be clear about the objectives and have adequate indicators that take into account the specificities of European funds, since it is not the same as aid to combat poverty, the results of which are very difficult to measure. That is why we need to simplify the main expenditure policies, in particular those for SMEs and individuals, which are more prone to error, and encourage close collaboration between the actors involved in management and control, mainly the European Commission and the Member States.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: - Madam President, I welcome the Commissioner, my fellow rapporteurs. What is very important to note in this report of the Court of Auditors, and I thank my colleagues at the Court of Auditors and the President, is that a large part of the irregularities stem from a lack of controls and a poorly developed financial management system, as well as from a large number of different procedures and rules that require additional interpretations.  It is in fact a call for all of us, a call to the European Commission and a call for Member States that we must work to strengthen administrative capacity, to implement financial management systems at all levels. So we need to focus on clearly setting goals, on clearly establishing rules and procedures that will be easier for end-users and for the entire administration to make the number of irregularities lower.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: – First of all, I would really like to congratulate the Court of Auditors, which has substantially improved the quality of its annual reports, and they are crucial in contributing to the proper management of the European Union's resources. Last year, the Union budget amounted to as much as 150 billion euro. It is therefore essential to reduce the high error rate for payments, which has already exceeded the 2% threshold for a number of years, as in the economic, social and cohesion policy areas, for example. It is unacceptable that the Commission and the Member States do not make use of all the information available to them and do not prevent errors. The Court's recommendations are not fully implemented, that is, the Commission should establish uniform principles and selection criteria for public procurement in all Member States, and that the collection of relevant and comparable data on european Union funds used in the Member States and others should be assumed. It is also important for the Commission to step up its efforts to recover amounts unduly spent and to deal with Member States as a matter of urgency in the face of accumulating, delayed funds. [language timed out]

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, the Court of Auditors' annual report for the financial year 2014 addresses a number of important issues.  Firstly, it calls for a fundamentally new approach to the management of The European Union's investment and expenditure. All the more so now that mercelial austerity has plunged Europe into recession and unemployment. That is why a more efficient way of managing European Union funds is needed.  Secondly, a focus of European Union funds is needed on cutting-edge areas such as job creation, support for farmers and small and medium-sized enterprises, as well as support for social and territorial cohesion.  Thirdly, better management and control of the way European funds are allocated is needed, especially when the Court of Auditors' own report reveals that the error rate for expenditure was 4.4%. Control against fraud and the breakdown of resources should therefore be intensified, as should the amounts that should not have been paid. So control and transparency everywhere.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Madam President, the principle outlined here today, which is that we should spend money in accordance with our long-term goals, is the only correct principle, and cohesion policy in this context is one of our principles, long-term goals or creating opportunities for stability, solving the problem of unemployment, developing certain less developed parts of our countries.  In some countries, structural funds are the largest investments. The money coming from these funds helps the most to develop these countries. And here we come to the situation that you have noted, which is that we need a simplification of regulations. It is necessary, not to have statistically better results, but to be able to absorb the resources at our disposal, which we so badly need especially in some countries in the east and south of the European Union.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Madam President, Mr President of the Court of Auditors, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. In the 2014 Annual Report, the European Court of Auditors criticises the European Union's spending policy, as it does every year. Of the total expenditure of EUR 142.5 billion, 4.4% or just under EUR 6.3 billion have been misused, around 1 200 cases have been referred to OLAF for examination and 22 specific suspected cases of fraud are being investigated. However, fraud is not the rule. Most violations of the rules and unjustified allocationof funds are in research projects, in the allocation of funds to scientists and in agriculture, for example, when forest areas are declared as pasture land in order to receive higher funding. The largest misallocations in volume terms are in the structural funds. In this context, the Court of Auditors quite rightly criticises the lack of coherence of the EU budget with the general targets, for example in relation to Europe 2020, the lack of concrete targets at which the actual benefits of the funds used can be calculated – for example, in the case of the Structural Funds – the lack of flexibility to respond to crises – we see this in the migration crisis – public procurement practices and the lack of due diligence and the low level of resources, particularly in some Member States. , particularly in regional policy and agriculture.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: – Thank you for the floor, President-in-Office. Thank you to the Court of Auditors for its report.  The error rate therefore is 4,4% this time. That's important information. The European Union budget is very important. It cares about economic growth, jobs and employment. It also represents the added value of each Member State and must therefore be carefully achieved.  In any case, control over the use of budgetary resources is also very important. Transparency, credibility must be taken care of, and I am also pleased that we are using high standards for error-finding. In any case, supervision must also be effective.  However, I would like to point out that the error rate of 4.4% may remind us that the rules should perhaps be clearer and more unambiguous. It's the only way we're going to be able to reduce the level of error.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: – Anyone who dares to regard the European Union with sufficient scrutiny and is therefore not hindered by an ideological blackmail perched by the proponents of the European Union with concepts such as peace and prosperity - and I am such a person - should be highly recommended in the reading of this report. The walk through the forest of an untold number of aid funds, guarantee funds and investment funds that are full of billions - as far as I am concerned Flemish tax money - and for which we, in particular as Flemings, receive little in return, that hike is startling.  After all, Belgium is in third place out of the 28 Member States in terms of per capita contribution. Moreover, my party calculated that because of the transfer situation within Belgium, no one pays more to the European Union than the Fleming. More than four percent of all that money in 2014 did not end up where it was supposed to be, twice what the Court considered acceptable. The smell of randomness and your-m'en- error that rises from the report says it all. Those who are not too bad to face the truth must have read the report.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: – I would like to add a few words to the agricultural chapter of the Court's report – if only because it is rare for us in the European Parliament to have a good word for either the auditors who carried out the audit or the European Commission itself, which was responsible for the implementation of the expenditure.  2014 was a transitional year, as both the old rules and the new rules were mixed this year. Nevertheless, the proportion of erroneous accounts has been reduced to an unprecedented historical minimum of around 2%. I believe that these results really mean that the European institutional system can function in the most difficult area.  Nevertheless, it is undeniable that we are approaching the time of the six-month review, and in this case it will be appropriate to say a few words about the different editions in substance. To be sure, the money spent by European taxpayers on the agricultural part really has to go to the farmers, and it should not be transferred any further. Thank you very much for the opportunity!

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, my most sincere thanks to all who have spoken. It is a very interesting debate this year, because what I am hearing is a predominant concern about how we can rebalance attention between compliance with the rules and what the budget actually delivers for our people. I think it is very important that we take this focus on performance extremely seriously. The EU budget actually has been doing good things, if you take the growth rates of Poland, Lithuania and Latvia, for example. Over the last MFF they have been boosted for Poland by 1.7%, for Latvia by 2.1% and for Lithuania by 1.8%. As the Budget Commissioner this year, I have been visiting projects funded by the EU: cancer research in Finland, SME support in the UK, connectivity of citizens in the cohesion countries and rural internet, but I also have seen that sometimes there has not been enough thought put into how this particular project connects with the rest of the economy, and there are examples where we could have – and must – do better. I think that a culture shift in thinking as regards what we get for the money has to be our overwhelming objective. Agility, focus on priorities, impact – this is what the discussion on the budget absolutely must be on. We do have now in the new MFF a better platform, because we have placed performance front and centre. We introduced performance reserve – 6% of the money we hold back, and if you do well, we give you more money. We have to work with our people in the Commission and, of course, in the Member States on a culture shift. This is not an easy thing, but it is a must if we are to be successful in making the best use of our taxpayers’ sacrifices. For every project, for every penny, we have to ask ourselves if this is the best use of money. I really appreciate each and every one of you who spoke in support of this rebalancing. It does not mean we turn our backs on compliance with the rules – not at all. Rules are there to be followed. Right now they are too complicated to be followed! We have multiple projects with thousands and thousands of people who have to grasp the concept of project management that we have introduced from the EU – a concept that may be easy for some, but it is certainly not easy for a small farmer or for an SME owner, so we have to work on simplifying the rules so they can be followed, and then we have to come with a hammer when the rules are not followed. I agree with those who have said that the persistence of the error rate is something that is undermining the credibility of the European Union. We know why this persistence is there. Rules are part of the problem, but so is how much commitment we build on to make sure that these rules are indeed followed. As I have said many times, we also have to find a way to reward those who take measures to correct errors, because this is what it is in the majority of cases – error, not fraud. Proven fraud is 0.2% of our budget – 0.2% too much. I am not at all defending it, but what about the remaining 4.2%? How do we encourage people to do what the Court tells us could be done if you take corrective measures and the error rate will go down? There we hit a problem, which is the multiannual nature of our programmes. When an error is detected in one year but only corrected in the next, that is not reflected in the error rate, and this is why in the Commission we strongly recommend that we think about a residual error rate as an acceptable measurement, because if people take measures to correct, then that should be a positive thing. We should be saying bravo, we recognise you have done it. At the moment it is difficult to do it in a multiannual fashion. We are caught in this annuality in how we measure. Finally, I do agree that we have to persistently balance performance and compliance. We should avoid the reasoning according to which focusing on performance is somehow interpreted to mean ‘oh well, compliance with the rules is not that important’ – it is important! Let me finish with the question that was posed to me on ‘name and shame’. Well, it is complicated as to which Member States are performing the worst. If you look at the Court of Auditors’ report, there is a table that shows frequency of detected errors in audit sampling for 2014 for the Member States. It is very clear that it varies from one area to another. In some areas some countries are doing better, in others they are doing worse. So I would be very reluctant to make general sweeping conclusions but rather say the following: we have to work with Member States day in, day out, because at the end of the day, 80% of our money goes in shared management, and it is only when Member States buy into being diligent and working with us that we can achieve that objective. Finally, many thanks go to the Court of Auditors for the report that it has presented. A lot of it is something that has been coming up year after year, but we are now seeing a very welcome change of direction towards performance. We have, with this interinstitutional group, a very important task to see performance eye to eye, because the worst thing we can do is to have a different interpretation of what performance means and then get into not very productive arguments about who is right and who is wrong on what has been achieved in that area. So I very much look forward to working with Parliament, the Council and the Court of Auditors on giving a very clear direction for the Commission – though the Commission is not the most important actor – and for those who implement projects, so we get the European budget to serve our people the best possible way in the future.

name: Vítor Manuel da Silva Caldeira
text: Court of Auditors. – Madam President, I would like first to thank you for the kind words addressed to the European Court of Auditors; on behalf of all those working there, thank you. Your words encourage us to do better and to practise what you preach. We do that every day, so I want to reassure Mr Marinescu that we are doing that and striving for it. I am very pleased to hear from the Vice-President that the Commission greatly welcomes our call for a wholly new approach to the European Union’s spending and investment. I am also pleased to see the broader consensus in this House on the need for that new approach. We simply cannot ignore the fact that it is a common task that needs interinstitutional cooperation from all institutions within Member States, because it is the best possible way to tackle the financial challenges ahead of us. I stress the need to use the mid-term review of the Multiannual Financial Framework and to take it as a golden opportunity to make progress. Members of Parliament have raised a number of issues in their speeches. I will not address every one of them, but I am encouraged by their willingness to reach a greater common understanding of what a new approach means, what a culture of performance means, and what we are looking for. That is something which will not be done overnight and which needs to go hand in hand with simplification of the rules as well as with clear objectives. I have understood the call for ways of reconciling transparency and simplification. This needs to be addressed in the best way possible. We need simplification because debt is amplifying the risk of error, but we also need to be transparent so that we can then say what we are achieving with the funds we are investing. So we have to have, first and foremost, a clear overall framework that provides direction. But we also need to be aware that spending funds is always risky. I am sorry to say this so bluntly, but geography is not the root cause of the errors. As we have demonstrated, management modes are, likewise, not the main cause of the problem. The main reason for the errors that we have found, and for their persistently high level, lies in the way this House and the Council decide on the legal framework for reimbursing costs. If you continue to have costs reimbursed on the basis of self-declarations by the final beneficiaries, then you will always have a higher risk of error. Simplification does not mean forgetting about control. It needs to have cost-effective arrangements to ensure that we comply with the rules but, at the same time, we need to ensure that these are used to the best effect. Then performance has a key part to play. What we are intending to measure is the interinstitutional work that we have to do. Flexibility is also an important consideration, so some Members estimate. I think that it is also vital to better address the backlogs which we have identified and which have been recognised on all sides. We need to use the budget in a more flexible way, together with all the financial instruments available, otherwise we will have funds committed but not being used. We know that at the end of 2014, the funds not yet used by all the Member States for the structural and investment funds were of the order of 23% of the total. That situation is better today, I believe, but that means that we are not making full use of resources, and there are reasons beyond that. Probably there are administrative capacities to develop. Probably there is also a need for Member State authorities to identify sustainable approaches that would make a difference to the lives of their citizens. In addition, a lot needs to be done to determine what makes a difference to citizens, for they will not think that building, say, a water-park is enough to make a difference. We need to see how sustainable approaches work and how they change citizens’ lives. I would like to conclude by saying that our call for a wholly new approach has to be followed up in interinstitutional dialogues, because that is the only way in which we can help to address the new challenges. It is the only way to tackle the long-standing issues that we have, but we need to take the opportunity afforded by the mid-term review of the MFF to move forward. We look forward to contributing to the dialogue and we stand side by side with this institution, the European Parliament, to further cooperate in that direction. But we cannot fail. If we miss this opportunity, we shall be failing to address the trust of citizens, and that is a crucial point in these times.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. Written Declarations (Article 162)

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – In its 2014 report, the European Court of Auditors calls for a new approach on the management and investment of EU funds. In line with its guidelines, the budget should be better aligned with the Community's long-term priorities and take greater account of possible crises. Furthermore, the Union should address the financial backlog without delay in order to free up funds and direct them where necessary. Some Member States still have problems absorbing the EU Structural Funds allocated to them.  The total EU budget in 2014 was €142.5 billion and the error rate for EU spending was 4.4%. Nevertheless, the auditors considered that they had no reservations about the reliability of the accounts and the EU's revenue. They detected the same estimated level of error (4.6%) in the case of expenditure under shared management with the Member States, as in the case of expenditure managed directly by the Commission. The highest levels of error occurred in expenditure under the headings "Economic, social and territorial cohesion" (5.7%) and 'Competitiveness for growth and jobs' (5.6%). The lowest estimated level of error, on the other hand, occurred in administrative expenditure (0.5%). However, the report stresses that more errors could be corrected and calls on the Commission to make full use of its powers in order to further reduce the error rate and recover larger amounts of irregularly spent funds.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. – I believe that the presentation of this report is a very important opportunity to carefully examine weaknesses in the definition and implementation of European policies. I'm going to stop at two strongly interrelated points. First, the EU has often favoured the development of gigantic infrastructures of dubious use. The case of airports is noteworthy, but the same lack of planning and coordination is found in other areas of transport and energy policy, under the dubious approach that infrastructure will eventually create its own market. The second is the difficulties of public administrations, especially local ones, which really want to implement alternative public policies, because of the administrative implications and financial needs implicit in the adoption of European projects. There is a need to rethly European funds to ensure their efficient use and their real contribution to improving social and regional cohesion through the transformation of the productive model. Finally, I wanted to address the importance of identifying not only management failures but also legislative failures. The case of pastures, for example, shows the need to reform agricultural policy to actually adapt it to environmental conditions on the ground.

name: Julia PITERA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – It is the task of the Court, the EU's independent external auditor, to examine whether the raising and disbursement of EU funds is in line with the principles of economy, efficiency and effectiveness. This is particularly important in times of crisis, when, as a result of growing problems, there is a natural decline in Europeans' trust in the Union in difficult situations. That is why systematically improving accountability and transparency in the process of supervising the use of public funds is so important in order to restore this trust. Close cooperation between the parliaments of the Member States and the public auditors of the Union is also of paramount importance.  In the process of building trust in the EU institutions, in addition to achieving the greatest possible transparency and economy, the desirability of expenditure is important. Public funds must be allocated for the most important purposes for citizens. Especially since the European Union budget is a major source of potential investment for many Member States. They provide significant support for national initiatives not only in improving economic productivity, but in creating jobs, securing borders or protecting the environment.  In order to carry out its tasks as best as possible, the ECA should constantly analyse and draw conclusions from them. The ECA's call for a new approach in the management of EU investment and expenditure should therefore be welcomed by introducing a number of significant changes to the activities of those responsible for the control of EU funds.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debates on cases of violations of human rights, democracy and the rule of law (Article 135 of the Regulation) and first of all the debate on 7 motions for resolution on Afghanistan, including the massacres in Zaboul province (2015/2968 (RSP)).

name: Bodil VALERO
text: Author. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for This is an alarming development we are seeing in Afghanistan – sectarian and ethnic violence, murders, kidnappings and attacks. It has escalated and, in particular, it is the Hazaras, who are the country's third largest group and mainly Shia, who have been affected. We are seeing a development in which some Taliban groups have joined Daesh and, as we all know, shia are one of Daesh's targets. When we compare it with what is happening in other countries in the Middle East, this is a very worrying development. The war in which many EU Member States were involved in Afghanistan is not over. It continues, but with less media attention when we are no longer there. It was right to leave. Democracy and the functioning of the rule of law cannot be created by military means. Instead, we are needed in Afghanistan for a long term with civilian efforts for peace, democracy, security, etc. Building a democracy takes time. In addition to aid, we must also show from the political side that Afghanistan is not forgotten and that we see what is happening. It is in this perspective that this resolution plays a role. The resolution strongly condemns the barbaric killings of 77 Hazaras. It condemns the attacks by The Taliban, Al-Qaeda and Daesh and other groups against all sections of society. It underlines the importance of protecting the particularly vulnerable Hazaras and also regrets the grief of the families. We believe in the resolution that kidnappings should be seen as a war crime. There is much more in the resolution, but in a minute and a half there is little time.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Author. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that these attacks confirm that for forty years Afghanistan has continued to be a people and a state that is a prisoner of the business of war, that it has created fundamentalism and that it forages the terrorism we are experiencing. And while it is true that, on the one hand, the presence of NATO troops is important in order to prevent that country from becoming the logistical base of all terrorist groups, it is also true that we must reflect on the role of NATO troops in recent years.  It is clear that it has been an insufficient role and we must be critical of it because, on the one hand, we have favoured those cunning Afghans, including thieves, who have emptied the coffers of Kabul Bank as well as the companies that have exploited the country's resources and, on the other, have continued to prosper terrorist groups.  I believe that we should promote stronger action as the European Union.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Author. – The terror of Daesh is prevalent in parts of Syria and Iraq, but the cancer is also spreading in Afghanistan. The gruesome murders of members of the Hazara minority show that the situation is becoming increasingly unsafe. There seems to be an alliance between the Taliban and Daesh. They find each other in the total aversion to a pluralistic Afghanistan. This evil cannot deal with the religious, ethnic and cultural minorities. They reject women's rights, democracy and the principles of the rule of law. But the people are afraid of the jihadists. Last Wednesday, thousands of people took to the streets of Kabul to express feelings of fear and revulsion. But they are also targeting the Afghan government of President Ghani. It falls short of protecting its own people. Corruption and rivalry between the various clans undermine the credibility and clout of the government. All too often, loyalty is bought off at the expense of human lives, at the expense of human rights. The unity government in Kabul must change its shoulder and the Union must monitor it. A conference on Afghanistan in Brussels is scheduled for next year. In the present circumstances, a strong European commitment will be essential.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Author. – Madam President, the European Union must not leave violence against minorities, such as in the Afghan region of Zábul, unansed. Seven civilians, including women and a young child from the Hazara minority, were abducted and subsequently massacred there.  And this is not the first and isolated case in which the rights of this minority have been suppressed. Similar incidents occur regularly for more than two years. The abduction and murder of civilians is a serious violation of international humanitarian law, which all warring parties are obliged to abide by. Even the ones in Afghanistan.  I and my faction strongly condemn the attacks by the Taliban, Al-Qaeda, Islamic State and other terrorist organisations against Afghan civilians, security forces and democratic institutions and civil society as a whole.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: author. – Madam President, the ongoing indiscriminate attacks by the Taliban and other insurgency groups have led to a sharp rise in civilian deaths. The brutal killing of Hazara civilians in the province of Zabul highlighted the fact that the local population remains under permanent threat. In order to protect vulnerable groups, the vicious circle of violence needs to be broken. I urge the Afghan authorities to act swiftly and conduct an impartial and comprehensive investigation into those murders. I also appeal to them to do their utmost to fulfil their international obligations by ensuring equal human rights for women and putting an end to the impunity of national security forces. However, can we expect human rights without a lasting peace, security and a sustainable state? I do not think so. It is feared that, with the gradual international disengagement and fatigue with Afghanistan, respect for human rights might deteriorate even further. A lasting solution to the current situation will depend on whether the government upholds its commitments on human rights. It will also require the continued support of the international community in the fight against insurgency and in the development of resilient Afghan institutions.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this is yet another massacre of seven civilians of Hazara origin, which is part of a long history of persecution suffered by this ethnic group. Always discriminated against and subjected to unfair economic and fiscal policies, the Hazaras have always lived on the edge of economic survival and their region, the Hazarajat, has always been kept underdeveloped, devoid of roads, schools and hospitals. Today the Hazaras are officially recognised by the new Constitution of Afghanistan and have obtained the full right of citizenship. But despite this they fear the growing power of the Taliban and Daish, perceived as a direct threat to their community.  Now, for us, supporting the peace process in Afghanistan is the prerequisite for any sustainable solution, and with this in mind, we must work actively towards the Ministerial Conference on Afghanistan to be held in Brussels in 2016.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, a family of seven has been killed. The family of seven was a Hazar family. I think we need to raise our investigation into human rights violations from this family to the entire Hazar nation.  The Hazara live in central Hindu Hazarajat. There are about three million of them, and they have been consistently and traditionally attacked by Pashtun tribes for at least two hundred years. Let us not forget that these are descendants of Genghis Khan's soldiers, who conquered these parts of Afghanistan as early as the thirteenth century. That is why we must support the Afghan government politically and militarily. We cannot afford to leave Afghanistan because there is a risk of creating a large theocratic nuclear Pakistan-Afghanistan whole.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, we have all seen the heartbreaking pictures of the protesters carrying the coffins of seven Hazaras, including children. A string of kidnappings over the past year is fuelling concern among the community about the sectarian and ethnic conflict. We strongly condemn these atrocious killings and kidnappings and stand with the Hazara group in its demand for justice and protection. We express our concern about the worsening security situation in Afghanistan. It is essential that cooperation in the region be intensified, particularly between Afghanistan and Pakistan. All neighbours in the region must play a constructive role in fighting the terrorism threat and promoting an Afghan peace process. The EU and the international community should assist through diplomacy and negotiations. I welcome the decision to hold a comprehensive ministerial conference on Afghanistan next year in Brussels. The exodus reflects the despair of many Afghans and emphasises the need for a clear signal of international support to mitigate it. We must not forget Afghanistan. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: blue-card question. – This situation is truly a tragedy and it is one which is heartfelt by all of us. Will you agree with me that there are lessons to be learned from our military involvement in Afghanistan without a clearly defined military objective and strategy for what would happen next? If you do agree with me, how can those lessons be applied to the current situation in Syria?

name: Afzal KHAN
text: blue-card answer. – Of course we should always be learning lessons, and the ultimate objective for Afghanistan, Iraq, Syria, or Libya is to bring about stability. That is the lesson we need to learn. Today we need to be bringing stability in Syria, and it is good to see all the key players playing their part in order to achieve this. I look forward to a successful and stable Syria.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
