text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, the other day we talked about how to tackle destabilization, and Afghanistan is a very clear example.  Mr Brzezinski reminded us of how the Taliban was funded to make a Vietnam for the Soviet Union and now we see, fifteen years later – almost fifteen years later – of the new occupation, failure: there is no more democracy, no more human rights; women continue to be suffocated, murdered and held in their homes; there is more violence and there is a strengthening of the Taliban.  I think we have to turn around; you have to think about things differently. And we would have to do so with a withdrawal and, above all, with a return to the United Nations: a transition under the auspices of the United Nations.  In addition, we must give confidence: attacks on unmanned U.S. aerial vehicles in Afghanistan and Pakistan must cease. An international investigation into the attack on the Doctors Without Borders hospital is needed.  Let's not be afraid. Let's change and try other things, especially international law.

name: Eva JOLY
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, Commissioner, Koundouz, this strategic city in north-eastern Afghanistan, fell into the hands of the Taliban at the end of September. The blow is hard for a government whose legitimacy rests on a promise, that of a state that will not collapse because its security forces are able to protect cities.  An investigative report, released a week ago, explains the rout by a complex chain of command. To put it bluntly, it is the corruption of some of the senior military officers that is pointed at, named, if not bought, by former President Karzai. Their failure in Afghanistan is causing a wave of panic. Corruption is the enemy of peace and peace seems to be moving further away as the Taliban, and now Daesch, continue their abuses.  So what can the European Union do? We must already start by not forgetting Afghanistan at a time when all eyes are on Syria, because it is the whole region that is affected by the Daesch threat and our actions in Racca will necessarily have an impact in Kabul. Second, we must push and help President Ghani to implement a relentless fight against corruption, which must begin with putting the army on track. Afghans deserve that we do not abandon them to their fate.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: - Udo Voigt (NI). Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I have the impression that, with such motions for resolutions, the asylum lobby here is constantly trying to prevent the repatriation of Afghan migrants. We simply have to say that the policy in Afghanistan – the military operation – has failed. Before we take care of Afghanistan, Cambodia or Bangladesh, we should also take care of human rights violations in Europe and put our own house in order. In France, artists such as Diendonné are condemned for politically incorrect opinions. In Austria, people are jailed for 15 to 20 years for making politically incorrect opinions. In Germany, an 87-year-old woman, Mrs Haverbeck, was recently convicted because of her opinion, 12 000 investigations for offences of opinion in Germany, 1 000 convictions with imprisonment in Germany speak their own language.  In Germany, they want to ban a party, the NPD. In Greece, the political leadership has been imprisoned, and one is also to be banned from a party. Such things should be omitted in Europe before doing anything elsewhere.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I decided, after hearing author Valer, that I would change the content of my contribution, because I was provoked to do so by a colleague who is no longer here. It was the coalition's troops that called the rapid withdrawal from Afghanistan a mistake. Well, I find that almost a joke, because even democratic candidates for US president now recognize that it is the rapid withdrawal from Iraq and Afghanistan that has created a power vacuum from which such destructive elements as Da'is and the Taliban grow and draw.  I would like to say that in this vacuum, precisely then, there is room for murder, ethnic cleansing, national cleansing and, in fact, the phenomena that we condemn here. And if we think we can fight such an uncivilization movement by writing a resolution, then we are in deep error. (The speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the blue card (Article 162(8) of the Negotiating Council).)

name: Bodil VALERO
text: question ("blue card"). – (the first words inaudible) in the chamber still and I did not say at any time that it was not right to withdraw the troops. I said it was right to leave Afghanistan. It was right to leave Afghanistan and that we need more civilian action, aid and other things to ensure democracy and security .m. I think it was right that we left in 2014.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. -To your question, I don't think so deeply. I do not think that leaving Afghanistan and Iraq quickly has created peace and a good situation in that part of the world. What you are presenting here is indeed an opinion that even those who participated in the rapid withdrawal from Afghanistan today reject, that is, President Obama's administration.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: GUE/NGL). Madam President, these senseless murders in Afghanistan may amount to war crimes. These are not my words, but a statement from the UN special mission that went to the region about two weeks ago.  We in Europe, therefore, must match what the UN says and recognise the people fleeing Afghanistan in order to save themselves and their children, the status of refugees coming from war zones, as is the case with people fleeing, so that they do not face the paranoids of ISIS, from Syria.  The Europe of democracy, freedom and rights cannot discriminate against victims of war and victims of terrorism according to their nationality. We must therefore also contribute to peace initiatives and development aid, but also to guarantee Afghans refugee status in accordance with un provisions.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: – Madam President, when we talk about Afghanistan today, it must be said that its extremely difficult situation comes not only from the circumstances that originate in Afghanistan itself, but also from the situation throughout the region. The security of all Afghan citizens, including various minorities, is the first prerequisite for further stabilising the country's development.  A country in which several terrorist organizations operate at the same time must not be left to its fate. Assistance must continue to be provided to the Afghan Government in order to be increasingly able to ensure the safety of its citizens. The appalling murder of members of one of the minorities still reminds us that the situation in Afghanistan is extremely complex. Nevertheless, there are now examples that give hope that the situation can be improved and a positive trend maintained. However, the European Union needs to contribute to this positive trend and not limit its assistance.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, I think it is right that the European Parliament wants to comment on the situation in Afghanistan. And I am also glad that the voice being heard here is across the political spectrum.  I think that we cannot remain silent on taliban violence directed particularly at the Hazar ethnic minority, and I consider it our duty to support the voice of the 100,000 protesters on the streets of Kabul. This has a great connection with the situations of the migration crisis, which we often discuss here in the European Parliament. After all, Afghans make up the second largest group in the European Union after refugees from Syria, of which 20 percent are. This is almost seven percent of the asylum seekers who come from Afghanistan. I therefore strongly join the European Parliament's urgent call on President Ghani and Prime Minister Abdullah to take appropriate measures to address the current pmalering situation of gross human rights violations.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, the situation in Afghanistan is acute as armed conflict increases and Daesh spreads its tentacles in cooperation with the Taliban, culminating in the Hazara massacres. At the same time, we have casualties of innocent people, as with the bombing of the Doctors Without Borders hospital in Kontouz. An action which the United States has confessed to, but yesterday it was wrong.  In these circumstances Afghanistan is in danger of becoming a refugee bomb. Already one and a half million Afghan refugees are in Pakistan and another four hundred and fifty thousand are in Iran, while more than 20% of the people who have flooded into Greece in recent months, as well as other European countries, come from Afghanistan.   In order, therefore, not to find ourselves in the same situation as the Syrian refugee flow, afghanistan's stability and economic development must be strengthened, NATO countries conducting war operations in Afghanistan must take over the accommodation of afghan refugees, while the same applies to China, Russia and Iran bordering that country.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Madam President, honourable Members, the European Union has been an unwavering supporter and participant in Afghanistan's reconstruction processes since 2001. As we did 15 years ago, today we also stand for a peaceful, democratic and stable Afghanistan. Some positive things have happened in the country, but unfortunately it continues to be a cradle of terrorism and extremism, which has resulted in thousands of innocent victims. We have been witnessing ethnic conflict lately, and large minority groups are being abused and attacked. After the US and other NATO members withdrew their troops from Afghanistan, the situation in the country apparently deteriorated. We can't leave her alone because there are a lot of disturbing processes going on there. The Taliban are increasingly active, and in most provinces we are also seeing a strong presence of Islamic State.  We need to support the authorities to ensure the security of the innocent population. We must work together to pull terrorism and extremism out of the country because it is a threat to all global security.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: – Thank you for the floor, President-in-Office. Many gross human rights violations in third countries require a clear and strong condemnation from all of us and a call for an immediate end to all acts of violence. Ethical and sectal persecution, abduction and killing of civilians, repression of the opposition, numerous attacks on freedom of expression, against journalists, bloggers and civil society. These are all throw away acts that must be condemned uniformly and require the authorities to respect the principles of the rule of law, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms. It is also necessary to strongly condemn war crimes, terrorism and the financing of terrorist operations and to strengthen the functioning of democratic institutions.  This year's recipient of the 2015 Sakharov Prize for Freedom of Thought is Raif Badavi, a blogger, writer and activist from Saudi Arabia who has been sentenced to 10 years in prison and 1,000 lashes for criticizing Islam. By selecting Badawi, we have given a clear message in the European Parliament that we must not deny the right to freedom of expression and deny it to anyone.

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, that is very kind of you. Let me start by expressing the regrets of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, Federica Mogherini, for not being able to take part in the debate. I am happy to stand up on her behalf. After the events in Kunduz in early October, we have now had to witness the cruel beheading of a group of Shia Muslims belonging to the Hazara community in the southern province of Zabul by anti-government elements. The EU has firmly condemned this attack, as well as other recent brutal and barbaric acts of violence in Afghanistan. We have extended our sincere condolences to the families of the victims, including women and children who were abducted last month and executed between 6 and 8 November. These new atrocities coincide with a growing number of violent clashes between insurgent groups, whether different Taliban-affiliated groups or those linked to Daesh. So far no group has claimed responsibility for the beheading of the seven people. The perpetrators must be found and held accountable for their crimes. Once again, we call on all parties to the armed conflict, including all anti—government elements, to uphold international law. The continued targeting of Hazaras risks fuelling ethnic tensions within Afghanistan. As many of today’s speakers mentioned, on 11 November there was a mass demonstration in Kabul, with reportedly more than 20 000 men and women grieving the brutal loss of life and protesting about what happened in Zabul. The demonstrators were mainly Hazaras, but they also included other ethnic groups – Pashtuns, Tajiks, Uzbeks and others. We should keep in mind that the ever—present security threat in Afghanistan remains one of the main contributors to increased migration, both to neighbouring countries and to the EU. The deteriorating security situation, with a record level of terrorist attacks and the civilian casualties stemming from them, plus a deteriorating economic situation and limited employment opportunities for educated young people: these are the origin of migratory pressures, and we in Europe are directly affected. We need to act. We have our 2014-2016 EU Strategy for Afghanistan. It flags, as a first objective, the promotion of peace, security and regional stability, and it is in this perspective that the EU has agreed to co-host next year’s ministerial conference on Afghanistan, in October 2016. This conference in Brussels will further foster the stabilisation process in Afghanistan, where strong Afghan leadership, combined with continued international solidarity, is needed to send a signal of renewed hope, confidence and positive change. We have a challenging security situation, grave human rights violations, a fragile political situation and a very dire economic situation. They all cause further risks of destabilisation and the continued flow of Afghan refugees and migrants – people fleeing because of that loss of hope. It is all the more urgent that the Government of Afghanistan and all partners in the region engage credibly to end the conflict and ensure a stable environment with the support of the international community. An Afghan-led and Afghan—owned peace process remains the prerequisite to any sustainable solution. On this path, the EU stands firm in its commitments to Afghanistan and to its people.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: I have received seven motions for resolutions to conclude the debate. The debate is over. The vote will take place on Thursday, 26 November 2015. Declarations in Iras (Article 162)

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: in writing. – I call for implementation of the provisions of the National Action Plan to end torture by initiating investigations and prosecutions based on the UNAMA findings, which are extremely important. Violence and human rights violations have led to widespread corruption and death, how long will it take for us to respond to the global atrocities and stop the bloodshed? Seven members of the Shia Hazara ethnic group, including three women and a child, were found with their throats cut on Sunday in an incident police blamed on Islamic State militants. The fighting in one of the Taliban’s traditional southern strongholds, underlines the risk of fragmentation facing the Islamist movement.  I agree that we must work with the NATO-led International Security Assistance Force (ISAF) in order to assist and aid the Afghan National Security Forces. (ASNF) These are the forces that have the greatest competences when it comes to fighting ISIS and other militants, since they have first-hand fighting experience against them.

name: Tadeusz ZWIEFKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Despite the long-standing commitment of the European Union and individual Member States to improving the situation in Afghanistan, the country remains one of the poorest and most dangerous regions in the world. Attacks, insurgency and fratricidal fighting continue to take a bloody toll on civilians. Vulnerable women and children are killed. Afghan ethnic and religious minorities are the most vulnerable to persecution. An inglorious example of this is the murder of seven members of the Hazar people. The bodies of those kidnapped and brutally murdered by ISIS, including two women and a child, have been found in Zabul province (southeastern Afghanistan). As the main guardian of human rights, the European Union cannot idly look at the barbarism and terror that the Afghan people are subjected to. The perpetrators of the murders must be punished, the Afghan protesters demand.  The necessary measures must be taken to increase security and rebalance the area. Peace and political stability are the basis for ensuring the development and future of Afghan society.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Next item: Cambodia (2015/2969 (RSP))

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: Author. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab We cannot accept the practice of human rights violations and the elementary principles of civilised political systems in Cambodia. There are political repressions, prison sentences, arrests of representatives of the leader of the opposition, representatives of opposition groups. This is by no means even a fierce political fight, it is simply a use of the barbaric weapon of criminal law to destroy the political opposition.  We must respond to this, as we did more than twenty years ago against the evils and practice of communism in Europe, which has committed the same thing as it does in Cambodia today. Hence the need for this resolution, the obvious, strong need for this resolution. One more thing: we must be consistent on this. A great deal depends on the European Commission and the European Council. We should be consistent and make humanitarian aid conditional on compliance with elementary standards.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the flagrant violations of human rights and repression we are witnessing in Cambodia can be summed up in the perfect combination of money laundering, corruption and Cambodian politics.  Clearly, there is also a great deal of speculation on the part of foreign investors and multinationals. In fact, Cambodia is in fact a country for sale and both resources – therefore, forests, lakes, oil – and human rights, the rights of the 700,000 people who have been displaced to encourage investment in agriculture, land grabbing, as well as the rights of workers, children and women working in the clothing sector are for sale. , which we then find ourselves in our market.  We have probably never taken a strong and firm position on Cambodia, and with this resolution the time has come to do so.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: Author. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab On behalf of the PPE Group, I would like to express my concern about the deteriorating political situation in Cambodia. The lack of dialogue between the government and other political parties, the acts of violence against members of the National Assembly, the issuing of an arrest warrant for the main opposition leader Sam Rainsy lead to a dangerous critical point, especially when it comes to respecting human rights in Cambodia. It should be stressed that that the European Union is Cambodia's largest development aid partner with a budget of EUR 410 million for the period 2014-2020, and the Government of Cambodia, Prime Minister Hun Sen, is therefore called upon to improve the situation in the country by unconditionally releasing the wrongly accused activists, repealing the law restricting the activities of associations and NGOs, restoring Rainsy's parliamentary immunity and recognising the role of civil society in Cambodia. I also ask the High Representative to monitor the situation in this country and to work with the government to restore democratic principles.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: Author. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Cambodia has a very special place in my heart and therefore it is very painful to see the rise and escalation of aggression by the Hun Sen Government against the legitimate political opposition. Eleven opposition politicians have been imprisoned after very flawed trials and have been sentenced to long, long sentences, accused of leading an uprising. Here we had called it legitimate opposition politics. Sam Rainsy, the opposition leader, is once again exiled. He's accused of defamation. Here he would have been labelled as a legitimate opposition leader who makes justified criticism. I'm glad he's with us here in the stands today. The judiciary has been politicised and opposition politicians abused. I am glad that today we are adopting this resolution, because freedom of assembly and freedom of expression belong to everyone. In Cambodia, the opposition has been systematically deprived of these fundamental rights. I am happy and happy that we are doing this today. It is important for the sake of our credibility.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the political situation in Cambodia has deteriorated. On 13 November, the government issued an arrest warrant against the opposition leader, stripped him of his status as a legislator and his parliamentary immunity and, as has been mentioned, 11 opposition activists are serving sentences of between 7 and 20 years in prison.  On 26 October, a group of pro-government demonstrators brutally attacked two members of the opposition party in Phnom Penh. It is therefore right that the voice of the European Parliament should be raised: the government must reseve the arrest warrant and all the accusations that have emerged against the opposition leader, the activists, the members of the National Assembly and the Senate.  We believe that political dialogue is essential for political stability but, in order to achieve this, the government authorities must stop persecuting human rights defenders, release immediately and unreservedly all those people imprisoned as a result of politically unjustified and fabricated accusations.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: Author. Madam President, I would like to apologise for not being able to participate in the previous debate, but I was being held up by a meeting of the electoral mission coordination delegation where I represent my group.  The situation in Cambodia is of concern, at the same time, both economically and socially and politically. In July, we denounced the NGO law and a similar law is now aimed at trade unions. It is one of the poorest countries in the world per capita. One third of the population lives below the poverty line, the youth unemployment rate exceeds 50% and about 1,000,000 people have been victims of land grabbing, particularly for large multinational agri-food companies, and the phenomenon appears to be worsening. Clientelism and corruption are wreaking havoc.  The political crisis has worsened since the July 2013 elections. Repression and harassment are the daily lot of opponents of the regime and all activists, including associations. We must use our weight, yes, to bring Cambodia back into the path of dialogue and before the situation continues to deteriorate. This is possible in this country, which is highly dependent on international aid.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I want to join my leaders, I want to draw attention to one fact that we recently spoke about the situation in Cambodia here in parliament's plenary, we have pointed out that in Cambodia laws are being adopted that are tinging against the non-profit sector, which are contrary to civil society and de facto make it impossible to set up non-profit, non-state and trade union organisations.  However, our resolution against Cambodia was not taken into account by the Cambodian Government at all and yet it has proclaimed these laws. It is good to say here that, unfortunately, our resolution does not take Cambodia into account, despite the fact that we are Cambodia's main partner, it has been said here, we will deliver several hundred million euros for the development of that country in the coming years. I therefore think, and this is my call and plea to the Representative of the Commission, that the Commission should take into account how much support we will want to give to Cambodia at a time when our words to respect democracy and the rule of law are not taken into account.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Cambodia is one of the most tested countries in the world. The crimes of the Pol Pot regime, with millions of deaths, still cast their shadow over the country today. It is a long, difficult road back to normality, punctuated by setbacks that depend on the whims of the Hun Sen regime. Last year there were restrictions on NGOs, civil society and trade unions, and now the democratic opposition is also affected. This is also due to the success of opposition leader Sam Rainsy. This makes those in power nervous, and it led to the withdrawal of his mandate, to the indictment for flimsy reasons. He is in exile today, and he is here with us today. I am very pleased that he can listen to our debate. But it would be in everyone's interest if he could be in Phnom Penh today and debate in the Cambodian Parliament. That is what we all want, and we call on the Cambodian Government, and also the Commission, to support us in this. Perhaps he could finally lead the country out of the darkness of history.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. - Madam President, the European Union will assist cambodia's development with €410 million between 2014 and 2020. We see the result of this assistance in a way that we continue to have a repressive regime that violates human rights, that has brought Cambodia to the brink of poverty, and is perhaps one of the poorest states in the world. The social, economic and political situation is repressive and I am convinced that we must act in this context.  That is why I support this resolution in the belief that in this way we are clearly signaling to the democratic forces in Cambodia, and especially to cambodia's non-governmental sector, which we need to continue to support and try to help as much as possible, we are sending a clear signal that we are not at peace with the current situation and that we are looking for change in that country when we talk about NGOs, trade unions and opposition.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Although the recent period has given us the hope that the changes that have begun in Cambodia's political life will bear fruit and that some kind of cooperation can be achieved between the two parties, the events of recent months suggest that we have been too optimistic about the power of change. The cambodian government's actions clearly have an impact on the opposition and thus on the impossibilation of democratic competition. In these circumstances, I believe that we need to closely monitor what is happening in the country, especially with regard to the fact that the European Union is Cambodia's largest partner of this kind with its EUR 410 million development assistance programme foreseen for the period 2014-2020. If we are serious about asserting our shared values around the world, then this need must also be part of development policy.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to focus, while sharing the comments on the political situation that all colleagues have made, on land grabbing, because indeed the trade agreement with the European Union 'Everything but arms' allows access to the European market free of all taxes and free of quotas.  Of course, this agreement has dramatic effects on local populations, particularly due to the practice of violently driving peasants from their land so that they can be allocated, through the economic land concession mechanism, to large companies. The British sugar company Tate and Lyle is probably one of the main culprits. Tens of thousands of hectares are being subtracted from farmers in the name of this agreement in favour of multinationals.  So, do we have to continue on this path? I asked the Commission the question, I was told that there would be a mid-term review on 21 November 2017 "blablabla". It's all "blabla." Commissioner, I have high regard for you because you are one of the Commissioners who put people before business. So it is not after 2017 that we will have to react, but it is here and now that we must take measures to put these agreements under surveillance and perhaps correct them.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, cosúil leis na Feisirí eile aontaím gur cheart dúinn labhairt amach i gcoinne cad atá ag tarlú sa Chambóid faoi láthair, go háirithe ós rud é go bhfuilimid ag tabhairt a lán cabhrach dóibh; cabhair airgead, cabhair le cúrsaí trádála agus mar sin de.  Ach is léir freisin, cé go bhfuil an Chambóid sásta glacadh leis an gcabhair a thugaimid dóibh, nach bhfuil siad ag tabhairt cearta daonna do mhuintir na Cambóide i gcoitinne agus nach maith leo lucht freasúra ach go háirithe. Ní féidir cur suas leis sin. Caithfear cearta daonna a thabhairt do chuile dhuine. Agus in aon tír, má tá rialtas agat caithfidh lucht freasúra a bheith ann comh maith. Agus mura dtarlaíonn sé sin, ní féidir linne gan rud éigin a dhéanamh faoi. Ba chóir dúinn i bhfad níos mó brú a chur ar údaráis na Cambóide. Go háirithe an rud atá ag tarlú do Sam Rainsy agus a thuilleadh, caithfimid stop a chur leis sin.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: Madam President, corruption and clientelism are indeed the hallmarks of authoritarian regimes. Europe has a duty everywhere to combat these undemocratic acts, especially when it provides development aid. The violation of human rights and the imprisonment of political opponents are unacceptable to us Europeans and we must speak with one voice to defend democracy in Cambodia, as elsewhere. Cambodia, as you know, has a troubled history. We need to help it get back on the path to democracy. Commissioner, thank you for opening a dialogue with the Cambodian government to verify the use of European aid and to ensure that it is properly used for the return to democracy.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, in Cambodia the regime of Hun Shen, which has been in power for over thirty years, has human rights violations on the agenda. The same applies to the lack of pluralism as well as gagging and persecution against the opposition. At the same time, the armed forces and security forces are acting uncontrollably by suppressing demonstrations and strikes.  In the economic field, the country is plagued by poverty, even though Cambodia is a rich country with mines, timber, oil, but the Cambodian people have not reaped the proceeds from the exploitation of the country's natural resources. With corruption and the interconnection of politicians and businessmen as the main element, 45% of the country's territory has been allocated to so-called investors, while since 2003 some four hundred thousand people have been driven from their land and 14% of the total land has been lost at the hands of small farmers.  In view of the European Union's development aid to Cambodia, pressure must be exerted to restore democracy.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: – Madam President, first of all let me say that I am very happy that the Cambodian opposition leader Sam Rainsy is here today, together with Tioulong Saumura, who is also a member of the Cambodian National Assembly. I welcome you both to this Chamber today. The message once again is clear: the Hun Sen government has to stop the political repression of political opposition and come back to respect for the rule of law and democracy. It is not the first time this Parliament has condemned such behaviour. We also call on the EU to stop ‘business as usual’ with Cambodia. Let me remind you that the EU is the largest foreign donor to Cambodia. We call on Hun Sen and the National Assembly to reinstate Sam Rainsy immediately and to restore his parliamentary immunity. This is why I am so delighted that we are adopting this resolution today. Thank you very much, Sam Rainsy. You are an example to all of us. Democracy and non-violence will always win.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I believe that these are indeed connected vessels. That is, the combined vessel of our assistance that we provide to Cambodia, but also their respect precisely to the demands of the other side. Here, we have approved resolutions that have already called on Cambodia, perhaps more than once, to respect political rights. Cambodia is a relatively homogeneous country, both nationally and religiously, and cannot, in my opinion, transfer this homogeneity to other areas, such as human rights.  But I also think we should really get our asses behind our own doorstep. Multinational corporations, which are based in the Territory of the European Union and to some extent take advantage of the situation in this country or even plunder the territory and nature there, I think that we should also deal with this in our home.

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Member of the Commission. –Madam President, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy I would like to express gratitude for the debate on this topic today and to thank all the honourable Members of this Parliament who have taken part in it. Recent actions against members of the opposition in Cambodia, described in detail by previous speakers, are indeed cause for serious concern and raise questions about the culture of dialogue on which the government and the opposition agreed in July last year. I do not have to stress here in this Parliament how important the role of the opposition is in the democratic process. It is the nature and even the responsibility of an opposition to question and criticise the government and to hold them accountable to the public. In Cambodia the EU has advocated for and supported a culture of dialogue established between the party of government and the main opposition party. We have stressed that dialogue should not prevent the opposition from playing its role and that it should not be used as an excuse for suppressing criticism. We have urged both parties to work professionally and refrain from personal attacks and insults. The government, especially, is in a position of power and has therefore a particular duty to act with restraint and responsibility. Patience is the sign of strength and confidence. We agree with speakers who called on the EU to monitor closely the evolution of the situation, and indeed this is what we are doing. It is important for Cambodia, for the country itself, to return to a path of engagement and cooperation. We issued a local statement expressing our deep concern about the violent attack on two opposition members of the National Assembly, and we have also been using diplomatic channels to urge both parties to cooperate constructively and to return to the spirit of the culture of dialogue, as was agreed last year. We believe that a strong democracy that allows for constructive debate about policy alternatives is in the interests of Cambodia and its people if the country is to grow and develop. The EU will continue to use its resources, including our development assistance that includes EUR 120 million for good governance and administration in Cambodia, to support that process.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: I have received seven motions for resolutions to conclude the debate. The debate is over. The vote will take place on Thursday, 26 November 2015.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Next item: Freedom of expression in Bangladesh (2015/2970 (RSP))

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: author. – Madam President, I very much regret the need for this resolution today, but we know that the debate will be watched in the Bangladeshi press, and I think that is positive. In my visits to Bangladesh as Chair of Parliament’s relevant delegation, we have seen a very vibrant press in the past, but it certainly feels under attack now. We know that governments and politicians in general do not always like a vibrant press, but it is part of democratic development, as are active NGOs and civil society. Indeed, much of Bangladesh’s considerable development in terms of gender equality, child nutrition and climate change adaptation is a result of civil society working with government. I think that it is really important that there should be general political condemnation of violent attacks and death threats against journalists, bloggers, writers and indeed the public in general. We need a high-quality justice system that acts impartially to put forward the best interests of the people and bring perpetrators to justice. We would certainly hope that the government will put in place a system of protection for those at risk and for members of the political opposition too, because they have also been under attack in many circumstances. There is a need for political agreement in Bangladesh to move the country forward.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, despite the guarantees provided for in the Constitution, the Penal Code and the act prohibiting torture, disappearances, the use of torture and other forms of ill-treatment continue to persist in Bangladesh. In recent years, numerous secular writers, bloggers and publishers have been killed simply because they expressed their opinions. Instead of providing help in dealing with this outrageous injustice, political and state institutions began blaming the victims themselves, making things worse. There are serious and credible accusations of torture for forced confessions and of those arrested. I would like to mention the case of the murder of the Italian Cesare Travella.  The Bangladeshi authorities must undertake transparent investigations into the killing of bloggers in strict accordance with constitutional guarantees of the right to due process, identifying the perpetrators of these crimes.  The European Union must call on the Bangladeshi authorities to make public commitments to ensure that members of political parties are also free to express themselves and to meet. And the members of the opposition parties who have been imprisoned for attending secret assemblies must be released immediately.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: author. – Madam President, the recent murders and violence perpetrated against secular and atheist bloggers, journalists and activists in Bangladesh are clearly acts of terrorism and deserve our utmost condemnation. They are part of a wider vision intended to destabilise Bangladesh’s fragile secular democracy and to establish an Islamist, Sharia-based medieval state in that country, led by Jamaat-e-Islami and splinter groups. The Bangladesh Government, though far from perfect, is committed to protecting the right to freedom of expression for its citizens but is doing so in very difficult circumstances. As we battle against terrorism in our own countries, with all our economic advantages, we are seeing how difficult that task is in Europe. Nevertheless, the balance between the need to protect citizens’ rights and the ideals of ensuring universal freedom of expression and religion is always a delicate one and is something of which we should remain mindful when we are discussing or criticising Bangladesh. Today’s resolution is a positive one, but we must not fall into the trap of demanding safeguards and protection for people while simultaneously criticising all measures introduced to protect a modern secular state such as that of Bangladesh.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Author. – Madam President, I would like to say, as Mrs Lambert and Mr Tannock have also pointed out, that we are talking about a country where freedom of expression, freedom of the media exists and anyone can see this in Bangladesh. The number of newspapers and disputes taking place in the press are proof. On the other hand, it's worrying what's been happening lately, namely death threats and assaults against journalists or bloggers. It is to be welcomed that the government is committed to a zero-tolerance policy towards these abuses. Of course there's a lot to do. It must not be forgotten, moreover, as Mr Tannock said, that we are talking about a country where the value of secularism is important, but which, on the other hand, is under the threat of ISIS which concerns us here in equal measure. We call on the government to ensure the effective protection of all journalists and bloggers who do not defend radical Islamist causes.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: author. – Madam President, freedom of speech and expression is fundamental to all democracies, including Bangladesh. The Bangladeshi Constitution guarantees these freedoms to all of its citizens in Article 39. It also states that only reasonable restrictions can be imposed on these freedoms. I believe we would all agree that murder at the hands of religious extremists for writing an internet blog is not a reasonable restriction. These acts of extremist violence are nothing less than acts of terrorism, terrorist acts on a par with the attacks on Charlie Hebdo in Paris. We are ready to work with the Bangladeshi Government to fight such terrorists and to help them to counter extremist movements in their country, but the government must also continue to work to make clear to its citizens, through its words and deeds, that there can be no justification for these crimes. No offence to religion or morality can justify murder.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Author. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on 6 August 2014, the Government of Bangladesh decided on a new media policy, with the aim of restricting freedom by banning any anti-state discourse, which ridicules national ideology and is inconsistent with Bangladeshi culture, and also restricts the dissemination of reports of rebellion and violence. On 31 October, the publisher Faisal Arefin Dipon was killed and another publisher was seriously injured. In the same days, the Ansarullah Bangla Team, an Al-Qaida-inspired group claimed responsibility for the killing of 5 secular bloggers and activists, and the group itself published a blacklist of those considered critical of Islam and vowed, essentially, that no one will be spared. Security forces are carrying out extrajudicial executions, kidnappings and arbitrary arrests, targeting opposition leaders and supporters, and on November 21, 2015, two leaders were executed for war crimes committed during the war of independence against Pakistan.  There is an untenable situation on which action must be taken, and we are doing so with this resolution.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: Author. – Madam President, human rights are inalienable, indivisible and interdependent and interrelated. Freedom of expression is a necessary right to achieve a democratic society, such as political or social rights.  Bangladesh is a front-line trading partner of the European Union, but it is not an example of human rights. Five bloggers and freelance journalists have been killed this year, and trade unions and every opponent of the regime are also persecuted.  And what about labour rights? After two years of the Rana Plaza tragedy, Bangladeshi workers remain in conditions close to slavery.  In Bangladesh, disappearances and extrajudicial executions are common. Violence against women and LGBT groups is the order of the day. In Bangladesh there is still a death penalty today.  Enough cynicism! We cannot continue to be partners in States whose authorities systematically violate human rights. The dignity of people must always be above the economic benefits of a few. Always!

name: Seán KELLY
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, obviously we are right to absolutely condemn the acts of Islamist extremists who have carried out brutal murders against bloggers and journalists, etc. This is particularly regrettable, because Bangladesh itself signed up to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights in 2000. For some, freedom of expression, which is guaranteed in that, is not really worth the paper it is written on. In particular, the country itself has an Information and Communication Technology Act, which criminalises defamatory anti-state publications and which is often used as a kind of ‘catch all’ to stop opposition to government. Journalists, bloggers and writers have been targeted, and I think it is only right we should call on the authorities to drop charges against journalists and writers for merely expressing their opinion.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, secular writers, bloggers and publishers have been hacked to death. ‘There is no freedom of expression in Bangladesh’ – so wrote Sakharov Prize winner, Taslima Nasrin, when she heard about today’s debate. Here she can have a voice, but in Bangladesh today such a voice risks being silenced for good. Unable to speak out any more are slain bloggers Avijit Roy, Washiqur Rahman, Niloy Neel and Ananta Bijoy Das. Bangladesh ranks 12th from bottom on the Committee for the Protection of Journalists 2015 impunity index, spotlighting countries where journalists are murdered and their killers go unpunished. I am proud that this resolution calls for independent investigations into such killings but never to resort to the death penalty in response. It is not just the killings that prevent free speech; the government has criminalised criticism. Section 57 of the ICT Act criminalises criticising Islamic religious views or reporting on human rights violations. I echo Amnesty International’s calls to repeal Section 57 so that Bangladesh complies with its international human rights obligations. Last week, the Bangladesh Government banned Facebook and What’s App ‘indefinitely’, citing security reasons. George Orwell said, ‘If liberty means anything at all, it means the right to tell people what they do not want to hear’. The Bangladesh Government and the European External Action Service, in their dealings with this government, must remember this.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab More recently, many innocent people have been murdered in Bangladesh in cold blood – activists, columnists, bloggers, foreigners, members of religious minorities, including Christians. Others were threatened with death. Behind the attacks are Islamist extremists, probably partly linked to the current opposition, in part cooperating with Islamic State or al-Qaeda.  We have experienced terrorism recently in Europe, and bangladesh's events are a clear signal that we are talking about a global problem that affects many countries in different regions of the globe. The authorities of the country are making every effort to find the perpetrators of the attacks and bring them to justice and to prevent similar attacks of violence in the future. We should strongly support such actions, while ensuring that terrorist attacks do not become a pretext for tightening the rules on media freedom or the activities of NGOs and human rights defenders, and unfortunately such efforts have taken place recently. Nevertheless, it would be a mistake in the current situation to focus solely on government policy in this area and to ignore the main problem that this government is trying to solve. Combating the threat posed by Islamic terrorism , regardless of its source and whether it is linked to internal forces in the country or to the Islamic State, should be an absolute priority for the authorities.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, under the Cooperation and Development Agreement we have with Bangladesh, we have increased funding for the period 2014-2020 by 70% compared to the previous period.  Article 1 of this Agreement specifies that respect for human rights and democratic principles is an essential element. Yes, in Article 1. Freedom of the press and the media is an indispensable pillar for a democratic, pluralistic and open society.  The continued murder of bloggers and publishers, the implementation of policies that address media freedom of expression, the prohibition of "anti-State" language, or the closure of social media, such as Facebook, WhatsApp or Messenger, are clear signs that democracy in Bangladesh is deteriorating too quickly.  At this point I would like to ask you these questions: Do we believe that Bangladesh is respecting the Agreement? Do we think we need to continue to maintain the same conditions?  In this regard, I would like to call on the European External Action Service to require the Bangladeshi Government, immediately, to return without delay to the path of democracy.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: – Madam President, the recent news that secular bloggers, publishers and journalists are once again the targets of violence in Bangladesh is extremely worrying. The attacks against, and indeed murders of, people exercising their freedom of expression there have escalated over the past year, and five secular thinkers have been killed in 2015. Such intimidation and the threats of continued violence are quickly eroding freedom of expression in Bangladesh – a freedom enshrined in that country’s constitution. Many writers have fled, are in hiding or have been silenced by such threats. This is unacceptable. The Government of Bangladesh must not be seen to be granting impunity to those responsible for attacks on secularism. In a climate of increasing fear and denigration of the freedom of expression, the government must move away from defending laws that prohibit criticism of itself and instead must protect free, independent and secular thought.

name: Diane JAMES
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, Bangladesh is one of the world’s newest and also poorest countries, but it has a very special relationship with the United Kingdom, which is a member of the United Nations. The European Union should recognise that Bangladesh is undergoing its own security threat coupled with a general-election outcome that has magnified the aspects of killing, maiming and intimidation of its citizens. It also has in place laws that further impact on freedom of expression – for instance, freedom of belief is not allowed. Now the usual European Union interference should not happen – specific actions, criticisms and threats do not work. Leave it to the body that is acknowledged in the world, across the world – the United Nations. Ignore what my fellow United Kingdom party, the Labour Party, would like to do, which is to take the United Kingdom off the United Nations, but let the United Nations solve this and leave the United Kingdom to be the principal voice leading what is required in Bangladesh.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI). Madam President, freedom of expression has been a conquest of European culture for many centuries. This conquest, however difficult it may be for some to understand, is neither given nor often desirable in some parts of the world. But as much as this bothers us, we should deal with the European Union before we deal with Bangladesh. Because, especially in recent years, this right has been sacrificed on the altar of political correctness, under the cloak of which many laws now restrict free expression.  Moreover, when laws are not enough, transnational structures assume the role of suppressing the free expression of ideas. You remember very well how some people reacted when, for example, a magazine published cartoons of Muhammad. The crackdown on expression was undertaken by the terrorists at Charlie Hebdo, but also in the recent heinous attacks in the French capital. It should be noted that these terrorists have many sympathies, both in Bangladesh and in other Muslim countries of the world.  Moreover, there is more hypocrisy in the Union when you talk about freedom of expression, but at the same time you work perfectly with regimes that have been proven to censor their citizens, very often with brute force, such as Saudi Arabia and Turkey.  So let us protect freedom of expression in Europe and then deal with the rest of the world.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Madam President, this is a matter of urgency because of the increasing lack of freedom of expression in Bangladesh. The media clampdown, the crackdown on social media, attacks on secular thinkers and opposition groups, and the shutting down of online platforms are clear signals of repression. It is worrying that the violence is coming from two directions: from radicalised groups and from the security forces. Western media have reported the spread of radicalisation in Bangladesh and threats issued by IS against that country. My message to the Bangladesh Government is that there are no better weapons for safeguarding a society from extremist violence than inclusiveness, democracy, respect for human rights and freedom of speech. I would urge the government, led by the Awami League Party, truly to heed this message. I know a significant step has been taken with the adoption by enforcement agencies of a zero tolerance policy towards human rights violations, as well as the Police Reform Act, but these measures really need to be implemented, and I urge the High Representative and the Commission to support Bangladesh in these efforts. Equally, they need to convene a national dialogue that includes all democratic parties and civil society.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Reporters Without Borders says simply and to the point: without freedom of information, there are no opponents. That's probably what the Bangladeshi authorities were after when they banned by law, in 2014, speeches against the state, speeches that ridicule national ideology or those that do not conform to Bangladesh's culture. That is why I call for the release of those detained on the basis of these provisions and convincing explanations of the fate of opponents who have disappeared from opposition parties and impartial investigations in the cases of these disappearances. The Cybersecurity Act 2015, as well as the Information Technology Act, must be amended so as not to limit opinions and visions different from those of the authorities. Free thinking and the word "free" cannot be hidden in prisons.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I wanted to thank the authors of this motion for a resolution, which I am happy to support. It is a fact that the situation in Bangladesh is deteriorating significantly. The condition is dismal there, but unfortunately it's getting worse. It described how journalists and bloggers were attacked. In short, the fundamental right to democracy, the right to freedom of expression, is being suppressed in Bangladesh. Not only by radical terrorist Islamic groups, but unfortunately by the government itself. I therefore call on and join the words that have been made against the Commission here that the Government of Bangladesh should be permanently alerted to this in its negotiations with the Institutions of the European Union. That it is not possible for an independent journalist, a blogger, to be jailed for criticizing a cabinet minister on his Facebook profile. That it is not possible for criminal law to contain Section 57, where there are facts which more or less prevent the government from criticising freely. Until the government of Bangladesh respects democracy, it cannot be supported.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, in Bangladesh the security forces and the famous Rapid Action Battalion are a state in the state. They violate human rights, they engage in violence, they are accused of disappearing dissidents, they persecute journalists, bloggers and trade unionists, all on the pretext of supposedly protecting the interests of the state and national ideology.  But what is the European Union doing? It closes its eyes to this violent violation of human rights and the social exploitation and impoverishment of the people of Bangladesh. All this in the name of its partnership and development cooperation agreement with Bangladesh. An agreement that gives European multinationals the opportunity to profit unashamedly, having set up their factories in Bangladesh, which operate by employing workers without social security, on hunger wages, by not observing labour rights and health and safety conditions, resulting in constant fires and hundreds of fatal accidents at work, as we have repeatedly denounced in this Chamber, Commissioner.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Mr. President, we need a secular Bangladesh. We should support the government in order for Bangladesh to remain a secular state, because we see what radicalisation of political scenes in various states or states falling apart before our eyes means.  We need that part of the world not to be covered by radical measures proposed by members of the Islamic State and others who do not believe in democracy and freedom. However, what also needs to be emphasized is, and that is where I support all those who say that the European Commission in the negotiations with Bangladesh should put on the table the question of freedom of expression of journalists, opposition, trade unions and everything that we do not have in Bangladesh today practically, because in practice there are practically no such freedoms. As the European Union, we are Bangladesh's largest partner in many respects, and therefore we have the right to ask the Government of Bangladesh.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I must say that I very much welcomed the awarding of the Sakharov Prize to Mr Badawi this year, because this Saudi-Arab blogger reflects on a group that advocates freedom of expression, and this is, in fact, an issue on which the resolutions of all the factions associated in our Parliament have also been tabled here. We are proving that freedom of expression is absolutely essential for us. And in political speeches, debate, free exchange of views is crucial. The accusation that has been made to journalists in Bangladesh is undoubtedly fabricated. I call on the Government, on the contrary, to prosecute the crimes, murders, abductions, terror to which civilians are exposed in this country, and for these fabricated, baseless accusations against journalists to be dropped.

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, as many Members of Parliament have noted, in Bangladesh in the past two years restrictive legislative measures and policies have been adopted, or are in preparation, which could have a negative impact on freedom of expression and independent media and narrow the space for civil society. Some examples of this which were mentioned include a 2013 amendment to the Information Technology and Communication Act and the draft cyber security act, as well as the national broadcast policy and the national online mass media policy. This year has been marked by tragic attacks on journalists and the brutal murders of secular bloggers and a publisher, while others are facing death threats. This is taking place against the backdrop of a volatile security situation, which includes an unprecedented attack on a Shia procession in Dhaka last month, as well as recent killings and attacks on foreign citizens. I extend my condolences to the family of Cesare Tavella, who was killed on 28 September. There was also the attack on Father Parolari last week. These issues were discussed at a meeting between High Representative/Vice—President Federica Mogherini and the Bangladesh Foreign Minister in Luxembourg on 5 November, as well as in a follow-up at the meeting of the EU—Bangladesh Joint Commission on 11 November in Dhaka. The EU has expressed its alarm at the deteriorating human rights and security situation. We have called on the government to protect bloggers and also to bring the instigators and perpetrators of attacks to justice and to prevent the repetition of such horrible acts. We have stated our concern about legislation and policies that can be used to restrict media and internet freedom, while calling on the government to defend and protect freedom of expression and other fundamental rights. Upholding these rights is an integral part of what is so very clearly a top priority for all of us today, namely the fight against radicalisation. When we restrict the public space for dissenting voices, what we are in danger of doing is fuelling extremism. Our cooperation, as set out in the EU—Bangladesh Cooperation Agreement, is based on a mutual commitment to respecting human rights and democratic principles, respecting the principles of the international conventions on core human rights and labour rights – some speakers spoke about labour conditions – and also underpinning the scheme that provides Bangladesh with quota—free and duty—free access to the EU market. The EU will therefore continue to raise freedom of expression in our dialogue with Bangladesh as we remain committed to assisting Bangladesh in carrying out the reforms necessary to strengthen democracy and governance. (Applause)

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The sitting has been suspended until 12:00.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: – Madam President, we are going to vote on three emergency resolutions, and we will vote on them, in particular, with registered nominal votes. We are prevented from the right to make written statements, to explain why we voted in a certain way, and this is inadmissible, so that we ask that the rules be amended immediately so that they normally allow a Member to make his explanation of vote on these matters.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: No explanations of vote concerning urgencies.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: The next item is the votes. (For the results of the votes and the details of their passage: see Minutes)

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: – Madam President, I simply wanted to say, with regard to Cambodia, that we have with us today in the gallery the opposition leader, Sam Rainsy. I would like everybody to know that he is here. (Loud applause)

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on her excellent As long as there is an expression that war is the engine of progress, it would be much more historically correct to say that trade is the engine of progress— always was and always will be. Trade gave a strong impetus to the movement of ideas, knowledge, cultures, people from one corner of the earth to another.  As we approach today, it was trade that gave one of the strongest springboards in the process of globalisation. The Doha Round was launched in 2001 within the Framework of the World Trade Organisation with the aim of gradually liberalising international trade through the removal of barriers, but after 2008 the negotiations actually stalled and several efforts to resume it were not successful. Over the last couple of years, a number of measures have been implemented suggesting that not everything has been lost.  This motion for a resolution seems to me to be very important because it denotes the European Parliament's high interest in working closely with its partners, The Member States, the other Institutions of the European Union with the extreme aim of successfully completing the Doha Round, and hedating effectively with the tasks. And then, as the 10th Ministerial Conference continues, efforts should be made to take into account the interests of all parties involved, especially in the case of developing countries, which is most important. Thank you!

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, my apologies for not being alert earlier. I support this proposal, I voted in favour of it, and, being a member of the Committee on International Trade, I am, of course, proud of the work that they are doing and will continue to do in the future. Opening up trade is imperative if we want to see sustainable economic growth, in particular in low-income developing countries. It is equally important to implement policies that promote the maximum distribution of trade reforms and counterbalance any negative effects, especially of reforms in areas such as budget transparency and education. I believe we should continue to work in this regard and to play a leading role in promoting tangible progress in the ongoing World Trade Organization (WTO) negotiations with a view to the full conclusion of the Doha Development Round in the near future, as well as in facilitating the full participation of low-income developing countries in global trade by acting as a bridge between the various positions and WTO members.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: – Madam President, Thomas Jefferson once said that peace, commerce and honest friendship with all nations are important, but we should not be entangling alliances with anyone. The World Trade Organization is an important organisation in that we need trade liberalisation and tariff reductions and we need to deal with anti-dumping. Unfortunately, our governments in the past have not listened to Thomas Jefferson’s words, and we have become entangled with the European Union, thus losing our spot in the World Trade Organization. As a consequence, we cannot influence properly the world trade liberalisation programme. We cannot influence tariff reductions that would benefit the people of the United Kingdom. Instead, we have to listen to EU technocrats, with their expansionist ideas, who will have it in their own interests, not those of our nation. Only by leaving the EU with a vote for ‘Brexit’, hopefully next year, will Britain regain its space in the World Trade Organization and be able to have growth in our economy once again.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Madam President, free trade is the greatest engine for peace and collaboration globally. As the great French economist Frédéric Bastiat observed, when goods do not cross borders, armies do. Free trade makes conflict both pointless and unduly hurtful to the perpetrator. Yet – and this point is still not widely understood, despite more than 40 years of membership of the European Union – the UK does not have a separate voice or vote in the World Trade Organization (WTO). We are represented by one-twenty-eighth of an EU official, I think at the moment a Swedish former sociology professor. That is not just a problem in theory, it is very much a problem in practice, when we think that Europe is the only continent on the planet not experiencing economic growth. The other continents are surging ahead, but the eurozone economy is the same size that it was in 2008. We do not sit on any great natural resources in my damp, green, exquisite island home. We have to make our way in the world through what we buy and sell. That means we have to be where the customers are. The customers are not in Europe, and we need to leave the European Union and take back our place in the WTO.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ The Doha Development Agenda (DDA) is a series of trade-liberalisation measures – including, inter alia, tariff reductions and anti-dumping provisions – on which all World Trade Organisation members are seeking binding agreement.  Strengthening the WTO in this manner is in the UK’s interest, as it bolsters international trading norms that the UK would enjoy as a fully active member on Brexit.  Though the motion for a resolution supports this process and calls for greater democratic accountability in WTO decision making, it promotes an activist role for the EU in advancing its own trade agenda through the WTO framework.  On these grounds, UKIP MEPs voted to abstain on the resolution.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – The Doha Development Agenda (DDA) is a series of trade-liberalisation measures – including, inter alia, tariff reductions and anti-dumping provisions – on which all World Trade Organization (WTO) members are seeking binding agreement. Strengthening the WTO in this manner is in the UK’s interest, as it bolsters international trading norms that the UK would enjoy as a fully active member on Brexit. Though the motion for a resolution supports this process and calls for greater democratic accountability in WTO decision-making, it promotes an activist role for the EU in advancing its own trade agenda through the WTO framework. On these grounds, UKIP MEPs voted to abstain on the resolution.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted against this Resolution because it maintains a logic of liberalization of international trade. Despite containing positive comments on what the Doha Development Agenda entails, it does not condemn that its spirit has been betrayed through multilateral agreements such as TCE, CETA, ATP, etc. These multilateral agreements are being hurriedly negotiated by major Western powers. It is a model that promotes the development of unequal international trade through agreements that guarantee their absolute control by large multinationals and the defense of their interests. We need trade that prepends peoples' rights to trade models that guarantee processes of economic development.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – I voted against this resolution on the WTO’s Doha Development Agenda talks. This resolution fails to recognise the negative impacts WTO agreements can have on the world’s poorest countries. The Doha Development Agenda talks, which were set up with the original intention of improving trade for developing countries, have been predictably dominated by industrialised countries instead. WTO actions should aim to contribute to achieving the recently adopted sustainable development goals instead of solely pushing trade liberalisation. Increasing trade for its own sake is not enough – trade must be fair if it is to lift people out of poverty.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. WTO members should urgently conclude the long-standing Doha Round with the fulfilment of their development mandate and make balanced but ambitious progress, because the stakes are high. Multilateral trade rules could be strengthened and imbalances in the trade structure corrected. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution. It also calls on the EU to take a leading role in the WTO negotiations and calls for greater democratic legitimacy and transparency through greater parliamentary participation in the WTO.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This text is intended to prepare for the December WTO meeting in Nairobi. The European Parliament wants the WTO to establish a global free trade that dismantles each country's standards in favour of global standards. It even proposes that the WTO should be able to deal with "non-trade issues". These further surrenders of sovereignty would be dramatic since they would prevent the States themselves from legislating. Especially since the text calls for WTO agreements to be legally binding on signatory states. I have, of course, opposed this text, which makes free trade a real dogma.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this vote, because two contradictory principles are involved. I oppose the calls for EU activism within the World Trade Organization (WTO). However, I support the general principle of strengthening the WTO itself and the liberalisation of trade. I note the positives, and further note that this weakens still further any economic case for the UK remaining in the European Union.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this resolution on the current situation of the Doha Development Agenda in the run-up to the 10th WTO Ministerial Conference. The Doha negotiations were launched in 2001 with a view to creating new trade opportunities, tightening multilateral trade rules and correcting existing imbalances in the trading system by focusing on the needs of developing and least developed countries. I support the structural reform of the WTO, which is needed to better ensure a non-discriminatory trading system. Trade liberalisation is an important tool for sustainable economic growth and development, but trade liberalisation also requires appropriate parallel policies, including budgetary transparency, fiscal policy, administrative simplification, education and training, institutional reforms and social policy.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution calls for the continuation of the Doha Agenda, on which ministers will meet in Kenya between 15 and 18 December 2015. Wto efforts to liberalise trade and financial flows are primarily in the interests of developed industrialised countries and, above all, of multinationals.  Instead of globalisation, which is about exploiting cheap labour for the sake of multinationals, it is necessary to follow a principle that every country should produce for itself, within the framework of realistic possibilities, what it needs. So production should be for man, not man for production. The focus should be on sustainable development and increasing the population retention capacity of developing countries. In this regard, it is worth quoting perhaps the most respected economist, John Maynard Keynes: "Financial calculations may be beneficial to invest my savings in those parts of the world where there is the highest return on capital or interest. But there is growing experience suggesting that the distance between the owner and the area of operation is bad for people-to-people relationships, and it is likely, or rather certain, to lead to long-term tensions and hostility, which invalidates financial calculations." On this basis, I rejected the proposal for a decision.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. The WTO being the armed arm of free trade under the US banner, I voted against this text which encourages the Union to continue in its wanderings.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I supported this report, which, prior to the 10th WTO Ministerial Conference, stresses in particular the importance of taking full account of the specific needs and interests of low-income developing countries and LDCs during the negotiations and recalls the need to ensure that the principle of special and differentiated treatment is integrated at each stage of the negotiations to take into account the varying levels of development of WTO members. It believes that, in order to be effective, the special and differentiated treatment provisions need to be more specific, subject to periodic reviews and applied in a targeted manner to meet the needs of developing countries and the LDCs that need them most.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We vote against it because the report supports a market logic that does not ensure the interests of developing countries or the workers and the environment of the European Union itself. For example, it focuses on removing barriers to trade arising from the crisis, without reflecting on the causes of the crisis. Allusions to support measures for developing countries are not sufficient to counteract the overall approach: trade facilitation as an objective in itself.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I would like to thank the relevant Members for their work in this report on the state of the Doha Development Agenda before the tenth WTO Ministerial Conference. I have supported the full commitment to the enduring value of multilateralism, while calling for the development of a trade agenda based on free and fair trade that is in everyone's interest and defines development as the central element of the whole process.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The Doha Round is the ongoing negotiation for an international free trade agreement under the aegis of the WTO. It began in 2001 and, 14 years later, it is still blocking, especially with India refusing any agreement to defend its agriculture. The text is due to prepare for the meeting in Nairobi in December. The text called for the WTO to establish an even deeper global free trade and to dismantle each country's standards to set global standards. It even proposes that the WTO should be able to address these "non-trade issues". This text still aims to lose the sovereignty of States in terms of trade policy, which is totally unacceptable, by making free trade agreements legally binding. I naturally voted against this text.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not agree with what emerges from this resolution with regard to the Doha Development Agenda with a view to the tenth WTO Ministerial Conference. We need an immediate change of course, we need to put the right of each state to defend its production system back at the centre of our policies and those of the WTO. On the other hand, the European Commission, which is supposed to represent us, continues undaunted to disregard the legitimate commercial interests of the 28 EU states. For these reasons, I was unable to support this text with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. In 2001, world trade organization member countries decided to launch the Doha Round with the aim of strengthening multilateral trade rules, expanding the opportunities offered by international trade and overcoming the imbalances that currently exist, focusing on developing countries and, fundamentally, the least developed countries. The conclusions of the 10th WTO Ministerial Conference, to be held in Kenya in December 2015, will be of paramount importance. We hope that the necessary support for the entry into force of the Trade Facilitation Agreement will be gathered and WTO support renewed as a system of global trade governance. The EU must maintain its leadership in promoting the negotiations currently taking place in the WTO, especially the Doha Round, which we wish to see concluded in the near future.  The Socialists are strong advocates of multilateralism in trade regulation. We defend multilateral governance as the most effective system for governing free and equitable global trade, with effective, fair, transparent rules at the service of economic development and the fight against poverty. That is why we have supported this resolution.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this resolution on the current situation of the Doha Development Agenda in the run-up to the 10th Ministerial Conference of the World Trade Organisation (WTO). The European Parliament supports the structural reform of the WTO, which is needed to better ensure a common, open, fair and non-discriminatory trading system that takes greater account of the role and interests of various economic operators, such as small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), micro-enterprises and innovative start-ups.
