Parliament calls on WTO members to actively support WTO efforts by establishing effective and effective working links and by ensuring closer cooperation with other international organisations involved in global trade negotiations, in particular with the International Labour Organisation, the World Health Organisation and the United Nations and its agencies. Parliament also considers it essential to conclude the protracted Doha Round in the implementation of development powers. Calls, therefore, on all WTO members, in the light of this ultimate objective, to consider all options in order to achieve a large-scale, global, coherent and realistic outcome.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ I support the Status Statement of the Doha Development Plan ahead of the WTO's 10th Ministerial Conference. The Doha Development Plan was launched in 2001 with the aim of creating new trading opportunities, strengthening multilateral trade rules and addressing the current imbalance, leading to fair and free trade and economic development of all continents and poverty reduction. Therefore, the results of the 9th Ministerial Conference of 2013 are of systematic importance for the organisation.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. The European Parliament calls, through this text, for the WTO to establish an even deeper global free trade that would also include the standards of each country. It is precisely this kind of provision that confronts developed countries with rapid deindustrialization, uncontrollable unemployment growth, and therefore also a decrease in their tax revenues and an increase in their social burdens, all leading to increasingly abysmal public deficits. Proponents of this deadly policy try to hide the risks of such orientations by advocating policies favourable to SMEs that in reality they make impossible to implement. The icing on the cake is that the text calls for WTO agreements to be legally binding, which would make them even more damaging. For all these reasons, I'm voting against it.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution as it ignores some of the main issues with the trade talks.  The needs and interests of developing countries, especially least developed countries are not the focus of the Doha development agenda which has been going on since 2001 and has been predictably dominated by the larger industrialised countries.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. Since 2001, the Doha Round has been a WTO-led round of negotiations on the liberalization of international trade. 14 years later, the agreement is on the wrong track, much to the chagrin of the Commission and the European Parliament. In particular, India is blocking any agreement to defend its agriculture. The text is intended to prepare for the December WTO meeting in Nairobi. The WTO is being asked to promote international trade agreements in order to deepen global free trade. To do this, it is recommended that the WTO dismantle each country's standards in order to establish international standards. The European Parliament welcomes sectoral free trade approaches, such as the Information Technology Agreement or TISA. The European Parliament is trying to hide the danger of such agreements by advocating a trade policy favourable to SMEs and developing countries. This motion for a resolution is outrageous and forces peoples to undergo trade agreements specifically designed to favour multinationals. The standardization of consumption in the world would enable them to achieve significant economies of scale and thus increase their profitability to the delight of shareholders. So I voted against that proposal.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Trade liberalisation is an important tool to ensure sustainable economic growth and development, which is an objective on which the European Union was built and which remains the main factor of cohesion between Member States. However, this liberalisation must be accompanied by appropriate supportive policies, involving macro and micro-economic measures, including budgetary transparency, fiscal policies and fiscal equity, administrative simplification, education and training, institutional reforms and social policies, in order to maximise and better distribute the benefits of trade reforms and effectively offset any negative effects. All this is specified in Parliament's resolution, together with the principle of special and differentiated treatment, the benefit of economic development of all continents and the contribution to poverty reduction.  The Doha Round was launched with the aim of creating new trade opportunities, strengthening multilateral trade rules and addressing the current imbalances of the trading system, putting the needs and interests of developing countries and, in particular, the least developed countries at the heart of the negotiations. I voted in favour of this resolution, considering that its completion is essential, and I will therefore support the objectives it proposes.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against. This resolution by the INTA Committee expresses a vision of the World Trade Organisation and its policies that are contrary to our point of view. In view of the WTO conference to be held in Nairobi in December, this text should provide the European Parliament's point of view. In truth, it is a script that has already been seen. The wishes and opinions expressed are the same as on previous occasions. On the contrary, in order to resurrect the economy of the most depressed area on the planet, the European Union, we need a real reform of the WTO that puts at the centre the right of each State to defend its production system, putting aside the free-trade ideas that are the basis of the Doha round and all the action of the supranational body in Geneva.  In the european case, then, the Member States should once again become the protagonists. The European Commission, which represents us in the WTO, fails to take account of the legitimate commercial interests of the 28 Member States of the Union. It is clear that there is no mention of this in this resolution. The European Parliament's attention seems to be focused exclusively on the development and growth needs of third countries. We must quickly return to putting the pursuit of our exit targets from the economic crisis at the top of the European and WTO priorities.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The World Trade Organization (WTO) is essential to ensure fair trade competition around the world. The European project is based on trade liberalisation. The European Union has also developed important trading networks with many third countries. However, in this approach, it is necessary to ensure that trade opening is non-discriminatory. In this regard, the WTO's multilateral approach regulates trade on the international stage by putting in place a set of rules to ensure fair global trade competition. We must continue the Doha negotiations taking into account the special needs of developing countries. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the motion for a resolution on the state of play of the Doha Development Agenda with a view to the 10th WTO Ministerial Conference. The Doha Round was launched in 2001 with the aim of creating new trade opportunities based on a multilateral system composed of fairer and fairer rules capable of developing fair and free trade at the service of the economic development of all continents.  I believe that the European Union must continue to believe in the Doha Development Agenda and work towards reaching a political agreement that will allow it to move forward, to ensure that the WTO's negotiating functions remain at the heart of further liberalisation of trade at world level. The resolution also stressed the importance of reaching a speedy conclusion to the Doha Round, with the emphasis on the value of multilateralism and on trade based on free and fair trade for the benefit of all, putting development at the heart of the process, and that is why I have chosen to vote in favour of it.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution was another worrying attempt towards a regressive trade agenda. As an MEP, I have been closely monitoring a number of trade agreements including TTIP, TiSA and CETA. The common thread running through these agreements is an aggressive attempt to call for further liberalisation, even though the disadvantages of liberalisation have become clear in many economic sectors – particularly in the financial sector. The Doha Development Agenda talks, which were set up with the original intention of improving trade for developing countries, have been predictably dominated by industrialised countries instead. WTO actions should be able to contribute to achieving the recently adopted sustainable development goals instead of solely pushing trade liberalisation. Increasing trade for its own sake is not enough – trade must be fair if it is to lift people out of poverty. It was for these reasons that I voted against this resolution.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ The Doha Development Agenda (DDA) is a series of trade-liberalisation measures – including, inter alia, tariff reductions and anti-dumping provisions – on which all World Trade Organisation members are seeking binding agreement.  Strengthening the WTO in this manner is in the UK’s interest, as it bolsters international trading norms that the UK would enjoy as a fully active member on Brexit.  Though the motion for a resolution supports this process and calls for greater democratic accountability in WTO decision making, it promotes an activist role for the EU in advancing its own trade agenda through the WTO framework.  On these grounds, UKIP MEPs voted to abstain on the resolution.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because we need a clear definition of low-income developing countries and emerging countries because under the original definition China is still a developing country. This plan urges for a trading system that does not discriminate, especially for companies, SMEs and innovative start-ups in developing countries.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution will serve as a basis for discussion at the tenth WTO ministerial meeting in Nairobi on 15 December. A first point concerns the principle of special and differentiated treatment of the least developed countries, which have an income level below the dollar per day, the so-called LDCs (Least Developed Countries). The summit will also serve to discuss the functioning of the WTO and the need for its thorough reform. In the light of the above, I voted in favour.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the resolution because I believe that the EU has to make clear that it is fully committed to this negotiation and especially to its full conclusion as early as possible. This is the message that we need to send to all the negotiating parties before the meeting.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament's motion for a resolution calls on the Commission and the Council to ensure that Parliament continues to participate closely in the preparation of the Tenth Ministerial Conference, to be informed immediately and if necessary to be consulted for the duration of the Ministerial Conference. The Commission is called upon to continue to support before the other WTO members the strengthening of the parliamentary dimension of the WTO (World Trade Organisation). It also calls on WTO members to ensure democratic legitimacy and transparency, thus strengthening the parliamentary dimension of the WTO. We fully agree with the approach of the resolution.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure. The Doha Round, to which the EU contributes with the reform of the common agricultural policy, was launched in 2001 with the aim of creating new trade opportunities and strengthening multilateral trade rules, placing the needs and interests of developing countries at the heart of the negotiations. A multilateral system based on fairer and fairer rules can contribute to fair and free trade at the service of the economic development of all continents and to reducing poverty. The 10th WTO Ministerial Conference, to be held in Kenya from 15 to 18 December 2015, will be the first such conference to take place in an African country. Parliament reiterated the need to ensure that the principle of special and differentiated treatment (SDT) is an integral part of the negotiations and reflects the different levels of economic development of WTO member countries, taking greater account of the role and interests of a number of economic operators, such as SMEs, micro-enterprises and innovative start-ups. It considers, however, that trade liberalisation should be combined with appropriate institutional and social reforms. Lastly, it recommends strengthening the parliamentary dimension of the WTO.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ The Doha Development Agenda (DDA) is a series of trade-liberalisation measures – including, inter alia, tariff reductions and anti-dumping provisions – on which all World Trade Organisation members are seeking binding agreement.  Strengthening the WTO in this manner is in the UK’s interest, as it bolsters international trading norms that the UK would enjoy as a fully active member on Brexit.  Though the motion for a resolution supports this process and calls for greater democratic accountability in WTO decision making, it promotes an activist role for the EU in advancing its own trade agenda through the WTO framework.  On these grounds, UKIP MEPs voted to abstain on the resolution.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 The 10th Ministerial Conference of the World Trade Organisation in Kenya will take place in December. Since its inception in 1995, the World Trade Organisation (WTO) has played a significant role in creating a rules-based international trading system. Since 2001, WTO members have engaged in a wide-ranging round of multilateral trade negotiations, the Doha Round, which seeks to further liberalize trade by putting the emphasis on development by strengthening developing countries' ability to benefit from international trade, and helping them fight poverty. In this regard, I welcome the TRADE Facilitation Agreement, ratified by the EU on 5 October and I hope that this new Ministerial Conference will reach a political agreement to advance the Doha Development Agenda, always ensuring the principle of special and differentiated treatment. I agree with the need to monitor economic growth and the sustainable development of appropriate macro and micro-economic monitoring policies, including budgetary transparency, tax equity, administrative simplification, education, training, social policies and institutional reforms.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the resolution because we need to involve developing countries quickly in world trade. We urgently need the speedy ratification and implementation of the Trade Facilitation Agreement. The EU, as a global trading partner, will also be able to benefit from this. However, we will only succeed in this if we take into account the specific needs of the developing countries. I also see these measures as an effective complement to our development policy.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote in favour of this report because I believe it is essential for Parliament to support the structural reforms of the WTO, so as to promote the development of an open, fair and non-discriminatory trading system, capable of enhancing the role and interests of the variety of actors involved such as small and medium-sized enterprises, micro-enterprises and innovative start-ups. The new provisions will ensure new opportunities for global trade, strengthen multilateral trade rules and be able to stem existing imbalances in the world economic system. These goals will boost the economic development of all continents and contribute to the reduction of poverty in the world, therefore, I hope that the European Union will commit itself to making new strong multilateral agreements, without neglecting the importance of bilateral, regional and plurilateral agreements, capable of promoting the development of an open trading system. In order to achieve these objectives, it will be necessary both to open up the liberalisation process and to update trade rules and disciplines in order to establish a code of shared rules that will create the conditions for possible future multilateralisation.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution focuses on the special needs and disadvantages of low-income developing countries. It calls for a clear definition of developing countries and low income so as to adjust the identifying factors merely enabling the World Trade Organization (WTO) to work more effectively. The resolution supports a structural reform system for the WTO, in order to better guarantee an open, fair and non-discriminatory trading system taking into account the role and interests of SMEs, micro-enterprises and innovative start-ups.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a "topical resolution" (RSP) ahead of the tenth WTO ministerial meeting, to be held on 15 December. The resolution serves to give the Union a common position on the main issues on the agenda of the ministerial meeting: at the heart of the debate will be the functioning of the WTO and the need for structural reform, which is necessary to ensure an open and non-discriminatory trading system, and which takes full account of the role of SMEs. Unfortunately, there are many plurilateral and bilateral agreements that the Member States are negotiating and that call into question the very usefulness of multilateralism, as proposed by the WTO, which is being reduced to a mere instrument for defining common rules rather than at the forefront of reducing tariffs, opening up new outlets and guaranteeing equal access to markets. The Nairobi Ministerial Meeting is therefore a crucial moment in redefining all relations. My opinion on the report can only be positive.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted against this Resolution because it maintains a logic of liberalization of international trade. Despite containing positive comments on what the Doha Development Agenda entails, it does not condemn that its spirit has been betrayed through multilateral agreements such as TCE, CETA, ATP, etc. These multilateral agreements are being hurriedly negotiated by major Western powers. It is a model that promotes the development of unequal international trade through agreements that guarantee their absolute control by large multinationals and the defense of their interests. We need trade that prepends peoples' rights to trade models that guarantee processes of economic development.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 The Doha Round is a series of negotiations between the economic and trade ministers of WTO Member States that have been going on since 2001. The ep's report is published at the 10th WTO Ministerial Conference in Kenya between 15 and 18 December, for the first time in an African country. In the current decision, the European Parliament says that the needs and interests of developing countries should be fully taken into account. It is important to redefine the concept of developing countries, e.g. China is still considered a "developing country".  Furthermore, the European Parliament supports the structural reform of the WTO, which would ensure a fair, non-discriminatory and transparent trading system, taking into account the interests and role of commercial operators, including SMEs, micro-enterprises and start-ups. The Decision encourages WTO Member States to do their best to conclude the Doha Round effectively as soon as possible and to ratify and transpose the Agreement on Global Trade Relief. I voted in favour of the adoption of the decision.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The Doha Round is the latest round of trade negotiations among World Trade Organization (WTO) members. The WTO has been instrumental in avoiding fully fledged and widespread protectionism. Launched in 2001, the Doha Round aims at creating new trading opportunities, strengthening multilateral trade rules and addressing current imbalances in the trading system by considering the needs of developing and least developed countries. This contributes to fair and free trade and the alleviation of poverty. This particular resolution deals with the state of play of the Doha Development Agenda in view of the 10th WTO Ministerial Conference which will take place in Kenya in December. Along with my Group I am glad that the resolution gives full commitment to the enduring value of multilateralism, respect for special and differential treatment in the negotiations and support for a structural reform of the WTO. The resolution also insists that the EU should continue to play a leading role in WTO negotiations, that Parliament continues to be closely involved and on strengthening the parliamentary dimension of the WTO. Negotiations should also consider the special needs of low-income developing countries. In view of these considerations I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I support the multilateral process in Geneva to complete the Doha Development Round of world trade talks. Although finding unilateral agreement is unlikely, given the divergences in the positions of key players ahead of the conference, this resolution calls for additional deliverables to be considered. In addition, supporting moves to help countries trade their way out of poverty is also something I am in favour of.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 Since the reform of the common agricultural policy represents the European Union's contribution to the expectations of the Doha Round, I believe that WTO member villages must proactively support efforts to create effective and effective working channels and strengthen WTO cooperation with other international organisations whose work has an influence on global trade negotiations, in particular the International Labour Organisation , the World Health Organisation, the UN and its agencies and bodies, such as the UN Conference on Trade and Development, the Food and Agriculture Organisation, the UN Environment Programme, the UN Development Programme and the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This resolution expresses Parliament's position on the progress of the Doha Development Agenda ahead of the 10th Ministerial Conference of the World Trade Organization (WTO). MEPs reiterate the importance of addressing the specific needs and interests of the least developed or low-income countries. As such, they consider it necessary to revise the definition of "developing countries", considering that China is still in this category.  The European Parliament also advocates structural reform of the WTO to better take into account the variety of players in the economy, such as SMEs, micro-enterprises and start-ups. Finally, it calls on all WTO members to speed up the Doha Round negotiations and recalls that the latest reform of the Common Agricultural Policy is the EU's agricultural contribution to these negotiations. Considering that this resolution is balanced, I voted in favour.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. The growing emergence of a variety of players in the global economy (SMEs, micro-enterprises) necessities structural reform of the WTO in order to better take into account the special needs and interests of individual member countries. That is why I supported the resolution on the progress of the Doha Development Agenda.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This report on the progress of an additional free trade system seeks to make a situation that is already difficult to cope with once again. In order to promote the WTO's participation in globalised free trade, including allowing it to deal with non-trade-related issues, this report continues in the classic logic of the Europeanists. What if Europe doesn't work? It is that we need more Europe; if globalized free trade has caused recession, relocation and ruins of our industries, we must not go any further in this direction. I am committed to the principle of sovereignty, and to the peoples who can have their policies. Continuing in the same direction that has led us to ever more problems, this report is to be fought urgently. So I voted against it.

name: Ian DUNCAN
text: in writing. ‒ I am a strong supporter of the multilateral process in Geneva to complete the Doha Development Round of world trade talks. This remains unlikely, given the divergences in the positions of key players ahead of the Conference.  However the resolution calls for additional deliverables to be considered.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution of the Committee on Foreign Trade of the European Parliament because the objectives set out therein to work towards ratification and adoption of the Trade Facilitation Agreement at the upcoming 10th Conference at Ministerial Level of the United States in Nairobi, Kenya, will be a step forward in the development of trade. The chances of accepting this agreement are high, as it is considered separately from the Doha Development Programme, which has been stagnant for almost 15 years. It is well known that differences in the positions of the negotiators of the Doja Development Agenda are rooted, and the chances of progress in this regard are minimal. This resolution recognises this and proposes that efforts should be focused on the adoption of sectoral international agreements such as the Trade Facilitation Agreement, the IT Agreement and the Natural Resources Agreement. Only in this way will the international community be able to overcome the stagnation in the development of trade relations caused by the long-standing negotiations on the Doja Development Agenda.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This report aims to free markets from all kinds of obstacles and controls, but this will lead to disastrous results for European citizens. The WTO seeks to impose its views on every aspect of society, on public administration management, tax policy, education, social policies and institutional reforms.  We are clearly opposed to world trade based on the implementation and imposition of binding obligations, which is why we are voting against the motion for a resolution on the current state of the Doha Development Agenda ahead of the 10th WTO Ministerial Conference.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: in writing. – The Doha Development Agenda (DDA) is a series of trade-liberalisation measures – including, inter alia, tariff reductions and anti-dumping provisions – on which all World Trade Organization members are seeking binding agreement. Strengthening the WTO in this manner is in the UK’s interest, as it bolsters international trading norms that the UK would enjoy as a fully active member on Brexit. Though the motion for a resolution supports this process and calls for greater democratic accountability in WTO decision-making, it promotes an activist role for the EU in advancing its own trade agenda through the WTO framework. On these grounds, UKIP MEPs voted to abstain on the resolution.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. The Doha Round was launched in 2001 with the aim of creating new trade opportunities, strengthening multilateral trade standards and addressing current imbalances in the trading system, putting the needs and interests of developing countries and, in particular, the least developed countries at the heart of the negotiations. Open and fair multilateral trade is more constrained by various non-tariff barriers than by customs duties, which are being substantially extinguished as globalisation progresses. I therefore advocate the enduring value of multilateralism and an agenda for trade based on free and fair trade for the benefit of all and whose process is focused on development. I voted in favour.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation because it is part of an ever-increasing openness to international free trade.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution insists on the neoliberal vision of the Doha Development Agenda (DDA) launched in 2001. An apologetic view of the deregulation of international trade, which is clear in several of the paragraphs and recitals of the resolution. The 10th WTO Ministerial Conference (CM10) will be held in Kenya from 15 to 18 December 2015 in Nairobi. It will be the first World Trade Organisation (WTO) Ministerial Conference ever held in an African country.  It will patent the deepening towards the liberalisation and deregulation of world trade. The crisis of capital profitability and its unprecedented degree of centralization and concentration of wealth leads it to seek new forms of exploitation, creating neocolonial agreements, in which developed countries dictate what developing countries should or should not do in areas such as fiscal and tax policies, administrative organization, education and training , institutional reforms and social policies, while exploiting their natural resources with irreversible consequences for the environment, and attacking progress and social achievements, such as public services and the right to fair pay employment. We therefore reaffirm the urgent need to suspend the "Doha Round".  Obviously we voted against it.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 It is very important that all WTO members ratify and implement the Trade Facilitation Agreement promptly so that it can enter into force before the opening of the 10th WTO Agreement. Ministerial conferences in December. This agreement will bring significant benefits to all WTO members, in particular developing countries and relevant economic operators, by strengthening transparency and legal certainty and reducing administrative costs and the length of customs procedures, enabling them to take full advantage of the opportunities offered by the growing predominance of regional and global supply chains, while enabling SMEs to benefit from more open markets. I therefore welcome the progress made so far on multilateral initiatives such as the Environmental Goods Agreement and the Information Technology Agreement and on initiatives such as the Agreement on Trade in Services.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting with conviction against this report. Since the European Commission represented us in the WTO, our country has suffered enormous damage because, by its very nature, the EU is unable to take account of the legitimate different commercial interests of the 28 Member States of the Union.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This report aims to free markets from all kinds of obstacles and controls, which will lead to disastrous results for European citizens. The WTO seeks to impose its views on every aspect of society, on the management of public administration, on tax policy, on education, on social policies and on institutional reforms. I am clearly opposed to world trade based on the implementation and imposition of binding obligations, which is why I am voting against the motion for a resolution on the current state of the Doha Development Agenda ahead of the 10th WTO Ministerial Conference.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The Doha Round creates new trading opportunities, strengthens multilateral trade rules and addresses current imbalances in the trading system by placing the needs and interests of developing countries and especially of the least developed countries (LDCs) at its centre. Thus, it contributes to fair and free trade at the service of the economic development of all continents and the alleviation of poverty. I support full commitment to the enduring value of multilateralism, respect for special and differential treatment in the negotiations, and the call for speedy ratification and implementation of the trade facilitation agreement. Moreover, structural reform of the WTO is needed in order to better guarantee an open, fair and non-discriminatory trading system based on shared rules, and which takes greater account of the role and interests of SMEs. Finally, I believe the EU should continue to play a leading role in promoting tangible progress in the ongoing WTO negotiations with a view to the full conclusion of the Doha Development Round in the foreseeable future, as well as in facilitating the full participation of LDCs in global trade by acting as a bridge between the various positions of the WTO members.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 The Doha Round, launched in 2001, aims to create new trade opportunities, strengthen rules on multilateral trade and address the current imbalances in the trading system, with the needs and interests of developing countries, and in particular least developed countries, at the heart of the negotiations. In my view, these objectives stem from the conviction that a multilateral system based on fairer and fairer rules can contribute to the development of fair and free trade for the economic development of all continents and to poverty reduction. The aforementioned aspects should be given priority. These agreements comply with WTO standards, are based on commonly agreed rules and create the conditions for a possible future multilateral framework.  Consequently, I think it is important to reaffirm the full commitment to multilateralism of lasting value and to push for a trade agenda based on free and fair trade in the interests of all parties and at the heart of which is development.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution convinced that it is essential to develop a trade agenda based on free and fair trade, which is in everyone's interest and defines development as the central element of the whole process. The EU must continue to play a leading role in promoting tangible progress in the current WTO negotiations with a view to the full conclusion of the Doha Development Round in the near future, as well as facilitating negotiations as a bridge between the different positions of WTO members.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The WTO needs to be revitalised. We need more open trade, more economic development. I hope that the Nairobi Conference will be a turning point in terms of economic growth and employment, bringing concrete help to the poor people in their own countries.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the structure of the motion for a resolution tabled following a statement by the Commission (pursuant to Article 123(2) of the Regulation) on the state of the Doha Development Agenda before the tenth Ministerial Conference of the World Trade Organisation. The implementation of the Doha Agenda is perfectly consistent with the European Union's objective of ensuring the creation of new trade opportunities, promoting multilateral trade and supporting the economies of developing countries. The tenth WTO ministerial conference to be held in Kenya in December, and therefore for the first time in an African country, will focus on the fundamental issue of the development of low-income countries and so-called 'emerging' economies and the creation of an open, fair and non-discriminatory trading system. In my opinion, it is necessary to take account of the great imbalance in levels of economic development and, consequently, to take effective measures so as not to leave the developing countries behind. In this respect, it is essential to adopt indicators of economic vulnerability rather than just the GDP criterion. Finally, I would like to see a concrete commitment on the part of the European Union to bring the Doha Round to a successful conclusion.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. The successive rounds of WTO negotiations have led to the development of international trade under the umbrella of international agreements. The last round of negotiations, called the Doha Round, began in 2001 with the objectives of creating new trade opportunities, strengthening multilateral trade rules and correcting current imbalances in the trading system, placing at the heart of the negotiations the interests and needs of developing countries, and in particular the least advanced countries. In this resolution, for which I voted today, Parliament notes that it is essential to conclude the long Doha Round and insists that the EU continue to play a leading role in promoting tangible progress in the current negotiations, in order to achieve an ambitious, balanced and realistic agreement soon.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We vote against it because the report supports a market logic that does not ensure the interests of developing countries or the workers and the environment of the European Union itself. For example, it focuses on removing barriers to trade arising from the crisis, without reflecting on the causes of the crisis. Allusions to support measures for developing countries are not sufficient to counteract the overall approach: trade facilitation as an objective in itself.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution which recalls Parliament’s full commitment to the enduring value of multilateralism and calls for a trade agenda based on free and fair trade for the benefit of all, with development at the heart of the process.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report, despite its pro-growth rhetoric, essentially promotes neoliberal policies. It promotes trade liberalisation so that large multinationals can penetrate developing countries everywhere.  From world trade the only ones who have to benefit are the giants of the EU and the US, those represented by the WTO, and not the peoples and developing countries as presented in the report. Our approach is in the exact opposite direction, namely the adoption of trade rules that addressed the important issues facing humanity, those of poverty, climate change, the right to work with social rights and the fight against social inequalities.  That is why we are voting against the report.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution as it stresses the importance of taking full account in the negotiations of the special needs and interests of low-income developing countries. A structural reform of the WTO is needed in order to better guarantee an open, fair and non-discriminatory trading system which takes greater account of the role and interests of the variety of economic operators, such as SMEs, micro-enterprises and innovative start-ups.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: in writing. ‒ The INTA Committee has outlined its objectives in regards to the tenth ministerial conference of the WTO in Nairobi. One of the goals is the ratification of the Trade Facilitation Agreement, but it remains unsure whether that will be possible. Since the possibility of reaching an agreement on the Doha round appears slim, the main question is what can be delivered independently from the TFA and what role the WTO should play in case an agreement cannot be reached. Should a multilateral agreement not be reached, the resolution therefore calls for innovative thinking on certain issues, such as development for the least developed countries, the Information Technology Agreement and the environmental goods agreement. Given these two initiatives that my group and I strongly support and the general nature of the resolution, I have voted in favour of it. By the way, in my opinion the euro must be abolished. It leads to dissension and discord in Europe.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: in writing. ‒ Today’s debate, in the light of the deep controversy which both TTIP and CETA have provoked in public opinion in many of our countries, enables Socialist and Democrat MEPs to reiterate that it is far better to pursue a multilateral trade deal in the world in which developing countries can be treated as equal partners, in preference to Europe being forced to pursue bilateral trade deals in which there will always be an imbalance of power and influence over poorer countries. Ten years after the launch of the Doha Round, for the first time a WTO ministerial conference will take place in an African country. We should take this symbolic opportunity to revive the WTO, and within it recommit ourselves to central principles of fair trade and sustainable development. The WTO will only function properly if it works for all of us, and European Union representatives must ensure that developing countries are at the heart of all and any reforms to trade regulation. For all who criticise TTIP, this is surely Europe’s best response?

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a resolution on the state of the Doha Development Plan ahead of the World Trade Organisation's 10th Ministerial Conference, as it encourages the creation of new trading opportunities and the strengthening of multilateral trading rules. Furthermore, it also focuses on addressing the current imbalances in the trading system, taking into account the needs and interests of developing countries, in particular the least developed countries. Bilateral, regional and plurilateral agreements can encourage the opening of trade and economic development, so I support this proposal for a resolution and the work on all sectors mentioned there.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This text comes in preparation for the December WTO meeting in Nairobi.  The European Parliament calls for the WTO to establish global free trade that dismantles each country's standards in favour of global standards. The text proposes that the WTO should be able to address "non-trade issues". Such surrenders of sovereignty would be catastrophic since they would deprive states of the power to legislate.  It also calls for WTO agreements to be legally binding on signatory states.  I voted against it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – The Doha Development Agenda (DDA) is a series of trade-liberalisation measures – including, inter alia, tariff reductions and anti-dumping provisions – on which all World Trade Organization members are seeking binding agreement.  Strengthening the WTO in this manner is in the UK’s interest, as it bolsters international trading norms that the UK would enjoy as a fully active member on Brexit. Though the motion for a resolution supports this process and calls for greater democratic accountability in WTO decision-making, it promotes an activist role for the EU in advancing its own trade agenda through the WTO framework. On these grounds, my fellow UKIP MEPs and I voted to abstain on the resolution.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the progress of the Doha Development Agenda in relation to the 10th WTO Ministerial Conference. The European Parliament promotes the consideration of the specific interests of the least developed countries and the clarified definition of this concept. Structural reform of the WTO is now needed and Parliament calls in this resolution for substantial and balanced results for all parties at the next conference.  This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. Although there are some proposals in this report, such as the oft-repeated call for reform of the WTO, the report maintains that agreements such as TTIP and TiSA are viable avenues for fair, open and also beneficial trade areas for developing countries. That is why I am opposed to this report.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution as it reiterates Parliament’s full commitment to the enduring value of multilateralism and calls for a trade agenda based on free and fair trade for the benefit of all, with development at the centre of the process.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution concerns the state of play of the Doha development agenda. On this subject, GUE/NGL is against plurilateral agreements and trade deals such as TTIP and TISA. I advocate reforming the WTO instead of establishing new trade agreements. All GUE/NGL amendments were rejected since they are defending a multilateral and international approach. I voted against this resolution, since the resolution does not reinforce a fair trade system, neither does it implement and promote social and development rights.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – The WTO serves the interests of developed industrial countries, including multinationals, and not to catch up with the more under-developed countries involved. It's unsupvocable. In one of the Galapagos Islands, a wonderful birdlife emerged, until a boat brought in some snakes. Soon the island was full of crawlers, and by the way, the birds were gone. Then the snakes ate each other. Then all animal life died out. If we were to choose bird chirping over the sight of dead snakes, globalisation, i.e. the exploitation of cheap labour for the sake of multinationals, should be followed so that every country produces for itself what it needs, as much as possible. That is, production should be for man, not man for production. Foreign trade, and in particular international capital flows, should be kept to a minimum. To do this, technological assistance should not be lent to developing countries.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote in favour of these motions for resolutions, which see Mr Lange and Mr Zalba as rapporteurs. I believe that the timing of these measures, which are being submitted to us just a few weeks before the WTO Ministerial Conference (MC10) to be held in Kenya from 15 to 18 December, is perfect. In this respect, it is useful that these measures provide a more precise definition at European level of a low-income country and an emerging economy. This makes it possible, in practice, to redistribute effectively the tasks and interests of the various actors involved and who can benefit from the agreements made under the aegis of the WTO.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: In writing. The next WTO Ministerial Conference in Nairobi on 15-18 December, the European Parliament has spoken on the progress of the Doha Development Round. The Lange-Zalba report is a plea for global trade, making open trade the answer to the current economic slump. It repeats the usual arguments about the virtues of trade but with a tropism of "support for the least developed countries". Yet, for these countries, to bind to these multilateral agreements is to deprive themselves of all the instruments of control of production or imports that protect their farms or their nascent industries. Emerging giants, such as India, are opposed to these negotiations, while smaller countries are seeking immediate benefits that will affect their longer-term development prospects. The amendments I have supported denounce these negotiations in terms dictated by the countries of the North and instead call for a multi-lateral system of trade, based on social and environmental objectives. But for all these reasons, I obviously voted against this text.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because I am opposed to a global free trade agreement within the WTO.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The Doha Round is the negotiation of an international free trade agreement under the aegis of the WTO. Launched in 2001, it is now on a bad track, not least because India is blocking its agriculture. The purpose of the text was to prepare for the December WTO meeting (Nairobi). The European Parliament wants the WTO to fully liberalise world trade and dismantle each country's standards. In the spirit of total abandonment of national sovereignty, Brussels would even like these WTO agreements to become legally binding on states. As a result, they would no longer be able to legislate on their own foreign trade. This global free trade agreement, aimed at stifling all state protectionism, represents what I am fighting for, on a day-to-day basis, in the European Parliament and especially in the Agriculture Committee. Logically, and without any hesitation, I voted against this text.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Negotiations in Doha were launched in 2001 to find new opportunities to trade and address imbalances in the trading system, focusing on developing countries and underdeveloped countries. In order to open new markets, it is necessary to take into account the sensitivity of certain sectors, in particular agricultural sectors, the reform of which represents the contribution of the European Union to the expectations of the Doha round of negotiations. Trade liberalisation is an important tool for ensuring sustainable economic growth and development, but needs to be complemented by appropriate accompanying policies covering macroeconomic and microeconomic measures. WTO members are urged to ratify and implement the Trade Facilitation Agreement, so that it enters into force before the start of the 10th Ministerial Conference. It would bring significant benefits to developing countries in terms of increasing production capacity and a greater share of global value chains. I supported the European Parliament's resolution because I believe that a multilateral system based on fairer and fairer rules can contribute to fair and free trade.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the motion for a resolution on the current state of the Doha Development Agenda ahead of the 10th WTO Ministerial Conference, because it is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this text. The Doha Round is an ongoing negotiation for an international free trade agreement, under the aegis of the World Trade Organization (WTO). This round began in 2001, and is in a rather bad way: negotiations are slowed down by the demands of several countries. This slowdown is worrying European instructions that this programme should succeed. The European Parliament calls for even stronger global free trade and calls for the dismantling of each country's standards in favour of global standards. This further loss of sovereignty is an aberration because it would prevent Member States from legislating. We strongly oppose this European fad of all-round free trade!

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ We need a clear definition of low-income developing countries and emerging economies, and we must ensure that the principle of special and differential treatment (S&DT) constitutes an integral part of the negotiations. This has always been part of EU trade policy and we just cannot dismantle our system of preferential trade with our friends in the African, Caribbean and Pacific countries without bringing a solution to their needs. Ten years after the beginning of the Doha Round, the WTO itself is at a crossroads. It is time to accomplish structural reform, in order to better guarantee an open, fair and non-discriminatory trading system based on shared and applied rules. It should contemplate new challenges such as climate change and sustainability as well as new actors such as SMEs and innovative start-ups.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 In favour of the European Parliament resolution on the state of the Doha Development Agenda prior to the Tenth Ministerial Conference of the World Trade Organisation. Nairobi will host the 10th Ministerial Conference of the World Trade Organisation from 15 to 18 December. The Doha Round was launched with the aim of creating new trade opportunities, strengthening multilateral trade rules and addressing existing imbalances, placing the needs and interests of developing countries. These objectives stem from the idea that a multilateral system based on fairer rules can contribute to fairer and more open trade for the economic development of all continents and to reducing poverty.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 The wto member states' multilateral round of multilateral negotiations began in 2011 with a specific objective of creating new trade opportunities and, at the same time, supporting the economic growth of the least developed countries, placing their interests and needs at the heart of the negotiations. This issue is therefore particularly important and requires shared support where, as in the motion for a resolution under comment, the aim is to urge all WTO member countries to proceed with the rapid ratification and implementation of the trade facilitation agreement, so that it can enter into force in time for the tenth ministerial conference.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: In writing. On the eve of the WTO Ministerial Conference in Nairobi from 15-18 December 2015, the European Parliament voted on the progress of the Doha Development Round, which was launched in 2001 and has so far fallen far short of expectations. At the time, after years of unbridled free trade, WTO member countries had floated the idea of putting trade at the service of the development of the countries of the South. This objective, while very laudable, has nevertheless suffered from the inability of States to agree on concrete measures. The text voted by the European Parliament has taken into account the need to make a real commitment to special and differentiated treatment for developing countries (DEVELOPING countries), especially in agricultural matters, where they are clearly disadvantaged. The Lange-Zalba report also proposes to reform the functioning of the WTO, involving national parliaments more. More urgently, the text calls for better access for all Member States' parliaments to the content of the ongoing trade negotiations. Without being overly deluded about the outcome of the Nairobi conference, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. While there are some useful proposals in the report, such as the long-repeated call for reform of the WTO, it maintains the view that agreements such as TTIP and TiSA are viable. I therefore reject the report.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The Doha Round, falsely known as the Doha Development Agenda, aimed to liberalize international trade, including by promoting access to the markets of rich countries for agricultural products from developing countries (DEVELOPING countries). Although it has been considered to have failed since 2006, particularly due to rich countries, the report wants to believe in a "structural reform of the WTO to better ensure an open, fair and non-discriminatory trading system, based on common rules and applied" for the next WTO ministerial conference in Nairobi. Based on assumptions such as 'trade liberalization is an important instrument to ensure sustainable economic growth and development', I fear that these reforms will do nothing good. I am voting against this ode to free trade.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. This text is intended to prepare for the December WTO meeting in Nairobi. The European Parliament calls for the WTO to establish global free trade that dismantles each country's standards in favour of global standards. It even proposes that the WTO should be able to deal with "non-trade issues". These further surrenders of sovereignty would be dramatic since they would prevent the States themselves from legislating, especially since the text calls for WTO agreements to be legally binding on the signatory states. The Member obviously opposes this text, which continues the Union's all-round free trade policy.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the current state of the Doha Development Agenda with a view to the 10th WTO Ministerial Conference. Knowing that the Doha Round aims to create new trade opportunities, strengthen multilateral trade standards and address the current imbalances in the trading system, and given the proximity of the 10th WTO Ministerial Conference to be held in Kenya from 15 to 18 December 2015, this motion for a resolution makes perfect sense. This motion for a resolution reinforces and defends an agenda based on free and fair trade for the benefit of those whose process is focused on development and also the need for structural reform of the WTO.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to support this resolution on the Doha Development Agenda as it stresses the Union’s support for a thorough reform of the WTO, in order to better guarantee a transparent, fair and open trading system that better incorporates the full scale of participants in the global economy.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. This favourable vote gives new impetus to the Doha Development Round launched in 2001. This cycle is win/win for developing countries as well as for developed countries. It aims to create new trade opportunities, strengthen multilateral trade rules and correct current imbalances in the trading system by placing the needs and interests of developing countries, particularly those of the least developed countries (LDCs), at the centre of the negotiations. In a globalized world, prosperity can no longer be claimed if it is not shared, if millions of people live in extreme poverty.  On the eve of the 10th WTO Ministerial Conference, to be held in Nairobi from 15-18 December 2015, positioning itself for the relaunch and final conclusion of the Doha Development Round is a responsible act in the head of the European Parliament. The conclusion of this Doha Round is a vital imperative that all WTO members must put at the top of their political agenda in order to achieve an ambitious, comprehensive, balanced and realistic outcome in the very near future.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. \u2012 Doha Round aims to strengthen multilateral trade rules and thus create a favourable environment for new trade opportunities for developed but also developing and least developed countries that have been marginalised in the world trading system for a long time.  I consider it natural that the multilateral trading system should be based on fair and objective rules that contribute to the economic development of all countries, with particular regard to the specificities of developing countries, where the achievement of development objectives such as the eradication of poverty and hunger and the provision of basic health and sanitary conditions must be ensured.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ The Doha Development Agenda, with a view to the 10th WTO Ministerial Conference of the Doha Round, was launched in 2001 with the objectives of creating new trading opportunities, strengthening multilateral trade rules and addressing current imbalances in the trading system by focusing on the needs and interests of developing countries and especially of the least developed countries. This contributes to fair and free trade at the service of the economic development of all continents and the alleviation of poverty. I am in agreement with the state of play of the Doha Development Agenda with a view to the 10th WTO Ministerial Conference and that is why I have voted in favour of this report

name: Sorin MOISĂ
text: in writing. ‒ In light of the 10th WTO Ministerial Conference which will take place in Nairobi from 15 to 18 December 2015, the European Parliament stresses the importance of a trade agenda based on free and fair trade and with development at the centre of the process. The principle of special and differential treatment should continue to be an integral part of the negotiations as it recognises the special needs of low-income and least developed countries, in particular in implementing trade provisions. We call for a speedy ratification of the Trade Facilitation Agreement – the successful outcome of the 9th WTO Ministerial conference in 2013 – by all WTO members. It was the first multilateral trade agreement concluded after the establishment of the WTO in 1995 and will bring significant benefits in particular to developing country members. Finally, we also welcome the progress made so far in plurilateral negotiations such as the Environmental Goods Agreement, the Information Technology Agreement and the Trade in Services Agreement with a view to their multilateralisation once a critical mass of participants has been reached.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Committee on International Trade has proposed the adoption of a parliamentary resolution ahead of the 10th WTO Ministerial Conference in Kenya between 15 and 18 December 2015. The proposed resolution reaffirms the European Parliament's full commitment to multilateralism and free and fair trade in the interests of all parties, with development at its heart. It re-advocates the liberalisation of trade by complementing it with accompanying policies including appropriate macro- and microeconomic measures, as well as simplification of public administration, education and training, institutional reforms and social policies, in order to fully exploit the benefits of trade reforms and to better distribute them, effectively counteracting any negative effects. I supported the motion.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The European Parliament calls for the WTO to establish an even deeper global free trade and dismantle each country's standards to set global standards. It even proposes that the WTO should be able to address these non-trade issues.   These further surrenders of sovereignty would be dramatic as they would prevent states from legislating. The European Parliament welcomes sectoral free trade approaches, such as the Agreement on Environmental Goods, Information Technology, TISA (dismantling of public services). The report tries to hide the danger of such agreements by advocating a trade policy favourable to SMEs and developing countries. It calls for WTO agreements to be legally binding.   Finally, it is a classic global free trade agreement that we oppose. As our amendments were rejected, the group opposed this report.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 I advocate for trade a multilateral, regulated and stable strategy, recognising that bilateral, regional and plurilateral agreements also promote trade opening and economic development and support the multilateral system, provided they are compatible with World Trade Organisation standards.  It is essential to defend an agenda for trade based on free and fair trade for the benefit of all and whose process is focused on development. Trade liberalisation is an essential tool for ensuring sustainable economic growth and development, which should be accompanied by macro and micro-economic measures such as budgetary transparency, budgetary policies, tax equity, administrative simplification, education and training, institutional reforms and social policies. I recommend that the European Union should continue to play a leading role in achieving progress in the ongoing WTO negotiations with a view to the full completion of the Doha Round for Development in the short term, as well as ensuring the participation of less developed countries in world trade.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This resolution text on the status of the Doha agenda aims to prepare for the December WTO conference in Nairobi. As a reminder, the Doha Round is the ongoing negotiation since 2001 for an international free trade agreement under the aegis of the World Trade Organization. Fourteen years after the beginning of this round, the agreement appears to be on the wrong track, much to the chagrin of the European Union, which would like it to succeed, which is recalled in the text. Parliament calls for the extension of the cycle with a view to establishing an even more successful international free trade system, without market constraints, and the adoption of legally binding international standards while dismantling the rules imposed by nation states. The text also proposes that the WTO should be able to address "non-trade issues" so as not to "impede market access" to the detriment of states, which would mean an unprecedented surrender of sovereignty and the development of materialistic logic for areas such as health or culture. So, despite calls for more democratic transparency in trade negotiations and an agreement in favour of SMEs and developing countries, I voted against this text.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the progress of the Doha Development Agenda for the tenth WTO Ministerial Conference. Launched in 2001, the Doha Round aims to create new trade opportunities, strengthen multilateral trade rules and correct current imbalances in the trading system by placing the needs and interests of developing countries, particularly those of the least developed countries (LDCs), at the centre of the negotiations. In this text, the European Parliament reaffirms its commitment to a rules-based multilateral trading system, while recalling the importance of taking into account the sensitivity of certain sectors in terms of market opening and in particular the agricultural sector. The European Union has contributed to the Doha Round by reforming its common agricultural policy.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which comes a few weeks before the tenth WTO Ministerial Conference, to be held in Kenya from 15 to 18 December 2015, for the first time in an African country. It supports structural reform of the WTO to better ensure an open, fair and non-discriminatory trading system that takes more account of the variety of players in the economy, such as SMEs and micro-enterprises and innovation start-ups. In particular, the resolution encourages WTO members to make substantial progress in Nairobi in December to enable a speedy conclusion of the Doha Round and to ratify quickly and implement the Trade Facilitation Agreement so that it can enter into force before the ministerial conference. In addition, the resolution urges all WTO members to consider all possible options from such a perspective in order to achieve an ambitious, comprehensive, balanced and realistic outcome for the Doha development agenda.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We strongly support this resolution, which should serve to impose a change of pace on the negotiations launched within the World Trade Organisation in 2001 in Doha. This round of negotiations is particularly important because it can strengthen the multilateral system of trade relations and, at the same time, take greater account of the needs and needs of the least developed countries.  The measure has the opportunity to make the next MINISTERIAL MEETING of the WTO, to be held in Nairobi in December, an important moment to make international trade fairer and freer. The efforts that the European Union supports in international and regional for a, as well as in its agenda of bilateral negotiations, must always move towards the removal of unjustified non-tariff barriers to trade, so as to strengthen and make the multilateral system of the World Trade Organisation more efficient and authoritative.  It is our opinion, in fact, that only with a WTO reinvigorated by the forthcoming negotiations can we pursue the objectives of international trade that gives fair, inclusive and sustainable rules to globalisation, in the interests of European citizens, but also of the poorest countries in the south of the world.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. I have not been able to vote for this report, but I fully support the position of the EPP Group and the French delegation to adopt this report. It supports a balanced and resolutely multilateral approach that can only foster a North-South rapprochement.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 The main objectives of the World Trade Organisation (WTO) are to make international trade easier and to successfully integrate the economies of developing countries into world trade. The Doha Agenda adopted at the WTO Ministerial Meeting in 2001 aims to promote these core values. Without a doubt, this development agenda is still worth following. To do so, however, certain changes and multifaceted reforms are inevitable and should be a priority at the Ministerial Conference in Nairobi.  In order to achieve the objectives set out in the agenda, structural reform of the WTO and the re-categorisation of developing countries and economies are essential, but perhaps more importantly the adoption and implementation of new, functioning international conventions, not least the encouragement of Member States to bring about changes in the national economy.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this resolution that will encourage fair and free trade through increasingly just and equitable rules, with the purpose of creating economic development across the globe.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I refused to endorse the report on the state of play of the Doha Development Agenda, as it marginalises the role of the Member States in favour of the Union. Moreover, the development of the negotiations, which can be described as modest, is not being formulated drastically enough.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the report submitted.  Further efforts are needed to bring the Doha Round to a swift conclusion and to achieve ambitious results. It should be noted that the long delay in these negotiations is creating major problems. In particular, rules acceptable to all international trade should be laid down which legitimise countries' willingness to act more fairly and openly. There is a need to take greater account of the very different economic development and individual needs of developing countries. Smarter developing countries should take some responsibility already in the current round and contribute according to their level of development. Furthermore, structural reforms should be carried out within the WTO in order to better ensure an open, fair and non-discriminatory trading system based on commonly applied rules.  Opportunities need to be created not only to help weak economies in the world, but also to develop strengths. It is therefore essential that all WTO members ratify and implement the trade facilitation agreement as soon as possible.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ The Doha Development Agenda (DDA) is a series of trade-liberalisation measures – including, inter alia, tariff reductions and anti-dumping provisions – on which all World Trade Organisation members are seeking binding agreement.  Strengthening the WTO in this manner is in the UK’s interest, as it bolsters international trading norms that the UK would enjoy as a fully active member on Brexit.  Though the motion for a resolution supports this process and calls for greater democratic accountability in WTO decision making, it promotes an activist role for the EU in advancing its own trade agenda through the WTO framework.  On these grounds, UKIP MEPs voted to abstain on the resolution.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 The conduct of the Doha negotiations has proved to be very complex and, to date, the rounds have not yet been concluded. I support the importance of speeding up the negotiation process, with a view to the tenth Ministerial Conference of the World Trade Organisation to be held in Kenya from 15 to 18 December. I believe that we need to carry out a structural reform of the WTO with the aim of including the least developed countries and developing countries more in a effectively multilateral, fair and non-discriminatory trading system, based on shared and applied rules and taking greater account of SMEs, micro-enterprises and innovative start-ups. I would therefore have voted in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ Negotiations started in Doha in 2001 opened up new opportunities to strengthen multilateral trading rules and address current imbalances in the trading system. As I consider the Doha plan a positive and necessary step forward, I support the draft proposal for a resolution on the state of the Doha Development Plan ahead of the World Trade Organisation's 10th Ministerial Conference.  The most important objective was to establish a fairer and fairer trading system that would contribute to fair and free trade, while also boosting the economic development of all continents. It is now necessary, more than ever, to push for the conclusion of a long-standing round of Negotiations from Doha in order to realise its development mandate.  I believe that the European Union must continue to retain a leading position in promoting progress in the ongoing WTO negotiations, with a view to the full conclusion of the Doha round of negotiations. I support the announced structural reform of the WTO, as this reform would take into account the needs and interests of developing countries and least developed countries, but also SMEs. Also, WTO Member States should be encouraged to strengthen ties with other organisations in any way linked to global trade, whose work can affect the course of negotiations.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ In wto reform negotiations, it is important to take full account of the specific needs and interests of low-income developing countries and least developed countries. It is also necessary to clearly define low-income developing countries and emerging economies, ensure that the principle of special and different treatment is an integral part of the negotiations in order to reflect the different levels of economic development of WTO member states as set out in paragraph 44. Ministerial declarations from Doha. Significant provisions of special and different treatment should be more precise and targeted and should be periodically checked to address the needs of those developing countries and least developed countries most in need.  I join in commending the example of the Trade Facilitation Agreement on the application of the principle of special and different treatment at the implementation stages, which could be useful in reviewing and guiding the provisions of special and different treatment. In this process, the European Union should stand up for the lasting value of multilateralism and call for a trade agenda based on free and fair trade that would benefit all and focus on development at its core.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I believe it is important to fully address the specific needs and interests of less developed countries as well as to set new criteria in defining poor and developing countries, which is demonstrated as necessary for example in the case of China. I support the structural reforms of the World Trade Organisation to guarantee open, fair and non-discriminatory trade that better meets the interests of different market stakeholders such as medium, small and micro enterprises and beginner companies.  In this context, I am committed to ratifying and implementing the Trade Facilitation Agreement (TFA) as soon as possible before the Ministerial Conference (MC10). At the same time, I commend the progress made in meeting pluratelar initiatives such as the Environmental Goods Agreement (EGA), the Information Technology Agreement (ITA) and the Trade Services Agreement (TISA). I emphasize that for Croatia, the country from which I come, as a member of the WTO, the upcoming accession of Bih is very important, and I fully support it.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The Doha Round was launched in 2001 with the aim of creating new international trade opportunities. This objective stems from the fact that a multilateral system based on fairer and fairer rules can contribute to fair and free trade, economic development on all continents and poverty reduction. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because I believe in the importance of reaching a political agreement that will enable the Doha Agenda to move forward. A trade agenda based on free and fair trade for the benefit of all, which puts economic development at the heart of the process.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 The resolution sets out the objectives and objectives for the Tenth WTO Ministerial Conference to be held in Nairobi, Kenya, and hopes that the recently agreed Trade Facilitation Agreement will be ratified in sufficient countries to become WTO rules. However, the chances of reaching a final agreement on the Doha Development Round seem slim. It is considered that the differences between the different positions are still icicilable. Therefore, the issue of results that remain independent of the Trade Facilitation Agreement remains, as well as the role of the WTO in the event that a full agreement cannot be reached.  The resolution calls on all parties to reach a final agreement. The resolution proposes that a number of issues be considered in an innovative way, paying particular attention to what the WTO can achieve in terms of the development of least developed countries, as well as the Information Technology Agreement and the Environmental Goods Agreement, which are initiatives that I strongly support.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 As a champion of free trade between nations, I support the idea of reforming the World Trade Organisation (WTO). I believe that a more effective structure of this organisation and a more detailed assessment of individual economies will make it possible to better fulfil the wto's main objective. I see this in removing trade barriers, which in turn will bring economic development and lower prices for consumers.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the status of the Doha Development Agenda in the run-up to the 10th WTO Ministerial Conference in Kenya from 15-18 December 2015. This is the first time such a conference has been held in an African country. This conference highlights the objectives of emerging economies. The objectives are varied and relate to the vision of our economies, which we must see in all their diversity. SMEs and SMEs need support to ensure that trade facilitation is complete. I fully support this initiative, which must succeed in proving today that multilateralism in trade still exists.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The Doha Round negotiations, launched in 2001, aim to improve multilateral trade through standards established consensually between counterparties. Such trade policies should be deepened around two axes: the reduction of protectionist trade barriers that prevent free trade, on the one hand, and the establishment of rules governing the maintenance of barriers to trade, on the other.  Article 207 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) establishes the common commercial policy as an exclusive competence of the European Union. Accordingly, the European Commission (EC) has been exercising its mandate, putting the needs and interests of developing countries at the heart of the negotiations.
