In this context, the principle of special and differentiated treatment should be an integral part of the negotiations, ensuring the sustainable economic growth and development of the least developed countries, which are the main victims of imbalances in the trading system. Considering that negotiations have stalled since the beginning of the crisis due to differences in certain areas of legal intervention, and considering the final objective of concluding the negotiations, I voted in favour of this report calling on the EC to consider the viable options for the full conclusion of the Doha Development Round.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which details the position of our Assembly ahead of the next WTO Ministerial Conference. The Doha Round has several objectives: the creation of new trade opportunities, a strengthening of multilateral trade rules and the correction of current imbalances in the trading system, particularly concerning the needs and interests of developing countries, particularly least developed countries. It is therefore necessary to have the means to achieve these objectives. This includes a structural reform of the WTO and a trade agenda based on a multilateral system, free and fair, for the benefit of all and which places development at the centre. Common and enforced rules must also be obtained. WTO cooperation with other relevant international organizations should also be encouraged. In addition, the democratic legitimacy and transparency of the WTO must be promoted by strengthening its parliamentary dimension. The Union, the main trading power, must allow for a breakthrough in the negotiations and a balanced and realistic conclusion of this round, in line with its objectives.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. In 2001, world trade organization member countries decided to launch the Doha Round with the aim of strengthening multilateral trade rules, expanding the opportunities offered by international trade and overcoming the imbalances that currently exist, focusing on developing countries and, fundamentally, the least developed countries. The conclusions of the 10th WTO Ministerial Conference, to be held in Kenya in December 2015, will be of paramount importance. We hope that the necessary support for the entry into force of the Trade Facilitation Agreement will be gathered and WTO support renewed as a system of global trade governance. The EU must maintain its leadership in promoting the negotiations currently taking place in the WTO, especially the Doha Round, which we wish to see concluded in the near future.  The Socialists are strong advocates of multilateralism in trade regulation. We defend multilateral governance as the most effective system for governing free and equitable global trade, with effective, fair, transparent rules at the service of economic development and the fight against poverty. That is why we have supported this resolution.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. In the run-up to the 10th WTO Ministerial Conference in Kenya from 15-18 December 2015 (for the first time in an African country!), the resolution I supported stresses the importance of fully considering the special needs and interests of low-income developing countries in the negotiations, but also considers it necessary to have a clear definition of these and emerging economies. The adopted text also supports structural reform of the WTO to better ensure an open, fair and non-discriminatory trading system that takes greater account of the diversity of economic actors, such as SMEs and micro-enterprises of innovation.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which comes moments before the 10th WTO Ministerial Conference in Kenya from 15 to 18 December 2015. I fully support the need for further liberalisation of world trade, based on a multilateral system based on fairer and fairer standards, which will contribute to trade opportunities promoting the sustainable and sustained development and growth of the least developed countries, in view of the principle of special and differentiated treatment, which should underpin this type of negotiations.  That was the objective of the 2001 Doha Round, which should now be revised in order to achieve more realistically the concrete and more balanced results sought for the world economy in trade terms. I am also in favour of structural reform of the WTO in order to better ensure an open, fair and non-discriminatory trading system that is on the role and heterogeneous interests of economic actors, SMEs, micro-enterprises and start-ups. It is therefore important that all WTO members should study viable solutions to conclude the Doha Round negotiations and rapidly ratify the Trade Facilitation Agreement, which will increase legal transparency and certainty, reduce administrative costs and reduce the duration of customs formalities.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which gives the european Parliament's official position for the negotiations to be held in Nairobi from 15 to 18 December at the tenth WTO Ministerial Conference. It is important to remember that the multilateral level of trade negotiations remains a priority for the European Union and that the WTO has its full support. In this sense, it is important to take into account in the negotiations the special needs and interests of low-income developing countries as well as LDCs (least developed countries), while stressing that a clear definition of these countries must be established. We also support a reform of the WTO that allows for an open, fair and non-discriminatory trading system, as well as an ambitious, comprehensive, balanced and realistic outcome for the Doha development agenda. There is also an urgent need for the Trade Facilitation Agreement to be ratified quickly and implemented. Finally, it should be noted that our work in the parliamentary committee has made it clear in the text that certain sectors, such as agriculture, remain sensitive and must be treated differently in trade.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the state of play of the Doha Development Agenda with a view to the 10th Ministerial Conference of the World Trade Organisation, as I believe that structural reform is needed which will lead to the economic development of the WTO member countries. This reform must be based on free, fair and non-discriminatory trade, based on shared and applied rules, which takes greater account of the role and interests of a number of economic operators, such as SMEs, micro-enterprises and innovative start-ups.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We vote against it because the report supports a market logic that does not ensure the interests of developing countries or the workers and the environment of the European Union itself. For example, it focuses on removing barriers to trade arising from the crisis, without reflecting on the causes of the crisis. Allusions to support measures for developing countries are not sufficient to counteract the overall approach: trade facilitation as an objective in itself.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted against this Resolution because it maintains a logic of liberalization of international trade. Despite containing positive comments on what the Doha Development Agenda entails, it does not condemn that its spirit has been betrayed through multilateral agreements such as TCE, CETA, ATP, etc. These multilateral agreements are being hurriedly negotiated by major Western powers. It is a model that promotes the development of unequal international trade through agreements that guarantee their absolute control by large multinationals and the defense of their interests. We need trade that prepends peoples' rights to trade models that guarantee processes of economic development.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 In the motion for a resolution adopted today, the European Parliament sets out its position on reaching a final agreement on the Doha Development Agenda, with a view to the tenth WTO Ministerial Conference (World Trade Organisation) in Nairobi. This report calls on all WTO members to ratify the Trade Facilitation Agreement (TFA) quickly so that it can enter into force in time for the tenth ministerial conference.  This agreement would bring significant benefits to all WTO members and in particular to the least developed countries (LDCs), as well as to important economic operators. Increasing transparency, reducing administrative burdens and the time of customs procedures will allow SMEs companies and not just access to new export opportunities. I voted in favour of this proposal because I believe that reaching a multilateral agreement that guarantees greater liberalisation of trade worldwide is beneficial to all WTO members, including the European Union.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this as it calls for EU activism within the EU. However, strengthening the WTO is in the UK’s interest. I believe the UK should leave the EU and take up its seat at the WTO.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 The WTO continues to face numerous problems and unresolved issues, but it should be borne in mind that it is not an easy task to reconcile the interests of countries at different stages of development and with often conflicting interests. Abandoning support for farmers and agriculture, especially in areas with difficult farming conditions, would lead to depopulation of many areas and unemployment. If agricultural production and the outflow of part of the population are to be eradicated in a given area, it is much more difficult and far more costly to restore life in the region than to support local production and offer farmers additional activities. Agriculture in areas with natural, peripheral and mountain handicaps also provides important environmental and climate services. In the context of the fight against climate change, it should also be noted that the specific nature of agriculture lies in the fact that it not only emits greenhouse gases, but is also responsible for absorbing and catching huge quantities of them. We must not forget the importance of agriculture for people's daily lives and the quality of the food they eat, which are linked to their health and life and the environment that surrounds us. In the context of multilateral negotiations and the progressive liberalisation of world trade, we must not forget that agriculture is not simply one of the sectors of national economies, but a supplier of key products for our lives that are strategically sensitive goods.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ The EU has consistently advocated for a rules-based and strong, multilateral approach to trade and I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution as it recognises that complementary approaches such as bilateral, regional and multi-national agreements may foster the opening of trade and may support the multilateral system. At committee level S&D MEPs were able to achieve many of its objectives, guaranteeing a commitment to the enduring value of multilateralism and respect for special and differential treatment in the negotiations, amongst many other things. I am very pleased with the work of Bernd Lange and this is a very good text.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 In the case of the European Parliament's legislative resolution on the state of play of the Doha Development Agenda before 10 December 2012, the Commission will present a report to the European Parliament and the Council on the state of play of the Doha Development Agenda before 10 December 2012. I voted in favour of adopting this resolution by the WTO Ministerial Conference. The document presented shall, in an appropriate manner, reflect the state of play of the Doha Round. The resolution stresses the need for a clear definition of developing countries, as it is necessary to highlight the different needs and levels of economic development between low-income and least developed countries.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 10. The WTO Ministerial Conference will be held in Kenya from 15 to 18 December 2015 and will be the first WTO Ministerial Conference to be held in the African country. In the framework of the negotiations, it is important to take full account of the specific needs and interests of low-income developing countries and least developed countries. It will be important to establish a clear definition of low-income developing countries and emerging economies. I supported the motion for a resolution in which, among other things, we support structural reforms of the WTO in order to better guarantee an open, fair and non-discriminatory trading system based on common and applied rules, which takes greater account of the role and interests of various economic operators, such as small and medium-sized enterprises, micro-enterprises and innovative start-ups. The resolution points to liberalisation as an important tool for ensuring sustainable economic growth and development, although it needs to be complemented by appropriate accompanying policies involving macro- and microeconomic measures, including a transparent budget, fiscal policies, tax equality, institutional reforms and social policies, in order to maximise and better distribute the proceeds of trade reforms and to balance negative impacts more effectively.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution in which Parliament takes a position with a view to the next Ministerial Meeting of the World Trade Organisation in Kenya in December, in order to reaffirm its commitment to a multilateral trading system that fully involves and benefits the least developed countries, in line with the objectives of the Doha Agenda launched in 2001. Since for the first time such a conference is taking place in Africa, we have an important opportunity to relaunch a multilateral model of international trade, which cannot be replaced by the various bilateral or regional agreements. This is because we also want the least developed countries to have access to the benefits of a multilateral system, by participating in the governance and definition of a fair trade agenda for the benefit of all parties and focused on development. That is why we need to rethink the WTO system, so that it can work well for all Member States, not least in the light of the new challenges that global trade also faces, such as climate change and sustainability.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 We support structural reforms of the World Trade Organisation with a view to ensuring an open, transparent and anti-discrimination trading system that takes greater account of the role and interests of small and medium-sized enterprises and innovative start-ups. For this reason, I welcome the progress made on initiatives such as the Information Technology Agreement or the Services Agreement.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU was created, inter alia, to promote free trade. Free trade in the free market is probably the most important thing that can improve the overall quality of life of citizens. The EU must therefore promote the development and liberalisation of trade and the free market around the world. For this reason, I have also supported structural reform of the WTO, which will more functionally guarantee an open, fair trading system based on general rules, as well as take more rigorous account of the interests and needs of various economic operators, including SMEs, up to those starting.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I supported the motion for a resolution because I believe that trade liberalisation is an important tool for ensuring sustainable economic growth and development, but should be complemented by appropriate accompanying policies covering macroeconomic and microeconomic measures, including budget transparency, fiscal policies and uniformity of taxation, simplification of administration, education and training, institutional reforms and social policies, all with a view to maximally increasing and better distributing the benefits of trade reforms and effectively mitigating negative impacts. Aware of the values of multilateralism, I hereby call for a trade agenda based on free and fair trade that would benefit all and would be at its core focused on development.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ The Doha Round of Negotiations was launched in 2001 to create new trading opportunities, strengthen multilateral trading rules and address current imbalances in the trading system. As these objectives stem from the belief that the multilateral system is based on fairer and fairer rules, one can expect to contribute to fair and free trade in the service of economic development of all continents and poverty alleviation.  The 10th Ministerial Conference of the World Trade Organisation (MC10) to be held in Kenya will be the world trade organisation's first ministerial conference in an African country. The European Union remains firmly committed to the Doha Development Plan and acknowledges that reaching a political agreement on the progress of the Development Plan will be of great importance and thus ensure that the WTO's negotiating role remains at the heart of further trade liberalisation globally. I support this Doha Development Plan because it calls for a trade agenda based on free and fair trade. Trade liberalisation is an important tool for ensuring sustainable economic growth and development.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 This report aims to free markets from all kinds of obstacles and controls, but this will lead to disastrous results for European citizens. The WTO seeks to impose its views on every aspect of society, public administration management, tax policy, education, social policies and institutional reforms.

name: József SZÁJER
text: Writing. \u2012 This Decision was taken weeks before the 10th Ministerial WTO Conference (Kenya, 15-18 December 2015). The European Parliament attaches particular importance to taking into account the specific needs of 'low-income developing countries' (LDCs), which it considers necessary to ensure that the concepts of 'low-income developing countries' and 'growing economies' are clearly defined. This is particularly important for China, since in this sense China is still a developing country without any other further discrimination possible. The European Parliament supports structural reform of the WTO in order to better ensure an open, fair and non-discriminatory system that takes due account of the needs of different economic operators (SMEs, micro-enterprises, innovative start-ups). The Decision encourages WTO Member States to make fundamental progress in Nairobi for the proper implementation of the Doha Round and calls on WTO Member States to ratify and implement the Trade Easier Agreement (TFA) rapidly.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the state of play of the Doha Development Agenda, which calls for a system of fair and free trade in the interests of all parties.  In my opinion, too, it is important that the interests of low-income developing countries and the least developed countries be central to the negotiations. Furthermore, I welcome and endorse the proposal's recommendation to give greater attention to SMEs, micro-enterprises and innovative start-ups in order to ensure a more efficient trading system. An essential element of the motion is its call for the role of the European Parliament to be further strengthened. It is important that Parliament is continued to be closely involved in the preparation of the Ministerial Conference and that it is kept informed and consulted, if necessary, during the ministerial conference. The Ministerial Conference in Nairobi in December will be an important stage in the Doha Development Agenda, which started 14 years ago, and it is indeed essential that the round is completed by fulfilling its mandate for development.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Doha Round was launched 15 years ago, and to this day the World Trade Organisation countries are unable to find an agreement to create new trade opportunities and correct existing inequalities in the international trade system. The European Union has always been a promoter of multilateral solutions and should therefore lead the negotiations during the current negotiations.  The conclusion of negotiations on the Doha Development Agenda as soon as possible is particularly important in view of the existing, at once newer, non-tariff barriers that hinder open and fair multilateral trade. Moreover, for the first time within the WTO, particular emphasis is placed on meeting the special needs and interests of developing countries, which in a globalising world are often unable to compete with economic giants. I have therefore decided to vote in favour of the resolution and I believe that the Ministerial Conference in Nairobi in December will prove to be groundbreaking.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has always been a supporter of free trade worldwide. This was manifested by supporting the creation of the World Trade Organisation (WTO) and by the various bilateral free trade agreements with other states or multilateral states, involving other regional structures. At the same time, however, the EU is constantly campaigning to address the current imbalances of the trading system through differentiated treatment of underdeveloped countries, in order to support their development as a result of free trade and the rejection of protectionist barriers. In this respect, the EU is in favour of a WTO structural reform that guarantees an open, fair and non-discriminatory international trade system and gives privileged place to small and medium-sized enterprises. At the same time, the EU supports the importance of dispute resolution mechanisms and greater transparency in the evaluation of trade policies. Also, as a direct representative of European citizens, the European Parliament supports the development of the wTO's parliamentary dimension, designed to ensure the legitimacy of the organisation. The completion of the Doha Development Agenda at the 10th WTO Ministerial Conference can be an important step towards achieving these generous objectives. That is why I believe that the European Parliament must support this ambitious EU mandate for the next WTO Ministerial Conference.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, in particular because I fully support the idea that structural reform of the WTO is needed to better ensure an open, fair and non-discriminatory trading system, based on common and enforced rules, which takes greater account of the diversity of economic actors, such as SMEs, micro-enterprises and innovative start-ups.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The purpose of this resolution is to reiterate the EU’s commitment to the Doha Development Agenda (DDA) in view of the upcoming 10th WTO Ministerial Conference, which will take place in December 2015 in Kenya. I supported the resolution because I identify with the principles it stresses. The EU’s key objective is a multilateral approach to trade and liberalisation by opening up the market and removing restrictive measures. The resolution puts a special emphasis on the needs of low-income developing countries and least developed countries. At the same time, it brings up the interests of certain economic operators, such as SMEs and start-ups. In order to better accommodate them and to achieve an open and fair trading system, it pledges for a structural reform of the World Trade Organisation.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union's trade policy must necessarily be geared towards the growth and development of our continent, but it is desirable that all trade should be accompanied by administrative simplification, education and training and social policies, so as to take full advantage of trade reforms and offset any negative effects. In the ongoing WTO negotiations, account will also have to be taken of the particular needs and interests of low-income developing countries and least developed countries to ensure that the negotiations reflect different levels of economic development, in order to protect the interests of the citizens of the various states.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported a report highlighting the importance of free and fair trade through the creation of new trading opportunities and strengthening multilateral trading rules with a view to economic development of all continents and poverty alleviation.  I believe that the necessity to facilitate full participation in global trade, i.e. the significance of taking into account the specific needs and interests of low-income developing countries and least developed countries, is properly recognised here.  I also consider that the call for swift implementation of the Trade Facilitation Agreement is also justified, as it seeks to strengthen transparency and legal certainty and reduce administrative costs and the length of customs procedures.  While the chances of reaching a final agreement on the Doha programme by the 10th WTO Ministerial Conference are slim, I believe work should continue to be done to achieve the objectives set and implement related initiatives, such as the Green Goods Agreement and the INFORMATION Technology Agreement.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the motion for a resolution on the state of implementation of the Doha Development Agenda before the 10th WTO Ministerial Conference (2015/2632(RSP)) because I believe that we need such a trade programme based on the free movement of goods and goods, while taking into account the interests of developing countries and less developed countries, because it is precisely the needs of these countries that are the greatest. As the programme is based on impartial rules, it will contribute to fairer trade aimed at economic development and poverty eradication.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We vote against it because the report supports a market logic that does not ensure the interests of developing countries or the workers and the environment of the European Union itself. For example, it focuses on removing barriers to trade arising from the crisis, without reflecting on the causes of the crisis. Allusions to support measures for developing countries are not sufficient to counteract the overall approach: trade facilitation as an objective in itself.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I believe in the value of multilateralism for ensuring trade objectives. I call for a trade agenda based on free and fair trade for the benefit of all, which should have development at the centre of the process. I stress the importance of taking full account in the negotiations of the special needs and interests of low-income developing countries and LDCs. I also support a structural reform of the WTO, in order to better guarantee an open, fair and non-discriminatory trading system based on shared and applied rules, which takes greater account of the role and interests of a variety of economic operators, such as SMEs, micro-enterprises and innovative start-ups; Trade liberalisation is an important tool to ensure sustainable economic growth and development, but it needs to be accompanied by appropriate flanking policies encompassing macro- and micro-economic measures, including budget transparency, fiscal policies and tax equity, administrative simplification, education and training, institutional reforms and social policies, so as to maximise and distribute better the benefits of trade reforms and effectively counterbalance any negative effects.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The Doha Round is the ongoing negotiation for an international free trade agreement under the aegis of the WTO. It began in 2001 and, 14 years later, the agreement is on the wrong track, much to the chagrin of the Commission and the European Parliament, who would like it to succeed. In particular, India is blocking any agreement to defend its agriculture. The European Parliament calls for the WTO to establish an even deeper global free trade and dismantle each country's standards to set global standards. It even proposes that the WTO should be able to address these "non-trade issues". These further surrenders of sovereignty would be dramatic as they would prevent states from legislating. The European Parliament welcomes sectoral free trade approaches such as the agreement on environmental goods, information technology, TISA (dismantling of public services)... It calls for WTO agreements to be legally binding. Finally, it is a classic global free trade agreement that I oppose.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 In order to ensure the close final conclusion of the Doha Development Round and to facilitate the full participation of least developed countries in world trade, the EU should continue to play a leading role in promoting tangible progress in ongoing WTO negotiations. The Decision calls on the Commission and the Council to ensure that Parliament is continued to be closely involved in the preparation of the 10th Ministerial Conference and kept informed and consulted during the Ministerial Conference. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We vote against it because the report supports a market logic that does not ensure the interests of developing countries or the workers and the environment of the European Union itself. For example, it focuses on removing barriers to trade arising from the crisis, without reflecting on the causes of the crisis. Allusions to support measures for developing countries are not sufficient to counteract the overall approach: trade facilitation as an objective in itself.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. By this resolution, the European Parliament intends to achieve an ambitious, comprehensive, balanced and realistic outcome in the Doha Round, as well as to promote the ratification and implementation of a trade facilitation agreement which can generate very significant benefits for world trade. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of that resolution.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted against this Resolution because it maintains a logic of liberalization of international trade. Despite containing positive comments on what the Doha Development Agenda entails, it does not condemn that its spirit has been betrayed through multilateral agreements such as TCE, CETA, ATP, etc. These multilateral agreements are being hurriedly negotiated by major Western powers. It is a model that promotes the development of unequal international trade through agreements that guarantee their absolute control by large multinationals and the defense of their interests. We need trade that prepends peoples' rights to trade models that guarantee processes of economic development.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I voted for this resolution because it advocates a trade agenda based on free and fair trade for the benefit of all.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. The 10th WTO inter-ministerial meeting under the Doha Agenda will take place from 15-18 December in Nairobi. The aim of this resolution is to define the european Parliament's position before the meeting.  Unsurprisingly, this resolution is a plea for global trade, making one of the answers, if not the answer, to the current economic slump through the all-out continuation of trade liberalization that ignores the failures of previous negotiations.  Better yet, this resolution goes so far as to call on the most advanced developing countries to take their share of responsibility for economic development. My group, the GUE/NGL, has tabled amendments to denounce this hypocrisy and negotiations dictated solely by the interests of the countries of the North. Amendments, of course, were rejected. So of course I voted against it.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. The Doha Round was launched in 2001 with the aim of creating new trade opportunities, strengthening multilateral trade standards and addressing current imbalances in the trading system, putting the needs and interests of developing countries and, in particular, least developed countries (LDCs) at the heart of the negotiations. This objective stems from the conviction that a multilateral system based on fairer and fairer standards can contribute to fair and free trade for the economic development of all continents and poverty reduction, with free trade and the presentation of supposedly neutral rules, but which do not consider the deep development inequalities of countries. In this sense, this model is in the antipodes of the model we propose, based on relations of complementarities and respect for national sovereignties and their right to produce and guarantee minimum levels of self-supply.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. While there are some useful proposals in the report, such as the long-repeated call for reform of the WTO, it maintains the view that agreements such as TTIP and TiSA are viable. I therefore reject the report.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Writing. I voted against the Doha Development Agenda because, although it is right to support the current crisis countries and to ensure that indigenous people do not have to emigrate from their country, these countries should not be deprived of the sovereignty to make their own decisions. It may sound good to support these countries financially, but money must not at the same time be allowed to buy power and then have a say in the respective countries! Every country has the right to free self-determination, even if it receives financial support!

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – The WTO needs consistent structural reform that guarantees a fairer, more open and non-discriminatory multilateral trade system based on clear rules shared and applied by all members of this organisation. Common rules must take greater account of the interests of all WTO members, including developing and least developed countries. I join the majority of the EP calling for a more balanced system that takes into account the interests of all economic operators with a focus on SMEs and micro-enterprises, not just the interests of large multinational corporations. It is very important to strengthen the parliamentary dimension of the WTO through the future structural reform of the organisation because that is the only way to ensure that transparency and democratic legitimacy that is missing today. We live in a new era of global trade that is characterised by a legitimate demand by citizens to understand and pursue multilateral trade negotiations in such a way as to ensure that the interests of nations and large global corporations do not conflict with the legitimate interests of citizens from all over the world. The involvement of national parliaments and the EP in the process of negotiating and implementing trade agreements is the only way to meet legitimate citizens' demands.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The resolution sets out the objectives and tasks to be pursued by the Committee on International Trade at the 10th Ministerial Conference of the World Trade Organisation to be held in Nairobi. Priority has been given to ensuring that the Trade Facilitation Agreement resulting from the previous WTO Ministerial Conference is ratified by a number of states sufficient for its entry into force.  The agreement agreed at the 9th Conference implements the demands of the Doha Round launched in 2001 to create new trade opportunities, strengthen multilateral trade rules and correct existing inequalities in the trading system by focusing negotiations on developing countries, in particular least developed countries. I consider it important to seek to facilitate access to the international trade market for the least developed countries, which will be a real opportunity to improve their economic situation, and I see an opportunity for a positive impact that the European Union can have on reaching a final agreement. I have therefore voted in favour of the text of the proposed resolution.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I supported this resolution with my vote in favour, a few weeks before the relevant ministerial meeting in Kenya. Among other things, the text provides for the need to clarify the relevant definitions for the categorization of States into emerging economies and low-income countries. At the same time, key issues are being raised for the modernisation and impetus of these countries, for example through support for SMEs and innovation.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. In the EU and the EPP, we have supported and will continue to support multilateralism and believe that the WTO is a vital framework for defending this approach. An approach that, as agreements such as the Trade Facilitation Agreement demonstrate, seeks in particular to improve the economic situation of the least developed countries, so that they have a strong trade base on which they can grow, as achieved by countries such as China, India or Brazil. Here I think it is appropriate to stress that the Nairobi Ministerial Conference will mark a turning point in the Doha Development Agenda. Multilateralism must not only coexist with, but also be complemented by bilateral, regional and plurilateral agreements, through which market access is being liberalized around the world.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 The 10th WTO Ministerial Conference (CM10) will be held in Kenya from 15 to 18 December 2015 in Nairobi. It will be the first World Trade Organisation (WTO) Ministerial Conference ever held in an African country.  It will patent the deepening towards the liberalisation and deregulation of world trade. The crisis of capital profitability and its unprecedented degree of centralization and concentration of wealth leads it to seek new forms of exploitation, creating neocolonial rasis agreements, in which the countries of the centre dictate what the countries of the periphery should or should not do in matters such as fiscal and tax policies, administrative organization, education and training , institutional reforms and social policies, while exploiting their natural resources with irreversible environmental consequences. We voted against it.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the state of implementation of the Doha Development Agenda before the 10th WTO Ministerial Conference because I believe that this trade agreement is based on fairer and impartial rules, thus contributing to fair and fair trade aimed at the economic development of all continents and the eradication of poverty.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her It is not all good in Ecuador – we know that, and there is also a lot to criticise. But improving trade relations, that is, above all, opening up prospects – especially economic prospects – for people. Improving trade relations also means opening up new dialogue relations, opening up new opportunities for dialogue, and above all dialogues not only between the countries or economic blocs involved, but above all dialogues between people, if you like, also dialogues on the value system.  If you like, this is where the old wisdom is fulfilled: change through trade. In this respect, I have voted in favour of the motion and look forward to deepening economic relations with Ecuador. I am also pleased with the improvements that we can then achieve for human rights through this change, through this trade.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Madam President, I am delighted to see Ecuador being drawn into a regional and global network of free commerce. The more open the trade, the less you have the tendency to oligarchy, which is the natural danger in a country like that, dependent on natural resources. Free trade is particularly in the interests of small and medium firms and of consumers in a country like Ecuador. It is also – and we always seem to forget this point – mentioned as one of the primary objectives of the European Union in the Treaty of Rome. It is right up there in Article 1. We want to work towards global free trade, and yet, more than half a century on, we still have fewer free trade agreements in place with other countries than non-EU Switzerland has. The Swiss have a better deal: they can piggyback EU free-trade deals; they can go further when they think the EU is being unduly protectionist; and they are able not only to trade with their immediate neighbours on the continent but also to do what they have done and sign free-trade agreements with China. Would not that suit a country like mine far better than our current subordination?

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Rapid economic growth, social reforms, relevant investment in education and health care, all this, but not only, shows that Ecuador has intensified its efforts in recent years to enter the Western Hemisphere among the most developed and advanced countries. Ecuador's accession to this trade agreement is logical. Because, together with Colombia, Peru, Bolivia, a member of the Andes Community, Ecuador will only expand its cooperation with the European Union.  In perspective, by the way, a fourth Member State, i.e. Bolivia, could also join the agreement. Accession is also very important given how intensely in recent years, if not longer, Latin America began to focus on intensifying relations with Asian countries and, above all, with China. And the European Union does not have to stand by, he/she, support.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ A Protocol signed in 2014 allows Ecuador to accede to the EU’s trade agreement with Colombia and Peru on ratification. A provision is in force to maintain the EU’s tariff preferences for Ecuador that it previously enjoyed under the Generalised Scheme of Preferences (GSP), throughout 2016 or until such time as the protocol on accession shall be ratified. The motion for a resolution supports Ecuador’s accession to the Agreement. Though the tariff reductions contained in the Colombia-Peru Agreement would help sectors of the Ecuadorian economy access EU markets, it also contains politicised sections. Because a full assessment of the Agreement’s implications for Ecuador must be left to the actual ratification process, UKIP MEPs voted to abstain on the resolution.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – A Protocol signed in 2014 allows Ecuador to accede to the EU’s trade agreement with Colombia and Peru on ratification. A provision is in force to maintain the EU’s tariff preferences for Ecuador that it previously enjoyed under the Generalised Scheme of Preferences (GSP), throughout 2016 or until such time as the protocol on accession shall be ratified. The motion for a resolution supports Ecuador’s accession to the Agreement. Though the tariff reductions contained in the Colombia-Peru Agreement would help sectors of the Ecuadorian economy access EU markets, it also contains politicised sections. Because a full assessment of the Agreement’s implications for Ecuador must be left to the actual ratification process, UKIP MEPs voted to abstain on the resolution.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I have not been able to support Ecuador's Resolution on Ecuador's accession to the Trade Agreement concluded between the EU and its Member States and Peru and Colombia by my opposition to this free trade agreement with Peru and Colombia, with which the EU has dynamited the positive dynamics of regional integration for the peoples of the Andean Community. This agreement with Peru and Colombia for the benefit of European multinationals has been widely rejected by trade unions, social movements and human rights organizations for their negative impact on the living and working conditions of farmers and workers. Although with differences in the time limits for the implementation of trade liberalization on both sides, as the agreement with Ecuador is based on the same provisions as the free trade agreement with Peru and Colombia, I have not been able to vote in favour of the Resolution.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – I abstained on this resolution which is an accompanying resolution for a vote due to take place next year on the accession of Ecuador to the Columbia-Peru Free Trade Agreement. The resolution sets out Parliament’s demands to be addressed prior to giving consent next year.  Positive aspects of the resolution include calling on the Ecuadorian Government to combat poverty, protect indigenous tribes, cooperate on specific environmental and deforestation programmes, recognise fair trade, and further principles of democracy and human rights. It also calls for a reflection and reassessment of the current Columbia-Peru Agreement before adding Ecuador as a partner.  Despite these positive aspects and attempts by myself to amend certain paragraphs, the text that was eventually adopted included wording that called for the ‘quick and complete entry into force and implementation of the agreement’, thereby negating the call for reflection on aspects of the Agreement dealing with labour rights, sustainable development, the environment, etc. For this reason I could not support the resolution.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. In December 2014, the EU and Ecuador signed Ecuador's connection to the current free trade agreement between the EU, Colombia and Peru. This asymmetric agreement aims to make it easier for Ecuador to develop, but above all it calls on the European Commission to ensure that human, labour and environmental rights are well respected in Ecuador. The European Parliament nevertheless notes that, despite all its right-of-hommist demands to Ecuador, the government has reduced poverty by almost half in 8 years. I have objected to this text, which constitutes a new case of Union interference in the internal affairs of a sovereign state.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This agreement has beneficial and harmful components. In its favour, I note potential tariff reduction. However, yet again it seeks to politicise trade. I therefore abstained on this motion.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on Ecuador's accession to the EU-Colombia-Peru trade agreement. This accession will have significant benefits for Ecuador's exports to the EU, as it will no longer be covered by the EU's unilateral generalised system of preferences. I believe that this agreement will help to promote and diversify trade and investment in both countries of the agreement, promote economic and social development and help reduce poverty and inequality.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which welcomes this new free trade agreement while expressing the right-of-hommist paternalism that the Union still claims to exert on these Latin American countries.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I approved this resolution on Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement with Colombia and Peru as it is another decisive step towards an alliance with important countries, which share common convictions and a strong growth rate, in a region that is increasingly turning to Asia and the Pacific. With this resolution, Parliament welcomes the conclusion of the negotiations with Ecuador and recognises the significant benefits that will flow from the point of view of Ecuador's exports to the Union. This agreement will stimulate and diversify trade and investment for both sides and accelerate Ecuador's economic and social development. It also reiterates that it calls on the relevant partners to work swiftly towards the effective implementation of the proposed action plans on human rights, the environment and labour.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against this Resolution. Sectors sponsoring the free trade agreement omit that these agreements are much more than just trade agreements. They don't count on the geopolitical and economic submissions involved. They do not raise the question of the social and environmental constraints they impose. They ignore harmful impacts on employment in certain productive activities, such as agricultural activities. Little or nothing matters to them that these agreements freeze production and exporting structures based on extractivism, imposed more than 500 years ago with the arrival of the Spanish carabelas. And, by the way, they also do not recognize that these agreements are proposed in the interests of transnational capital.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. In December 2014, the EU and Ecuador signed Ecuador's connection to the current free trade agreement between the EU, Colombia and Peru. This asymmetric agreement should make it easier for Ecuador to develop. This report welcomes this free trade agreement and Parliament even calls for monitoring the banana quota produced by Ecuador, which is one of the world's largest producers.  Unfortunately, this report is still interfering in the country's policy by calling for respect for human rights, labour or the environment, but Parliament recognises a halving of poverty in 8 years in Ecuador.  I do not support this report, which welcomes this free trade agreement with a fairly strong (albeit benevolent) interference in Ecuador's domestic policy.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not agree with the positions contained in this resolution applauding Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement between the EU, Peru and Colombia. I believe that this agreement could be a serious problem for sectors that are important to us, such as agriculture and textiles, for these reasons I voted against this text.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The European Union and Ecuador conceded negotiations for Ecuador's accession to the EU-Colombia-Peru Trade Agreement on 12 December 2014. However, the ratification process is being delayed, with the risk that the administrative procedures necessary for its entry into force cannot be carried out before the current tariff preferences available to the Andean country expire. With this resolution, which I supported with my vote, Parliament expresses its wish that the Agreement should enter into force as soon as possible, with the guarantee of the safeguard provided for by the European banana industry. We recognize the progress made in Ecuador, but call for the establishment of an action plan by which Ecuador undertakes to properly implement a number of fundamental social and environmental rights, as agreed at the time with Colombia and Peru.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted for this resolution because Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement with Colombia and Peru is another decisive step forward in forming an alliance with important, like-minded and fast-growing economies in a region that is increasingly focusing on Asia and the Pacific. The European Parliament welcomes the conclusion of negotiations with Ecuador on the protocol to its accession to the Trade Agreement between the European Union, Colombia and Peru, recognising the significant benefits of this accession for Ecuador's export to the EU, especially given that it will no longer be covered by the EU's unilateral generalised system of preferences. It is important that this agreement enters into force and is implemented quickly and comprehensively, which will contribute more to the protection of citizens and the environment. This agreement will help to promote and diversify trade and investment in both countries of the Agreement, promote economic and social development and help reduce poverty and inequalities.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒I support this Statement on Ecuador's accession to the EU-Colombia-Peru Trade Agreement. This Agreement will stimulate and expand trade and investment on both sides of the Signatories of the Agreement. I also call for the implementation of the Action Plan on Social and Environmental Rights in line with those already agreed.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. In December 2014, the EU and Ecuador signed the South American country's affiliation to the current free trade agreement between the EU, Colombia and Peru. This asymmetric agreement is supposed to promote Ecuador's development. The report calls on the Commission to ensure that human rights are respected in Ecuador. In addition, the European Parliament is calling for banana quotas to be respected as Ecuador is one of the world's largest producers. The European institutions are taking advantage of this agreement to interfere in Ecuador's internal affairs. This interference is unbearable as their government has managed to halve poverty within eight years. Finally, we can only be opposed to this report, which welcomes a free trade agreement. That is why I voted against it.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that strong trade is one in which product diversity and the number of members is constantly increasing, in a centralised market where the rules applied enjoy transparency and fairness. Such trade has been taken by Ecuador's accession to the Trade Agreement with Colombia and Peru, and there is still decisive progress in allying with important countries that share the same vision and are experiencing rapid development in a region that is increasingly oriented towards Asia and the Pacific region. The Ecuadorian government has had numerous developments in recent years in all sectors, from the protection of vulnerable social classes by strengthening human and workers' rights to environmental rights, in the context of Ecuador hosting the largest concentration of species in world biodiversity. Ecuador has also seen economic growth, coupled, of course, with a drop in poverty levels, and ratified some ILO conventions.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution welcomes Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement already in force between the EU, Peru and Colombia, to which our delegation voted against. Countries such as these can be a problem for certain productive sectors such as agriculture and textiles. Similarly, you do not perceive offensive commercial interests for companies in the Italian system. In general, our delegation has a very sceptical attitude towards a European Commission which, under the Treaties, now negotiates exclusively every trade agreement. In this case, then, we are faced with countries that use these agreements as if they were instruments for development aid. The Northern League is opposed to the use of international trade to promote the development of others. Others, in our opinion, are the right tools.  The costs of development promoted through free trade agreements will always be paid by European small and medium-sized enterprises – perhaps those of the southern European states – open to unreserved competition from products from the rest of the world. I am voting against.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The European Union concluded a free trade agreement with Peru and Colombia in 2012. Negotiations with Ecuador had been suspended. At Ecuador's request, negotiations have restarted and now Ecuador is able to be part of the same agreement. It is important for the commercial development of a country like Ecuador to benefit from a free trade agreement with the European Union. In this way, the country will benefit from many advantages, notably from the point of view of exports to the Union. This agreement takes into account the sensitivity of the agricultural sector. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement concluded between the EU and its Member States and Colombia and Peru. I think it is very important to forge ever stronger alliances with fast-growing, open-minded countries and regions with excellent prospects for economic expansion. Ecuador is one of these realities, having invested over US$40 billion in the social sector in recent years, to improve access to education, health care and social security for even the weakest sections of the population. The proposal presented today will bring important benefits for Ecuador's exports to the EU, ensuring the increase and diversification of trade and investment for both sides. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote for your acceptance.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this resolution which is an accompanying resolution for a vote due to take place next year on the accession of Ecuador to the Columbia-Peru Free Trade Agreement. The resolution sets out Parliament’s demands to be addressed prior to giving consent next year.  Positive aspects of the resolution include calling on the Ecuadorian Government to combat poverty, protect indigenous tribes, cooperate on specific environmental and deforestation programmes, recognise fair trade, and further principles of democracy and human rights. It also calls for a reflection and reassessment of the current Columbia-Peru Agreement before adding Ecuador as a partner. Despite these positive aspects and attempts by myself to amend certain paragraphs, the text that was eventually adopted included wording that called for the ‘quick and complete entry into force and implementation of the agreement’, thereby negating the call for reflection on aspects of the Agreement dealing with labour rights, sustainable development, the environment, etc. For this reason I could not support the resolution.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ A protocol signed in 2014 allows Ecuador to accede to the EU’s trade agreement with Colombia and Peru on ratification. A provision is in force to maintain the EU’s tariff preferences for Ecuador that it previously enjoyed under the Generalised Scheme of Preferences (GSP), throughout 2016 or until such time as the protocol on accession shall be ratified. The motion for a resolution supports Ecuador’s accession to the Agreement. Though the tariff reductions contained in the Colombia-Peru Agreement would help sectors of the Ecuadorian economy access EU markets, it also contains politicised sections. Because a full assessment of the Agreement’s implications for Ecuador must be left to the actual ratification process, UKIP MEPs voted to abstain on the resolution.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I welcome the negotiations with Ecuador for its accession to the Trade Agreement between the EU, Colombia and Peru, which I believe will be beneficial to Ecuador’s export markets.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement concluded between the EU and its Member States and Colombia and Peru for a number of reasons, including the call for safeguard clauses to be included simultaneously established by both parties, in order to protect domestic production against excessive imports that can cause serious harm. Given that safeguarding the future of our planet is a common responsibility, the text calls on the EEAS and the European Commission to support the Ecuadorean Government in its efforts to develop and support effective environmental management both in general and in sensitive areas such as the Amazon and the Galapagos Islands.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 It is noted that apart from Colombia and Peru, Ecuador is one of the largest banana producers in the world. The Commission is therefore requested to ensure fair compliance with import activation volumes. The Commission is invited to use the possibility of suspending the duty exemption for bananas imported from these countries. DG Trade and the Government of Ecuador are asked to provide convincing answers to the questions and concerns raised before the vote on Ecuador's accession to the free trade agreement. Under these conditions we support it positively.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure. Parliament welcomed the conclusion of negotiations with Ecuador on the protocol for its accession to the trade agreement between the EU, Colombia and Peru, recognising the important benefits this will bring for Ecuador's exports to the EU. Over the past eight years, Ecuador has experienced solid and inclusive economic growth; this result was achieved by investing US$40.8 billion in the social sector – in access to education, health care and social security – with specific programmes for the most vulnerable groups such as children, the elderly and the disabled. Accession is a further decisive step forward in the alliance with important, similar-minded and fast-growing countries and regions in a region increasingly oriented towards Asia and the Pacific.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ A protocol signed in 2014 allows Ecuador to accede to the EU’s trade agreement with Colombia and Peru on ratification. A provision is in force to maintain the EU’s tariff preferences for Ecuador that it previously enjoyed under the Generalised Scheme of Preferences (GSP), throughout 2016 or until such time as the protocol on accession shall be ratified. The motion for a resolution supports Ecuador’s accession to the Agreement. Though the tariff reductions contained in the Colombia-Peru agreement would help sectors of the Ecuadorian economy access EU markets, it also contains politicised sections. Because a full assessment of the Agreement’s implications for Ecuador must be left to the actual ratification process, UKIP MEPs voted to abstain on the resolution.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I express my full support for ecuador's inclusion in the trade treaty already in force between Europe, Colombia and Peru. This is the extension of a free trade agreement aimed at facilitating trade and investment in the industrial, agricultural and fisheries sectors. The accession of Ecuador represents an opportunity to extend and strengthen trade and economic relations between the European Union and Latin America.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ In June 2012 the EU signed an ambitious and comprehensive Trade Agreement with Colombia and Peru. Once fully implemented, it will open up markets as well as increase the stability and predictability of the trading environment. The EU needs to ensure the establishment of a transparent and binding roadmap on human, environmental and labour rights, and that the Colombian and Peruvian governments are requested to report on the implementation of action plans on sustainable development prior to the consent given by this Parliament. The Commission should inform Parliament about its developments and should submit a report focusing on the implementation of the action plans by the governments and the accompanying measures taken.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I have not been able to support Ecuador's Resolution on Ecuador's accession to the Trade Agreement concluded between the EU and its Member States and Peru and Colombia by my opposition to this free trade agreement with Peru and Colombia, with which the EU has dynamited the positive dynamics of regional integration for the peoples of the Andean Community. This agreement with Peru and Colombia for the benefit of European multinationals has been widely rejected by trade unions, social movements and human rights organizations for their negative impact on the living and working conditions of farmers and workers. Although with differences in the time limits for the implementation of trade liberalization on both sides, as the agreement with Ecuador is based on the same provisions as the free trade agreement with Peru and Colombia, I have not been able to vote in favour of the Resolution.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution deals with the accession of Ecuador to the EU-Peru and Colombia trade agreement. EU trade negotiations with the Andean Community (Bolivia, Columbia, Ecuador and Peru) started in 2007. The agreement with Peru and Colombia was concluded in 2012. As the Council considered this to be a ʽmixed agreementʼ, it needs also to be ratified by all EU Member States; this process is currently ongoing. This would be another decisive step forward in the alliance with important, fast-growing countries. I welcome this agreement, which will boost and diversify trade and investment on both sides. By voting in favour of this report I also supported the call for an action plan on social and environment rights in line with those already agreed.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ The principle of developing trade relations between the EU and the Andean Community, which is one of the fastest growing markets for EU businesses in Latin America, is something I support. I also believe that the accession of Ecuador to the free trade agreement with Columbia and Peru will be mutually beneficial for all states involved.

name: Ian DUNCAN
text: in writing. ‒ The ECR Group and I have been very supportive of the accession of Ecuador to this trade agreement and, in general, of the further development of trade relations between the EU and the Andean Community, which is one of the fastest growing markets for EU businesses in Latin America.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution on Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement concluded between the EU and its Member States and Colombia and Peru. The resolution is comprehensive – on the one hand it draws attention to the current economic and social situation in the country, especially the strong economic growth in recent years and the significant reduction of poverty, and on the other it criticises environmental issues such as deforestation and indigenous issues. The European Union needs to develop its trade relations with emerging regions such as Latin America, as this will provide many opportunities for mutual investment and fully contribute to the economic growth of both regions.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We are voting against, because such agreements, which also put Ecuador in the World Trade System, automatically weaken its position and also turn that state into dependent on the policy of the International Capital.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: in writing. – A protocol signed in 2014 allows Ecuador to accede to the EU’s trade agreement with Colombia and Peru on ratification. A provision is in force to maintain the EU’s tariff preferences for Ecuador that it previously enjoyed under the Generalised Scheme of Preferences (GSP), throughout 2016 or until such time as the protocol on accession shall be ratified. The motion for a resolution supports Ecuador’s accession to the Agreement. Though the tariff reductions contained in the Colombia-Peru Agreement would help sectors of the Ecuadorian economy access EU markets, it also contains politicised sections. Because a full assessment of the Agreement’s implications for Ecuador must be left to the actual ratification process, UKIP MEPs voted to abstain on the resolution.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. The European Parliament called on the Andean countries to ensure that a transparent and binding roadmap on human, environmental and labour rights be put in place and for the Colombian and Peruvian governments to present action plans for sustainable development before Parliament gives its consent.  The Government of Ecuador has invested US$40.8 billion in the social sector over the past eight years - in access to education, health care and social security - with specific programs for the most vulnerable groups, such as children, the elderly and people with disabilities. I therefore consider very positive the conclusion of negotiations with Ecuador on the Protocol with a view to its accession to the TRADE Agreement between the EU, Colombia and Peru, recognising the important benefits this will entail for Ecuador's exports to the EU, especially given that the country no longer benefits from the EU's unilateral system of generalised preferences. I voted in favour.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I abstained on this deliberation because it is part of a programmed free trade policy.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution deals with Ecuador's agreement to the Trade Agreement concluded with Colombia and Peru. It is considered that this could allow Ecuador to benefit from better disposal of its main exports to the EU, such as fishing, bananas, cut flowers, coffee, cocoa, fruit and nuts. The reference made to the policies pursued by the Ecuadorian government is positively noted: "for having invested more than US$40 billion in the social sector over the last eight years"; and encouraging him to continue "with his progressive policy of social and sustainable development". Support is reaffirmed "for all measures ... to combat poverty, inequalities, all forms of violence", as well as measures "aimed at ensuring the effective protection of the rights of workers and the most vulnerable people and groups, such as children, women, minorities and indigenous peoples, in order to achieve social and economic development". None of this erases the unjust blackmail process that Ecuador has been subjected to by the EU to sign this agreement, which it has resisted for several years. Blackmail that included, among other things, the suppression of the system of generalised tariff preferences enjoyed by this country.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament should be made aware of the implementation of action plans by governments and the accompanying measures adopted by the European Commission through cooperation programmes, in particular in relation to education, training, regulatory cooperation and the creation of socio-economic opportunities for the most disadvantaged sections of society, and with support for progress in the areas of democracy, respect for human and workers' rights and the protection of the environment. It is important for Ecuador to take similar measures to Colombia and Peru in the area of labour rights and the environment. However, when adopting these reforms, the protection and preservation of indigenous and local communities that embody the traditional way of life and their importance for the conservation and sustainable use of biological diversity must not be forgotten.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 We are voting against this agreement not because the country in question is a problem for certain productive sectors of our country but because, in general, we are opposed to the line of a European Commission which, under the Treaties, now exclusively negotiates any trade agreement.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I support the accession of Ecuador to the Trade Agreement with Colombia and Peru, as it will open up markets and increase the stability and predictability of the trading environment. The accession of Ecuador to the Trade Agreement with Colombia and Peru is another decisive step forward in the alliance with important, like-minded, and fast-growing countries and regions. I would like to call for a prompt implementation of the Free Trade Agreement with Ecuador, as it will contribute to reinforcing the social development model of the country, ensuring the necessary respective safeguard structures, the elimination of inequalities and the protection of workers, peasants and the environment. The Agreement will provide improved access to the Ecuadorian market for many key EU exports, for example in the automotive sector or for alcoholic beverages. However, the Agreement will not only secure access to markets; more importantly it will also create a stable and predictable environment that will help boost and diversify trade and investment on both sides.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the fact that Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement with Colombia and Peru is another decisive step towards an alliance with like-minded, important and rapidly developing countries in a region that is increasingly turning to Asia-Pacific. It is also to be welcomed that the Ecuadorean Government has invested $40.8 billion in the social sector over the last eight years, including in access to education, health care and social security, through specific programmes targeting the most vulnerable groups, such as children, the elderly and people with disabilities. Against this background, I consider it important to urge the Ecuadorean Government to take similar measures on the basis of the action plans submitted by Colombia and Peru, as this provides an opportunity to improve the general living conditions of citizens, including human and labour rights and the environment.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Ecuador's accession to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and Colombia and Peru represents an important step in the alliance with important countries characterized by their rapid growth. With the conclusion of the negotiations, Ecuador will be able to increase its exports to the European Union, resulting in greater growth in the country's economy which must bring greater well-being to the citizens of Ecuador.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. This is another step towards intensifying future cooperation with fast-growing countries. The agreement can also expand direct investment and trade volumes.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the accession of Ecuador to the EU-Peru and Colombia Trade Agreement given that the accession of Ecuador to the Trade Agreement with Colombia and Peru would be a step forward in the alliance with fast-growing countries in a region that is turning more and more to Asia and the Pacific. I ask that both the Directorate-General for Trade and the Ecuadorian Government provide convincing answers to the questions and concerns raised, before Parliament votes on Ecuador’s accession to the trade agreement.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. ‒ The accession of Ecuador to the Trade Agreement between the EU, Columbia and Peru will boost trade and investment and will be an important driver for economic and social development in Ecuador. I therefore supported this resolution that will encourage a swift entry into force and implementation of this Agreement.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against this Resolution. Sectors sponsoring the free trade agreement omit that these agreements are much more than just trade agreements. They don't count on the geopolitical and economic submissions involved. They do not raise the question of the social and environmental constraints they impose. They ignore harmful impacts on employment in certain productive activities, such as agricultural activities. Little or nothing matters to them that these agreements freeze production and exporting structures based on extractivism, imposed more than 500 years ago with the arrival of the Spanish carabelas. And, by the way, they also do not recognize that these agreements are proposed in the interests of transnational capital.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Agreement which will boost and diversify investment and trade between both the EU and Peru and Colombia. I also support the calls for an action plan on social and environmental rights in line with those already agreed.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that the accession of Ecuador to the trade agreement with Colombia and Peru would be another decisive step forward in the alliance with important, like-minded and fast-growing countries in the region.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as the accession of Ecuador to the trade agreement with Colombia and Peru would be another decisive step forward in the alliance with important like-minded and fast-growing countries in a region that is turning more and more to Asia and the Pacific. The accession of Ecuador to the EU-Peru and Colombia Trade Agreement matches the ambitions of both the EU and Ecuador. The Ecuadorian Government has invested USD 40.8 billion in the social sector in areas such as education, healthcare and social security over the past eight years, with specific programmes targeted at assisting the most vulnerable groups such as children, the elderly and the disabled.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's resolution on Ecuador's accession to the Trade Agreement concluded between the EU and its members and Colombia and Peru on the basis that it strengthens the EU's cooperation with andean countries, thereby contributing to ecuador's export activities to the EU. It is important that the Agreement ensures and promotes respect for human rights and democratic principles and that the Ecuadorian authorities establish an enhanced dialogue with civil society. I also think it is extremely positive that contracting parties undertake, inter alia, to preserve biodiversity and to encourage environmental programmes, and therefore I support this Report.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – A Protocol signed in 2014 allows Ecuador to accede to the EU’s trade agreement with Colombia and Peru on ratification. A provision is in force to maintain the EU’s tariff preferences for Ecuador that it previously enjoyed under the Generalised Scheme of Preferences (GSP), throughout 2016 or until such time as the protocol on accession shall be ratified. The motion for a resolution supports Ecuador’s accession to the Agreement. Though the tariff reductions contained in the Colombia-Peru Agreement would help sectors of the Ecuadorian economy access EU markets, it also contains politicised sections. Because a full assessment of the Agreement’s implications for Ecuador must be left to the actual ratification process, my fellow UKIP MEP colleagues and I voted to abstain on the resolution.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement between the European Union and Peru and Colombia. Ecuador's policies are in line with its WTO commitments and integrate stakeholders in a transparent manner. Parliament therefore encourages the agreement to enter into force quickly, while recommending that the Ecuadorian government take measures, including on labour law and the environment. This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. In principle, there is nothing against free trade agreements, but between countries with completely different economic strengths, they must be viewed critically, as they can often harm the small, local economic landscape in the less developed country and increase dependence on the more developed trading partner. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Afzal KHAN
