text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, as it encourages a quick and complete entry into force and implementation of this agreement, which will boost and diversify trade and investment on both sides and act as an important driver for economic and social development in Ecuador.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the conclusion of negotiations with Ecuador for its accession to the Trade Agreement between the EU, Columbia and Peru. This trade agreement will of course benefit Ecuador both on its exports and imports. The EU will have to ensure the effective application of the trade agreement. However, I cannot fully support this motion for a resolution, since the measures for cooperation in education, fair trade, sustainable development, training and creating socioeconomic opportunities are not enough. Therefore, I voted abstention.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – I cannot support the EU's trade policy with developing countries, as there is clear evidence that, in addition to liberalised trade and capital flows, less developed countries cannot catch up. The motion for a resolution is on Ecuador's accession to the EU trade agreement previously concluded with Peru and Colombia. Peeling off the packaging is clearly the responsibility of the Ecuadorean Government to ensure without delay the removal of the existing barriers to access to its market. Such agreements unilaterally serve the interests of multinationals, thereby making under-developed countries more at their service than before. For this reason, the resolution should be rejected, but I cannot overruly the decision of a sovereign country, so abstention remains.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I am in favour of the motion proposed by Mr Scholz. I believe that Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement with Colombia and Peru is another decisive step forward in the alliance with important countries. The Ecuadorian Government's efforts to invest as much as $40.8 billion to improve its welfare and social policies, as well as the ratification of ILO Convention No 169 on ethnic minorities, are also to be welcomed. All this to demonstrate the will of these countries to associate economic growth with social progress that brings them closer to European standards.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because it welcomes this free trade agreement to prepare us for the TAFTA. In addition, it interferes in the name of human rights in Ecuador's domestic policy.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the expansion of free trade, but if we are dealing with trade, a simple agreement to lift trade barriers between two or more states is enough.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Ecuador's approach to the EU-Colombia-Peru Trade Agreement represents a positive impact on the expansion of trade and investment. It also contributes to alleviation of poverty and reducing inequalities. The Government of Ecuador has been urged to implement action plans to ensure the rights of citizens, especially women and children, are protected.  Ecuador has seen economic growth in recent years. This is supported by the fact that the Government has invested more than $40 billion in the social sector over the past 8 years, and that poverty has decreased. Along with Colombia and Peru, Ecuador is one of the world's leading banana producers. The importance of the Joint Subcommittee on Trade and Sustainable Development, as the only mechanism envisaged to monitor the implementation of sustainable development commitments, was underlined. I supported Ecuador's accession to the Agreement because I think it will have a positive impact on economic growth and the continuation of a better social policy.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. – Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement will contribute to increasing trade and investment on both sides. Increased, transparent and fair trade is an important stimulus for economic and social development, contributing to poverty alleviation and the elimination of inequality.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the motion for a resolution on Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement concluded between the EU and its Member States, on the one hand, and Colombia and Peru, on the other, because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this membership. Under the guise of a trade agreement, it is in fact interference by the European Commission in Ecuador's affairs. This agreement, which is totally asymmetrical, makes it easier for Ecuador to develop, but allows the Commission to ensure that human, labour and environmental rights are respected. This interference in the affairs of a country is intolerable, and we cannot endorse these actions.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this resolution which draws attention to the EU objective of including a binding trade and sustainable development chapter in all trade agreements concluded with both industrialised and non-industrialised partners. It supports, in this connection, the inclusion in the trade agreement between the EU and Ecuador of a sustainable development chapter reflecting the partners’ common commitment to promoting respect for, compliance with, and full and proper enforcement of international human rights agreements, ILO Conventions and key multilateral environmental agreements such as the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES).

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 In favour of concluding negotiations with Ecuador on the protocol for its accession to the trade agreement between the EU, Colombia and Peru. This agreement will bring new market opportunities and benefits to Ecuador's main export industries to the EU, in view of the fact that the EU has in turn opened up its market to imports from Peru and Colombia, committing itself to immediately liberalising industrial and fisheries products.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 Negotiations between the EU and Ecuador for its accession to the EU-Colombia/Peru trade agreement were concluded on 17 July 2014. In view of the many economic benefits that the conclusion of the negotiations will bring for Ecuador's exports to the EU, I believe that I must support, by voting in favour, Mr Caspary's motion for a resolution, which aims to encourage the rapid and complete entry into force and implementation of this agreement. It will ensure the protection of citizens and the environment at the highest level and the increase and diversification of trade and investment on both sides.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: In writing. In voting on the Scholz report, the European Parliament was called upon to give its directives on Ecuador's accession process to the EU- Peru-Colombia trade agreement. The final text gives demanding support to the approach of the European Commission and the Ecuadorian government, which, however, will have to step up their efforts if they are to achieve ratification of the agreement. For the European Commission, it will be a question of finding a good balance between a resolutely protective approach for small Ecuadorian farmers and an approach that is not unfavourable to European banana producers (particularly in overseas territories). The Ecuadorian government, for its part, is called on, before the ratification of the agreement, to put in place convincing measures in the fight against child labour, against deforestation and for the respect of trade union rights. These are essential prerequisites for the signing of a trade agreement with the Union. If I voted in favour of this resolution, I wish to remain vigilant. I do not rule out abstaining from voting on the final agreement if it does not take into account the european Parliament's concerns.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. In 2012, the European Union and its member states signed a trade agreement with Colombia and Peru. This agreement covers both trade and development issues to ensure a stable environment for sustainable trade. The accession to this agreement by Ecuador, an important partner of the Union, will facilitate cooperation between these three countries and the European Union. Ecuador shares common values and promising growth dynamics with Peru and Colombia. This accession is therefore a decisive step for the regional integration of the Latin American sub-region.  I welcome the vote in favour of this resolution. This is a strong signal from Parliament to encourage the four partners to move forward to strengthen competitiveness and access to the markets of small and medium-sized enterprises in these three countries and those of the Union. The agreement will stimulate and diversify trade and investment for the benefit of the four parties. This is an important step in accelerating the economic and social development of Ecuador and its two neighbours.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The report welcomes Ecuador's accession to the ongoing eu-trade agreement between Colombia and Peru. It should be remembered that this agreement, concluded in 2012, aims to establish a free trade area with the Union and the South American countries concerned. To this end, it provides for the abolition of tariffs and prohibits any future protectionism: "No party adopts or maintains prohibitions or restrictions on the importation of goods from another party or bans or restrictions on the export, or export, of goods destined for another party."  In this context, the priority objective, enshrined in the Ecuadorian constitution, for the development of fair trade, can be questioned by the Union. Moreover, in a completely neo-colonial attitude, the report welcomes "the significant efforts made by Ecuador in the environment" even though Ecuador is more committed to the defence of the environment than all the states of the European Union. I am voting against this text.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on Ecuador's membership of the Trade Agreement concluded between the EU and its Member States and Colombia and Peru. It is extremely important for the EU to strengthen its trade relationship with Colombia, Peru and now With Ecuador. We must not forget that this region of the world is increasingly turning to Asia and the Pacific. It is to be commendable for ecuador's efforts, including the investment of US$40.8 billion in the social sector over the last eight years. It will also be important for the Government of Ecuador to take note of the action plans presented by Colombia and Peru to adopt similar measures. This is an opportunity for Ecuador to improve the living conditions of its citizens in terms of human, labour and environmental rights.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because Ecuador should be entitled to benefit from the full range of agreements and associations that the other countries in the region are a part of.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report since I am in agreement with the accession of Ecuador to the EU-Peru and Columbia Trade Agreement. EU trade negotiations with the Andean Community (Bolivia, Columbia, Ecuador and Peru) started in 2007. Peru/Colombia was concluded in 2012. As the Council considered this to be a ‘mixed agreement’, it needs also to be ratified by all EU Member States and this process is currently ongoing. Negotiations with Ecuador were concluded in July 2014 to join the EU multi-party Free Trade Agreement with Peru/Colombia. The Agreement was initialled on 12 December 2014. Although no longer a GSP+ beneficiary country as of 1 January 2015, Ecuador enjoys temporarily current tariff treatment on a reciprocal basis following the adoption of the Tariff Stand-still Regulation at the end of 2014 by Parliament and the Council until the EU-Peru/Colombia Free Trade Agreement applies also to Ecuador according to the terms negotiated for its accession.

name: Sorin MOISĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The accession of Ecuador to the EU-Colombia and Peru FTA represents an important step in strengthening EU trade relations with the Andean Community and more generally with Latin America. The Agreement is expected to boost trade and investment in both sides. More importantly, it will contribute to alleviating poverty and reducing inequality in Ecuador. I highlight in particular the inclusion of trade and sustainable development provisions which will promote compliance and enforcement of the relevant ILO and environmental conventions in the three countries.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU concluded trade agreements with Colombia and Peru on 17 July 2014. Ecuador, which wished to join the Agreement, successfully concluded the negotiations on this and corked the Protocol allowing Ecuador to establish preferential trade relations with the EU by joining neighbouring Colombia and Peru on 12 December 2014. The Committee on International Trade has proposed the adoption of a parliamentary resolution welcoming the conclusion of the negotiations, highlighting in particular the $40.8 billion invested by the Ecuadorean Government in the social sector over the past eight years, which has launched specific programmes for the most vulnerable groups, such as children, the elderly and people with disabilities.  It commends the strong growth of the Ecuadorian economy over the past few years and the fact that it has directly reduced poverty, especially extreme forms of poverty, and inequality, and has increased the middle class. (According to the latest World Bank data, between 2006 and 2014, poverty in Ecuador fell from 37.6% to 22.5% and extreme poverty fell from 16.9% to 7.7%.) I supported the proposal.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. In December 2014, the European Union and Ecuador signed Ecuador's connection to the current free trade agreement between the European Union, Colombia and Peru. This asymmetric agreement should make it easier for the country to develop. This report is a request to the Commission to ensure that human, labour and environmental concerns are well respected in Ecuador. The free trade agreement is expected to enter into force in 2016. We abstain on this text which welcomes this free trade agreement which is more of a strong enough interference in Ecuador's domestic policy.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 I would like to support the conclusion of negotiations with Ecuador with the aim of joining the EU, Colombia and Peru, will bring significant benefits to Ecuador's exports to the European Union, especially given that the country no longer benefits from the EU's unilateral system of generalized preferences. It is important to stress that the conclusion of this Agreement will enhance and diversify trade and investment on both sides and will act as an important driver for economic and social development in Ecuador, helping to alleviate poverty and reduce inequalities. However, I warn that Ecuador, like Colombia and Peru, is one of the world's leading banana producers and, therefore, it is imperative that the Commission controls and ensures that the import volumes provided for in the stabilisation mechanism for bananas are respected. I would argue that, in the event that imports increase anomalously, the Commission should suspend the exemption from customs duties enjoyed by bananas imported from these countries so as not to cause serious damage to the economies of the producing regions of the European Union, such as Madeira.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement between the European Union and Peru and Colombia. The aim is to allow the country to join its neighbours, Colombia and Peru, in their preferential trade relationship with the Union.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome this motion for a resolution which has become necessary following the conclusion of negotiations with Ecuador on the protocol for its accession to the trade agreement between the EU, Colombia and Peru. Ecuador's accession to this plurilateral agreement is a further decisive step forward in the alliance with important, fast-growing countries and regions in a region that is increasingly oriented towards Asia and the Pacific. In addition, this agreement will increase and diversify trade and investment on both sides, act as an important factor for economic and social development and help alleviate poverty and reduce inequalities.  In this respect, however, the establishment of a transparent and binding roadmap for human, environmental and labour rights is of fundamental importance. Finally, there is still a question of the coherence of Ecuador's policies with its wto commitments and trade agreements, with regard to full transparency, consultations with civil society and barriers to market access.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 Ecuador's accession to the existing trade agreement between EU Member States and Colombia and Peru could make many positive changes for all parties. Peru and the Union need to grow their markets, especially in terms of exports. And this kind of expansion stimulates trade, which is the basis for social and economic development. However, we know that serious human rights violations often take place in the countries mentioned above. As the protection of human rights and democracy is one of the EU's priorities, these principles should also be emphasised in our relations with the Andean countries. Only in this way can we ensure a level playing field for all in this convention.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this resolution that enhanced the Protocol on Ecuador’s accession to the Trade Agreement between the EU, Colombia and Peru. Ecuador’s exports to the EU will benefit both parties involved as this will ensure progressive social development, as well as transparency and sustainable development of policies.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. In principle, I do not see any problems in Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement that already exists with Peru. Nevertheless, I do not have clear demands in the area of human rights and better environmental protection. That is why I abstained.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the report on Ecuador's accession to the EU-Colombia-Peru trade agreement. This is a very important and decisive step forward in forming an alliance with important fast-growing economies.  This agreement is essential for the economic development of both partners. It will help to promote and diversify trade and investment in both countries of the Agreement and to support democratic development and economic and social progress.  It will also help to attract more European investment, which will promote economic and social development in the long term and help reduce poverty and inequality. In order to develop a serious political dialogue and to expand effective sectoral dialogue, Ecuador must ensure consistency of its policies with the WTO and immediately remove the remaining identified barriers to market access. Transparent and binding action plans on human rights, the environment and workers' rights must be developed and they are well implemented.  In order for the effective implementation of the Agreement, it is essential that all provisions of the Agreement are effectively implemented from the date of entry into force of the Agreement.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ A Protocol signed in 2014 allows Ecuador to accede to the EU’s Trade Agreement with Colombia and Peru on ratification. A provision is in force to maintain the EU’s tariff preferences for Ecuador that it previously enjoyed under the Generalised Scheme of Preferences (GSP), throughout 2016 or until such time as the protocol on accession shall be ratified. The motion for a resolution supports Ecuador’s accession to the Agreement. Though the tariff reductions contained in the Colombia-Peru Agreement would help sectors of the Ecuadorian economy access EU markets, it also contains politicised sections. Because a full assessment of the Agreement’s implications for Ecuador must be left to the actual ratification process, UKIP MEPs voted to abstain on the resolution.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Ecuador's accession to the EU's trade agreement with Colombia and Peru will benefit Ecuador's exports to the EU, mainly because the EU's generalised system of preferences will no longer apply; Consequently, this country will be provided with a driving force for economic and social development. While sharing the importance of concluding this agreement, I also support the need to monitor environmental sustainability in the design and implementation of cooperation activities funded by the Commission and to facilitate the exchange of good practice between the contracting parties with regard to corporate social responsibility. In my opinion, the Commission must also ensure that the maximum import volumes defined in the banana stabilization mechanism are actually respected, to protect producers and the European market. I would certainly have voted in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I support the Commission's declaration of Ecuador's accession to the Agreement on Trade between the European Union and the Republic of Peru and the Republic of Colombia. Ecuador's accession to the Trade Agreement is another shift in alliances with countries that are important partners to us in all segments of cooperation and development. Ecuador is a developing country that has significant economic growth. The European Union and Ecuador can benefit from a lot of mutual benefit, not only in mutual commodity exchange, but also in creating a stable environment for economic operators, strengthening competitiveness, technology transfer and innovation.  Economic growth must not be at the expense of the environment and civil society, but must be sustainable.  Ecuador is rich in biodiversity, is one of the 17 most diverse countries in the world and contains the highest concentration of plant and animal species, between 5% and 10% of the world's biodiversity. Many sensitive areas, such as the Amazon, the Galápagos Islands and Yasuni National Park hide numerous native species as well as native tribes. For this reason, it is necessary to make joint efforts to preserve the environment and biodiversity, not only for mutual benefit, but also for the benefit of humanity.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ Ecuador's economy has achieved strong growth over the past few years and, more importantly, inclusive economic growth and has directly reduced poverty, in particular extreme poverty and inequality levels, and strengthened the middle class.  It is worth welcoming the fact that, according to the latest World Bank figures, poverty in Ecuador between 2006 and 2014 fell from 37.6% to 22.5%, while extreme poverty decreased from 16.9% to 7.7%, partly thanks to the Ecuadorian government for investing more than $40 billion in the social sector over the past eight years. The European Union should continue to encourage Ecuador to continue its successful policy of progressive social and sustainable development. One way is to support Ecuador's accession to the Agreement on Trade with Colombia and Peru, which will greatly benefit Ecuador's exports to the EU, especially as it is no longer entitled to the benefits granted by the EU under the unilateral General Scheme of Preferences. I hope for the swift and comprehensive entry into force and implementation of this Agreement, which will ensure the highest level of protection of citizens and the environment, encourage and diversify trade and investment on both sides, and act as an important driver of economic and social development and contribute to further poverty alleviation and reducing inequalities in Ecuador.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I support the proposal for a resolution on Ecuador's accession to the EU-Colombia-Peru Trade Agreement. Agreements concluded with Colombia and Peru are good agreements and Ecuador's accession allows the European Union to form alliances with important countries and regions of equal worldview and rapid growth.  Although this is the accession of a new state to the already existing Agreement, I think it is justified to apply adapted conditions to Ecuador due to the significant differences that exist in the field of economics and economy. Specific mechanisms, such as for example a longer period of time for the regulation of tariff treatment for goods from Ecuador, will facilitate the process of implementing the Agreement. It should also be noted that there is progress in development as seen in reducing poverty rates and levels of inequality and the middle class has grown.  Consequently, the European Parliament encourages the Government of Ecuador to implement the action plans submitted by Colombia and Peru and to adopt similar measures, as this is an opportunity to improve the overall living conditions of citizens, including human and labour rights and the environment. I believe that Ecuador's accession to the Trade Agreement will be beneficial for all parties involved, as it allows new trade routes to be opened. It also deepens the relationship and establishes economic cooperation between countries.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 Together with the Social Democratic Faction, I was happy to support the ongoing negotiations on Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement concluded by the European Union in 2012 with two other Andean states, Colombia and Peru. I think that both sides will benefit from this step in the future, Ecuador will make a major increase in exports to Europe, and for Europeans there will be room for investment. As in the case of the agreement with the two South American states mentioned above, the European Union also has the possibility to enforce demands for greater emphasis on human and labour rights or environmental issues by Ecuador. South America is a strategic partner for Europe, and I consider the strengthening of diplomatic and trade relations with its states to be a very good path.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because I believe that Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement between the EU, Colombia and Peru is a further step forward in the alliance with important and rapidly growing countries and regions. In addition, the text of the Protocol of Accession to the Agreement fulfils the ambitions of both the EU and Ecuador. This agreement will increase and diversify trade and investment on both sides, act as an important factor for economic and social development and help alleviate poverty and reduce inequalities. I hope that this agreement will be implemented quickly and fully.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider the removal of barriers between the EU and Ecuador to be a step that will benefit both sides. Free trade helps and is the best medicine for emerging-market countries. This is also the case in Ecuador.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on Ecuador's accession to the EU-Peru-Colombia trade agreement. Large commercial complexes are born or consolidated today on all continents. The ASEAN countries, MERCOSUR and West Africa are coming together to form regional groups with the aim of trading more easily, more freely by reducing trade barriers. Europe must take advantage of its advance to get our partners such as Ecuador to facilitate imports of European products into its territory. It is in this logic that Ecuador must bind itself to the existing trade agreement with the countries of the region which are Peru and Colombia. Europe will now have easy access to the Ecuadorian market. However, Ecuador is the world's largest producer of bananas. The risk of an explosion in Ecuadorian banana exports to Europe at the expense of European producers (I am thinking particularly of the UPRs) will be contained thanks to the quota set out in the agreement and, above all, the possibility of applying safeguard measures at the slightest warning sign. One of my roles will be to closely monitor this market to prevent any risk to our producers and consumers.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that Ecuador no longer benefits from the generalised system of preferences of the European Union (EU), and considering that it is of fundamental importance to establish alliances with fast-growing countries, which advocate similar positions in a region increasingly focused on Asia and the Pacific, the European Commission has submitted a statement to the European Parliament on Ecuador's membership of the TRADE Agreement concluded between the EU and Colombia and Peru.  To this end, Parliament decided to close the debate by presenting a motion for a resolution which was put to the vote that day. The motion for a resolution confirms expectations that the Trade Agreement and the bilateral clause included correspond to the ambitions of the EU and Ecuador. Also with regard to the interests of Portugal, and in particular the economy of the Autonomous Region of Madeira, the Commission's negotiations took into account the impact of imports of bananas from Ecuador. Therefore, EU producing regions, such as Madeira, enjoy the additional protection of this clause which creates the legal basis for suspending the exemption from customs duties enjoyed by bananas in Ecuador in the event of a disproportionate increase. I voted in favour.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. The European Union and Ecuador conceded negotiations for Ecuador's accession to the EU-Colombia-Peru Trade Agreement on 12 December 2014. However, the ratification process is being delayed, with the risk that the administrative procedures necessary for its entry into force cannot be carried out before the current tariff preferences available to the Andean country expire. With this resolution, which I supported with my vote, Parliament expresses its wish that the Agreement should enter into force as soon as possible, with the guarantee of the safeguard provided for by the European banana industry. We recognize the progress made in Ecuador, but call for the establishment of an action plan by which Ecuador undertakes to properly implement a number of fundamental social and environmental rights, as agreed at the time with Colombia and Peru.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. In this resolution, the European Parliament voted in favour of Ecuador's planned accession to the multi-party free trade agreement between the Eu, on the one hand, Colombia and Peru, on the other. However, if I preferred to abstain on the final vote, I voted in favour of amendments calling on the Ecuadorian government to tackle issues such as child labour, women's rights and deforestation.  Furthermore, as Ecuador is one of the largest banana producers in the world, I have also in particular supported the Commission's request to activate the safeguard mechanism which suspends the exemption from tariffs on Ecuador's banana imports into the European market if they exceed a certain volume deemed harmful to the EU's banana-producing regions, both economically and in terms of employment.  The text of the resolution also requires the Commission to "actively pressure" Ecuador to comply with the same obligations that forced Colombia and Peru under the roadmap for environmental protection, workers' rights and human rights, which accompanied the multi-party agreement.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. On 17 July 2014, negotiations between the EU and Ecuador were concluded with a view to the accession of the EU to the EU-Colombia-Peru Trade Agreement, ensuring that country benefits that are significant for its economy, at a time when it no longer benefits from the EU's unilateral system of generalised preferences.  Although I voted in favour of this report, I endorse the concerns raised in the Committee on International Trade, to which I belong, regarding the need for this country to adopt policies consistent with the wto commitments and also to comply with the action plans presented on human, environmental and labour rights. I would also point out that Ecuador is, alongside Colombia and Peru, one of the world's leading banana producers, and it is therefore essential that the Commission should play a role in controlling and verifying import volumes, alongside an assessment of the direct and indirect impact of banana imports from these countries, and it is worth using a possible suspension of the exemption from customs duties , if there is a disproportionate increase in the volume of imports, causing serious damage to the economies of European producing countries, such as Portugal and Spain.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement between the European Union and Peru and Colombia. On 26 June 2012, the EU signed a free trade agreement with Colombia and Peru after six years of negotiations. Negotiations with Ecuador were suspended in 2009 and resumed in 2013 at Ecuador's request. The accession protocol was finalized on 17 July 2014, and Ecuador was thus able to join the Peru-Colombia agreement.  We are pleased with this agreement on the degree of openness of public procurement and market access with the abolition of tariffs on many products and the introduction of transitional periods for other products. The text also recalls the sensitivity of the agricultural sector, particularly bananas, as Ecuador is the world's largest exporter. A stabilisation mechanism is provided as part of the agreement and will be triggered if certain thresholds are exceeded, so as not to jeopardise our European production. We will ensure that the Commission respects its proper functioning and will remain attentive to its effective implementation.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement between the European Union, Colombia and Peru as it promotes increased trade and investment between the parties concerned. Furthermore, this agreement represents an opportunity for Ecuador to improve the living conditions of its citizens.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against this Resolution. Sectors sponsoring the free trade agreement omit that these agreements are much more than just trade agreements. They don't count on the geopolitical and economic submissions involved. They do not raise the question of the social and environmental constraints they impose. They ignore harmful impacts on employment in certain productive activities, such as agricultural activities. Little or nothing matters to them that these agreements freeze production and exporting structures based on extractivism, imposed more than 500 years ago with the arrival of the Spanish carabelas. And, by the way, they also do not recognize that these agreements are proposed in the interests of transnational capital.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted against Ecuador's resolution on Ecuador's accession to the Trade Agreement concluded between the EU and its Member States and Peru and Colombia because of my opposition to this free trade agreement with Peru and Colombia, with which the EU has dynamited the positive dynamics of regional integration for the peoples of the Andean Community. This agreement with Peru and Colombia for the benefit of European multinationals and agribusiness has been widely rejected by trade unions, social movements and human rights organizations for their negative impact on the living and working conditions of SMEs, small and medium-sized peasants, workers and local markets. Although with differences in the time limits for the implementation of trade liberalization on both sides, as the agreement with Ecuador is based on the same provisions as the free trade agreement with Peru and Colombia, I have not been able to vote in favour of the Resolution.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Negotiations with Ecuador on 17 July 2014 for its accession to the trade agreement between the European Union and Colombia and Peru, signed in June 2012, were concluded. I voted in favour of Parliament's motion for a resolution because this accession represents an important step forward in the alliance with the rapidly developing countries in the Latin American region. Ecuador has pledged to reduce poverty in recent years, falling from 37.5% to 22.5%, and has focused on improving social and environmental conditions. By joining the trade agreement, the country will be able to enjoy the benefits of trade with the EU, thus promoting further economic and social development. In the same way, the Union will increase its economic relations with the Latin American market, which is considered to be one of the markets of greatest growth and interest in the world.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this vote. The agreement has beneficial and harmful components. Full assessment is best left to the ratification process.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this agreement as it will boost and diversify investment and trade between both of the sides. We also called for an action plan on social and environmental rights in line with those already agreed.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the motion for a resolution on Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement between the European Union and its Member States and Colombia and Peru. I support Ecuador's efforts for deeper integration into the international business community, but also its commitments to protect its natural cultural heritage, such as the Galapagos Archipelago with rare endemic species.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The Ecuadorian Government has invested $40.8 billion over the last eight years in the social sector, access to education, health care and social security, including through special programmes for the benefit of the most vulnerable groups, such as children, the elderly and people with disabilities. Ecuador also manages to improve the conditions of its indigenous communities, which are adversely affected by the mining strategy of corporations. I therefore welcome the conclusion of negotiations with Ecuador on the protocol on its accession to the EU-Colombia-Peru trade agreement. This agreement will bring many export benefits to the EU to Ecuador, while serving as an important stimulus for economic and social development and contributing to poverty alleviation and reducing inequality. On the other hand, it is important for Ecuador to ensure consistency of its policies with the obligations arising from the WTO agreements and the trade agreement, and to ensure full transparency and extensive consultation with stakeholders prior to their adoption. On environmental issues, it should be noted that, despite the efforts made by the country, Ecuador and neighbouring countries are facing intense deforestation, significant biodiversity loss, water pollution and soil erosion. Ecuador and the EU should therefore also conclude an agreement on cooperation in the field of the environment and the promotion of programmes against deforestation. This would contribute in particular to improving the living conditions of the local population.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the agreement to include Ecuador in the trade agreement between the European Union, Colombia and Peru, which will allow an increase in exports to Europe for the benefit of the Ecuadorean economy. As the Group of the Party of European Socialists, we believe that trade is a means of making progress, both from an economic point of view and from the point of view of the well-being of citizens, allowing new markets to be opened up but also by making sure that investment serves to reduce inequalities and improve living conditions. This is what we want for Ecuador, which we want to include in its existing close links with other South American countries, by asking its government to establish a clear and transparent path on human, environmental and social rights as a condition for the conclusion of the agreement, as was done with Peru and Colombia when this trade agreement was concluded.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 The promotion of bilateral economic and trade agreements and relations between states and the development of free trade agreements in a global context mean ambitious and fruitful partnerships, bringing more and more opportunities for the development of European states.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒I support this resolution proposal because Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement with Colombia and Peru represents one important step in trade relations. This resolution will encourage Ecuador to take measures taken by both Colombia and Peru, to start the economy, but also to improve the general standard of its population including human rights, labour rights and the environment. This resolution should also encourage other countries in the environment to make further efforts to achieve this goal, i.e. to achieve this goal. trade agreement, which is an opportunity to improve the living standards of their population.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ Ecuador's approach to the Trade Agreement with Colombia and Peru is another decisive step towards forging alliances with important countries and regions of equal worldview and rapid growth. Human rights and democracy are essential factors in the overall relationship between the European Union and and the Andean countries, so it calls on all partners to ensure respect for all social and political rights. Economic growth in Ecuador has been positive, directly reducing poverty and inequality levels and increasing the middle class.  Ecuador, along with Colombia and Peru, is one of the world's leading banana producers. Governments of Andean countries should take all necessary and technical measures to establish a trade agreement and all partners are invited to ensure compliance with all social and political rights. I support the Position of the Council for the establishment of a joint subcommittee on trade and sustainable development as the only mechanism envisaged under the Trade Agreement to monitor the implementation of commitments on sustainable development of the economy.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report and I support the accession of Ecuador to this free trade agreement. This is a welcome expansion of the Andean free trade zone to cover one of the fastest growing markets in South America.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Agreements that also place Ecuador in the World Trade System automatically weaken its position and also turn that state into a policy-dependent international capital.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union supports a policy to encourage good relations and free trade with Latin American countries. In this context, relations with the countries of the Andean area are a priority. The Union has already concluded a multilateral free trade agreement with Colombia and Peru in 2012. It is intended to replace the old agreements under the General Preferential Scheme (GSP+), which expired on 1 January 2015. Ecuador thus remained outside a formal free trade agreement, although in practice it benefits from temporary preferential tariffs. Despite the fact that last year there were problems with imports of fresh bananas from Ecuador, the country's accession to the multilateral agreement between the EU, Colombia and Peru is necessary for the development of trade between the Union and Ecuador and the increase of mutual investment. This does not, however, mean giving up certain conditionalities that the EU must demand over the Ecuadorian side, such as respecting certain social conditions for workers in that country and respecting the environment. Without these clauses, which are in line with the values promoted by the EU at international level, the signing of the agreement would not have the expected effects on Ecuador's development. The current initiative is an important step in this direction.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text but I do not guarantee that this will still be the case in the next phase. I take this opportunity to denounce the lack of improvement in the situation in Colombia regarding labour rights, social rights and fundamental rights in general.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution that welcomes the conclusion of the negotiations with Ecuador on its accession to the Trade Agreement between the EU, Colombia and Peru. It is expected to benefit Ecuador’s exports to the EU and to boost trade and investment on both sides. At the same time, it should facilitate economic and social development and contribute to reducing poverty. The resolution sets out specifics tasks for both partners. On one hand, it appeals to Ecuador to ensure consistency with its WTO and trade agreement commitments and remove market-access obstacles. On the other hand, it invites the Commission and the European External Action Service to play an active role in guaranteeing sustainable development. I consider it important that the report emphasises human rights and democracy and urges the Government of Ecuador to promote them.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported Ecuador's accession to the Agreement on Trade concluded between the EU and its Member States and Colombia and Peru, as I believe that the accession of a country such as Ecuador will increase the profits of international trade of the European Union.  Indeed, like other Andean countries, Ecuador is one of the fastest growing markets for the European Union in Latin America, as it has achieved significant economic growth recently and thus directly reduced poverty and inequality levels.  However, I find it particularly positive that this resolution, in addition to focusing on the current economic and social situation in the country, also reflects on many problems in Ecuador such as intensive deforestation and declining biodiversity. Supporting Ecuador in its efforts to develop and sustain effective environmental governance, especially in sensitive areas such as the Amazon and the Galapagos Islands, is extremely important for the future of our planet.  A distinctive fact of this country are numerous native and local communities, native tree species and dozens of endangered animal species. It is therefore essential to encourage the preservation of the world's natural heritage, which can be partially achieved through the support of the UN Human Rights Council decision establishing an intergovernmental working group on transnational cooperation and human rights.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the motions for a resolution on Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement between the EU and its Member States and Colombia and Peru, because I believe that Ecuador is a strategic partner of this trade agreement and that Ecuador's exports to the EU will bring many benefits, and this cooperation will increase investment in both Ecuador and the Union. This will have a significant impact on economic and social development and indirectly contribute to poverty and inequality reduction.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against this Resolution. Sectors sponsoring the free trade agreement omit that these agreements are much more than just trade agreements. They don't count on the geopolitical and economic submissions involved. They do not raise the question of the social and environmental constraints they impose. They ignore harmful impacts on employment in certain productive activities, such as agricultural activities. Little or nothing matters to them that these agreements freeze production and exporting structures based on extractivism, imposed more than 500 years ago with the arrival of the Spanish carabelas. And, by the way, they also do not recognize that these agreements are proposed in the interests of transnational capital.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the conclusion of the negotiations with Ecuador on the protocol for its accession to the Trade Agreement between the EU, Colombia and Peru, recognising the important benefits that this will bring for Ecuador’s exports to the EU, particularly in view of the fact that it no longer benefits from the EU’s unilateral Generalised Scheme of Preferences. I encourage the quick and complete entry into force and implementation of this agreement, which will ensure the protection of citizens and the environment at the highest level. I consider that this agreement will boost and diversify trade and investment on both sides, act as an important driver for economic and social development, and contribute to alleviating poverty and reducing inequality. More generally I always support free trade. I believe Europe can only grow with new markets and not with more budget!

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. In December 2014, the EU and Ecuador signed Ecuador's connection to the current free trade agreement between the EU, Colombia and Peru. This asymmetric agreement should make it easier for Ecuador to develop. This report is a request to the European Commission to ensure that human, labour and environmental rights are well respected in Ecuador. This was indeed an express request from the European Parliament to the European Commission. I cannot give my vote in favour of a report that welcomes this free trade agreement which is a fairly strong interference in Ecuador's domestic policy. I choose abstention.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement with Colombia and Peru is another decisive step towards a like-minded alliance with important and rapidly developing countries in a region that is increasingly turning to Asia-Pacific. The text of the Protocol on its accession to the Trade Agreement reflects the aspirations of both the EU and Ecuador. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against this Resolution. Sectors sponsoring the free trade agreement omit that these agreements are much more than just trade agreements. They don't count on the geopolitical and economic submissions involved. They do not raise the question of the social and environmental constraints they impose. They ignore harmful impacts on employment in certain productive activities, such as agricultural activities. Little or nothing matters to them that these agreements freeze production and exporting structures based on extractivism, imposed more than 500 years ago with the arrival of the Spanish carabelas. And, by the way, they also do not recognize that these agreements are proposed in the interests of transnational capital.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. By this Resolution, the European Parliament welcomes the conclusion of the negotiations with Ecuador on Ecuador's Protocol of Accession to the Trade Agreement concluded between the EU and Colombia and Peru, recognising how much it will benefit Ecuador's exports to the EU. That is why I thought it appropriate to vote in favour of that resolution.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I have not been able to support Ecuador's Resolution on Ecuador's accession to the Trade Agreement concluded between the EU and its Member States and Peru and Colombia by my opposition to this free trade agreement with Peru and Colombia, with which the EU has dynamited the positive dynamics of regional integration for the peoples of the Andean Community. This agreement with Peru and Colombia for the benefit of European multinationals has been widely rejected by trade unions, social movements and human rights organizations for their negative impact on the living and working conditions of farmers and workers. Although with differences in the time limits for the implementation of trade liberalization on both sides, as the agreement with Ecuador is based on the same provisions as the free trade agreement with Peru and Colombia, I have not been able to vote in favour of the Resolution.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I voted in favour of Ecuador joining the EU-Colombia trade agreement with Peru. It is my belief that this will benefit Ecuador's exports to the EU and further stimulate trade and investment on both sides. In my opinion, this is a clear win-win situation for all parties involved.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. The European Union is currently engaged in trade negotiations with Mercosur. The European Parliament is thus taking a position on the free trade agreement, which is still being negotiated, between the European Union and Ecuador, as it has done with those previously with Colombia and Peru.  Rapporteur, my colleague Helmut Scholz, from Die Linke, recalled the need to respect social and environmental rights. Investments have been made by the Ecuadorian government to improve access to health and education and to combat poverty.  The agreement, however, mainly favours the opening of the Ecuadorian market to mining companies and the development of neoliberal industrial and economic policies. These economic and industrial farms risk permanently degrading areas of the Amazon rainforest, causing displacement of local farmers and worsening the situation of indigenous peoples, not to mention the risks to workers' rights. I have therefore chosen to abstain on this resolution.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The text of ecuador's protocol of membership to the Trade Agreement with Colombia and Peru corresponds to the ambitions of the EU and Ecuador, and supposedly takes into account the asymmetric relations in the proposals for market access in favor of Ecuador and includes the specific adaptations requested by Ecuador. We fear that in the future the fundamental premises based on free trade and the presentation of supposedly neutral rules will emerge over these good intentions, but which do not consider the deep inequalities of development of countries. In this sense, we naturally express our reservations.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. In principle, there is nothing against free trade agreements. However, they must be viewed critically between countries with completely different economic strengths, as they very often destroy the small-scale economy in the weaker country and create more unemployment and dependence on the "West".

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Writing. I voted in favour of Ecuador's accession to the EU trade agreement on the one hand and Peru and Colombia on the other. New trade relations with overseas countries are good and right for Europe's relations with non-European countries, as long as the EU does not use such agreements to interfere in the economies of the trading countries. As long as the quality of the goods is impeccable and ecologically unobjectionable, I see no reason not to enter into negotiations with Ecuador and to establish new political and economic relations.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on Ecuador's accession to the EU-Peru-Colombia trade agreement. Unfortunately, the Treaty of Lisbon has given the EU competence for free trade agreements. Within this framework, the EU has concluded a free trade agreement with Peru and Colombia, to which Ecuador is now joining. I am very much in favour of advancing world trade and also trade with individual states. However, this should preferably be done unilaterally by the EU unilaterally reducing its trade restrictions through tariffs and other measures. If trade restrictions are only dismantled at each other and, so to speak, in step, this delays the process, which ultimately harms consumers in particular.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which makes it clear that Ecuador fulfils the conditions required for its accession to this pact. In addition, the European Parliament has taken into account political, social and environmental issues that are being promoted and need to be further supported by the country's government.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite the fair reference to the social development policy of the Ecuadorian Government present in this report, the European Union seeks to enforce its liberalizing agenda of world trade, in this case with particular interest in that region of the planet, having even already signed agreements with Colombia and Peru on June 26, 2014. We abstained.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on Ecuador's accession to the EU-Colombia-Peru trade agreement because I believe that the agreement will increase and diversify trade and investment on both sides and contribute to reducing poverty and inequality. I also support the resolution's call for the conclusion of a cooperation agreement between Ecuador and the EU, which would support specific environmental programmes relating to the prevention of deforestation.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favour of this resolution, but with the bitter awareness that the text adopted is a rather weak text, it is a text of façade, because it lacks a series of important actions and indications that the European Union must put into practice as soon as possible in order to really protect and protect animal welfare and recognise them as sentient beings. , as enshrined in Article 13 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.  There is, for example, no clear reference to a commitment to finance alternative methods to animal testing and their promotion and dissemination also in academia, in university curricula, for a rapid abandonment of this practice, as requested by 1 200 000 citizens with the European initiative 'Stop vivisection'. There are also a number of other calls, which did not go into the final resolution, addressed to the Commission and the Member States, for example to harmonise legislation on the use of wild animals in circuses, to ban the use of cetaceans in captivity and the illegal trade in wild animals.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I supported this report, but I expect that the report to be prepared by the European Commission for the years to come 2016-2020, as called for by the European Commission in this document, will be more ambitious than the European Union's action to date. I believe that respect for animals as living creatures is part of the ethical standards of our advanced European society, and I would personally like, for example, if part of the future strategy was to ban so-called fur farms, that is, animal behaviour for fur coats, which is now a very strong issue, for example, in the country where I come from, in the Czech Republic. It would be good if this matter were uniformly regulated throughout the European Union. So I hope that the next strategy will be more ambitious than the European Union's action to date.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I too was able to vote in favour of the resolution because it was balanced. I must also say that anyone who looks at the development of European agriculture fairly will see that not only has the public interest in animal welfare increased, but there have also been real improvements. Nevertheless , and this is true, there is still a lot of work to be done – we must continue to work on the issue. However, I must stress at least three points that I would have liked to see more clearly in the resolution: firstly, of course, we must take into account the fact that we have a European internal market. It is not acceptable for us to allow differences between the Member States, because that simply means shifting animal cruelty from one Member State to another. Secondly, of course, we must also look at the fact that we have world trade, and we must also see that when we import animal products, the same standards naturally apply there. Thirdly, I would have liked us to include pet farming in the consideration of animal welfare, because there are still many uncontrolled things taking place there. In this respect, there is still much to be done, but we should continue to discuss this together.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, bhí áthas orm cuidiú leis an tuarascáil seo i gcoitinne mar a rinne an chuid is mó de na Feisirí. Feicim gur ghlac 542 Feisire leis an tuarascáil. Dar ndóigh is ceart aire a thabhairt d’ainmhithe. Gan dabht ar bith, tá siad an-tábhachtach don chine daonna mar pheataí, mar chairde agus mar fhoinse bia. Deirtear gurb é an madra an cara is fearr atá ag an bhfear, agus tá sé sin fíor do mhná comh maith.  Ach ag an am céanna tá áthas orm gur dhiúltaíomar dá lán de na leasuithe a tháinig ón eite chlé. Chomhairigh mé 36 leasú ar fad ón eite chlé agus dhiúltaigh mise agus mo ghrúpa agus an Pharlaimint do 32 díobh, agus bhí sé sin ceart mar bhí siad ag dul thar fóir ar fad.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, it is difficult to speak out after this joke by my colleague Kelly, but I wanted to say that I supported this motion for a resolution also because it improves dialogue with all stakeholders, because we must also look at the situation and the possibilities in the international field to improve animal protection from international perspectives. European society is certainly advanced in this sense, we try to respect standards in animal husbandry, improve their welfare, but we also have certain reserves. For example, not only for those fur farms that mr. Pospisil referred to, but also for dog breeders. That's a bit of a field unscathed, too, and it's a big problem in my country. I'd like to point that out. I was happy to support this motion for a resolution, but we still have work to do in our own field.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Madam President, this is the report that has taken up the most attention and has had the most amendments and the most debate out of all the things that we have been talking about today: animal welfare. Of course, people feel strongly about it. It touches us emotionally, and it opens the door to what has come to be known as virtue signalling: people using a legislative or political issue as an opportunity to broadcast to the world what very nice people they are. But stand back and ask the question: is it right for sensitive issues – moral issues, one might say – of this nature to be dealt with at a continental level? Is it not precisely matters of this kind, in which opinions run so strongly among our constituents, that ought to be determined through our national democratic mechanisms and procedures? Putting an amendment or signing a resolution might give you a momentary warm glow, but is it really a way of strengthening democratic accountability in Europe?

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – It has historically and evolutionarily come to the realm of man being its highest biological species, and therefore we have the greatest responsibility as living beings over other living beings. Given the fact that several animals live next to a human being and we use many of them in our daily diet, we have a special responsibility. I would like to say that in 1974, in the European Union, in fact at the time in the Community, the first legislative foundations in the field of animal welfare emerged, and only almost forty years later, in 2012, a whole strategy for animal welfare and welfare was put into practice. Consequently, the modernisation of economic policy, the development of international relations, also on the basis of compliance with animal care standards and not only, the organisation of various international events and a number of other activities, sign the fact that the European Union is oriented towards guaranteeing the rights of our biological relatives. Support.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – I would like to emphasise that I was relieved to welcome this report, with relief and not with satisfaction, but I was pleased with the report as well as with the tasks carried out. I would like to stress that all the issues that have been raised have been extremely interesting, but unfortunately a few amendments have alarmed me (fortunately they have been rejected). I would like to stress that I expect greater consequences and better anticipation in this area, because it is very important that the European Parliament does not forget these issues when pathologies in particular arise.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution, ‘A new animal welfare strategy for 2016-2020’, seeks, under the guise of protecting animals, massively to extend EU regulatory control. Even if some of the proposals are worthy, the unintended consequences would be horrendous and the legal and behavioural ramifications divisive and damaging.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 More protection is needed for animals in the European Union. The resolution, despite the rejection of the amendments we have tabled, provides a good starting point for extending animal protection in Europe. Animals are not goods that are "produced", discarded, sold and bought, have the right to an existence and a death deprived as much as possible of suffering ... this is the least that a country that professes to be civilised passes. There is still a long way to go but something seems to be starting to move. Gandhi said that 'the greatness of a nation and its moral progress can be judged by the way it treats animals' and at the moment Europe is unfortunately only small on the basis of this concept. I voted in favour of the resolution because I believe that it is necessary to defend those who do not have a voice in order to do so themselves.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – This resolution, ‘A new animal welfare strategy for 2016-2020’, seeks, under the guise of protecting animals, massively to extend EU regulatory control. Even if some of the proposals are worthy, the unintended consequences would be horrendous and the legal and behavioural ramifications divisive and damaging.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because I believe it is necessary for the European Commission to propose a new strategy on animal welfare for the period 2016-2020, which addresses areas such as trafficking in exotic species, trophy hunting, 'cultural' practices involving animal abuse or suffering (such as bulls in the Spanish State), industrialized agri-farming, etc. A new animal welfare strategy for 2016-2020 would help us to move towards more sustainable and fair agricultural and livestock production.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this strategy which calls on the Commission to draw up a new animal welfare strategy for the period 2016-2020. It also asks the Commission to implement outstanding points from the current strategy and for further evaluation of the 2012-2015 strategy.  The joint resolution which was eventually adopted was a result of inter-party negotiations in the days leading up to the vote and was balanced in calling for ambitious new policy instruments where scientific evidence demonstrates welfare problems, while also recognising that the level of animal welfare in the European Union is among the highest in the world. There were certain amendments which I could not support, including those which would have detracted payments from existing schemes for farmers who are already struggling to make ends meet. But also some amendments which I could support including those to combat the illegal wildlife trade and illegal bird hunting.  Overall, I chose to support this strategy which was good from the point of view of asking the Commission to ensure an ambitious updated and comprehensive legislative framework.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. I support the adoption of an animal welfare strategy for the years 2016-2020, if it is to renew the content of the one that is now in force and runs until the end of 2015. With this strategy, we can ensure that the various existing laws are properly implemented in order to ensure better harmonisation within the internal market. There is no need to create new rules for this. It must also help us to include animal welfare in the scope of the Union's trade policy, particularly under its non-tariff component.  Indeed, it is even necessary on this very point to demand the rejection of free trade agreements which would not guarantee full compliance by imported products with EU animal welfare standards, in order to prevent any distortion of competition for products from third countries. Finally, this strategy should enable us to reaffirm the need to provide sufficient budgetary resources in the CAP to help farmers better meet the requirements of animal welfare legislation, and more particularly in terms of standards.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. In view of the interlinked links between animal welfare, animal health and public health, and because EU citizens want to be able to make better informed choices as consumers, I welcome this resolution, which calls for the development of an EU-wide strategy for the protection and welfare of animals for the period 2016-2020. I regret, however, that the text does not advocate a ban on animal testing for budgetary resources, as is already the case in the cosmetics sector. I also criticise the fact that, with regard to the production of foie gras and duck liver, no stop to forced feeding by means of metal pipes (the practice of plugging) is required. That is why I abstained in the final vote.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. Article 9 of this text is of the most interest as it calls for reciprocity of standards in trade treaties and the impossibility of challenging them in trade negotiations. We believe it is absolutely necessary to maintain high standards that guarantee our farmers; it is also a way to stop the TTIP negotiations. In the hope that the Commission will take this request for reciprocity into account, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this resolution, I support animal welfare of course, but the resolution seeks to grant the Commission legislative competence on matters which should be the responsibility of Member States. I note further that this is a non-legislative report and will not actually impact animal welfare.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on animal welfare. I agree that animal welfare should be further improved on the basis of established scientific conclusions and with due attention to the efficiency and competitiveness of agricultural livestock farming. I support the calls on the Commission to implement without delay the remaining points of the European Union strategy on the protection of animal welfare 2012-2015. The Commission should assess the existing strategy and develop a new broad strategy for the protection of animal welfare for the period 2016-2020. The Commission should adapt policy measures or introduce new measures to address animal welfare problems where there is clear scientific evidence to support these problems. The Commission should closely monitor the implementation of EU animal welfare legislation in the Member States.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. Article 9, which calls on the Commission to "take account of the reciprocity of animal welfare standards[,] by prioritizing it as a non-commercial issue in its trade policy and in its negotiations of international trade agreements, and to promote animal welfare in third countries by demanding equivalent welfare standards for imported animals and products. , with strict controls" - having been adopted, I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I supported this resolution, which urges the Commission to assess the current strategy and develop an ambitious new strategy for animal welfare and protection over the period 2016-2020 in order to exploit the work resulting from the previous strategy and to maintain a rigorous regulatory framework for animal welfare in all Member States.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Resolution, agreed between popular, socialist, conservative and liberal, because it addresses the growing sensitivity of public opinion on animal welfare, and because we consider that it is closely linked to the issue of public health. It points out that animal welfare cannot be achieved at the cost of imposing higher expenditure and bureaucratic hurdes on farmers, the thus undermining the competitiveness of the European countryside. It urges the Commission to ensure that Member States comply with European regulations and calls for the development of scientific and technological studies to promote alternatives in animal welfare.

name: Joëlle BERGERON
text: In writing. I voted for the joint resolution on a new strategy for animal welfare because I believe that animal welfare must be part of the common values cherished by the Member States of the Union and of any civilised country. I regret, however, that this resolution does not dare to go to the end of its own logic and put the finger where it hurts. Indeed, in the context of the ritual slaughter of animals prescribed by certain religions, notably Islam, the unnecessary suffering inflicted on animals demonstrates the extent to which the welfare of animals is held, by certain groups of people, for something that should not be respected. According to the legislation of some Member States, ritual slaughter can only be done after the anaesthesia of animals promised religious sacrifice. It is time for this obligation to extend to the whole of the Union.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I supported this Resolution as negotiated between the groups as it is necessary for the Commission to implement without dilation the outstanding points of the European Union Strategy for the Protection and Welfare of Animals 2012-2015. The Commission needs to ensure an up-to-date, comprehensive and clear legislative framework, and the efforts already made by farmers on animal welfare must be recognised. I therefore voted against the amendments tabled by the GUE/NGL and Verts/ALE Groups.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I hope that this resolution will allow us to establish a new animal welfare strategy for the period 2016-2020. Efforts have been made by the 2011-2015 strategy, but we must now go further and remove all ambiguities. Without affecting the competitiveness of our farmers already hard hit by the crisis, I think it is necessary to sustainably and financially encourage agricultural policies with animal welfare standards: phasing out cage systems, quail farming, animal suffering,... Similarly, we must fight against this extensive agriculture which puts us at risk not only for health and the environment but also for animal welfare. Overall, I voted in favour of all the amendments that go towards more animal protection and I regret that many of my colleagues have not followed this path. I supported food labelling on slaughter and breeding methods, I condemned the illegal trade in animal species, I supported the prohibition of ritual slaughter without anesthesia or the strengthening of animal protection rules during transport. Finally, I also supported funding for the search for good practices to eliminate animal experimentation. Overall, I voted for this text.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution on a new animal welfare strategy is unbalanced and presents a number of critical issues, which is why I did not support it with my vote.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted for this resolution because animal welfare should be further improved on the basis of established scientific conclusions and with due regard for the efficiency and competitiveness of agricultural livestock farming. It would therefore be useful to define what is appropriate for livestock farming in order to ensure clarity of animal welfare standards throughout the European Union. The European Parliament urges the Commission to evaluate the existing strategy and to develop a new broad strategy for the protection of animal welfare for the period 2016-2020, with a view to continuing the work undertaken with the previous strategy and ensuring that a system of high animal welfare standards continues to be in place in all Member States. Parliament also calls on the Commission to adopt policies or introduce new measures to address animal welfare problems where there is clear scientific evidence to support these problems. The Commission should closely monitor the implementation of EU animal welfare legislation in the Member States. In addition, the Commission should develop, exchange and disseminate best scientifically based practices, as well as support innovation and research in the development of new animal welfare methods and technologies.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. Animal welfare is an issue that is close to everyone's heart and requires the adoption of a clear strategy by the European Union, combining animal protection and protection with the needs of the internal market and our economic position on the international stage. It is therefore necessary for the Commission to carefully assess the effectiveness and outstanding points of the current strategy and, in the light of these evaluations as well, to draw up a new and ambitious strategy for the period 2016-2020. We must also remember that, while it is true that animal welfare receives its highest levels of protection in Europe, and we must be proud of this, this approach must also be promoted at world level and requires a certain reciprocity also by third countries, without which we risk penalising our production system, while failing to achieve results on a global scale.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒I support this decision, as EU animal welfare legislation contributes to building a level playing field in the Union and thus the internal market. In addition, animal welfare is closely related to animal health and public health.  In conclusion, I consider that there are imbalances in the food supply chain that put the primary producer at a disadvantage and this situation at farm level limits investment opportunities in infrastructure and animal welfare.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report aims to improve animal welfare, particularly on farms. The rapporteur admits that farmers are saturated with administrative obligations. For this reason, it recommends that the CAP be given a sufficiently ambitious budget to limit the relocation of production to countries where these standards would not be met. We also welcome the fact that this report requires reciprocal standards, contributing to animal welfare in the negotiation of international trade agreements, without which our producers would face unfair competition. That is why I voted for this text.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
