text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution would like to define some general criteria for the Commission with a view to the forthcoming presentation of animal welfare legislation (2016-2020); the same is the subject of strong criticism within the Member States regarding the implementation at national level and the sustainability and scientific correctness of certain measures. All this with great bureaucratic (and investment) burdens for operators.  However, some of these indications also contribute to the high level of quality of European agricultural production and, quite rightly, paragraph 9 of the resolution points out that these should not be the subject of trade negotiations with non-EU countries and that, on the contrary, similar standards should be required for imported products/animals. Unfortunately, the rest of the text is littered with the usual rituals, attempts to ban hunting (21rev, 22rev but also in a broad sense, 12rev, which I would point out to you) and some techniques/types of breeding that, even when foreign to our productive context, we protect as intrinsic expressions of traditional and popular European cultures.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the motion for a resolution on the animal welfare strategy for the period 2016-2020. Achieving a high level of animal welfare is an essential element in protecting their health and ensuring their productivity. At the same time, animal welfare is of great interest to European citizens, who want to be able to make more informed choices as consumers. With the resolution that we adopted, we called on the Commission to implement without delay the outstanding points of the European Union Strategy for The Protection and Welfare of Animals 2012-2015 and to draw up a new and ambitious one for the period 2016-2020, capable of ensuring continuity of the previous strategy. In addition, we have stressed the importance of improving the application and compliance with existing legislation and we have asked the Commission to include reciprocity of animal welfare rules, as a non-commercial concern, in its trade policy and in the negotiations on international trade agreements. In view of all these points, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this strategy which calls on the Commission to draw up a new animal welfare strategy for the period 2016-2020. It also asks the Commission to implement outstanding points from the current strategy and for further evaluation of the 2012-2015 strategy.  The joint resolution which was eventually adopted was a result of inter-party negotiations in the days leading up to the vote and was balanced in calling for ambitious new policy instruments where scientific evidence demonstrates welfare problems, while also recognising that the level of animal welfare in the European Union is among the highest in the world. There were certain amendments which I could not support, including those which would have detracted payments from existing schemes for farmers who are already struggling to make ends meet. But also some amendments which I could support including those to combat the illegal wildlife trade and illegal bird hunting.  Overall, I chose to support this strategy which was good from the point of view of asking the Commission to ensure an ambitious updated and comprehensive legislative framework.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution, ‘A new animal welfare strategy for 2016-2020’, seeks, under the guise of protecting animals, massively to extend EU regulatory control. Even if some of the proposals are worthy, the unintended consequences would be horrendous and the legal and behavioural ramifications divisive and damaging.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I agree with the rapporteurs in urging the Commission to implement the European Union Strategy on the Protection and Welfare of Animals 2012-2015 and legislative framework that covers all animal categories.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 Full compliance by European and national legislation with Article 18 TFEI, i.e. that animals are considered sentient beings, is essential. The European Animal Welfare Strategy for 2016-2020 shows a timid approach but I voted in favour because we need to protect our animal friends.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 Through the joint motion for a resolution, the Commission is invited to ensure the development, exchange and dissemination of scientifically documented best practices and to support innovation and research on the development of new animal welfare methods and technologies. The President is therefore rightly entrusted with forwarding this resolution to the Council and the Commission.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote in favour of the measure. EU animal welfare legislation contributes to the creation of a level playing field within the Union and, therefore, to the proper functioning of the internal market. European citizens have a strong interest in animal welfare and want to be able to make more informed choices as consumers. Community and national animal welfare rules, due to their complexity and differing interpretations, create legal uncertainty and can cause producers in some Member States a serious competitive disadvantage. Parliament urges the Commission to carry out an assessment of the existing strategy and to develop a new and ambitious animal protection and welfare strategy for the period 2016-2020, which will continue the work carried out under the previous strategy and ensure continuity of the regulatory framework in order to achieve strict animal welfare standards in all Member States. It calls on the Commission to closely monitor the implementation of EU animal welfare legislation in the Member States. Parliament also pointed out that producers are burdened with administrative obligations and that the new European strategy should not increase the existing burdens any further.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution, ‘A new animal welfare strategy for 2016-2020’, seeks, under the guise of protecting animals, massively to extend EU regulatory control. Even if some of the proposals are worthy, the unintended consequences would be horrendous and the legal and behavioural ramifications divisive and damaging.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. One of the main concerns of European citizens is animal welfare: whether in respect for the feelings and suffering of animals, or from a health and health perspective related to animal consumption. It is up to the European Union to ensure this desideratum and to apply in its policies the best standards of animal protection, not least because animal welfare is strictly related to public health and animal health. I share the demands expressed in this Resolution, and in particular with the need to devise an ambitious new strategy for the protection and welfare of animals for the period 2016-2020, continuing the work carried out under the previous strategy. I believe that the rules in this area should be clear and should not give way to divergences in interpretations, despite their complexity, and that animal welfare should be promoted not only in Europe but also in third countries, requiring equivalent standards for imported animals and products, associated with strict controls. The degree of civilism of a society is shaped by the way it treats its animals!

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for Amendment 21 rev, not because I want the Commission to be the relevant authority on animal welfare, trade or any rules relating to the UK, but because I think the killing of animals for the purpose of ʽtrophiesʼ is abhorrent.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote in favour because I believe it is essential to improve the European animal welfare strategy. I believe that this improvement is necessary because EU and national animal welfare rules are often a source of legal uncertainty and competitive disadvantage for producers in some Member States because of their complexity and differing interpretations. In addition, I believe that this strategy should also be improved in order to satisfy the interests of European citizens, who want to be able to make more informed choices as consumers. I also hope that the Commission will monitor closely the implementation of EU animal welfare legislation in the Member States.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ Over the past 40 years, EU animal welfare legislation has evolved on the basis of sound scientific knowledge, improving the quality of animals’ lives in accordance with citizens’ expectations. The Commission should draw up a new strategy for the protection and welfare of animals for the 2016-2020 period so as to ensure further positive developments in EU animal welfare policy.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: Written. I voted in favour of the EU renewing its common animal welfare strategy. I care about animal welfare and consider it important both for ethical reasons and for the production of good and healthy food. It is also important to have uniform rules that are implemented in the same way throughout the Union in order to avoid distortions of competition between Member States.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because I believe it is necessary for the European Commission to propose a new strategy on animal welfare for the period 2016-2020, which addresses areas such as trafficking in exotic species, trophy hunting, 'cultural' practices involving animal abuse or suffering (such as bulls in the Spanish State), industrialized agri-farming, etc. A new animal welfare strategy for 2016-2020 would help us to move towards more sustainable and fair agricultural and livestock production.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament believes that animal welfare should be further improved both through better implementation and enforcement of existing EU legislation and through the development of a new and ambitious animal protection and welfare strategy. In the resolution that I voted in favour, the European Parliament calls on the Commission to develop an ambitious strategy for 2016-2020 that focuses on trade policy, animal welfare in third countries, adequate funding of the common agricultural policy and the exchange of good practices based on scientific data.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution deals with the proposal of a new animal welfare strategy for the years 2016-2020. It urges the Commission to implement, without delay, the points outstanding from the European Union Strategy on the Protection and Welfare of Animals 2012-2015. It also urges the Commission to evaluate the existing strategy and to draw up a new and ambitious strategy for the protection and welfare of animals for the 2016-2020 period in order to build on the work of the previous strategy and ensure the continuation of a framework for delivering high animal-welfare standards across the Member States. I believe that through such an updated policy we would not only be protecting our pets and animals closer to home but we will also be protecting all living beings and thus protecting our ecosystems and our planet. Hence I supported this resolution.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome today’s Motion for a Resolution calling on the Commission to evaluate the existing animal welfare strategy and come forward with a new strategy for 2016-2020. We have the strongest animal welfare rules in the world in Europe, but unless existing rules are properly enforced there is no point in bringing forward new legislation in this field.  So the Commission should evaluate how the current strategy has worked and where it has failed on enforcement, they should propose ways of strengthening enforcement mechanisms to ensure that legislation on animal rights is not effectively worthless.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that a new strategy for animal welfare needs to be carried out, as the current strategy ends at the end of this year and there are still a number of points to be implemented. For the time being, we want to see the implementation of the current strategy, but also the preparation of a new strategy is essential as the current strategy does not sufficiently reflect the importance of animal health for animal welfare or the link between animal health and public health.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This resolution calls on the European Commission to renew its animal welfare strategy for a period of four years. Indeed, the current strategy is expected to be completed by the end of 2015. On this issue, it is necessary to be realistic and measured in its approach. Indeed, since 2006, when the first welfare strategy was launched, many efforts have been made and Parliament has adopted a whole series of legislative acts involved in improving animal welfare, such as the zootechnical regulation, of which I am the rapporteur, the regulation on organic production, the regulation on official controls or the prohibition of the practice of cloning for commercial purposes.  This resolution is balanced as it has been possible to reject a series of excessive amendments tabled by left-wing groups. Skeptical of the implementation of horizontal legislation in this area, I have unsuccessfully opposed paragraph 3, which calls on the European Commission to adopt a comprehensive and up-to-date legislative framework on animal welfare; indeed, such a formulation may leave short any kind of interpretation. Nevertheless, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Dennis de JONG
text: Written. 'The SP Group considers it important that more protective measures should be introduced for animal welfare. However, it is necessary to weigh explicitly whether European legislation is necessary or whether it should be regulated at national level. On the basis of this principle, the SP has decided to abstain on parts of the proposal.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 Respect for and protection of animals are essential elements of today's society and must be guaranteed as an expression of great civilisation. In this respect, the European Union's strategy for 2012-2015 was certainly a step forward, but the European Commission is now called upon to draw up a new and more ambitious one, presenting a proposal for a legislative framework that is not affected by the interests of big business and that guarantees higher levels of protection and animal welfare, while also allowing greater harmonisation at Community level. Given my sensitivity on this issue and as a member of the Animal Welfare Intergroup, I nevertheless voted in favour of more ambitious amendments, with a higher animal protection content, which I regret did not obtain a majority.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. The EPP has succeeded in uniting the ALDE, CRE and S-D groups around a joint resolution; the text advocates a balanced approach to the issue of animal welfare, considering that animal welfare should continue to be improved on the basis of existing scientific knowledge and taking into account the efficiency and competitiveness of the livestock sector.  That is why I voted in favour of the resolution on the new animal welfare strategy from 2016 to 2020. On the other hand, I am opposed to an increase in European animal welfare legislation for our breeders. Before any new strategy and measure, there is a need for better compliance with current animal health or welfare regulations.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Written. The resolution on a new animal welfare strategy is a bit of a missed opportunity. The N-VA delegation supported the resolution in the final vote because it is a step forward, but we lack real ambition. For example, we would have liked to have seen the commercial transport of animals limited to 8 hours. We have been working for this for a long time and it is a pity that no majority was found for this. We also lack the clear will to finally arrive at harmonised identification and registration requirements for pets. However, this would be a powerful tool to curb the illegal puppy trade. We would rather see a ban on dieron-friendly practices, such as the annual traditional pilot hunt in the Faroe Islands of Denmark, and a ban on the controversial bullfights. Citizens are showing their outrage and disapproval in droves. The demand for a European action plan to combat the illegal trade in wild plants and animals has also not been met. Unfortunately, there is still a strong enforcement of the ban on illegal bird hunting. In short, I can't hide my disappointment.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, while bringing up a number of observations ahead of the plenary presentation. I would like to point out that a pre-existing strategic framework and that the proper application of existing rules must first be ensured in order to ensure better harmonisation of legislation within the internal market, without strengthening the current rules and creating new ones. I also said that well-being must be included in the scope of trade agreements (in the non-trade section) and to go further, we cannot accept free trade agreements that would not guarantee the application of this compliance with EU welfare standards to imported products.  Finally, I particularly supported point 8 of the resolution, which stresses the importance of adequate funding for the CAP, given that we need a budget that lives up to our ambitions in order to prevent the relocation of production and trade to countries or continents with lower standards of animal welfare.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the new animal welfare strategy for the period 2016-2020 because I believe that animals should be protected from harm and deeds. According to various studies, animal violence has its impact and continuation in violence against humans.  An example of inhumane treatment in Bulgaria is the carts moving on the roadway, which are towed by horses or donkeys. This happens in a European capital such as Sofia and is unacceptable. There are also reports of organized fights with pets.  I believe that a strategy and action is needed against the perpetrators of such acts, and I therefore support the joint resolution.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution concerns the implementation of a new strategy for the protection and welfare of animals for the period 2016-2020, in order to ensure the continuity and clarity of the operations necessary to achieve positive developments in EU animal welfare policy.  We are voting in favour of the proposal as a whole, as we are in favour of banning imports and trafficking of cloned animals within the Union and of implementing official controls on the stability and predictability of investment in the sector, while ensuring health. Finally, the motion for a resolution itself highlights concern about the effective implementation and enforcement of existing EU animal welfare legislation, but stresses that improving implementation and compliance with existing legislation should be a key objective for all animal health and welfare rules.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 In line with the direction of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the political resolution on the EU animal welfare strategy.  I do not consider it timely to talk about animal welfare issues at this time, when the EU faces huge challenges, such as migration and the fight against terrorism. Animal welfare standards are the most advanced and stringent in the world in the EU and I therefore do not support any effort to tighten standards or to introduce new standards. Instead, standards need to be simplified. The only reason for my support is that a large number of proposals to preserve the competitiveness of EU livestock farmers have been included in the report. On the one hand, we must also require livestock keepers from countries outside the EU to meet the same animal welfare requirements as EU standards, otherwise their products will not come into the EU. On the other hand, an adequate budget for the common agricultural policy must continue to be spent in order to ensure that farmers can comply with strict farming and livestock standards. Thirdly, we need to significantly strengthen the negotiating bargaining power of farmers in the food supply chain.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: in writing. – This resolution, ‘A new animal welfare strategy for 2016-2020’, seeks, under the guise of protecting animals, massively to extend EU regulatory control. Even if some of the proposals are worthy, the unintended consequences would be horrendous and the legal and behavioural ramifications divisive and damaging.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this motion because it was too weak. The amendments proposed by my Greens/EFA Group were rejected by Parliament. It is disappointing that the Commission has not brought forward a new strategy. I know that this is one of the issues on which my constituents in Wales feel very strongly and I have had many messages about it. In 2014 I organised a petition calling for a Commissioner responsible for animal welfare. I believe that if this had happened, we would have a strategy now.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. \u2012 The resolution follows on from the oral question i initiated earlier this year and it gives a very clear signal to the Commission that Parliament expects more and clear measures to achieve better animal welfare in the Union. The resolution contains the most important points; requirements for all measures in the current strategy to be met as a matter of urgency, requirements for a new strategy for the years 2016-2020, requirements for a legal framework for animal welfare and requirements for a definition of the concept of good animal welfare. In order to ensure a broad settlement, I chose to support the resolution and the main proposals and to vote against a number of proposals on the detailed content of a future strategy. The aim of the resolution is to call for a new strategy, not to describe in detail the content of a new strategy.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 National animal welfare standards should not be contrary to the principles of the Single European Market, which is closely related to public health and animal health. With a set of existing legislation on this subject I agree with the need to assess the current strategy and devise a new ambitious strategy for the protection and welfare of animals in order to continue the work carried out under the previous strategy and to ensure the continuity of a framework for adopting high animal welfare standards in all Member States. I would also point out the efforts already made by farmers on animal welfare in the different Member States. I voted in favour.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. \u2012 Ensuring animal welfare, in addition to having obvious ethical implications, helps to protect public health. The intensive use of animal farms and differences in the application of existing rules within individual Member States have negative effects on consumer health, but also on the proper functioning of the internal market. For these reasons too, therefore, we need to adopt a new strategy for the protection and welfare of animals based on sustainable agriculture, respectful of animals, the environment and, ultimately, man.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. The first major flaw of this resolution is the lack of recognition of the great contradiction between the increasingly liberal, market-oriented Common Agricultural Policy that pushes farmers towards intensive production models, where profit outslays animal welfare and health, and all the scientific evidence that warns us of the need to defend ecological balances, animal welfare, biodiversity and public health. It could and should have gone further, criticising and refusing the productivism of the current CAP and advocating another agricultural policy. We believe that there is a need for a legal framework that reflects the concerns of the general ity of citizens with regard to the safeguarding of animal welfare, but we have not followed all the amendments tabled.  Before condemning or prohibiting/banning more or less traditional practices, we should defend the need to ensure staff who carry out inspections, and other specialised personnel who act and are present on the ground, supporting producers such as public veterinarians and other animal health professionals. Another flaw is that due focus is not given to the reasons for the failure of the previous animal welfare strategy.  Despite its shortcomings and limitations, we recognise positive aspects in this resolution.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Although more than 30 basic animal welfare acts have been adopted in the last 30 years, many of which ensure different levels of animal protection, many existing legal acts do not recognise animals as sentient beings. The European Union must do more to ensure that current animal welfare legislation is properly enforced and implemented. It is very important that any harmonisation of the legislative framework in the future does not lead to a drop in the level of animal welfare or a reduction in ambitions to improve animal welfare. The European Commission must strengthen existing standards on the basis of updated scientific knowledge and in the light of negotiations on international trade with third countries where there is not the same level of protection.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I cannot support this report because instead of dealing only with animal welfare it has also invaded other fields such as the hunting ban.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the proposal as a whole, as I am in favour of banning imports and marketing of cloned animals within the Union and I believe that official controls should be applied for stability and predictability of investment in the sector, while ensuring health.  Finally, the motion for a resolution itself highlights the concern about the effective implementation and enforcement of existing EU animal welfare legislation, but stresses that improving implementation and compliance with existing legislation should be a key objective for all animal health and welfare rules.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I believe it is very important to draw up a new strategy for the protection and welfare of animals for the 2016-2020 period so as to ensure the continuity and clarity of operations which are essential to achieving further positive developments in EU animal welfare policy. European citizens care deeply about animal welfare and in recent years more and more people have become concerned about the ethical treatment of animals. The new strategy to improve welfare conditions for animals kept on farms, living in zoos and used for experiments must be promptly developed and effectively implemented, and the Commission must keep striving to ensure that farm animals are kept and transported under conditions that do not subject them to mistreatment, abuse, pain or suffering. The Commission must consult widely with farmers, veterinarians, animal welfare organisations and other experts to help ensure that improving living conditions for animals would also make European food and agricultural products more competitive within Europe and around the world.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that European citizens are strongly interested in animal welfare and want to be made with the right information as consumers. This information is a fundamental right of consumers within the UNION. EU legislation on animal welfare contributes to a level playing field within the Union and thus to a well-functioning internal market. Furthermore, we know that animal welfare is closely linked to animal and public health. For these reasons, I support this report in that it urges the Commission to implement without delay the unfinished issues of the EU Strategy for the Protection of Animals and Animal Welfare (2012-2015) and urges the Commission to ensure that all categories of animals, such as farm animals, wild animals, animals for research purposes, pets and aquatic animals, are covered by any harmonisation of the legal framework on animal welfare.  I also consider it important to call on the Commission to make use of the new EU reference centres for animal welfare to assist in the implementation of existing rules by disseminating information and sharing best practices, providing training to competent authorities and implementing the application of approved animal welfare indicators. Animal welfare is one of the engines of economic development.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the proposal for a Joint Resolution bearing in mind that EU citizens have a deep interest in animal welfare and wish to be able to choose more informedly as consumers. Similarly, we need to keep in mind that animal welfare is related to animal health and public health. A new strategy, ambitious and balanced at the same time, is therefore needed for the protection and welfare of animals covering the period 2016-2020 to establish stringent animal welfare standards in all Member States.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on a new animal welfare strategy for the period 2016-2020 because respect for and safety of animals is essential in today's society, which has among its requirements the care of all living beings as an expression of great civilisation. There is a need, following clear scientific evidence that has shown many problems with animal welfare, to create new instruments to meet the new responsibilities that each State has with regard to increased legal and ethical protection against animal species other than humans. The protection of animals on farms and the safety of the food supply chain must therefore be guaranteed, so there must be administrative obligations to ensure animal health and consequently public health.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ Animal welfare is a topic on which constituents from my region are continuously writing to me to demand action.  While I acknowledge the important role played by the Commission in improving animal welfare in Europe over the past years, crucial steps remain to be taken. The recognition that animals are sentient beings should be the basis of any effective piece of legislation aiming to protect the wellbeing of animals. Yet the majority of existing acts fail to recognise this key principle. While the adoption by the Commission of the Strategy on the Protection and Welfare of Animals 2012-2015 has been a crucial step in improving animal welfare, it is disappointing that only nine out of the 19 actions contained in it have been implemented. I count on the Commission to build on progress it has made with a strategy for 2016-2020 that investigates why this has been the case, and draws lessons from failure as well as success.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. ‒ In this motion for a resolution, I chose to respect the compromise reached by the four major groups in Parliament. This explains my vote against the amendments presented.  I felt that that the option of granting the broadest support and simplest resolution possible was best and I opted not to delve into specifics that ignore other equally important issues.  Similarly, I believe that many of the topics covered in these amendments, which are, of course of great importance, are at the same time of a high scientific level that would be required for an elaboration of reports and studies that supported the different positions on issues regarding animal welfare.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: in writing. ‒ Animal welfare is a crucial issue for the European Union and I have worked hard to ensure high standards are upheld. The health of livestock is essential for the success of European farming and will help maintain a good base of food production here in the EU. In addition, mistreatment of animals must be prevented and care standards must be maintained, and indeed improved. I, therefore, support an update of the EU’s Animal Welfare Strategy. However, this motion for a resolution that was presented does not offer an effective path going forward. It is more important to enforce the existing animal welfare strategy than to introduce a whole raft of new measures. In summary, I fully support the EU having an animal welfare strategy for 2016-2020, but I do not feel that the joint motion for a resolution calls for the right approach and I therefore chose to abstain from this vote.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that there is still much to be done in the field of animal welfare. The Commission must as soon as possible develop a new, ambitious post-2015 strategy containing specific objectives. Animals are still victims of violence and cruelty which we can no longer accept. We have taken a big step forward with the animal health regulation, we also need welfare legislation.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Resolution, agreed between popular, socialist, conservative and liberal, because it addresses the growing sensitivity of public opinion on animal welfare, and because we consider that it is closely linked to the issue of public health. It points out that animal welfare cannot be achieved at the cost of imposing higher expenditure and bureaucratic hurdes on farmers, the thus undermining the competitiveness of the European countryside. It urges the Commission to ensure that Member States comply with European regulations and calls for the development of scientific and technological studies to promote alternatives in animal welfare.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on a new animal welfare strategy for the period 2016-2020, as it calls on the Commission to come forward with a new proposal on this issue. It also stresses the need to continue the efforts launched in the 2012-2015 strategy and calls on the Commission to implement the missing elements of the 2012-2015 strategy without delay. I supported this document because it calls on the Commission to include animal welfare standards in the agreements negotiated with third countries.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it urges the Commission to draw up a new and ambitious EU strategy for the protection and welfare of animals and stresses that improving the enforcement of, and compliance with, existing legislation should be the key goal of all animal health and welfare rules. Labour MEPs have always been and will continue to be active in ensuring that animal rights and animal welfare are respected in the UK and across Europe.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I support the reassurance that any harmonisation of the legislative framework will not lead to a decline in animal welfare standards or a lowering of ambitions to improve animal welfare, and I agree with the call to the Commission to augment existing standards on the basis of updated scientific findings.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of Parliament’s resolution on a new animal welfare strategy 2016-2020.The resolution, which builds on the current strategy which expires this year, calls for better implementation of existing EU rules in all Member States to ensure high animal welfare standards across the EU. Even though the level of animal welfare in the EU is one of the highest in the world, this resolution aims to further improve standards through the basis of scientific findings with due regard for the efficiency and competitiveness of agricultural livestock husbandry. EU citizens have a strong interest in animal welfare and this resolution should enable them to make more informed choices as consumers.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this resolution as EU citizens have a strong interest in animal welfare and they wish to be able to make more informed choices as consumers. Animal welfare is interrelated with both public and animal health in the European Union. Where there is clear scientific evidence demonstrating animal welfare problems the Commission needs to adapt policy instruments or introduce new ones to resolve these problems.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: in writing. ‒ For the last three years I have had the privilege of serving as Honorary Vice-President of Britain’s pre-eminent animal welfare organisation, the RSPCA. In that capacity, I am proud to support today’s vote for a new and ambitious EU animal welfare strategy. Sadly, in my own East of England constituency, for the last year in which figures are available, some 232 people were convicted for animal neglect and cruelty. That is why I draw attention to paragraph 8 in particular, arguing the need for more effective implementation and enforcement of current EU legislation relating to the welfare of animals. In that context, and without seeking to politicise an organisation which remains absolutely true to its charitable status, I do want to place on record my deep concern at Conservative attempts to prevent the RSPCA from undertaking its prosecutory role. Animal cruelty is a crime. The RSPCA has an outstanding record for prosecuting those responsible for animal cruelty. It is the perpetrators of animal cruelty who have to be stopped, not those who prosecute them.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I would like to reiterate the need to implement the points outstanding from the European Union Strategy for the Protection and welfare of Animals 2012-2015. There is also a clear need for a new strategy for the protection and welfare of animals for the years 2016-2020. High animal welfare standards are needed across all Member States.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's resolution on the new animal welfare strategy for 2016-2020, as I think it is necessary for the Commission to prepare and present a new approach to animal welfare for the next four years. In this context, account should be taken of, inter alia, the attitude towards wild animals and the fact that domestic animals are often not treated adequately. Animals are beings who certainly feel suffering, pain and other emotions, and therefore I believe that a concrete strategy for 2016-2020 needs to be realised at EU level in order to address this issue appropriately.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This text calls for the reciprocity of standards in trade treaties and the impossibility of challenging them in trade negotiations.  This is the guarantee for us to maintain high standards and to protect our farmers, a way to stop the TTIP negotiations. I voted for it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – This resolution, ‘A new animal welfare strategy for 2016-2020’, seeks, under the guise of protecting animals, massively to extend EU regulatory control. Even if some of the proposals are worthy, the unintended consequences would be horrendous and the legal and behavioural ramifications divisive and damaging.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution for a new animal welfare strategy from 2016 to 2020. The priorities of the EU's animal welfare strategy should be the dissemination of good practices and better enforcement of legislation in the Member States. The European Parliament is also calling on the Commission to integrate animal welfare into its international negotiations and into the financing of the common agricultural policy. This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Jarosław KALINOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Animal welfare has been a very popular issue recently and relates not only to breeding rules, but also to the provision of comprehensive veterinary care to animals, including regular vaccination, adequate transport conditions and humane slaughter. Against this background, the rations of animal rights activists and producers clash. It is in the interest of the breeder to sell as much as possible at the least cost, which unfortunately can lead to abuse of inappropriate living or medical conditions. Leaving aside the moral dimension of such actions, this may result in a reduction in the quality of meat and other products of animal origin. It should be remembered that the more comfortable the living conditions of animals, the higher the quality will have products from them. There is also a second extreme: if the highest possible standards were introduced and enforced, production costs would increase several times, leading to higher prices and, consequently, primarily impacting consumers. In this case, it is necessary to examine all the fores and cons. It is only on this basis that legislation should be drawn up which will benefit animals, breeders and, above all, consumers.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I agree with this report. Animal welfare in Europe needs to be improved and the definition of 'good animal husbandry' must be clarified so that there are effective minimum standards of protection. On the other hand, taking into account careful animal welfare, which also involves necessary interventions in nature, such as hunting, we must not over-regulate excessively and unnecessarily. As the final version of the report takes sufficient account of this idea, I can vote in favour.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution as it urges the Commission to draw up a new and ambitious EU strategy for the protection and welfare of animals and stresses that improving the enforcement of, and compliance with, existing legislation should be the key goal of all animal health and welfare rules. Labour MEPs have always been and will continue to be active in ensuring that animal rights and animal welfare are respected in the UK and across Europe.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote in favour of this motion for a resolution on the animal welfare strategy for the period 2016-2020. Animal welfare plays an important role in EU policies. The safety of the food chain is indirectly affected by the welfare of animals, in particular those reared for food production, due to the close link between animal welfare, animal health and food poisoning. Stressors and poor welfare conditions can result in animals and, indirectly, on the end consumer, a greater predisposition to disease. I therefore call on the Commission to review the existing strategy and to develop a new and more ambitious one in order to improve today's quality standards of farming and the level of food safety.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it effectively and reasonably protects animal welfare. Having been a volunteer member of a SPA (independent of the one in Paris) for more than ten years, I am particularly committed to the defence of animals. Moreover, this resolution has the immense merit of calling for respect and reciprocity of these standards of protection in free trade treaties. Not sure, however, that the United States agrees with the TAFTA!

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because it contains an essential article. The Commission calls on the Commission to enact ambitious animal welfare standards, and above all to take into account the reciprocity of these standards. In the context of the TTIP negotiations, I see it as an attempt to preserve the interest of our breeders. While it is essential to put in place strict standards on this subject, it is equally important that these standards are respected by the third countries with which we trade. Our breeders are binding on respect for animals, our slaughterhouses are also subject to strong rules, so it is right that livestock and slaughter in the United States comply with the same rules, or risk creating totally unfair competition.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The level of animal welfare protection in the European Union is among the highest in the world. However, there is still room for further improvement. I supported a European Parliament resolution calling on the Commission to draw up a new strategy for 2016-2020 that sets new standards in the protection of animal welfare in the Member States. Animal welfare should be further improved on the basis of existing scientific research, but also taking into account the welfare of citizens' pets and the efficiency and competitiveness of livestock farming. It is important that national animal welfare rules do not contravene the principles of the EU single market.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. – Animal welfare in several perspectives affects public health. The European Union has some of the strictest animal welfare rules. I consider it essential that these conditions are not reduced in the future and that the Commission prepares legislation in this area for 2016-2020 that responds promptly to the latest scientific research.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on the new animal welfare strategy 2016-2020, because it is complete and documented, and for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 23/11/2015.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this resolution which emphasises that European citizens have a strong interest in animal welfare and wish to be able to make more informed choices as consumers.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on a motion for a resolution on the new animal welfare strategy 2016-2020. Of course, I am not opposed to quality animal welfare and the proposal put forward contains a number of positive points and planned steps, but there are still a few proposals that cannot be supported from my point of view. E.g. a ban on hunting, which has a long historical tradition in the Czech Republic, with the fact that hunting over-breeding animals is of course beneficial. Furthermore, entrenching the obligation to kill fish only under anesthesia, so we would probably be forced to forgive our traditional Christmas carp, and last but not least, a total ban on animal research. I was therefore not able to identify with the proposal overall and abstained in the final vote.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 Animal welfare is closely linked to animal health and public health and is also key to ensuring sustainability. It is true that national animal welfare rules, due to their complexity and differing interpretations, create legal uncertainty and can cause producers in some Member States a serious competitive disadvantage. A lack of compliance with the rules and the absence of a legislative roadmap distort competition. In order to avoid these problems, I believe it is necessary to propose, on the one hand, a harmonised legislative framework, on the other, to take legal action against Member States that do not comply with the relevant legislation. That is the purpose of the motion for a resolution, and I am therefore totally in favour of it.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. A ban on painful practices such as stuffing ducks and geese for the production of liver pate, the culling of tails and the trimming of beaks, the dehorning of livestock or the keeping of calves in cages is to be welcomed.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because the implementation, management, reporting and control of the European Structural and Investment (ESI) Funds are still difficult for both beneficiaries and managing authorities, in particular those with limited administrative and financial capacity. In its resolution, the European Parliament asks the Commission to provide guidance to Member States and regions on how control, monitoring and reporting activities can be streamlined and simplified, including requirements for beneficiaries, in order to address existing weaknesses.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the motion for a resolution on a new animal welfare strategy, but believe implementation of existing rules is necessary before contemplating new measures.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This report welcomes the fact that "the level of animal welfare in the EU is one of the highest in the world". It therefore logically stresses that support for European agriculture "prevents the relocation of production and trade to countries or continents where animal welfare standards are lower". There is still a long way to go. And while the rapporteur welcomes Parliament's 'adoption of legislation on animal welfare issues, such as animal health, zootechnical conditions, biological production and official controls', I would like to point out that the European Commission is constantly promoting farming methods that are contrary to animal welfare. For example, the latest recommendations for pig farms that value the "full-size" system. I vote for this text, despite its timidity and hypocrisy.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of motion-to-resolution RC B8-1278/2015 on a new animal welfare strategy for the period 2016-2020. This resolution is the most comprehensive and which effectively demonstrates the reality of the EU in terms of a new strategy for animal welfare. The level of animal welfare in the EU is in fact one of the highest in the world. And you can't go back. To this end, the European Commission should adapt policy instruments or introduce policy instruments where it has clear scientific evidence demonstrating animal welfare problems. It will also be up to the European Commission to closely monitor the implementation of EU animal welfare legislation in the Member States.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution to emphasise the Commission’s need to implement the outstanding elements from the European Union Strategy for the Protection and Welfare of Animals 2012-2015 as well as drawing up a new strategy for the coming years so that we may ensure the continuation of high animal welfare standards across the Member States.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Written. – Parliament calls for a new and ambitious strategy for the protection and welfare of animals for the period 2016-2020, while at the same time implementing the outstanding themes of the previous strategy. European citizens attach great importance to the welfare of their animals. Whether it is the protection of farm animals or pets, enthusiasts and consumers want animals to be kept in the best conditions. In recent years, particularly in the agricultural sector, important steps have been taken to optimise animal welfare. It is therefore important to include the reciprocity of animal welfare standards in the negotiations for bilateral and international trade agreements and, equally, to include sufficient resources in agricultural policy to avoid relocation to countries and regions where less stringent standards are applied.  This resolution is the starting point for the development of a new strategy on animal welfare. A European poll will also be conducted in 2016. This survey of citizens will be of the utmost benefit in determining European animal welfare policy.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. \u2012 The issue of animal welfare is a topical and sensitive issue, as a number of diverse interests, legislation and level of conditions need to be taken into account within EU countries. I take it for granted that animal mistreatment must be prevented by setting appropriate standards of care and adjusting transport and farming conditions, which is appropriate to be tackled at European level. The challenge remains to find the right rate and to develop an effective strategy that will not become unnecessarily burdensome for farmers and producers in its implementation. Finally, I would like to point out that it is very important to continue to support European meat production that meets high standards. In this context, I would like to reiterate the fact that the European Parliament has rejected the production of meat from cloned animals.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on a new animal welfare strategy for 2016-2020 since the present strategy on animal welfare ends this year and the Commission should implement, without delay, the outstanding points from the current strategy and present a new one that would be beneficial not only for the animals, but also for EU citizens that have a strong interest in animal welfare. Animals should not be abused and should be treated with dignity and respect. We have the obligation to speak for those who have no voice. That is why I voted in favour of this extremely important resolution.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 On this subject, the ALDE, EFDD, PPE, GUE/NGL, S&D and ECR groups tabled a motion for Parliament's resolution, among which ALDE, PPE, S&D and ECR agreed on a joint compromise proposal. I supported this compromise motion.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this European Parliament resolution which proposes a new strategy for animal welfare between 2016 and 2020. I agree with this text, which proposes the introduction of a definition by the Committee on good practices in the agricultural field, but I also consider that the new strategy should not increase the administrative burden on producers. This text reminds us that they have already made a significant contribution to improving animal health by respecting a strict normative framework.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 With the adoption of this resolution, we intend to draw the Commission's attention to the failure to implement the EU Strategy for Animal Protection and Welfare 2012-2015 and urge it to develop a new and more ambitious one for the period 2016-2020.  In fact, we need to continue the work that has already been done and ensure continuity in the existing regulatory framework. Improving the application and compliance with existing legislation should be the main objective of all animal health and welfare rules in all Member States. But this is a concern that goes beyond the Community's borders: reciprocity of rules, as a non-commercial concern, must be included in our trade policy and in the negotiations on international trade agreements.  We are interested in promoting animal welfare in third countries by demanding equivalent welfare standards for imported animals and products, combined with increasingly stringent controls. We are also in favour of ensuring adequate funding for the CAP, so that the budgetary level corresponds to that of the objectives. It should be remembered that this matter is of a general nature, it is horizontal in nature and, as such, it is just as important as the provisions on agriculture, the environment or consumer protection.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. I was not able to vote for this report, but I fully support the position of the EPP Group and the French delegation to adopt this report. The European Commission first adopted an animal welfare strategy in 2006, for a period of 4 years (2006-2010). The main problem affecting animal welfare in the EU is the failure of Member States to apply EU legislation. Another obstacle to full and consistent application is that the market does not provide sufficient economic incentives for compliance. It is therefore necessary to make greater value to the education and vocational training of all stakeholders concerned and to ensure the optimal implementation of the measures already taken.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this resolution in order to maintain a cohesive and well-functioning internal market based on the EU legislation related to animal welfare, as well as to ensure that EU citizens are increasingly informed regarding their consumer choices.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this text as all our voters agree on some very clear principles which need to be reflected in the unified EU strategy on animal welfare, but also in all national legislations. Animals should not be made to suffer needlessly, regardless of cultural customs or traditions, as we are now living in a modern society. All acts related to animals, both pets and livestock, need to be properly regulated across the EU to insure a maximum level of quality of life and treatment for these animals. It is also a matter of human health – as the consumption of meat increases, animals which were mistreated, crowded, fed unhealthy feed or otherwise abused will have negative effects on the health of our citizens. Therefore, both for the sake of the animals but also of European people, this new strategy should be properly implemented by the Commission and Member States.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this motion because it contains many positive points for a real step forward in the field of animal welfare – especially as far as farm animals are concerned, the better treatment of which I have long advocated.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the report that the EU must ensure the highest level of animal welfare. In particular, it is necessary to develop a new broad strategy for the protection of animal welfare for the period 2016-2020. The legislative framework should be up-to-date, comprehensive and clear. However, administrative simplification must in no way lead to a reduction in the level of animal welfare.  The necessary approach focuses on the overall quality of animal welfare. International cooperation needs to be promoted and the Union's approach to animal welfare should be further supported. In this context, the principle of reciprocity of animal welfare standards should be included as a non-trade aspect in trade policy and negotiations on international trade agreements. In addition, the Commission should monitor more closely the implementation of EU animal welfare legislation in the Member States. I believe that alternative methods of non-animal testing should be encouraged and financed under new and existing funding schemes and the gradual cessation of animal testing should be encouraged. Effective implementation of measures to prevent cruelty and neglect of animals is essential.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece is in favour of animal welfare, but voted against the relevant resolution of the European Parliament, as it is being used as a pretext by the EU to implement its unpopular strategy. Behind the "sensitivity" for animals is the objective of developing "attractive" products - foods that will enhance "the efficiency and competitiveness of livestock production" for the monopolies of the industry.  Both the logic of the report and the proposals - amendments made within it, driven by the standards used by monopolies on the transport, installation, breeding and slaughter of animals , seek to throw out small and medium-sized farmers. At the same time, monopolies in the name of these standards will be endowed with financial aid.  In the face of these developments and in conflict with the CAP, the poor farmers, on the side of the working class and together with the other grass-roots groups, must fight for a path of development in which the rural economy, livestock production and other sectors of the economy will develop in a balanced way, on the basis of meeting popular needs and not on capitalist gain. , with release from the EU.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution, ‘A new animal welfare strategy for 2016-2020’, seeks, under the guise of protecting animals, massively to extend EU regulatory control. Even if some of the proposals are worthy, the unintended consequences would be horrendous and the legal and behavioural ramifications divisive and damaging.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Within the European Union, our animals enjoy the highest standards of welfare in the world. We must be proud of this and continue to work to ensure that the regulatory framework for animal protection is further implemented, that the European Union can serve as a model for the rest of the world and that the civilisation of a people is also measured through the level of welfare and respect for animals. I would therefore have voted in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ Over recent years, the protection and welfare of animals kept for breeding purposes has significantly increased in the European Union. Unfortunately, while most farming animals in the EU have improved their quality of life, this has unfortunately been paid for by many farmers in some cases with their reduced quality of life. Animal welfare needs to be taken care of, but at the same time these measures need to be aligned with the real opportunities of European farmers and financially adequately assisted in these efforts. This burden must not affect the competitiveness of European agricultural production, both internally and globally. This is why I believe that Europe needs a new strategic framework, but also an improved and simplified legislative framework, which the European Parliament has already asked the Commission for in its 2012 resolution.  I would also like to recall the European Parliament's call on the Commission to carry out research on the EU meat and dairy labelling scheme with a view to informing consumers about the methods of breeding and the impact of such labelling for animal welfare, which should have been followed by a legislative proposal where appropriate. I believe this would maximise the impact of consistent and transparent consumer information.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒A high level of animal welfare is essential for sustainability and animal welfare is closely linked to animal health and public health. Unfortunately, due to their complexity and different interpretations, national and EU animal welfare rules leave room for legal ambiguities and can put producers in certain Member States at a severe competitive disadvantage.  I therefore join calls on the Commission to develop a new ambitious animal protection and welfare strategy for the period 2016-2020 to continue the work started under the current strategy, which would ensure the continuation of the implementation of the framework in order to adopt high animal welfare standards in all EU Member States.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒I support the proposal for a resolution on the New Animal Welfare Strategy 2016-2020. While the previously adopted EU Animal Welfare Strategy 2012-2015 is being implemented, I think it is useful to unification of existing rules, but also to achieve higher standards, to continuously work towards improving the legal rules and measures implemented to achieve the EU's objectives in this area.  National rules must not contravene the principles of the EU single market. The regulation of animal welfare legislation contributes to building a level playing field and thus a thriving EU internal market. Given that the complexity and diversity of interpretations of national and EU animal welfare rules leave room for legal ambiguities, it is necessary to allow producers to be more informed when making decisions. Due to such ambiguities, manufacturers may be placed at a very disadvantage compared to the competition.  I support a review of the current strategy and the development of a new one, ensuring that high animal welfare standards are reached in all Member States. It is not negligible that European citizens have shown great interest in the regulation of animal welfare issues related to animal health and public health, and for these reasons it is very important to regulate this issue with quality and efficiency.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on a new animal welfare strategy 2016-2020. I do not return to the attempts of environmental groups turned into spokespersons of the anti-foie gras movements, which sought the blow before the end of the year holidays by denying the efforts made by the foie gras sector. For a party nostalgic for the slogan "it is forbidden to ban", they are the first to want.... ban everything. Fortunately, my political group, the EPP, has been able to unite several reasonable parties in the establishment of a resolution linking the interest of animal welfare, the change in our habits and, of course, also the model of society that we have built around the food chain.

name: Emil RADEV
text: in writing. \u2012 Today I voted for the European Parliament resolution calling on the European Commission to draw up a new and more ambitious strategy for the protection and welfare of animals for the period 2016-2020. related to their registration and identification, the increasing need to develop an action plan on trade and trafficking in exotic and wild animals and the welfare of animals held captive and in circuses.  In some Member States, these issues are settled to a lesser or greater extent, but while there is no single and harmonised European legislation, all issues relating to the welfare of these animals will suffer a different interpretation, which will ultimately only lead to legal uncertainty. This, in turn, would only bring losses – losses to European competitiveness, public health, and the health and well-being of the animals themselves.  In this regard, I believe that the European Commission should think carefully about these issues and present to us, in the remaining time until the end of the year, a specific and adequate policy taking into account all the problems listed by Parliament.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament's joint motion for a resolution brings together the positions of four parliamentary groups on an animal welfare strategy for 2016-2020, and calls on the European Commission to make full use of its powers in the implementation, without further delay, of the outstanding points. Given the complexity and abundance of Community animal welfare legislation, it is essential to step up efforts to improve the implementation and enforcement and control of such application in accordance with the applicable legal requirements.  Notwithstanding the foregoing, the European strategy should not burden producers with administrative burdens, nor should it reduce market stability and resulting predictability, which is the guarantor of the sector's high levels of investment. In view of the above, and sensitive to animal welfare, on the one hand, and evidence-based and scientifically supported methods and practices, on the other, I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. Co-signer of the resolution for a new animal welfare strategy for the years 2016 to 2020, I note that the plenary supported, by a very large majority of 542 votes in support, a pragmatic approach on this very important subject.  The level of animal welfare in the European Union is one of the highest in the world. It should also be stressed that new measures to improve animal welfare are being developed as the European Parliament is currently participating in negotiations to consolidate legislation on animal health, zootechnical conditions or organic production. However, I believe that the text should have been strengthened. On issues as sensitive as the protection of live animals during commercial transport, the fight against the illegal trade in wild animals, compliance with the Birds Directive or the ban on the detention of cetaceans in captivity, the European Parliament will have to be more ambitious in the future.  The European Union needs to return more broadly to the intensive farming method, which is bad for animals and the environment. And the question of the phasing out of cage systems, their replacement with practices that meet the ethological needs of animals, must no longer be taboo.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: In writing. The current strategy for animal protection and welfare 2012-2015 ends with a very mixed record: half of the planned actions have not been implemented and the Commission is not carrying out any serious new legislative proposals to harmonize animal welfare and protection in Europe. By rejecting an ambitious resolution, the political groups of the grand coalition in the European Parliament have shown themselves indifferent not only to animal suffering, but also to European citizens and consumers who are outraged at animal abuse in industrial farming, slaughterhouses and transport. Europe must legislate on this issue which affects our health, our food and our environment; we need a new action plan. We cannot tolerate in Europe unbearable practices against animals which are recognised as sentient beings by the Lisbon Treaty. The interests of large food industry groups must not take pre-miss legitimate concerns about human and animal health.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on a new animal welfare strategy. It is high time to evaluate the 2012-2015 strategy, to implement the outstanding points of the strategy without delay and to develop an ambitious new strategy for the period 2016-2020.  The Commission needs to be more ambitious and must require third countries to adopt equivalent standards for imported animals and products, with strict controls. It should also encourage the exchange of best practices and support innovation and research to develop new techniques and technologies dedicated to animal welfare.  Finally, let us not forget the need to provide the CAP with sufficient funds to prevent the relocation of production and trade to countries with lower standards.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I supported and voted on the text of this resolution, which urges the Commission to assess the current strategy and develop an ambitious new strategy for animal welfare and protection over the period 2016-2020 and to maintain a rigorous regulatory framework for animal welfare in all Member States. Animal welfare standards should not be pulled down for reasons of administrative simplification. The Commission is invited to: - to be more ambitious in taking into account the reciprocity of animal welfare standards; To promote animal welfare in third countries by requiring equivalent welfare standards for imported animals and products, with strict controls.  I also voted in favour of more ambitious amendments, such as the one calling on the Commission to guarantee the funding of scientific research on less cruel slaughter practices and to fund other methods of testing that do not use animals in order to avoid subjecting animals to significant suffering and to abolish animal testing as soon as possible. I also supported an amendment calling on the Commission to recommend to Member States that the detention of cetaceans in captivity be banned.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This joint motion for a resolution deals with the need to create a new animal welfare strategy for the period 2016-2020. It is remarkable that well-being in the EU is one of the highest in the world and, as such, it is necessary to continue to preserve this prominent place that the Union has been gaining over the last decades with its measures, which have made significant progress in this area. Animal welfare as well as informed and conscious choices by consumers are two extremely important factors, which have been taken into account in the implementation of measures contributing to the sustainability of high European standards. I agree, in particular, with the rapporteur on the need to disseminate good practice and promote animal welfare in third countries with which the EU establishes trade agreements in order to ensure that imported products follow equivalent lines of control and rigour. For this reason, I vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the new animal welfare strategy for the period 2016-2020 as I believe that there is a need for simplification and harmonisation of legislative law between the Member States of the European Union in the field of animal health and welfare. At present, the different Community and national rules not only create legal uncertainty but also lead to competitive disadvantages between producers and uncertainties of information between consumers.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Resolution, agreed between popular, socialist, conservative and liberal, because it addresses the growing sensitivity of public opinion on animal welfare, and because we consider that it is closely linked to the issue of public health. It points out that animal welfare cannot be achieved at the cost of imposing higher expenditure and bureaucratic hurdes on farmers, the thus undermining the competitiveness of the European countryside. It urges the Commission to ensure that Member States comply with European regulations and calls for the development of scientific and technological studies to promote alternatives in animal welfare.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because I believe it is necessary for the European Commission to propose a new strategy on animal welfare for the period 2016-2020, which addresses areas such as trafficking in exotic species, trophy hunting, 'cultural' practices involving animal abuse or suffering (such as bulls in the Spanish State), industrialized agri-farming, etc. A new animal welfare strategy for 2016-2020 would help us to move towards more sustainable and fair agricultural and livestock production.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite the positive animal welfare outcomes resulting from the strategy implemented by the European Commission in the period 2010-2015, there is still a wide range of opportunities for improvement. Mistakes, careless and facilitating approaches, ignorance and direct and indirect mistreatment of animals deserve a detailed reflection for a new strategy. That is why I voted positively for this motion for a resolution. Although several of the amendments tabled do me seem appropriate and deserve my agreement, in some cases I voted negative or abstaining, not because of their content, but because I believe they are out of step with the context of the document that was on the ballot, which is nothing more than a resolution of generic concepts to work on a specific strategy for the next four years. The document under discussion and vote is a document that stimulates the Commission's initiative and not the future strategy itself. In this yes many of the suggestions proposed will have their space.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this vote. I think this could lead to a new massive regulatory framework. I think the rules we currently have are adequate and that they should be enforced properly.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as I think it adequately addresses the animal welfare concerns and – particularly in Recital E – makes specific provisions for Member States not to be at a competitive disadvantage as a result of animal welfare policies.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft legislative resolution on the new animal welfare strategy 2016-2020, as we need to be able to ensure safe food of animal origin in the EU. However, we must also ensure that the new strategy does not impose additional administrative burdens and cost increases on our farmers. At the same time, I applaud farmers' efforts on animal welfare.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Recently, the sensitivity of EU citizens to animal welfare has increased. As it is important for citizens to be able to decide what foods they will consume, the Commission should proceed to develop a common strategy on the conditions under which animals are kept. I therefore agree with the EP's position, which calls on the Commission to take into account the latest results of scientific research showing shortcomings in the breeding conditions to which animals are exposed.  European legislation today is too fragmented and creates legal uncertainty that disadvantages producers and does not provide sufficient certainty for consumers. It is therefore necessary to consolidate the rules on animal husbandry in the light of new scientific conclusions. However, the Commission should first of all think that animals are often kept for mass production in conditions that are inhumane. Animal welfare should be further improved on the basis of prevailing scientific knowledge and with due regard to the efficiency and competitiveness of livestock farming in agriculture. A high level of animal welfare is important to ensure sustainability, although it is linked to investments and additional operating costs.

name: Bart STAES
text: Written. It is shameful how the European Commission deals with animal welfare. The agreements made in 2011 expire at the end of 2015 and are far from being realised. Certain agreements have hardly been transposed into legislation by the Member States. For example, animal transport (by 29 hours) in some Member States exceeds the set limit of 8 hours and lacks control. Furthermore, figures show that 15 Member States have failed to ban battery hens and 17 Member States are still allowing sow boxes. Standards have not been adopted in trade agreements, and both the Council and the Commission blocked the initiative to require dogs to be chipped. Nevertheless, the Commission remains confident that everything will be fine. The resolution, which has yet to be put to the vote, is a missed opportunity. Although the content was broadly agreed during the Intergroup on animal welfare, the largest groups have withdrawn their tails. Instead of calling for a new strategy with binding agreements and clear commitments, there were particular complaints about high administrative burdens on animal welfare. Asking for legislation without specifications is a recipe for an empty box and that's exactly what happened. That is why I voted against the resolution.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. I support this proposal for a resolution, as EU animal protection legislation contributes to a well-functioning internal market. European citizens have a great interest in animal welfare. I also support the proposal for a resolution, as national animal welfare rules must not contravene the principles of the EU single market. I consider animal welfare to be closely linked to public health. Furthermore, animal welfare needs to be further improved on the basis of prevailing scientific findings.  This resolution will contribute to a higher level of animal welfare where it is important to ensure sustainability, including investments and additional costs that are not distributed proportionally throughout the food chain.
