Due to its complexity and different interpretations of EU and national animal welfare rules, legal uncertainty is created and can put producers in individual Member States at a serious competitive disadvantage. I therefore support this motion for a resolution so as not to result in such a situation.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ The European Union's Animal Protection and Welfare Strategy 2012-2015 (COM(2012)0006) was launched with a view to setting out a clear plan for implementing European Union animal welfare policy measures. This strategy includes many aspects of Parliament's Resolution of 5 May 2010. On the Council's proposal, a new animal protection and welfare strategy has been drawn up for the period 2016-2020. The purpose of the strategy is to simplify the Legal Framework of the European Union, the continuity and clarity of operations necessary to achieve further positive developments in the field of animal protection. I support the Council's position on the drafting of a new strategy for the protection and welfare of animals for the period 2016-2020. I believe that simplifying the European Union's legal framework for animal welfare and protection will provide better conditions for their lives.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on a new animal welfare strategy for the period 2016-2020. I join the call in the resolution for the European Commission to implement as soon as possible the unasuniated points set out in the European Union Strategy for the Protection and Welfare of Animals 2012-2015 and to evaluate the existing strategy and develop a new, ambitious strategy for the protection and welfare of animals for the period 2016-2020. I also miss the more effective implementation of existing legislation.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this joint resolution on a new animal welfare strategy for 2016-2020.  Achieving the highest possible EU standards for the protection and welfare of animals and, in particular, ensuring that existing animal welfare legislation is fully implemented throughout the Member States, is something that I, and many constituents in Wales, feel very strongly about.  I therefore welcome this resolution’s call for a new and ambitious strategy to be drawn up for the years 2016-2020, to ensure the continuation of a framework to deliver high animal welfare standards across the Member States.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 There should be a ban on imports and marketing of cloned animals within the Union and formal controls should be applied for stability and predictability of investments in the agricultural sector, while ensuring health.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution, as I believe that animal welfare measures are important and that their continuity must be ensured. This is because the EU-wide animal welfare strategy also contributes to the proper functioning of the internal market. In the strategy, I believe that innovation, education and coherence between the different funds should be given a priority.  Furthermore, I think it is important to place greater emphasis on informing consumers and ensuring transparency, as we need to know whether producers are complying with animal welfare living records for food purchased. However, I note that care must be taken to ensure that these rules do not hinder the functioning of the single market. Animal welfare standards are already high in the EU, which helps to reduce the negative effects of intensive livestock farming. Raising this high level further is difficult, and let us not forget that most farm animals would not be able to survive in a domesticated natural environment. Rather, countries outside the EU should be encouraged to take over our best practices.  I agree that the Commission should draw conclusions from the 2012-2015 strategy and incorporate them into the 2016-2020 strategy to be developed so that they do not create administrative burdens and price increases for producers and consumers.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Respect for and protection of animal welfare as sentient beings is enshrined in Article 13 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU. However, it is a principle that is all too often forgotten. I voted in favour of this resolution because, despite the rejection of our amendments, it is always a step forward because the Commission is being asked to present a legislative proposal on animal welfare. We will therefore have the opportunity to resubmit our proposals. The sticking points for which we will fight again are: full compliance with Article 18 TFEI in European and national legislation; the gradual but definitive abandonment of animal experimentation respecting the demands of the "Stop Vivisection" campaign; a ban on ritual slaughter; the ban on the use of animals in circus shows and the concrete commitment to the closure of all dolphinaric dolphinarics. We voted in favour of those amendments which included a number of points dear to us, such as the illegal trade in animals and poaching.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The way a society treats animals, domestic or wild, is defining for its degree of civilization. Thus, avoiding ill-treatment of animals and recognising their rights are essential principles that deserve to be supported by the European Union. The current European regulations are insufficient and need a harmonised strategic framework for the coming period, conferred by European Parliament resolutions. This framework concerns issues relating to livestock farming, as well as environmental, public health, internal market and free movement (pets). Important problems arise from the persistence of the abominable practice of dogfighting, the presence of stray dogs in major cities, the violent killing of domestic animals, the use of animals as guinea pigs, the threat of extinction in the case of elite breeds or the use of wild animals in circuses. To avoid these practices, an integrated approach, promoted by the European Commission for the period 2016-2020 and based on rigorous scientific criteria, is needed. The current resolutions are absolutely necessary for a unified approach to the problem and for the overall improvement of the situation of animals in the territory of the Member States.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I co-signed and then voted on this resolution. We call on the Commission to ensure an up-to-date, comprehensive and clear legislative framework that ensures full implementation of the provisions of Article 13 of the EUSF. I would remind you, however, that animal welfare standards should not be pulled down for reasons of administrative simplification. The text stresses that these objectives are not mutually exclusive.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The main objective of this resolution that I supported is to urge the Commission to implement the points that are still pending from the EU Strategy on the Protection and Welfare of Animals 2012–2015 and to draw up a new strategy for 2016–2020 period. At the same time, it recalls the principle of administrative simplification and warns that the new strategy should not add more burdens on producers. Among other things, the resolution highlights the potential of EU legislation on animal welfare to contribute to a level playing field within the EU and to mitigate comparative disadvantages for producers.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported the initiative for a new Animal Welfare Strategy for the period 2016-2020, which proposed that simplifying the European Union's legislative framework for animal welfare should be a key part of the new strategy. I believe this will be of benefit not only to consumers across the European Union, but also to animal breeders. In addition to increased transparency, emphasis should also be placed on allowing more aid to be granted to breeders to meet animal housing standards, in order to comply with EU laws. On the other hand, consumers should be given more information on what animal welfare declarations mean on product labels. Increasing standards will improve the quality of animal breeding and end products, and the competitiveness of breeders in relation to imports from abroad will be achieved by promoting standards of accommodation and animal care.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the joint motion for a European Parliament resolution on a new animal welfare strategy for the period 2016-2020, as I believe that, although the level of animal welfare in the EU is one of the highest in the world, this level must also be upgraded and implemented, which have already been based in the past but unfortunately have not yet been realised. I believe that the animal welfare strategy for 2016-2020 is very important, as it also indirectly affects human health. In the new strategy, the definition of animal welfare would also contribute to the coherence of animal welfare standards in the European Union.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Resolution, agreed between popular, socialist, conservative and liberal, because it addresses the growing sensitivity of public opinion on animal welfare, and because we consider that it is closely linked to the issue of public health. It points out that animal welfare cannot be achieved at the cost of imposing higher expenditure and bureaucratic hurdes on farmers, the thus undermining the competitiveness of the European countryside. It urges the Commission to ensure that Member States comply with European regulations and calls for the development of scientific and technological studies to promote alternatives in animal welfare.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ While European legislation in the field of animal welfare contributes to equal conditions of competition in the European Union and to the smooth functioning of the internal market, and European citizens have a deep interest in the welfare of animals, this is a public health issue and therefore I gave my support to this motion.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Animal welfare should be further improved in accordance with current scientific knowledge, taking into account the efficiency and competitiveness of agricultural livestock production. The definition of good animal husbandry would favour the development of uniform animal welfare standards across the EU. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Resolution, agreed between popular, socialist, conservative and liberal, because it addresses the growing sensitivity of public opinion on animal welfare, and because we consider that it is closely linked to the issue of public health. It points out that animal welfare cannot be achieved at the cost of imposing higher expenditure and bureaucratic hurdes on farmers, the thus undermining the competitiveness of the European countryside. It urges the Commission to ensure that Member States comply with European regulations and calls for the development of scientific and technological studies to promote alternatives in animal welfare.

name: Vladimir URUTCHEV
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported parliament's joint motion for a joint resolution on a new animal welfare strategy 2016-2020, as I believe that a single legislative framework at European level is needed to strengthen the common understanding of animal welfare. This framework should cover the different aspects of legislation, including animal health, zootechnical conditions, organic production and official controls. The pan-European approach will not only strengthen the competitiveness of the internal market, but will also give a clear signal to third-country trading partners to comply with equivalent standards with regard to imported animals and products. The high level of European standards is directly related to the quality of products of animal origin and thus to consumer confidence. Adequate funding for animal welfare activities can be provided under the common agricultural policy in order to prevent the shift of production and trade to countries with lower standards in this field. Further incentives under the Common Agricultural Policy for investments in agricultural holdings are needed in order to improve animal welfare. This will not only make final production more competitive on the market, but will also improve the situation of producers in the supply chain.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. We are talking about a resolution calling on the Commission to update the animal welfare strategy for the period 2016-2020 in line with Article 13 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. The animal welfare requirements, legal or administrative provisions and the customs of the Member States in this area, need to continue to be respected. It is also necessary for institutions to take animal welfare into account when negotiating treaties with third countries. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because I believe it is necessary for the European Commission to propose a new strategy on animal welfare for the period 2016-2020, which addresses areas such as trafficking in exotic species, trophy hunting, 'cultural' practices involving animal abuse or suffering (such as bulls in the Spanish State), industrialized agri-farming, etc. A new animal welfare strategy for 2016-2020 would help us to move towards more sustainable and fair agricultural and livestock production.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of a new animal welfare strategy for 2016-2020. It is imperative that we uphold European values by protecting and safeguarding the welfare of animals. To achieve this the Commission must draw up a new and ambitious plan. In its response where there is clear scientific evidence demonstrating animal welfare problems the Commission must be flexible in its adaption of existing instruments to meet these issues. The promotion of innovation and research on the development of new animal welfare techniques and technologies is also vital to ensuring, so far as possible, good treatment of animals in these situations. There has been good progress on this recent years, but we need to go further in the years to come.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I voted in favour of this resolution calling for a new animal welfare strategy. As an animal lover, I believe that this resolution sends a very clear signal to the Commission that we in the European Parliament expect more clear measures to ensure better animal welfare in our European Union.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. For more than 30 years, the EU has been developing legislation to better protect animals. More than thirty texts providing for varying degrees of animal protection have already been produced, but their implementation and application in the Member States remains very irregular.  The European Union's strategy for the protection and welfare of animals for the period 2012-2015 set out some 20 priority actions, but only nine of them have been carried out by the Commission so far. This framework needs to be renewed and updated to address the sector's challenges. Unfortunately, the resolution that has been proposed to us is not up to what we would expect.  My group, the GUE/NGL, had tabled, together with the Greens, a number of amendments to take into account the protection of animals in the areas of livestock, transport and slaughter. All of these amendments were rejected.  This resolution is therefore only a declaration of good intentions without real measures and actions. So I abstained.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. The attacks on animal welfare are a consequence of agriculture increasingly subject to the logic of profit in an increasingly competitive global market. The absurd levels of productive intensity that we have in the European Union, whether at the level of laying hens or in the intensive production of pigs, birds or rabbits, are not the result of any whim on the part of our farmers. It is a contingency that forces them to maximise animal productivity, even if they simply fail to guarantee the profitability of their farms. It is this contradiction that is yet to be resolved. A contradiction between an increasingly liberal, market-oriented CAP that pushes farmers to production models where profit overlaps with animal welfare, and all the scientific evidence that alerts us every day to the need to stop this madness. Stop in the name of animal welfare, biodiversity and public health. It is therefore important to extend our agricultural equation to other social and environmental variables in the name of the survival of our planet.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. A ban on painful practices such as stuffing ducks and geese for the production of liver pate, the culling of tails and the trimming of beaks, the dehorning of livestock or the keeping of calves in cages is to be welcomed.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: Written. \u2012 Civilised society also takes care of its weakest. Animal welfare is an issue to which the whole of Europe must pay more attention. Unfortunately, many Member States have not even implemented the current, rather light animal protection regulation. Problems in intensive production and outright atrocities are still common in, for example, meat cattle production. Domestic animals suffer in many Member States because the ways of curbing stray dog populations, for example, are downright barbaric. It is up to the legislators, the Commission and the Member States to ensure that these shortcomings are addressed without delay. Culturally, there should be no excuse, let alone support through agricultural aid, production methods or the killing of animals for entertainment purposes. Investments in animal welfare do not always mean higher production costs in agriculture. Often, productivity is also improved, the use of drugs decreases and chick mortality decreases when the requirements of species-specific behaviour of animals are better taken into account. It would also be important to note that consumers are prepared to pay more for products where attention has been paid to animal welfare. In my country, Finland, for example, 70% of consumers see the conditions under which farmed animals are housed as problematic. One solution would be to create common, species-specific criteria for animal welfare. A consumer interested in ethical consumption would benefit from a label that would guarantee even a reasonable level of keeping of animals. At the same time, producers would not have to compete with unfair production methods, but could invest in quality and well-being.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the proposals to improve animal welfare, as animal welfare has traditionally been a core concern of national homeland security policy and therefore any initiative aimed at improving deserves support. Gandhi put it aptly when he said, "The greatness and moral progress of a nation can be measured by how it treats animals." Europe should also be able to be judged by such standards.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the motion for a resolution on a new animal welfare strategy for the period 2016-2020. The measures seem to me to be balanced. I rejected the amendments tabled by the Left and the Greens with a view to improving the protection of certain animals – fish, pigs, laying hens, hunting deer, etc. – because they have always called for action from the European Commission. However, I am opposed to greater shifts of competences to the EU. So I do not rule out the possibility that I could support individual projects at national level. However, the EU should live on its diversity, which is best ensured by finding different solutions to issues that are difficult to deal with and which are controversial.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the adoption of the resolution on a new animal welfare strategy 2016-2020. I find the passage expressing concern about the excessive complexity and the large number of legislative acts regulating the subject particularly appropriate. I would like to stress the importance of ensuring animal welfare and compliance with animal health standards, but I would remind you that, for this to happen, simple and clear legislation is needed. It is now important for the European Commission to present a new and ambitious strategy for 2016-2020, a framework that I hope will be able, in the sign of continuity with the previous regulatory framework, to guarantee Europe the highest standards of animal protection in the world.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I have decided to support this resolution, which calls on the Commission to prepare a new ambitious animal welfare strategy. I believe that a level playing field across the Union and thus the promotion of the internal market are necessary in this area. One of my priorities is also to promote consumer protection, and I believe that such a strategy will also contribute to ing consumers to make more informed choices so that they can better exercise their rights. Finally, but not in the last place, I supported this resolution because animal welfare is linked to animal health and ultimately to public health, that is, the health of all of us.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 The first major flaw of this resolution lies in the absence of recognition of the great contradiction between the increasingly liberal, market-oriented Common Agricultural Policy that pushes farmers towards intensive production models, where profit outsof animal welfare and health, and all the scientific evidence that alerts us to the need to defend ecological balances , animal welfare, biodiversity and public health. It could and should have gone further, criticising and refusing the productivism of the current CAP and advocating another agricultural policy. We believe that there is a need for a legal framework that reflects the concerns of the general ity of citizens with regard to the safeguarding of animal welfare, but we have not followed all the amendments tabled. Despite its shortcomings and limitations we recognise positive aspects in this resolution.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the animal welfare resolution because I believe that animals must be respected and protected as sentient beings as laid down in Article 13 TFEI. I am convinced that we must abandon the hypocrisy that allows 'for scientific reasons' thousands of animals to be horridly sacrificed for the testing of medicines and other products, when we now know that this is an unnecessarily cruel practice that does not even produce certain results. In the same way, we cannot continue to allow too many animals to be exploited in circuses for the amusement of an audience that cannot understand the suffering behind a life that is unnatural to them. Nor can we accept religious reasons for allowing animals to be slaughtered in barbaric manners that cause them atrocious suffering. I believe that the time has come to address this issue by demonstrating the maturity of our degree of civilisation and, although I welcome this vote, I regret that the amendments we tabled, which would have helped to improve and make the text even stronger, have been rejected.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a European Parliament resolution on a new animal welfare strategy for the period 2016-2020, as I believe it proposes reasoned calls for the Commission to address fully the problems of the environment and public health arising from the lack of concern for animal welfare. Among other things, the motion for a resolution calls on the Commission to support the development of a new sustainable food policy that would accept an increase in animal welfare on farms in connection with the expansion of plant-based food and consumption.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, dar ndóigh vótáil mé i bhfabhar na tuarascála seo chomh maith, agus mar iarmhúinteoir mé féin tuigim chomh tábhachtach is atá oideachas. Dá lán daoine is é an t-aon seans atá acu éalú ó bhochtanas, a gcearta polaitiúla, sóisialta agus eacnamaíochta a chur i bhfeidhm, agus dar ndóigh jab a fháil sa saol.  Ach tá suas le billiún leanaí óga in áiteanna ina bhfuil cogadh, foréigean agus easaontas ar siúl agus níl an seans acu dul ar scoil agus caithfimid ár ndícheall a dhéanamh chun cabhrú leo, go háirithe chun go bhféadfaidh siad dul ar scoil agus go mbeadh na múinteoirí in ann iad a mhúineadh agus iad a chosaint. Agus caithfimid gach iarracht a dhéanamh chun é sin a chur i bhfeidhm sna tíortha seo.  Dar ndóigh tá straitéis 2020 againn, agus táimid ag cur béim ansin ar sheans a thabhairt do gach uile dhuine ní amháin dul go dtí an bhunscoil, ach an mheánscoil agus an scoil tríú leibhéal comh maith. Is sin mar ba chóir.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I would like to highlight the problem of youth radicalisation in the field of education. Radicalisation of those children who have no future in education here. And to draw attention to the problem of children now heading to Europe as part of a migration wave. We must give these children a future in education, because, as my colleague Dati's report also points out, the area of prevention against the radicalisation of young people is always linked precisely to the role of the education system. I therefore supported both the Report by My Colleague Dati and this motion for a resolution, because, in my opinion, education is the most basic value that we can give to those children who are now pouring into Europe, who do not need a future, and they, when they return to the territories from which they came, will undoubtedly serve as a factor in dampening the mood in that society that is radical.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – It has already come to a historical point that children, women, old men are the ones who suffer first in almost any conflict. Quite statistically, as several colleagues have already said, around one billion children live in different types of conflict-affected areas, a quarter of them are under the age of 5, ten million children are refugees, while an additional 19 million have been displaced in their home countries. That's not normal. And I support only one conclusion – that is not normal and we need to adjust our policy. I wholeheartedly welcome the increase in the European Union's financial assistance from THE EUR 4.4 billion in the programme from 2007 to 2013 to EUR 4.7 billion for education aid in developing countries, planned for the period 2014-2020. And indeed, colleagues, if children are the future of our planet, then education is undeniably an investment for our future, both figuratively and in fact.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ This motion for a resolution calls for the EU to provide access to education for children in emergency situations. This motion for a resolution is in light of certain situations such as the Syrian civil war, which has completely demolished infrastructure in the region and has left children without education. The EU perceives this lack of education infrastructure to be a thriving ground for extremism; therefore the motion is calling for funding and an action plan for the situation. Even though we agree that education is important for children in emergency situations we do not feel it is within the remit of the EU to do this.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Union has always been committed to the protection of children and children through the signing of international and European treaties, which stipulate respect for the fundamental rights of these categories, as well as the provision of means of intervention in the event of violations of them. Education, in particular, allows the development of critical thinking, the creation of the citizens of tomorrow, as well as a conscious knowledge of their rights. Ensuring educational and educational continuity for refugee, displaced or otherwise resident children in crisis areas can be a form of support not only at school, but also psychological and humane. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – This motion for a resolution calls for the EU to provide access to education for children in emergency situations. This motion for a resolution is in light of certain situations such as the Syrian civil war, which has completely demolished infrastructure in the region and has left children without education. The EU perceives this lack of education infrastructure to be a thriving ground for extremism; therefore the motion is calling for funding and an action plan for the situation. Even though we agree that education is important for children in emergency situations we do not feel it is within the remit of the EU to do this.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this Resolution, although I welcome the call made by this Resolution to the European Commission to increase the level of humanitarian aid funds earmarked to support the education of children affected by humanitarian emergencies and protracted crises, while calling on host countries to make an effort for better integration into their education systems. The final text of the Resolution gives the private sector a "crucial" role in education systems. The right to quality education with universal access to all with the private business of a few is unacceptable and incompatible. Therefore, throughout the process of adopting this Resolution, we have defended the need to make this Resolution a clear appeal and commitment to public, free and universally accessible education systems for both basic and secondary and university education, which has been rejected by a majority made up of conservatives and liberals, mainly. Since my head-on refusal for the European Commission to finance private enterprises in the education sector and my commitment to public education, I abstained from voting on this Resolution.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of the resolution as it calls for an increasing share of EU humanitarian funds for the education of children in emergencies and protracted crises, and on all host countries to help integrate child refugees into their national education system.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. According to United Nations estimates, one billion children live in conflict-affected areas. Of these, 250 million are under five years of age and are denied the fundamental right to education. Sixty-five million children are between the ages of three and 15, most affected by emergencies and protracted crises, and are at risk of falling out of the education system. I therefore welcome the European Parliament's resolution on education for children in emergencies and ongoing crises.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The text underlines the importance of education in conflict zones. Indeed, education has a major role to play in the reconstruction of post-conflict societies. In addition, children with access to education are less at risk of forced marriages, early pregnancy, armed group membership, radicalization, and human trafficking. However, the text proposes to integrate teachers from displaced communities, which could generate quite logically a phenomenon of communitarianism. In addition, the text calls for the creation of 'educational corridors', which would allow students from these conflict zones to continue their studies at a European university. In these circumstances, the desire for a very long-term integration seems to supplant the original objective of temporary local aid and therefore prevents any societal reconstruction in the countries of origin. While the general idea is good, its application is nevertheless unsuitable for future issues.  So I abstained.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this resolution, because I agree with the principle of the resolution but not that it should be implemented by the European Union.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on education for children in emergencies and protracted crises. One billion children live in conflict-affected areas, of which 250 million are living in conflict-affected areas. under the age of five and are not allowed to exercise their right to education. In the long term, quality education can be an essential component in rebuilding conflict-affected societies, as it can increase children's earning opportunities, enable them to keep their families healthy and improve their ability to escape poverty. I agree that the focus must be on secondary education and vocational training, as well as basic primary education. I support the calls for Member States to draw up specific admission programmes for unaccompanied minors and single mothers with children. The EU and its humanitarian aid agencies should systematically include education and child protection throughout the disaster response cycle and ensure that flexible multi-annual crisis support funds are in place.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution underlines the importance of education in conflict zones. Is. Children with access to education are less likely to be forced marriage, early pregnancy, joining armed groups, radicalization, trafficking or other abuses. The text calls for the creation of "educational corridors" that would allow students from conflict zones to continue their studies in European universities. However, it also proposes to integrate teachers from displaced communities, which could create a phenomenon of communitarianism. That is why I chose to abstain.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. According to the United Nations, one billion children live in conflict zones, 250 million of whom are under the age of five and are deprived of their basic right to education. I have therefore, of course, supported this resolution, which underlines the importance of quality universal public education as a catalyst for development, which has a positive impact on actions in the areas of health, job creation, poverty reduction and economic development. As this report argues, education is a powerful tool, essential to create a sense of normalcy, to ensure an awareness of rights and to help children, adolescents and young people overcome trauma, reintegrate into society after conflict and acquire the skills necessary to rebuild society and promote peace-building and reconciliation.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because of the importance that education has in emergencies. If we are to achieve the ambitious Global Goal No. 4 — inclusive and quality education for all — of the 2030 Agenda, we not only need to increase its funding, it is also absolutely crucial to coordinate emergency response programming with the long-term programming required by sustainable development. On the other hand, I would like to explain my abstention in Amendment No 1 proposed by the GUE/NGL group. The initial text of paragraph 25 underlines the importance of the private sector as a potential source of innovative funding for education. That is not to say that the text bets on privatized education, as the GUE/NGL Group amendment wants to imply.  The document highlights in paragraph 1 the importance of quality universal public education as a catalyst for development. I have always advocated quality public education as the most effective tool for moving towards real equality of opportunity.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on this motion for a Resolution on Education for Children in Emergencies and Protracted Crises. The motion for a Resolution calls very positively for the increase in funds for education in emergencies, considering education as a fundamental, cross-cutting and necessary element in any humanitarian action. In addition, the report underlines the importance of public, universal and quality education - both primary, secondary and higher - for crisis overcoming and for achieving sustainable development. However, the report includes a paragraph that opens the door to the privatization of education, which we consider unacceptable.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I supported the motion for a Resolution on Education for Children in Emergencies and Prologed Crises and I welcome the work done to reach this text, which highlights the importance of quality universal public education as a catalyst for development that increases the chances of other health intreventions , sanitation, disaster risk reduction, job creation, etc. In addition, it should be noted that there should never be any discrimination against disadvantaged children, particularly those with disabilities, with regard to access to education in emergencies.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This text on the education of children in emergencies and long-term crises underlines the importance of education in conflict zones. The text reminds us of the obvious: children with access to education are less exposed to the risks of forced marriage, early pregnancy, membership of armed groups, radicalization, trafficking and human trafficking. Nevertheless, this proposal proposes to integrate teachers from the communities of displaced people, which could create a phenomenon of communitarianism.  Finally, the text calls for the creation of "educational corridors" to enable students from conflict zones to continue their studies in European universities. So I abstained.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution being voted on is acceptable and without any critical issues. I think it is important to remember the value of education and to emphasise the need for more investment in this area, targeting them to all children, but paying particular attention to the education of those living in areas of crisis or conflict. For these reasons, I supported the text with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. U2012 65 million children between the ages of three and fifteen are caught up in some kind of crisis, usually long lasting, without access to education. We're talking about more than one generation lost globally. This socialist-promoted motion for a resolution calls for an increase of humanitarian aid devoted to education in crisis situations from 1.9% to 4%, increasing the share of humanitarian aid in the 2016 budget by 26 million to ensure access to emergency education. Finally, it urges Member States to support the Commission's objective of increasing the percentage of humanitarian funds for education and to boost the creation of a comprehensive fund. The Socialists underline the importance of education as a key factor for development, job creation and poverty reduction, as well as a powerful tool to help children overcome trauma caused by conflict or other emergencies. That is why I voted favourably on this motion for a resolution.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this resolution on children's education in emergencies and protracted crises. Every child is primarily a child and should be guaranteed rights in a non-discriminatory manner, regardless of their or her or her parents' ethnic origin, nationality or social status, whether they are migrants and their status as a resident. Education is one of the fundamental rights of human rights and the right of every child; whereas education is essential for the full enjoyability of all other social, economic, cultural and political rights. The European Parliament stresses that global high-quality public education is a key factor in promoting development, improving prospects for other actions in the areas of health, sanitation, disaster risk reduction, job creation, poverty reduction and economic development. The role of education must also be emphasised, which is an effective tool for the emergence of a common understanding of what is normal, better awareness of rights and the ability to help children, adolescents and young people overcome trauma, reintegrate into post-conflict society and acquire the skills needed to rebuild their societies and promote peace-building and reconciliation. Parlkament also stresses the need to focus on secondary education and vocational training, as well as basic primary education.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The UN estimates that 1 billion children live in conflict areas, 250 million of whom are under the age of 5, and cannot exercise their fundamental right to education. Some 65 million children between the ages of 3 and 15 are at risk of being interrupted from their schooling due to protracted crises, and some 37 million children in crisis-stricken countries do not attend school but are due to their age in primary or secondary school. Add to this the fact that an estimated 175 million children are affected by natural disasters each year. Education in emergencies or precarious conditions is a specific area where humanitarian and development actors must work closely together to coordinate aid, recovery and development. I agree that the Commission should develop mechanisms for effective responses to its own and its partners' activities and participate in the work of the International Platform, which will create concrete tools for emergency education in the context of the 2016 Humanitarian Summit. I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 Investing in education means investing in the future, and the resolution adopted today is a small but important step in recognising this fundamental principle. I also very much welcome the announcement by the European Commissioner for Humanitarian Aid, Mr Stylianides, that the target of allocating 4% of the EU humanitarian aid budget to the education of children in emergency situations by 2019 is likely to be achieved as early as next year. The decision to increase this part of development aid plays an important role in reiterating that the right to education, which is held by all children and young people, is a top priority even in the most critical contexts. It is precisely in these areas that education is one of the most effective means of prevention and protection against violence, forced recruitment and tendencies to radicalisation; it is a fundamental psychological aid to guarantee children a sense of normality even in the most difficult situations and is the only means capable of providing them with prospects for the future. Education is one of the essential prerequisites for enjoying all other social, economic, political and cultural rights. We need to act quickly if we are not to be faced with other 'lost generations'.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Simple, peaceful, and shareable resolution. It recalls the value of education and calls for more investment in the sector with a particular focus on the education of children living in crisis or conflict zones. I am voting in favour.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. \u2012 In areas of the world affected by either conflict or natural disasters, children are the most disadvantaged group. The fundamental right to education is an essential factor in the training of future professionals and must be protected at all costs. We cannot afford for various political crises or wars to sacrifice generations of children, reducing their prospects through lack of schooling. Children will only be able to understand all other rights - social, economic, cultural and political - only after acquiring the education through which they will operate. Education also plays a fundamental role in creating a health consciousness, thus facilitating health and sanitation interventions. Moreover, the lack of education should not be a factor of discrimination in the future. I believe that the role of host countries and international donors is essential in providing this fundamental right through deeper involvement in education, psychological support and promoting the learning of the language of the host country, in order to ensure better integration of refugee children. I therefore support the motion for a resolution - Education for children in situations of emergency and prolonged crisis.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The United Nations has one billion children living in conflict zones. Access to education and schooling in these conflict zones is almost non-existent. When conflict persists, it means that the child is deprived of elements that are essential to his development for many years. Humanitarian and development assistance must serve an objective of schooling and proper education for children in conflict zones. In this way, children affected by the conflict will be able to more easily continue their intellectual growth once peace is restored. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the motion for a resolution, 'Education of children in emergency situations and prolonged crises' because 62 million children in the world live in areas affected by armed conflicts, are minors of primary and lower secondary age who do not attend school because they live in places affected by prolonged crises. For all children in the world living in crisis areas, the study represents not only a diversion for the present, but also an opportunity for the future. That is why the international community and the European Union have a duty to take concrete measures to ensure that these children have a future. Education in emergency situations is the sector that receives the least funding, with only two% of humanitarian aid. Unfortunately, too little is still being done.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution, which was aimed at ensuring that children living in conflict-areas have access to education.  It is truly disturbing that close to one billion children – 250 million are under the age of five – find it difficult to access education because of living in a conflict or other emergency situation.  Given our own history of conflict in Ireland and given the crucial importance that young people can play in post-conflict stability when equipped with the necessary skills, this was a particularly important resolution.  If young people are not provided with the necessary opportunities and education this increases the risks of social upheavals or slipping back into a vicious cycle of violence. A proven way of counteracting any such vacuum is through a concentrated focus on education.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ This motion for a resolution calls for the EU to provide access to education for children in emergency situations. This motion for a resolution is in light of certain situations such as the Syrian civil war, which has completely demolished infrastructure in the region and has left children without education. The EU perceives this lack of education infrastructure to be a thriving ground for extremism; therefore the motion is calling for funding and an action plan for the situation. Even though we agree that education is important for children in emergency situations we do not feel it is within the remit of the EU to do this.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I understand that education is a key for development that can help children to earn potential in order to escape from a poverty cycle. Europe needs to help the most vulnerable to ensure that a poverty cycle does not grow.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The figures are attached: according to UN estimates, 1 billion children live in conflict zones, of which 250 million are under five years of age and are denied the fundamental right to education; some 65 million children between the ages of 3 and 15 are affected by emergency situations and prolonged crises and are at risk of interrupting their education, while some 37 million children of primary and lower secondary age are not educated in crisis-affected countries. I can only vote in favour of a resolution which directs the international community to see education as a central element of its humanitarian response, since it is a catalyst capable of increasing the effectiveness of the entire humanitarian response and also of contributing to the medium and long-term development of the populations concerned.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The resolution calls on the Commission and the Member States to open 'corridors' so that pupils from war zones, in particular Syria, Iraq and Eritrea, can be admitted to universities. It also calls on the EU and its humanitarian organisations to systematically integrate education and child protection into the overall emergency response cycle and to ensure flexible multiannual resources for prolonged crises. We support the resolution positively.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution on the education of children in emergencies and prolonged crises highlights an issue of major importance. An estimated 65 million children are affected by emergencies, while 37 million children do not attend school due to prolonged crises. The resolution highlights the catalytic role that education can play in development. In particular, quality education can be a key element in rebuilding post-conflict societies, as well as helping children escape the cycle of poverty. However, an amendment that I co-signed and stressed the crucial importance of public funding and public education planning, in order to effectively ensure universal access for all, was rejected at the vote, which is why I abstained from the final vote.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I decided to vote in favour of the measure. According to UN estimates, one billion children live in conflict zones. Education is a fundamental human right of every child and is a key element in the full enjoyment of all other social, economic, cultural and political rights, as well as being an essential tool for the emancipation of the female figure. In the period 2014-2020, the European Union will invest EUR 4.7 billion in education in developing countries, an increase from the EUR 4.4 billion invested in the period 2007-2013. Parliament stressed the importance of high-quality universal public education as a catalyst for development, which could improve the prospects for success of other Union interventions. It calls on the European Union and its Member States to consider these objectives as the main priority of their internal policies and in their relations with third countries. It calls on the Eu ropean Union and the Member States to include the education of children among the priorities when allocating resources from union trust funds. Parliament called on the Member States to support the Commission's objective of increasing the share of humanitarian funds allocated to education in emergency situations.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ This motion for a resolution calls for the EU to provide access to education for children in emergency situations. This motion for a resolution is in light of certain situations such as the Syrian civil war, which has completely demolished infrastructure in the region and has left children without education. The EU perceives this lack of education infrastructure to be a thriving ground for extremism; therefore the motion is calling for funding and an action plan for the situation. Even though we agree that education is important for children in emergency situations we do not feel it is within the remit of the EU to do this.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. According to UN estimates, one billion children, 250 million of whom are under the age of five, live in conflict-affected areas and are denied their fundamental right to education. Education is a fundamental human right and a right that assists all children. Education is essential for the full exercise of all other social, economic, cultural and political rights.  At a time when Europe is in the face of the refugee crisis, the Commission and the Member States should support refugee students and create "teaching corridors" for students from conflict countries. I agree and support the announcement by the Commissioner for Humanitarian Aid and Crisis Management to dedicate 4% of the EU Humanitarian Aid Budget to the education of children in emergency by 2019. In the face of the increasing humanitarian crises, the international community should consider education as a central element of its humanitarian response, as education is a catalyst, capable of improving the effectiveness of the global response and contributing to the medium and long-term development of affected populations.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the resolution because we need to find ways to integrate the most vulnerable among refugees as far and as quickly as possible. This can only be done through unrestricted access to education and learning and learning about our language, our social systems and cultures.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. Education is a fundamental human right and a right of every child and is a key element for the full enjoyment of all other social, economic, cultural and political rights. Nowadays, many children living in conflict zones are denied the fundamental right to education or risk interrupting their school career due to prolonged tensions within the area in which they reside. I firmly believe that education is the foundation of responsible citizenship and that it can transform a society and contribute to social, economic and political equality. Unfortunately, however, in emergency situations, the objective of providing quality education is not always a priority for humanitarian responses. Given that each child is first and foremost a child whose rights must be respected without discrimination, I support this motion for a resolution which considers education to be a priority in countries in difficulty, not only primary but also secondary. I believe that it is a good proposal to create 'educational corridors' to facilitate the reception in universities of students from countries in conflict and I am in favour of increasing humanitarian funds allocated to education in emergency situations.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ Education during emergencies and crisis situations is the most underfunded sector. Children, adolescents and young people face increasing threats and are disproportionally affected in the event of crisis. Out-of-school children face a higher risk of early marriage and pregnancy, recruitment into terrorist groups, and being trafficked and they face labour exploitation. We need to bridge the gap and improve the future prospects of children through humanitarian aid and development cooperation measures. Paragraph 25 highlights the need to bring together private investments and public finances in vocational and educational training (VET). This is needed also in developed countries. The GUE amendment is also true but not to the exclusion of the original text.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 The oral question (O-000147/2015 (DEVE) and the resolution (pending LV) focus on the situation of children in emergency situations and protracted crises. I am voting in favour given the very nature of the report, which seeks to ensure greater attention to children and ensure that they are continuously education, psychological support, an emergency response and consolidated and safe humanitarian aid.  It helps to safeguard refugee children, displaced children or children living in places where there is a lack of political stability, providing them with psychological support, but above all continuous education in order to protect and safeguard the common good, but also to know and enforce their rights.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this Resolution, although I welcome the call made by this Resolution to the European Commission to increase the level of humanitarian aid funds earmarked to support the education of children affected by humanitarian emergencies and protracted crises, while calling on host countries to make an effort for better integration into their education systems. The final text of the Resolution gives the private sector a "crucial" role in education systems. The right to quality education with universal access to all with the private business of a few is unacceptable and incompatible. Therefore, throughout the process of adopting this Resolution, we have defended the need to make this Resolution a clear appeal and commitment to public, free and universally accessible education systems for both basic and secondary and university education, which has been rejected by a majority made up of conservatives and liberals, mainly. Since my head-on refusal for the European Commission to finance private enterprises in the education sector and my commitment to public education, I abstained from voting on this Resolution.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ Millions of children around the world are being deprived of an equal shot at life because of conflict, poverty, protracted crises, lack of education and natural disasters. This resolution stresses the importance of universal high-quality public education as a catalyst for development, which improves prospects in the areas of health, sanitation, disaster risk reduction, job creation, poverty reduction and economic development. It also highlights education’s role as a powerful tool that is necessary in order to give a sense of normality, to raise awareness of rights and to help children overcome trauma, reintegrate themselves after conflicts, and acquire the skills needed to rebuild their societies and promote reconciliation. It calls on the Commission and the Member States to establish ‘education corridors’ to ensure that students from countries in conflict, in particular Syria, Iraq and Eritrea, are accepted in universities. It also calls for the EU to include education in the whole emergency-response cycle. It is through such initiatives and actions that we can really start changing the destiny of these individuals. Hence I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the European Union must work with partner countries, other donors, the private sector and civil society to improve young people's education prospects in conflict and emergency situations, given the crucial importance of the stabilising role that young people can have after the end of conflicts thanks to their eventual skills acquired to restore infrastructure, basic services , health and educational care systems, as well as to reduce the risks of a young population without occupation causing social unrest or slipping back into the vicious circle of violence.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This resolution calls on Member States to support the European Commission's objective of increasing the share of humanitarian funds for the education of children in emergency situations to 4% (of humanitarian aid). It also stresses the importance for all host countries to help integrate refugee children into their national education systems.  An estimated 65 million children are affected by emergencies and long-term crises in 35 countries, and about 37 million children of primary or lower secondary school age are out of school in crisis-affected countries. However, education in emergencies is the most underfunded sector, with only 2% of humanitarian aid allocated to these needs. Considering that education is one of the strongest instruments to get children, and any individual, out of an unfavourable situation, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. In situations of crisis and conflict, education is the most neglected area. Education and schooling for children are priorities because they help to train the citizens of tomorrow. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution for an increase in humanitarian aid for the education of children and a better integration of refugee children into the education systems of the Member States.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 Today, around 65 million children live in crisis areas where they do not have access to adequate education due to the situation, because in these regions the sector is typically underfunded. The aim of the motion is to encourage Member States to support the European Commission's proposal to increase the share of EU humanitarian aid for education to 4%. The motion also calls on Member States to help integrate refugee children they receive into their national education systems. High-quality education must be a priority in crisis and disaster zones, as this could be the key to the recovery and stabilisation process after the crisis in the longer term. In addition, strengthening education can play a significant role in preventing children from falling victim to radicalisation, which can put them in the hands of terrorist groups and armies. Access to adequate education can also be an important tool in the fight against poverty. In agreement with the above objectives, following the people's party line, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I supported the resolution calling on Member States to support the objective of increasing the share of EU humanitarian funds for the education of children in emergency situations to 4%. According to UN estimates, one billion children live in areas affected by conflict, emergencies and prolonged crises. Many of them are deprived of their fundamental right to education or run the risk of having their schooling interrupted. The resolution also calls on all host countries to ensure that refugee children have full access to education, preferably through their integration into national education systems.  I consider this to be a top priority because education not only ensures a higher level of integration but also breaks the spiral of violence. It is through education that we can hope to reduce the risk of ending up with a young, unemployed population, causing social upheaval or falling back into a vicious cycle of violence. Lifelong learning will also limit opportunities for young people to get involved in armed groups or engage in extremism.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – Today, around 65 million children live in crisis areas where they do not have access to adequate education because of the situation, in which the sector is typically underfunded. The aim of the motion is to encourage Member States to support the European Commission's proposal to increase the share of EU humanitarian aid for education to 4%. The motion also calls on Member States to help integrate refugee children they receive into their national education systems. High-quality education must be a priority in crisis and disaster zones, as this could be the key to the recovery and stabilisation process after the crisis in the longer term. In addition, strengthening education can play a significant role in preventing children from falling victim to radicalisation, which can put them in the hands of terrorist groups and armies. Access to adequate education can also be an important tool in the fight against poverty. In agreement with the above objectives, following the people's party line, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Ian DUNCAN
text: in writing. ‒ I support efforts that will help vulnerable children of refugees to continue their education despite the crisis. I support academic progress and employment that will enable them to prosper, make a contribution to the region, and eventually return to rebuild their torn countries. The UK Government has already given thousands of refugees the chance to continue their schooling.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I support this resolution and believe that there must be a strategy that ensures the education of children in emergencies. Education is a guarantee of development and has its influence in the widest range of areas of our daily lives. It is also a guarantor of a good future. It cannot be allowed to go back and raise the level of illiteracy, it would be detrimental to our society. When immigrants fleeing conflict are admitted to the EU, all those who have gained status must receive an education with us because their entry into our society is mandatory. Otherwise, marginalisation can only deepen, and this leads to many subsequent problems, especially radicalisation , the most recent threat of the moment, which has been rooted in the Western world for many years and deepened by the lack of a strong and decisive policy of Western countries.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Education, and in particular high-quality public education, is a catalyst and basis for reducing unemployment and poverty, developing and lifting the economy. However, the fact that humanitarian aid is needed in countries that have suffered wars and disasters is not enough if it is not accompanied by the assumption that the EU should not finance actions designed to relieve countries destroyed by political interests, especially Western countries.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 Today, around 65 million children live in crisis areas where they do not have access to adequate education due to the situation, in which the sector is typically underfunded. The aim of the motion is to encourage Member States to support the European Commission's proposal to increase the share of EU humanitarian aid for education to 4%. The motion also calls on Member States to help integrate refugee children they receive into their national education systems. High-quality education must be a priority in crisis and disaster zones, as this could be the key to the recovery and stabilisation process after the crisis in the longer term. In addition, strengthening education can play a significant role in preventing children from falling victim to radicalisation, which can put them in the hands of terrorist groups and armies. Access to adequate education can also be an important tool in the fight against poverty. In agreement with the above objectives, following the people's party line, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: in writing. – This motion for a resolution calls for the EU to provide access to education for children in emergency situations. This motion for a resolution is in light of certain situations such as the Syrian civil war, which has completely demolished infrastructure in the region and has left children without education. The EU perceives this lack of education infrastructure to be a thriving ground for extremism; therefore the motion is calling for funding and an action plan for the situation. Even though we agree that education is important for children in emergency situations we do not feel it is within the remit of the EU to do this.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 According to UN estimates, one billion children, 250 million of whom are under the age of five, live in conflict-affected areas and are denied their fundamental right to education; around 65 million children aged 3 to 15 are particularly affected by emergencies and prolonged crises, at the risk of interrupting their school ingenuity, and around 37 million children of primary school age and the early years of secondary education do not go to school in crisis-affected countries.  Around the world, there are almost 10 million refugee children and about 19 million children have had to move within their country following conflicts. In terms of funding, $8 billion a year is needed to ensure educational support for children affected by emergencies, and the contribution to emergency education by affected governments leaves a total funding gap of $4.8 billion. To address this, there is a need to strengthen funding for humanitarian and development aid and for fragile states to increase public spending in the field of education. I voted in favour.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. The UN estimates that billion children live in conflict-affected areas. A quarter of these children are under five years old and denied the right to education. While we welcome the call on Member States to contribute to the increase in humanitarian funds for the education of children in emergency situations to 4 % of the humanitarian aid provided for in the EU budget, we believe that these funds should be channelled to the promotion of universal access to free and quality public education in all levels of education. Only with an educational policy that has as its pillars these premises will it be possible to reverse the vicious circle that generates poverty that plagues the areas of the planet most affected by emergencies and prolonged crises. Much of these situations are a painful demonstration of the inhuman, exploitative and aggressive character of the capitalist system and have causes and responsible: the processes of destabilization in various parts of the globe and the wars of imperialist aggression, the policy of economic dominance and the collection of natural resources. In this regard, we condemn that eu and Member State action within the EU should be based on charity and not solidarity, which serves as a palliative and not an antidote.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 There is no doubt that progress has been made in the area of education for children in emergencies and protracted crises since the adoption of the Millennium Development Goals, but the 2015 targets will not be met. Poverty eradication, universal access to education and gender equality can only be achieved through the development of public services to which everyone has access. Progress in education has been slowest in conflict-affected countries and in fragile and conflict-affected countries. It is important to strengthen the resilience of education systems in these countries and to ensure uninterrupted teaching at a time of crisis. The European Union, the Member States and other stakeholders involved at different levels need to be more involved in order to provide instruments to ensure the development and general education in such crisis-affected countries. However, I welcome the increasing international attention being paid to this issue. The European Union must continue to support the commitment of third-country governments to develop national legal frameworks aimed at resilience, prevention and disasters and risk management on the basis of an international regulatory programme.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I support this resolution which rightly recalls the value of education and calls for more investment in education, with a particular focus on the education of children living in crisis or conflict zones.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Education, and in particular high-quality public education, is a catalyst and basis for reducing unemployment and poverty, developing and lifting the economy. However, the fact that humanitarian aid is needed in countries that have suffered wars and disasters is not enough if it is not accompanied by the assumption that the EU should not finance actions designed to relieve countries destroyed by political interests, especially Western countries. That is why I am voting against this report.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Education is a fundamental human right and the right of every child. It is vital in order to be able to enjoy in full all other social, economic, cultural and political rights. It is a catalyst for development, which improves the prospects of other interventions in the areas of health, sanitation, disaster risk reduction, job creation, poverty reduction and economic development. Efforts in this direction will ensure that the principle of policy coherence is respected. I therefore absolutely agree on the need to ensure a more integrated, systematic and effective response to education needs in emergencies and I strongly believe that the EU must work with partner countries, other donors, the private sector and civil society to improve educational opportunities for young people in conflict situations. Education has to be considered as an integral part of the humanitarian response. All actors must increase their commitment to education by mobilising the education cluster in the early stages of an emergency and by ensuring that sufficient funds are dedicated to it.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the United Nations' estimate that one billion children live in conflict-affected areas. The EU and its humanitarian organisations must therefore systematically include the education and protection of children throughout the emergency response cycle and ensure that flexible multiannual funds are available for protracted crises.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP motion for a resolution on education for children in situations of emergency and prolonged crisis, as one billion children currently live in conflict zones and their fundamental right to education is being thused. I believe that guaranteed public education is the basis of an evolved civilisation, which contributes to improving everyone's living conditions and promotes social, economic, political and gender integration and equality, the latter essential and pre-evolving element of women's emancipation, wanting to prevent violence against them. Unfortunately, even today we have to note how detrimental it is for the human being not to have the opportunity to educate himself and therefore to make progress, how often this essential good is little considered, and despite the fact that we are in an emergency situation, less than 2% of all humanitarian funds were allocated to this sector in 2014. Therefore, I fully agree with and believe it is essential to support the announcement by the European Commissioner responsible for humanitarian aid and crisis management to allocate 4% of the EU humanitarian aid budget to the education of children in emergency situations by 2019.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. ‒ Further to being a catalyst for development and poverty reduction, education plays a crucial role, especially in a protracted crisis or in the reconstruction of post-conflict societies. Evidence shows that children with access to school and education are less likely to be exposed to forced marriage, radicalisation or human trafficking. I therefore supported this resolution that calls on the EU to work with partner countries, civil society and other relevant partners to improve educational opportunities for young people in conflict situations but that also urges the Member States and the Commission to support refugee students in transit.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on this motion for a Resolution on Education for Children in Emergencies and Protracted Crises. The motion for a Resolution calls very positively for the increase in funds for education in emergencies, considering education as a fundamental, cross-cutting and necessary element in any humanitarian action. In addition, the report underlines the importance of public, universal and quality education - both primary, secondary and higher - for crisis overcoming and for achieving sustainable development. However, the report includes a paragraph that opens the door to the privatization of education, which we consider unacceptable.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as education is a human right that should be guaranteed for all children but it is often one of the most underfunded areas in humanitarian responses. Time spent without access to education, particularly in younger years, can mean the creation of lost generations that could otherwise contribute to rebuilding their countries.  The international community must prioritise education in its humanitarian responses by increasing humanitarian aid and improving delivery on the ground. Development and humanitarian aid should also be bridged to ensure the effectiveness of these programmes in fragile states.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ An estimated 65 million children aged between three and 15 are most affected by emergencies and protracted crises, with the risk of disruption to their education, and approximately 37 million children of primary and lower secondary age are out of school in crisis-affected countries. It is important to comprehend that education is vital in order to be able to enjoy in full all other social, economic, cultural and political rights.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Unfortunately the resolution does not escape the philosophy of the dominant and majority neoliberal circles of the EU. While the resolution refers to the education of children in emergencies and stresses the need to protect children, noting the UN guidelines and mentioning the Millennium Development Goals, it nevertheless insists on promoting and supporting private initiative in education, thus privatising not only schools, but also universities and colleges.  For us, education is a good that belongs to every people. That is why we do not accept the promotion of privatisation. Let alone in areas that are going through long-term crises, or emergencies. There the state should not promote the sell-off of its infrastructure, but should incorporate education into its plans for recovery. For the above reasons abstention was the appropriate attitude to this resolution.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution as there are almost 10 million children who are refugees and an estimated 19 million children worldwide who have been displaced in their country as a result of conflict. I believe that every child’s rights should be respected without discrimination regardless of their or their parent’s ethnic origin, nationality or social, migration or residence status. Education is essential for the integration and improvement of living conditions of children with disabilities or special educational needs.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a motion for a resolution on the education of children in emergencies and protracted crises, because it is children who are the most vulnerable and innocent group of people in our society most affected by the current situations and problems in the world. According to UN figures, one billion children live in conflict zones, 250 million of them under the age of five and have no fundamental right to education. The availability of education to children is extremely important, especially to the millions of children who have been forced to become refugees. Universal and high-quality public education is of great importance because it brings the development of society in all areas, and this is only one of the points mentioned in this proposal that I support.

name: Jean-François JALKH
