text: In writing. This text highlights the importance of education in conflict zones.  Education has a leading role in the reconstruction of post-conflict societies. In addition, children with access to education are less at risk of forced marriages, early pregnancy, armed group membership, radicalization, and human trafficking. However, the text proposes to integrate teachers from the communities of displaced people, which could generate quite logically a phenomenon of communitarianism.  I voted for it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – This motion for a resolution calls for the EU to provide access to education for children in emergency situations. This motion for a resolution is in light of certain situations such as the Syrian civil war, which has completely demolished infrastructure in the region and has left children without education. The EU perceives this lack of education infrastructure to be a thriving ground for extremism; therefore the motion is calling for funding and an action plan for the situation. Even though we agree that education is important for children in emergency situations we do not feel it is within the remit of the EU to do this.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the education of children in emergencies and long-term crises. Education is a right for every child in the world and children who find themselves caught up in emergencies or long-term crisis should not suffer. The text stresses that education strengthens development and is an element of rebuilding societies after conflicts. Parliament also calls on Member States and humanitarian organisations to enable refugee children in very difficult situations to continue their education. This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. This motion contains some good proposals to ensure that displaced young people continue to be informed and trained. It is also interesting that only 2% of all humanitarian aid currently goes to education. The motion calls for an increase to 4%, but even that does not seem to be enough in the face of the challenges. The resolution is on the right track, but not ambitious enough, because the education factor for displaced persons cannot be overstated. It is only through education that we can ensure that these people want to return and put an end to the spiral of violence one day. I would like to see more ambition on this issue, but I am happy to vote in favour of the report.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report, as education is one of the most underfunded areas in humanitarian responses. Years without education mean lost generations that could contribute to rebuilding their countries and fostering inclusive and resilient societies. The international community must prioritise it, by increasing humanitarian aid and improving delivery on the ground. Development and humanitarian aid must also be bridged to ensure the effectiveness of their programmes in fragile states. Education is a human right that should be guaranteed for all children and especially in emergency situations.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 Today, around 65 million children live in crisis areas where they do not have access to adequate education due to the situation, in which the sector is typically underfunded. The aim of the motion is to encourage Member States to support the European Commission's proposal to increase the share of EU humanitarian aid for education to 4%. The motion also calls on Member States to help integrate refugee children they receive into their national education systems. High-quality education must be a priority in crisis and disaster zones, as this could be the key to the recovery and stabilisation process after the crisis in the longer term. In addition, strengthening education can play a significant role in preventing children from falling victim to radicalisation, which can put them in the hands of terrorist groups and armies. Access to adequate education can also be an important tool in the fight against poverty. In agreement with the above objectives, following the people's party line, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I gave my positive opinion because I believe that the education of children, as well as being a fundamental and inalienable right of every individual, as enshrined in the 1989 UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, is one of the main instruments for finding a solution and for lifting the fortunes of peoples affected by war or tragic and unforeseeable events, such as natural disasters. Given that almost a billion children in the world, about a quarter of whom are under five years of age, live in war zones, are denied their right to education, I think it is significant that this Parliament is mobilising for the adoption of measures that enshrine a concrete COMMITMENT by the EU to protect them.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I abstained on this resolution. Of course, it underlines the importance of raising children to build a more stable world. But it proposes to recruit teachers from displaced communities, which is likely to strengthen communitarianism.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 37 million children are currently out of the education system due to conflicts and crises. We now face the risk that entire generations will be left without access to education, which could result in serious consequences in the future, a further increase in violence and a final escalation of further conflicts.  At the same time, education is the most underfunded humanitarian aid area in the world. It allocates only 2% of all humanitarian aid. We must break this vicious cycle and start investing in education, which is one of the fundamental rights of children around the world and is a very important tool to combat conflicts and crises.  Greater access to education leads to improved living standards, better economic prospects and the promotion of dialogue, tolerance and peaceful problem solving. It is estimated that increasing the proportion of young people with secondary education from 30% to 60% could halve the risk of conflict. Quality education is also a key aid in the fight against radicalisation and extremism. Through education, young people develop critical thinking skills, acquire social and civic competences and learn respect for diversity.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I do not agree with discrimination against one student at the expense of others.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒According to UN figures, around 1 billion children live in conflict areas. Such conditions make it difficult to implement children's fundamental right to education. Given the growing number of humanitarian crises and the number of displaced populations, the international community should think of education as a fundamental response. Education is a means of development needed for young people to overcome trauma, reintegrate into a society after conflict and acquire the skills needed to rebuild and promote peacebuilding. I supported MP Linda McAvan's report because it is important to include children's education as a priority in redistributing EU funds, cooperation with donors is needed as well as improving the insurance of educational institutions against attacks. During the war, programmes targeting children victims of war were developed in Croatia as a result of co-operation between governmental and non-governmental organisations. Croatian experience is useful in planning and implementing support programs for children that can be applied anywhere.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. – Children are among the most vulnerable sections of the population in the event of crises. Endangering their lives, health and lack of adequate education impairs their quality of life, contributes to the spread of poverty and, at the same time, poses a serious threat to future generations. The consequences of a lack of education are a serious factor even after the crisis has ended.  In conjunction with misery, this creates the preconditions for the emergence of local centres of further unrest and conflict. I fully support the adoption of measures that will ensure that children are educated, especially during long-lasting crises, create the conditions for their return to school and inclusion in a proper life.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution on the education of children in emergencies and prolonged crises, because it is well documented, and for and for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 25/11/2015.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I abstained on this vote. This text is motivated by the considerable increase in crises around the world, and by the tragic increase in the number of children affected by it. He points out that education is a fundamental right and the basis of responsible citizenship. The proposal stresses that education must be a priority for Member States and humanitarian structures.  Despite good ideas, we are disturbed by some points of this proposal. It proposes, for example, to welcome and educate refugee children and adolescents, which is laudable, but it also suggests integrating teachers from displaced communities, which could lead to a communitarian effect. The idea is still laudable, but not well suited.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution which stresses that girls and other disadvantaged children, including disabled children, should never be discriminated against in terms of access to good education in emergency situations.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the education of children in emergency situations and prolonged crises. Education is a fundamental human right, which must be respected and protected for all, especially children, without discrimination and regardless of ethnic origin or nationality. Unfortunately, even today, almost a billion children are denied this right, especially for those living in conflict zones; around 65 million children are affected by emergency situations and are at risk of interrupting their school career. Action by the European Union to act and to include education and the protection of children among its priorities is essential, so that this right, which is the key to the full enjoyment of all other social, economic and cultural rights, the foundation of responsible citizenship, is respected.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Writing. \u2012 According to UN estimates, 1 billion children currently live in conflict-affected areas, 250 million of them under the age of five, and are denied the basic right to education and, overall, about 37 million children do not go to school in conflict-affected countries, which are alarming figures. I wonder what can grow out of such children and whether a so-called lost generation is born before our eyes. Children who do not go to school are more likely to succumb to recruitment to the armed forces or groups, which is now more than the current issue. I stress that the right to education is one of the fundamental human rights and rights of every child and plays an essential role for integration. Since I attach great importance to education, including in extreme conditions of conflict, natural disaster or other crisis situations, I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution today.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 An estimated one billion children live in conflict zones, nearly 10 million children are refugees. These are children who are denied rights which governments have undertaken to respect in the 1989 United Nations Convention, including the fundamental right to education. I therefore believe that we must support Mrs McAvan's position, which stresses, in this motion for a resolution, the need to pay attention to secondary education and vocational training as well as to basic primary education, and calls for the development of specific reception schemes for unaccompanied minors and single mothers with children.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. This is a good proposal in itself to ensure that displaced young people continue to be educated and thus trained. However, this resolution is not ambitious enough, as the education factor for displaced persons cannot be overstated. It is only through education that we can ensure that these people return or that they will one day leave the spiral of violence. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The Millennium Development Goals set the goal that all children would be able to achieve a full cycle of primary education by 2015. Target not met (91% compared to 83% in 2000), particularly in view of the increasing number of crises, displaced persons, but also because of attacks on educational institutions by government security forces and non-state armed groups in some 30 countries around the world.  The report supports the pursuit of this objective and calls, among other things, for the "development of public services accessible to all", the strengthening of development aid and the establishment of sustainable funds at the international level to ensure education in an emergency. Nevertheless, it calls for strengthening the involvement of the private sector in according with the logic advocated in the Union. This is what I am opposed to, let alone in countries lacking state structures. Multinationals do not have a charitable interest in development, but are driven by capitalist logics that are particularly destabilizing in crisis or developing countries.  I cannot condone that. I abstain.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The text underlines the importance of education in conflict zones. Indeed, education has a major role to play in the reconstruction of post-conflict societies. In addition, children with access to education are less at risk of forced marriages, early pregnancy, armed group membership, radicalization, and human trafficking. However, the text proposes to integrate teachers from displaced communities, which could generate quite logically a phenomenon of communitarianism. In addition, the text calls for the creation of 'educational corridors', which would allow students from these conflict zones to continue their studies at a European university.  In these circumstances, the desire for a very long-term integration seems to supplant the original objective of temporary local aid and therefore prevents any societal reconstruction in the countries of origin. The general idea is therefore good, but its application is inadequate to the issues to come. The member therefore abstains.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the education of children in emergency situations and prolonged crises. The EU must continue to set an example in this area. The announcement by the Commissioner for Humanitarian Aid and Crisis Management was extremely important, which announced its objective of dedicating 4% of the EU humanitarian aid budget to the education of children in emergencies by 2019. It must not be forgotten that there are almost 10 million refugee children in the world and that some 19 million children have had to move within their country following conflicts.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it seeks to ensure that a child’s education will remain a priority even during cases of humanitarian crisis.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. Education is a fundamental and inalienable right for every child, regardless of ethnic origin, nationality or social status. However, millions of children living in situations of conflict and humanitarian crises are deprived of education. Today, about half of the world's schoolchildren live in conflict zones and 10 million children are refugees. Their future is uncertain and their chances of getting into school are very low.  I welcome the adoption of the resolution, which aims to remind children of education in emergencies and long-term crises. Education is an integral part of these children's survival, social well-being and physical, emotional, moral and social development. It is crucial to increase support for children's education programmes in conflict zones while paying special attention to vulnerable groups, particularly girls, children with disabilities and young children. I agree with Parliament's call for all actors to increase and diversify funding instruments and to make this objective a priority for humanitarian aid.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. \u2012 The UN estimates that conflict-affected areas are home to one billion children who are denied the fundamental right to education by not being able to go to school or have to stop school in the long term due to conflict or crisis.  Children and young people who have not been or have stopped going to school are at risk of many risks, starting with poverty, the loss of the possibility of finding adequate employment in the future, but also the threat of exploitation, human trafficking or recruitment to terrorist or extremist groups. I believe that education also plays a crucial role in rebuilding society after the end of the conflict in the long term, as it offers the prospect of better integration into the working environment and thus the possibility of educating and contributing to economic growth. Otherwise, the lack of education and positive opportunities leads to a deepening of frustration and dissatisfaction, which are a breeding ground for criminal and anti-social activities, violence and extremism. I therefore support EU investment in education in emergencies and under unstable conditions, and I appreciate the merit work of all humanitarian and development actors who work closely together on the important link between aid, reconstruction and development.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I support the report on education for children in emergency situations and protracted crises, which stresses the importance of universal high-quality public education as a catalyst for development, which improves the prospects of other interventions in the areas of health, sanitation, disaster-risk reduction, job creation, poverty reduction and economic development. Education’s role is as a powerful tool that is necessary in order to give a sense of normality, to raise awareness of rights and to help children, adolescents, and young people overcome trauma, reintegrate themselves into society in the aftermath of conflicts, and acquire the skills needed to rebuild their societies and promote peace-building and reconciliation. That is why I have voted in favour of this important report

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament's Committee on Development has tabled a motion for a parliamentary resolution on the exercise of the fundamental right to education for the 1 billion people living in conflict areas and the 10 million children who have fled outside their home countries and the 19 million children displaced in their home countries. The draft urges the international community to consider education as a central element of humanitarian aid, which can act as a catalyst for the effectiveness of general action and can also contribute to improving the situation of the population concerned in the medium to longer term. I fully agree with the findings of the draft and I was happy to support it.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. Education is a fundamental human right of all children and is essential for the full exercise of all other social, economic, cultural and political rights. It should be stressed that education is the basis of responsible citizenship and can transform a society and contribute to social, economic, political and gender equality. The Incheon Declaration notes with concern that conflicts, natural disasters and other crises continue to hinder education and development. Therefore, it is committed to developing more inclusive, responsive and more resilient education systems, and also said that education must be delivered in safe, welcoming and violence-free learning environments. I support education as a key to the reconstruction of post-conflict societies, as training will contribute to improving the life prospects of populations and breaking the cycle of poverty. I support and support this proposal on the air that the EU should develop, through cooperation with different international organisations, specific reception programmes for children affected by emergencies and prolonged crises.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because, according to the United Nations, one billion children live in conflict zones, 250 million of whom are under the age of five and are deprived of their basic right to education. An estimated 65 million children aged 3 to 15 are affected by emergencies and long-term crises and are at risk of school disruption, and some 37 million children out of primary and lower secondary school in countries experiencing crises.  About half of the world's schoolchildren live in conflict-affected areas; in the Arab States, 87% of out-of-school children are affected by conflict and an estimated 175 million children are at risk of natural disasters each year. In addition, some groups, such as poor children, girls and children with disabilities, are seeing their already reduced prospects decline further in conflict-affected areas or in fragile contexts. Let's mobilize to save their future!

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 Today, the number of areas affected by conflicts and disasters is increasing rapidly, and the European Union, as one of the most important players in world politics, must consider it its duty to help countries in a situation of hope. In addition to providing rapid and direct humanitarian assistance, long-term measures also play an important role. As a result of constant conflicts, the inhabitants of these areas are lost from the possibility of exercising their fundamental rights, such as the right to education. As a result, a so-called 'lost generation' can develop, which poses a serious threat to the development and transformation of society in the right direction. That is why we need a proposal that fully supports the education of children from conflict-torn countries, with a particular emphasis on girls and young people from disadvantaged backgrounds.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this resolution that will instate equal rights for every child, regardless of their ethnic origin and social, migration or residence status, particularly in terms of educational opportunities for young people in conflict or emergency situations.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. ‒ We voted in favour of the resolution as it calls for increasing the share of EU humanitarian funds for the education of children in emergencies and protracted crises, and on all host countries to help integrate child refugees into their national education system.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this text as it is an important text on child protection and care in the European Union. As the most vulnerable and yet the most important part of human society, it is vital that children are educated and prepared to deal with a wide variety of crises. It is a matter of survival but also societal development and all efforts should be made in ensuring adequate financing programmes for access to training courses and long-term education for children in emergency or extraordinary situations, both for those in the EU and those outside our borders.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution because I consider it important to point out that, in the context of the unstable and internal conflicts of the world's war-torn countries, children are the most vulnerable group. It makes sense that we focus our attention most on the countries that are the biggest source of migration to the EU. A major step forward is the establishment of the Bekou Trust Fund, the Madad Trust Fund and the Trust Fund for Africa, which can become effective tools for addressing the frequent conflict between humanitarian and development aid, i.e. immediate assistance in terms of providing "first aid" to vulnerable areas, on the one hand, and longer-term and more comprehensive assistance aimed at creating the conditions for self-sufficient "operation". I would therefore very much like the EU and the Member States to make the education of children one of the key priorities that is a necessary part of efforts to improve the situation in the longer term when allocating resources from EU trust funds.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. This motion for a resolution calls on EU countries to integrate refugee children in emergency situations into national education systems and believes that education reduces the risk of radicalisation of young people. In principle, nothing stands in the way of these demands. However, it seems to me completely pointless to formulate these aspects outside of a coherent strategy for dealing with the current migration crisis, which should, in principle, start with the nation states. That is why I voted against the report.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the resolution tabled. Quality education is a key factor in rebuilding conflict-affected societies and improving the effectiveness of humanitarian aid. It is therefore essential to increase the resilience of education systems and to ensure continuous learning in emergency and protracted crises. The EU's cooperation with partner countries, other donors, the private sector and civil society needs to be strengthened. It should be noted that international donors should pay particular attention to education in order to involve children and provide them with psychological support. In order to ensure a higher and more appropriate level of integration of children, language learning of the host country must be encouraged, learning options and accessibility increased. Particular attention must be paid to public funding of education and the public education structure in order to effectively ensure universal access to education for all.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ This motion for a resolution calls for the EU to provide access to education for children in emergency situations. This motion for a resolution is in light of certain situations such as the Syrian civil war, which has completely demolished infrastructure in the region and has left children without education. The EU perceives this lack of education infrastructure to be a thriving ground for extremism; therefore the motion is calling for funding and an action plan for the situation. Even though we agree that education is important for children in emergency situations we do not feel it is within the remit of the EU to do this.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 The waves of refugees pouring into Europe pose problems not only in the sphere of humanitarian law, but also in terms of the more proper dimension of international protection of human rights. And it is a universal human right, recognised by the United Nations Universal Declaration of 1948, to guarantee education for all children. We cannot therefore forget this, all the more so when these children come from conflict situations, they are forced to leave their homes, their schools and their country. It is our duty to ensure that they continue their studies. I would like to remind you that bodies such as UNESCO have arisen precisely from the conviction that it is not possible to build a peaceful future unless we educate children and future generations for peace. Ensuring the continuity of education for refugee children is therefore an investment in the future construction of the stability and peace of the countries of the European Union and of those from which refugees come. I would therefore have voted strongly in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. Every child, regardless of the circumstances in which they find himself or her, has the right to education. But not only do children in both conflict and crisis situations have the right to education, but by allowing children access to education and in war-affected countries and crisis situations, we also provide them with protection because while in school, children are less at risk of being forced into work or child marriage, recruited to become child soldiers or become victims of human trafficking. Through education, children acquire the necessary life knowledge and skills that have an irreplaceable effect on their future, and by attending school, a glimmer of stability returns to the lives of refugee children and they learn how to cope more easily with the situation they are in, which in turn contributes to the well-being of children. Of course, access to education cannot be separated from economic development and is the key to recovery, but education is really important for the progress of children living in conflict areas or forced to leave their home. I therefore support the appeal for a more integrated, comprehensive and effective response to the need to education for children in crisis situations, and I believe that we can contribute more to better education for more children who have been denied access to education.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. According to UN estimates, one billion children live in conflict zones, 250 million of them under the age of five and have no fundamental right to education. As many as 65 million children aged between 3 and 15 are most affected by emergencies and protracted crises, putting their education at risk. Half of children from around the world who do not attend classes live in conflicting areas, in Arab countries 87% of non-school children live in conflict-affected areas, and around 175 million children are likely to be affected by natural disasters each year, and as many as 37 million primary and lower secondary school children do not attend classes in countries affected by the crisis. This is terrible data that points to the need for urgent action to protect the most vulnerable group most in need of care, safety and education.  We need more initiatives such as the EU's Children of Peace, which aims to fund humanitarian education projects in emergency situations, which is why I am joining calls for the Commission to expand this initiative and further engage in the No Lost Generation Initiative launched by many donors, humanitarian and development entities, including the EU, to give millions of children in Syria and neighbouring countries access to education.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒The possibility of sudden situations occurring exists continuously and is consistent with the fundamental values of the European Union, react in a timely manner and try to prevent negative consequences that may arise as a result of individual events. Precisely to protect fundamental principles, such as solidarity, respect for human dignity, equality, tolerance, the EU has established the Department for Humanitarian Aid and Civil Protection (ECHO). This Committee's action focuses on the protection of the human lives and dignity of those affected. However, the action covers the wide content of all possible activities to improve quality of life. Education is one of the ways of quality building of post-conflict communities and it is especially important to support the development of educational institutions and enable every child to exercise one of his basic rights, the right to education.  Knowing that around a million children are in areas affected by war and denied the right to education, action by Member States and humanitarian organisations should be directed to support the development of education systems in a positive direction. Given that humanitarian aid is the only way to enable children in war zones to participate in educational programmes and thus provide opportunities for development and progress, I think it is necessary to focus attention on this issue. I therefore support my colleague Linda McAvan's motion for a resolution.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 Education of children in crisis situations and protracted crises is one of the most pressing problems of our time. While not so much seen in television news, it is one of the most negative effects of a situation in which millions of people have to live in refugee camps after being driven from their homes. Support for education to operate in such conditions must be as high as possible on the priority list. Personally, I think that education must come after ensuring the protection of lives, health and adequate nutrition. We're fighting for generations to come.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the education of children in emergencies and long-term crises. Many humanitarian crises mark history. Millions of children have been and are victims of conflict. To ignore them is to make them lost generations. And lost generations form a breeding ground for the following conflicts. To avoid this, it is necessary to ensure a link, a framework for the education of children in any situation. The wars against the terrorist organization Daesh, or Boko Haram in Nigeria, show that children are at the heart of these conflicts. To prevent children, victims of conflict, from growing up to become adults, actors guilty of conflict, let us maintain an educational link and invest in all generations, wherever they are.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution in question follows the oral question to the European Commission (EC) by Mep Linda McAvan, who, on behalf of the Committee on Development, asked about concrete measures to adequately address educational needs in emergency situations.  Currently, 1 billion children live in conflict-affected areas and are denied their fundamental right to education - which governments have pledged to respect under the UN Convention. However, Parliament warns that the Convention will not go from dead to hand if the provision of quality education in emergency situations is relegated to the background. In this context, the Commission considers that, without prejudice to material security and child welfare, education should also be included in humanitarian aid programmes, this time leveraged by an increase in humanitarian funding, sufficient to respond to emergencies. In view of the deliberations above, I voted in favour.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the education of children in emergencies and long-term crises. According to the United Nations, one billion children live in conflict zones, 250 million of whom are under the age of five and are deprived of their right to education. Approximately 65 million children between the ages of 3 and 15 are at risk of school disruption and 37 million children are out of primary and lower secondary school. And out-of-school children are at greater risk of early marriage and pregnancy, recruitment by the regular army or armed groups, trafficking and forced labour. Quality education can also play an important long-term role in rebuilding society after conflict.  Finally, education should be made a priority in humanitarian aid, development aid and the allocation of resources from EU funds. In particular, we call on all EU Member States to support the Commission's objective of increasing the European humanitarian aid budget for education in emergencies by 4%.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. U2012 65 million children between the ages of three and fifteen are caught up in some kind of crisis, usually long lasting, without access to education. We're talking about more than one generation lost globally. This socialist-promoted motion for a resolution calls for an increase of humanitarian aid devoted to education in crisis situations from 1.9% to 4%, increasing the share of humanitarian aid in the 2016 budget by 26 million to ensure access to emergency education. Finally, it urges Member States to support the Commission's objective of increasing the percentage of humanitarian funds for education and to boost the creation of a comprehensive fund. The Socialists underline the importance of education as a key factor for development, job creation and poverty reduction, as well as a powerful tool to help children overcome trauma caused by conflict or other emergencies. That is why I voted favourably on this motion for a resolution.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution which, in view of the protracted nature of the current crises, calls on all humanitarian actors (of which the European Union is at the forefront) to ensure that the education of children is an integral part of their intervention by resorting to the poles of action at the onset of a crisis and ensuring that sufficient funds are devoted to them. The text of the resolution also calls for special attention to more vulnerable groups such as girls, disabled children and poor children.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. The number of children and young adolescents in vulnerable situations for conflict reasons in their home countries is increasingly significant and alarming. The constant state of risk to which these young people are exposed has led many families to leave their countries and head towards Europe looking for a better future. However, many of them remain in refugee camps or do not have the means to escape the national conflicts they face on a daily basis. It is therefore necessary to act for the safety and future of these children who end up being victims of an unstable system that does not grant them the educational conditions to which any child is entitled under the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child.  I therefore think it is important for the EU to provide and secure more resources for the education of refugee children and young people, as education is a cornerstone for the continuity of a better, capable, secure and wholesome society in its most basic essence. For the reasons put forward above, this motion for a resolution has been welcomed and voted in favour.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. According to UN figures, about half of the world's schoolchildren live in conflict-affected areas and an estimated 65 million children aged 3 to 15 are affected by emergencies and crises. In the face of these alarming figures, the European Union and the international community must act as soon as possible. For example, I voted in favour of this text, which calls on Member States to support the Commission's objective of increasing the share of eu's humanitarian funds for the education of children in emergency situations to 4%. As we face and respond to the refugee crisis, host countries must ensure that refugee children have full access to education. Finally, the Union must work with partner countries to improve the education of children in conflict and prevent them from becoming targets of armed conflict. The European Union must act for the generations of tomorrow.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on this motion for a Resolution on Education for Children in Emergencies and Protracted Crises. The motion for a Resolution calls very positively for the increase in funds for education in emergencies, considering education as a fundamental, cross-cutting and necessary element in any humanitarian action. In addition, the report underlines the importance of public, universal and quality education - both primary, secondary and higher - for crisis overcoming and for achieving sustainable development. However, the report includes a paragraph that opens the door to the privatization of education, which we consider unacceptable.

name: György SCHÖPFLIN
text: Writing. \u2012 Today, around 65 million children live in crisis areas where they do not have access to adequate education due to the situation, in which the sector is typically underfunded. The aim of the motion is to encourage Member States to support the European Commission's proposal to increase the share of EU humanitarian aid for education to 4%. The motion also calls on Member States to help integrate refugee children they receive into their national education systems. High-quality education must be a priority in crisis and disaster zones, as this could be the key to the recovery and stabilisation process after the crisis in the longer term. In addition, strengthening education can play a significant role in preventing children from falling victim to radicalisation, which can put them in the hands of terrorist groups and armies. Access to adequate education can also be an important tool in the fight against poverty. In agreement with the above objectives, following the people's party line, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this Resolution, although I welcome the call made by this Resolution to the European Commission to increase the level of humanitarian aid funds earmarked to support the education of children affected by humanitarian emergencies and protracted crises, while calling on host countries to make an effort for better integration into their education systems. The final text of the Resolution gives the private sector a "crucial" role in education systems. The right to quality education with universal access to all with the private business of a few is unacceptable and incompatible. Therefore, throughout the process of adopting this Resolution, we have defended the need to make this Resolution a clear appeal and commitment to public, free and universally accessible education systems for both basic and secondary and university education, which has been rejected by a majority made up of conservatives and liberals, mainly. Since my head-on refusal for the European Commission to finance private enterprises in the education sector and my commitment to public education, I abstained from voting on this Resolution.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this vote. I agree with the sentiments of the report, however I think nation states should action this and not the EU.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider education to be one of the most important investments in the future of our children and a key tool for eradicating poverty in the world. It is important to ensure access to quality education also in countries affected by conflicts, fighting and instability. I therefore voted in favour of adopting this resolution on education for children in emergencies and protracted crises.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Education is a fundamental human right and the right of every child and is crucial for its further development and development and application in life. Education makes the exercise of all other rights, such as social, economic, cultural and political, on condition. The UN estimates that around one billion children live in conflict-affected areas. It is estimated that up to 65 million children aged between 3 and 15 are most affected by emergencies and protracted crises and are at risk of interruption or completion of education. It is currently estimated that 19 million children are displaced as a result of various conflicts and receive no education. I supported the motion for a resolution because it identifies a system and options for financing the education of children in emergencies and protracted crises. Humanitarian and voluntary organisations, individual Member States, international organisations and the UN need to work together in this area. The motion for a resolution also points to the need to increase funding for children's education and to respect all initiatives, declarations and development programmes adopted in the past, which have often not been implemented.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 The best progress in aid to the developing world can be achieved mainly through the promotion of education, in linking humanitarian and development aid and achieving coherence in EU policy in this area. The right to education for all children without distinction is a fundamental principle on which we should build all our further efforts on a global level.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I support this motion for a resolution because, according to UN estimates, one billion children live in conflict-affected areas, of which 250 million are children under the age of five and have no fundamental right to education. It is also estimated that 65 million children aged between 3 and 15 are most affected by emergencies and protracted crises, putting their education at risk. I believe that education is a fundamental human right and the right of every child, because education is essential in order to fully enjoy other social, economic, cultural and political rights.  This resolution highlights the importance of universal and high-quality public education as a catalyst for development that improves the opportunities for other actions in the areas of health, sanitation, disaster risk reduction, job creation and poverty reduction and economic development, and also highlights the importance of education as a powerful instrument needed to provide a sense of normal life, and to strengthen awareness of rights and help children. It is important for young people to overcome trauma, and to reintegrate into society after conflict and adopt the skills needed to rebuild their societies.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ According to UN estimates, one billion children live in conflict zones, of which 250 million are under the age of five and have no fundamental right to education. Education is a key factor for integrating and improving the living conditions of children with disabilities and/or special educational needs. The EU's Children of Peace initiative for 1.5 million children affected by conflicts and crises in 26 countries provides access to schools where they have the opportunity to learn in a safe environment and receive psychological support. Education requires a longer-term approach that cannot be fully secured through humanitarian aid. European Union humanitarian aid is vital for communities and victims of new and protracted crises, especially children who are among the most vulnerable victims of humanitarian crises. I support this resolution because I believe that quality education for children is crucial in rebuilding, conflicting affected societies, as it can increase their earning potential, provide them with better care for the health of their families and improve the chances of getting out of a closed cycle of poverty.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the education of children in emergencies and protracted crises. The right to education is one of the most important human rights, yet there is still a worldwide uproom ing of as many as 250 million children under the age of five, according to the UN. This is outrageous, and we must all work together to establish instruments to improve the education of children in countries where emergencies are in place. Schooling and education are also very important for the eradication of poverty.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The resolution on the education of children in emergencies and long-term crises stresses the need to protect children, takes note of UN guidelines and mentions the Millennium Development Goals. Unfortunately, however, it does not escape the philosophy of the EU's dominant and majority neoliberal circles. It insists on promoting and supporting private initiative in education, thus privatising not only schools, but also universities and colleges. For us as the Left, education is a good that belongs to every people. That is why we do not accept the promotion of privatisation. Let alone in areas that are going through long-term crises, or emergencies. There the state must integrate education as part of its recovery plan, not sell off its infrastructure.  For the above reasons we voted to abstain on this resolution.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Education, and in particular high-quality public education, is a catalyst and basis for reducing unemployment and poverty, developing and lifting the economy. However, the fact that humanitarian aid is needed in countries that have suffered wars and disasters is not enough if it is not accompanied by the assumption that the EU should not finance actions designed to relieve countries destroyed by political interests, especially Western countries.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion, as the UN estimates that 1 billion children live in conflict areas, 250 million of whom are under the age of 5. Many people are also unable to exercise their fundamental right to education. The report highlights that there are almost 10 million refugee children and that around 19 million children in the world have been displaced by a conflict in their own country. I therefore believe that education should be prioritised and treated not only as a humanitarian issue, but also as an area of development cooperation. Education is a fundamental right which every child is entitled to, irrespective of the ethnic origin, nationality and social, migration or residence status of his parents.  So it is not simply a need for aid, but it must be linked to recovery and development! I agree that education is the basis for responsible citizenship, can transform a society and contribute to social, economic, political and gender equality, and is an important factor in the social, cultural and professional emancipation of girls and women and in preventing violence against women and girls. I support the call for Member States to draw up specific plans for the reception of unaccompanied children and single mothers.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The UN estimates that there are one billion children living in conflict-affected areas who are denied their fundamental right to education. The number of children with limited access to education is likely to increase due to the current migration crisis. That is why it is so important to take action both within the Union itself and within our external relations to help these children.  What is certain is that the economy of any country cannot grow without a young and educated workforce. It is therefore our duty to provide education to children in emergency situations and protracted crises, as they will be an essential part of the process of rebuilding societies in countries where conflicts have ended. Parliament's resolution is a legitimate element of the EU strategy, which is why I decided to vote in favour of it.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Children are the human category most vulnerable to emergencies and crises. That is why they must be adequately protected from these risks. Globally, the right to education of a significant part of children is affected by existing armed conflicts, precarious social situations or natural disasters. A significant number of children are also refugees or displaced.  Education is a fundamental right for children, which can give them prospects for a better life and the chance to overcome the difficult situations they find themselves in. Unfortunately, this right is not guaranteed everywhere by the ruling states and governments. The European Union has been involved in remedying the situation through the Children for Country initiative and participation in UN programmes. However, more involvement is needed to eliminate discrimination against girls and children with disabilities, avoid dropping out of school, combat illiteracy, ensure the education of children in crisis-affected areas, psychological support for children in conflict zones, social integration of refugee children, prevent child abuse and trafficking. A number of funds have already been created, but more humanitarian funding is needed for education. It is therefore necessary to adopt the current resolution.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted for this resolution. It recalls that, according to the United Nations, one billion children live in conflict zones, 250 million of whom are under the age of five and are deprived of their basic right to education. An estimated 65 million children aged 3 to 15 are affected by emergencies and long-term crises and are therefore at risk of school interruption, and some 37 million children out of primary and lower secondary school in crisis-prone countries.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution draws attention to the situation of children stuck in conflicts, which the current refugee crisis makes ever more distressing. These numbers are worryingly large, with the UN estimating that one billion children are affected worldwide and almost 10 million as refugees. I voted in favour of the resolution, promoting education as a human right and uninterrupted learning in spite of conflicts. Since education offers a perspective for a decent life, I believe that all children should be able to share this vision. Regarding refugee children, the resolution calls on hosting countries to include them in national education systems as much as possible. Moreover, it calls on the Commission and the Member States to establish ‘education corridors’ to ensure that students from countries in conflict, in particular Syria, Iraq and Eritrea, are admitted to universities. To finance the proposed measures, the resolution asks for increased resources, beyond the less than 2% of all humanitarian funds that this policy area received in 2014.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing. \u2012 The protection of minors and the prevention of abuse and trafficking involves their inclusion in schools and educational programs, through the definition of standards of reception, insertion and language support. It is essential to support refugee students in transit also through cooperation with different international organizations. 'Educational corridors' must be created to ensure that students from conflicting countries are admitted to universities. New information and communication technologies have taken on an increasingly important role in the field of emergency education and can improve the activities of operators in these contexts, including through e-learning and e-teaching platforms. This report is a step in the right direction.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported a proposal to increase humanitarian aid in the education sector in countries affected by emergencies and protracted crises to 4% of all humanitarian aid to ensure children have access to quality education.  In fact, I believe that in countries affected by emergencies and protracted crises, the right to education must be ensured, which can be significantly improved by increasing the share of humanitarian aid set aside for this purpose.  In addition, I believe it is of utmost importance that refugee-taking countries ensure full access to education for refugee children, not only at primary level, but also in secondary and vocational training, and to promote their integration and inclusion in the country's education systems. This can be achieved by establishing proposed "educational corridors" through which learners from such countries, especially from Syria, Iraq and Eritrea, can be accepted in universities. This will make it easier to integrate into the country's society and adapt to new cultural environments.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the european Parliament's motion for a resolution on the education of children in emergencies and protracted crises (2015/2977(RSP)) because I believe that every child has the right to education. Free primary education should be its fundamental right, regardless of where it comes from and in what circumstances it is based. It is necessary to provide education for all children, as education is essential for the enjoyment of other social and economic rights.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on this motion for a Resolution on Education for Children in Emergencies and Protracted Crises. The motion for a Resolution calls very positively for the increase in funds for education in emergencies, considering education as a fundamental, cross-cutting and necessary element in any humanitarian action. In addition, the report underlines the importance of public, universal and quality education - both primary, secondary and higher - for crisis overcoming and for achieving sustainable development. However, the report includes a paragraph that opens the door to the privatization of education, which we consider unacceptable.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ The huge number of children who are in a very difficult situation in many countries is well known and explained very well in the resolution. Therefore I support this resolution to call for the proportion of humanitarian funding to education in emergency situations to be increased to reach 4% of the budget of EU humanitarian aid as a minimum investment to ensure access to quality education for children in emergencies and protracted crises.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. Despite a good initiative, this text presents several problematic points. While the proposal calls on Member States to allow access to education for refugee children and adolescents by integrating them into national education systems and by making it easier for them to learn the language of the host country, it also proposes to integrate teachers from displaced communities, which could create a phenomenon of communitarianism.  The integration of refugee students in transit in the universities of member countries is also one of the guidelines of this text which calls for the creation of "educational corridors" to enable students from conflict zones (Syria, Iraq and Eritrea in particular) to continue their studies in European universities. So I choose abstention.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The UN estimates that 1 billion children live in conflict areas, 250 million of whom are under the age of 5, and cannot exercise their fundamental right to education. It is estimated that some 65 million children between the ages of 3 and 15 are at risk of being interrupted due to emergencies and protracted crises, and some 37 million children in crisis-stricken countries who do not attend school but would be in primary or secondary school by their age. About half of all children who do not attend school in the world live in conflict areas. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on this motion for a Resolution on Education for Children in Emergencies and Protracted Crises. The motion for a Resolution calls very positively for the increase in funds for education in emergencies, considering education as a fundamental, cross-cutting and necessary element in any humanitarian action. In addition, the report underlines the importance of public, universal and quality education - both primary, secondary and higher - for crisis overcoming and for achieving sustainable development. However, the report includes a paragraph that opens the door to the privatization of education, which we consider unacceptable.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. We are talking about a motion for a Resolution that highlights the importance of quality universal public education as a catalyst for development. The motion for a Resolution rightly points to the worrying situation of educational progress faced by conflict-affected countries as well as the need for access to education for children who have been forced to become refugees. It also proposes measures to try to change this situation. That is why I think it is appropriate to vote in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this Resolution, although I welcome the call made by this Resolution to the European Commission to increase the level of humanitarian aid funds earmarked to support the education of children affected by humanitarian emergencies and protracted crises, while calling on host countries to make an effort for better integration into their education systems. The final text of the Resolution gives the private sector a "crucial" role in education systems. The right to quality education with universal access to all with the private business of a few is unacceptable and incompatible. Therefore, throughout the process of adopting this Resolution, we have defended the need to make this Resolution a clear appeal and commitment to public, free and universally accessible education systems for both basic and secondary and university education, which has been rejected by a majority made up of conservatives and liberals, mainly. Since my head-on refusal for the European Commission to finance private enterprises in the education sector and my commitment to public education, I abstained from voting on this Resolution.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly supported a motion that went through Parliament calling on Member States and the United Nations to properly back education in areas of protracted crisis. Education is a fundamental human right, but more than that, it is also one of the key determinants of a child’s future. Out-of-school children and adolescents face a higher risk of early marriage, pregnancy, recruitment into armed groups, trafficking and labour exploitation. By ensuring universal and high-quality education we can promote stability and it can act as a catalyst for development. Education bind societies back together, giving people the skills to help rebuild their own countries. All of this requires long-term investment and thinking. For all of these reasons I backed this resolution.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I voted in favour of this plan because education is a fundamental and inalienable right for every child, regardless of their origin. Promoting education as a human right and obtaining education in spite of the prevailing conflicts in certain regions must be a priority of our humanitarian aid, as I believe that education is still the best guarantee of a decent life.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. We are going through one of the world's worst humanitarian crises since the Second World War. Today, half of the world's schoolchildren live in conflict-affected areas.  In order to enable the schooling of children exposed to emergencies, almost 7.5 billion euros per year are needed and the funding gap in this area now amounts to more than 4.5 billion euros.  If the EU's aid increases, since it will be 4.7 billion euros in developing countries for education for 2014-2020 (compared to 4.4 billion for the period 2007-2013), this is still well below the real needs. This resolution calls for more resources, in particular, to achieve the Millennium Development Goals in education and supports the establishment of a global emergency education funding mechanism to address current shortcomings. Unfortunately, rather than reminding Member States of their commitments, this resolution calls for more private sector investment. Merchandiseting education and humanitarian aid cannot be a solution. While the military intervention alone in Mali has cost about one billion euros, more than ever, I believe that it is all a matter of political choices.  So I chose to abstain.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. The UN estimates that 1 billion children live in conflict-affected areas, with a quarter of these children under the age of five and denied the right to education. It is also estimated that 65 million children are affected by emergency situations and prolonged crises and that approximately 37 million children of primary and low secondary education do not.  While we welcome the call on Member States to contribute to the increase in humanitarian funds for the education of children in emergency situations to 4 % of the humanitarian aid provided for in the EU budget, we believe that these funds should be channelled to the promotion of universal access to free and quality public education in all levels of education. Only with an educational policy that has as pillars these premises will it be possible to reverse the vicious circle of poverty that plagues the areas of the globe most affected by emergencies and prolonged crises.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. This is a good proposal in itself to ensure that displaced young people continue to be educated and thus trained. However, this resolution is not ambitious enough, as the education factor for displaced persons cannot be overstated. It is only through education that we can ensure that these people return or that they will one day leave the spiral of violence. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 Safeguarding the child in crisis or war contexts is an essential duty. The European Union cannot turn a blind eye to what is happening in many parts of the world and can ignore its political, economic and humanitarian aspect of this issue. Many steps have been taken, but many objectives must be achieved. I therefore voted in favour of a report which expresses the need to give the EU even greater responsibility for the defence of children.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Writing. I voted against the resolution because, as we know, children are our future, but this resolution is being proposed as a sham to enforce minority policies of asylum lobbyists in Europe. Of course, children should be supported and supported worldwide, but primarily in their own country and not when they move through Europe as nomads! The children cannot be blamed for this, but for the parents. However, such an approach must not be supported by an education policy aimed at continuing to allow economic migrants to enter Europe who only promise a better life and a better education.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament resolution on education for children in emergency situations and long-term crisis situations. For all its emotional understanding and the perfectly reasonable reasons behind the request to help children in emergency situations, it is not the EU's job to define the framework here. Genuine human and charitable aid takes place in an interpersonal context. It is not a task for parliaments, but for people who want to practice charity. Any interference by the EU, the nation states or even by the authorities in general prevents private involvement, which I believe is crucial here. Sometimes less is more – especially in the interpersonal sphere, if we want to maintain social coexistence.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 There are not a few organisations and NGOs around the world that focus their humanitarian action and assistance on children. Today, around ten million children worldwide live in refugee camps, while nearly nineteen million have been displaced from their homes by armed conflict. Particular attention should therefore be paid to strengthening a significant part of humanitarian action and aid in these areas. I supported the report with my vote in favour.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I support this resolution, as I consider education to be crucial for the reconstruction of countries affected by disasters or conflicts of war and, as a result, to support the economies of countries. Above all, educated people can move forward with the development of society, and educated people with critical thinking are less influenced and can contribute to the building of democracy. In my opinion, education is also a powerful tool needed to create a sense of normality and raise awareness of rights and help children and adolescents overcome trauma, re-engage with society after the conflict, acquire the skills needed to rebuild society and promote peace and reconciliation.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Millions of children in the current increasingly unstable situation live in war-affected areas, and millions of children do not even have access to basic education as a result of conflicts. This situation contributes to the fact that children are not only directly threatened by the ongoing conflict in the country, which is taking away their safety, but non-existent education also threatens their chances of a better future. These prospects are even worse for disadvantaged groups of children, children affected by poverty, girls or children with disabilities. And although the European Union is the largest donor of humanitarian aid, education for children in conflict areas remains unattainable due to other priorities, uncoordinated systems and a lack of partners. It is for this very reason that I was happy to support the report calling for more funding for education, but also for better cooperation with the private sector and donors.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. The UN estimates that billions of children live in conflict-affected areas. Much of these situations are a painful demonstration of the inhuman, exploitative and aggressive character of the capitalist system and have causes and responsible: the processes of destabilization in various parts of the globe and the wars of imperialist aggression, the policy of economic dominance and the collection of natural resources. In this regard, we condemn that eu and Member State action within the EU should be based on charity and not solidarity, which serves as a palliative and not an antidote.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, simplification, in particular of cohesion policy, is certainly needed because, of all the good things we do in the European Union, this is probably the most confusing in respect of application and oversight, etc. Then we add gold-plating, which often makes it even more difficult for would-be beneficiaries and, of course, more costly for SMEs. There really is a need for greater simplification, and I am delighted that the new Commission has put emphasis on that. They will have a field day here, because there is so much simplification needed. I once gave a talk on cohesion policy and I think it was probably the most boring speech I ever gave, because I was trying to explain something that is so complicated, it was almost impossible to put it in simple terms.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, companies do not want to do European projects not only in the Czech Republic, but also in other Member States of the European Union. They do not want to do them precisely because of how complex they are, what administrative burdens are associated with them. I am glad that we are trying to go down the path of simplification, because this is the only way to maintain any interest in European projects at all, in European funds. We should focus on achieving results, on the measurability of these results, on the sustainability of the results in practice, not just on a cheap or misleading burden of an administrative nature. For your idea: in the Czech Republic, the rural development programme, which is part of European funds, contains rules on 700 pages. Which of the novice farmers would like to read such a mathematics?

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: PPE). Madam President, the truth is that we are wasting time and time is precious, especially when it comes to the process of absorbing Community funds. There are countries, such as my own Greece, where Community resources are the only source to flow fresh money.  What can we do about it? First of all, let us make 31 December a mandatory condition for the transition to electronic cohesion and not make discounts. The common provisions will reduce the time between the submission of the application and the financing. In every way we speed up the process of returning money to beneficiaries.  You know, we are still struggling in Greece to absorb the resources of the previous Community framework, 2009-2013, and 2014 has not yet started to be absorbed. We need to help, too. We must crack down on red tape and move immediately to the resources we are entitled to.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Cohesion policy is one of the main instruments of the European Union, effectively realised the redistribution of funds in favour of less developed regions. Unfortunately, however, it should be noted that, as in several other cases of use of mutual funds, the distribution of cohesion policy resources is a very complex process.  It sometimes takes a very long time to submit a project to the transfer of the report. What do I want to say to that? While it is unlikely that anyone here will question the need for cohesion policy itself, it should long be reformed with the aim of simplifying and making all the principles of potential funded projects much more understandable. On the other hand, transparency in the implementation of the projects themselves should also be promoted.  And again, it would be very logical to switch (or at least partially) to the electronic format, as it concerns not only the cohesion project, but also the European Parliament. Because sometimes the number of papers that we colleagues spend ... just sorry tree. Thank you!

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ This report is regarding a simplification of the procedure in cohesion policy. In simple terms Parliament thinks that there are many faults in the current system that have many negative effects, i.e. the language is too complicated and also lost in translation, the procedure for allocation of cash is too slow and the process of transposition is too slow. This in turn has created a system that is not cost-effective. This motion for a resolution essentially asks for digitalisation of this process and calls for e-cohesion. Even though we are against the Commission distributing money and the processes involved with that, this resolution is essentially asking for a simplification of the current procedure which would make things more cost-effective in the long run. Therefore an abstention was recommended.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – This report is regarding a simplification of the procedure in cohesion policy. In simple terms Parliament thinks that there are many faults in the current system that have many negative effects, i.e. the language is too complicated and also lost in translation, the procedure for allocation of cash is too slow and the process of transposition is too slow. This in turn has created a system that is not cost-effective. This motion for a resolution essentially asks for digitalisation of this process and calls for e-cohesion. Even though we are against the Commission distributing money and the processes involved with that, this resolution is essentially asking for a simplification of the current procedure which would make things more cost-effective in the long run. Therefore an abstention was recommended.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution because it is an official position of the European Parliament to ask the Commission and the Member States to work together to lighten administrative burdens as well as to simplify the rules on cohesion policy funds. This concern expressed by Parliament concerns, inter alia, the relatively high percentage of programmes which are ultimately not carried out, due not only to budgetary constraints linked to the impact of the crisis and austerity policies, but also to delays in payments, the bureaucratic burden or the contradiction of rules. However, such simplification of the rules should not serve as an excuse for, on the one hand, letting your guard down from account control and the use of allocated budget items, or on the other hand, to leave the door open to financing instruments that are already beginning to participate actively in operational programmes, such as private credit institutions or venture capital funds.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – This resolution was proposed by the Committee on Regional Development in recognition of the fact that complicated procedures, such as administration and onerous auditing procedures, can place a heavy burden on beneficiaries of cohesion policy funding.  The resolution recommends a simplification of the rules, especially for those beneficiaries with less administrative and financial capacities, in order to better meet the needs of funding recipients. It also calls on the Commission to enter into an ongoing dialogue with Parliament, the Committee of the Regions and other stakeholders on all aspects of any simplification process. We therefore voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. Complicated procedures for applying for and managing EU financial assistance from Structural and Cohesion Policy funds sometimes deter potential applicants altogether. This does not actually raise the funds available. The policy therefore fails to serve its purpose, because it was supposed to motivate us to successfully apply for and manage EU financial assistance. I therefore welcome the resolution initiated by the Committee on Regional Development and adopted by the European Parliament as a whole, which once again raises this issue and calls, among other things, for guidelines and roadmaps for simplification from the European Commission in order to raise awareness among Member States and their regions of reducing the administrative burden and over-regulation in connection with the award of public contracts. At the same time, it is essential that all, i.e. the European Commission and the Member States and their regions, optimise their monitoring, control and reporting activities in order to remove the current bottlenecks, while not losing an appropriate balance between simplification on the one hand and the prevention of irregularities, such as fraud, on the other.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This report acknowledges that administrative procedures are too complex and that simplification is more than necessary. However, it asks the Commission to provide a roadmap to the Member States. In addition, a strengthening of relations with local authorities without going through the national authorities is requested. I have therefore chosen to abstain on this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This report is regarding a simplification of the procedure in cohesion policy. In simple terms Parliament thinks that there are many faults in the current system, which has many negative effects. The language is too complicated and also lost in translation, the procedure of allocation of cash is too slow and the process of transposition is too slow. This in turn has created a system that is cost-ineffective. This motion for a resolution essentially asks for a digitalisation of this process and calls for e-cohesion.
