Even though we are against the Commission distributing money and the processes involved with that, this resolution is essentially asking for a simplification of the current procedure, which would make things more cost-effective in the long run. This is utterly unobjectionable and I voted in favour.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 Although the reform of cohesion policy for the 2014-2020 programming period was carried out, addressing simplification methods, the implementation, management, reporting and control of the European Structural and Investment Funds are still difficult for both beneficiaries and managing authorities. I agree that the Commission should provide detailed simplification guidelines in order to inform Member States of their task of eliminating or at least significantly reducing the administrative burden resulting from the selection of proposed projects and monitoring and control activities involving public procurement processes at national and local level. It is important that the Commission and the Member States promote simplification of the rules governing financial instruments of the ESI Funds in order to better adapt these instruments to the needs of beneficiaries.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. The text recognises that administrative procedures are too complex and therefore require real simplification. This admission is to the credit of the Brussels bureaucrats.  Nevertheless, it calls on the Commission to provide a roadmap for states and calls for strengthening relations with local authorities at the expense of national authorities. Another way to cut back on what is left of our sovereignty... I abstained.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this simplification. The general cohesion policy has, right now, many overlapping spaces and spaces on which it is difficult to decide what would be its best fit. We understand that a simplification in the respective policy would allow greater ease in understanding the usefulness of the policy, as well as greater chances that citizens would be aware of the existence of it.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a Resolution on simplification and orientation to the results of cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020 to ask the Commission to introduce detailed guidelines on simplification in order to inform Member States and their regions of their task of eliminating or at least reducing the administrative burden and over-regulation observed at national and local level in recruitment processes selection of project proposals and follow-up and control activities. In addition, the Commission should provide a sheet to streamline and simplify control, monitoring and reporting activities for beneficiaries in order to eliminate current bottlenecks.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I abstained on this text on the search for simplification and effectiveness in cohesion policy for 2014-2020. Indeed, it recognizes that administrative procedures are too complex and require real simplification. Unfortunately, at the same time, this text calls on the Commission to provide a roadmap for Member States and even calls for strengthening direct relations with local authorities to the detriment of national authorities. I cannot therefore endorse this party which wants to sweep away the sovereignty of nation states in favour of EU-local government relations.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe it is essential that European cohesion policy moves towards a clear simplification. Our businesses, our territories and our citizens need less administrative burdens, less regulation at both national and regional level. I am also convinced that the Commission itself should have a less bureaucratic approach during the application phase for access to EU funding, so as to facilitate access to and disbursement, maximising its effectiveness, for all these reasons I intended to support this text with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The EU institutions have taken important steps to address the issue of simplification. Despite the efforts made, excessive formalities remain an obstacle to the efficient management of the EIE Funds.  This motion for a Resolution calls on the Commission, inter alia, to share simplification initiatives and guidelines, to strike an optimal balance between accountability and simplification, to fully implement electronic cohesion in the management of the EIE Funds, to adopt and implement a flexible approach to beneficiaries' data and information facilitation obligations , and participate in a structured and permanent dialogue with the European Parliament and other partners. For all this, I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted for this resolution because, although the reform of cohesion policy for the 2014-2020 programming period was carried out, addressing simplification methods, the implementation, management, reporting and control of the European Structural and Investment (ESI) Funds, the reporting and control of the European Structural and Investment (ESI) Funds are still difficult for both beneficiaries and managing authorities, in particular with limited administrative and financial capacity. The European Parliament considers that the Commission should provide detailed simplification guidelines in order to inform Member States and their regions of their task of eliminating or at least significantly reducing the administrative burden resulting from public procurement processes at national and local level, the selection of proposed projects and monitoring and control activities. Parliament therefore calls on the Commission, in coordination with the Member States and in accordance with the principle of proportionality, to establish and implement flexible principles for the data and information requirements for beneficiaries during the application process and in the reporting process relating to EU funding under shared management, as well as to promote the exchange of good practices.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 Notwithstanding the reformed cohesion policy for the 2014-2020 financial planning period, which addresses simplification methods, the application, management, reporting and control of the European Structural and Investment Funds remain cumbersome for both beneficiaries and managing authorities, in particular those with lower administrative and financial capacity. The current over-regulation, including the process of transposing the rules into national law, causes delays and creates longer absences from the market and indirect costs for potential beneficiaries who require EU funds, thereby reducing the investment impact of EU funding and creating barriers for beneficiaries, citizens and companies, in particular small and medium-sized enterprises in the Union. Complex procedures can place a significant burden on beneficiaries, in particular small and medium-sized enterprises, NGOs and municipalities that need EU funding. Since, in general, these organisations do not have the financial and human resources and expertise to successfully apply for and manage EU funds, I consider it necessary to further simplify the procedure, and I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 Simplifying cohesion policy is an important step towards making the most of the opportunities for growth and development offered by this policy, especially in the light of its contribution to achieving the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy. Investment in small and medium-sized enterprises, macro-regional strategies, as well as urban and territorial strategies, demonstrate the close link between the support offered by cohesion policy and the short- and long-term objectives of the Union. Despite this, the benefits of cohesion policy and its funding are not yet being exploited to the full, mainly because of the many bureaucratic burdens that prevent those who could benefit from it from enjoying it to the full. That is why we need a simpler cohesion policy, which will attract potential beneficiaries to this fundamental instrument, making the procedures linked to the management and disbursement of funds more streamlined and transparent. We also need an approach that is more focused on tangible and measurable results and that makes this policy more accessible, including in terms of the timing of obtaining funding.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution acknowledges that the complexity of administrative procedures reduces the effectiveness of structural funds in EU Member States. The text stresses that beneficiaries, particularly SMALLos and SMEs, no longer necessarily have an interest in making requests as the costs of obtaining these funds are sometimes too high. This is why simplification would help to increase the absorption rate of funds. We are pleased to see the European institutions becoming aware of the negative consequences of their bureaucratic system, which are harmful to economic actors. Nevertheless, we are opposed to the Commission making new recommendations to the Member States. We consider that the factors of the current administrative complexity are mainly to be sought in the Commission's refusal to review its internal functioning. Finally, we are absolutely not in favour of the Union strengthening its relations with local authorities as requested in the text.  I therefore abstained on this text.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that cohesion policy is one of the most important instruments available to the European Union to combat inequality and to support territorial and social cohesion in its regions. The 2014-2020 programming period has made remarkable changes in the simplification methods addressed in cohesion policy, but, nevertheless, certain procedures for reporting, control over the European Structural and Investment Funds are still hampered by bureaucratic mechanisms. These types of cumbersome procedures become an impediment both for beneficiaries, in particular small and medium-sized enterprises, NGOs and municipalities whose administrative and financial capacity is limited, and for managing authorities. Furthermore, another obstacle faced by the above-mentioned beneficiaries is the current over-regulation which causes delays, involving certain indirect costs for those eligible to receive EU funding. All these difficulties lead to negative ends, reducing the impact of investments in European finance. Immediate measures should be taken to simplify and guide cohesion policy towards performance in order to increase the impact of European projects and to attract beneficiaries constantly.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission should introduce detailed guidelines on simplification in order to make Member States and regions aware of their task of eliminating, or at least significantly reducing, the administrative burden and over-regulation present at national and local level in the framework of procurement procedures, the selection of proposed projects and monitoring and control activities. The Commission is invited to define and apply, in coordination with Member States and in line with the principle of proportionality, a 'light' approach to beneficiaries' data and information obligations during the application and reporting phase on EU funding under shared management. The Commission and the Member States make more frequent use of the multi-fund approach, taking into account the needs of the beneficiaries. Vote.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. Cohesion policy is key to achieving the growth and employment targets set out in the Europe 2020 strategy. The structural funds that make up the cohesion policy allow European citizens to finance their various projects. These funds must be available as quickly as possible so that this funding has a direct impact on the real economy and on job creation. With this in mind, procedures for obtaining these funds must be simplified so that they are allocated more quickly to recipients. Of course, controls are necessary. It is not a question of funding any project. However, we must not get lost in a bureaucracy that would scare away the smallest project owners. I voted in favour of this report and therefore for a more effective cohesion policy.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on 'Towards simplifying cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020 and its results orientation'. The Union's institutions have made considerable progress towards simplifying the procedures for access to the European Structural and Investment Funds. Despite the improvements in tasks, however, there are still many procedures to be streamlined in order to prevent the impact of investments promoted by EU funds from being limited by over-regulation. This proposal calls on the Commission to introduce detailed guidelines on simplification in order to eliminate or significantly reduce the administrative burden under local legislation, which is why I voted for its acceptance.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This was a particularly important resolution, the aim of which is to simplify access to cohesion funding.  The resolution was proposed by the Committee on Regional Development in recognition of the fact that complicated procedures (such as administration issues and onerous auditing procedures) around cohesion policy funding can place a heavy burden on beneficiaries and that there is a need to simplify the rules, especially for beneficiaries with less administrative and financial capacities, in order to better align financial instruments to beneficiaries’ needs. It calls on the Commission to enter into an ongoing dialogue with Parliament, the Committee of the Regions and other stakeholders on all aspects of any simplification process.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ This report is regarding a simplification of the procedure in cohesion policy. In simple terms Parliament thinks that there are many faults in the current system that have many negative effects, i.e, the language is too complicated and also lost in translation, the procedure for allocation of cash is too slow and the process of transposition is too slow. This in turn has created a system that is not cost-effective. This motion for a resolution essentially asks for digitalisation of this process and calls for e-cohesion. Even though we are against the Commission distributing money and the processes involved with that, this resolution is essentially asking for a simplification of the current procedure which would make things more cost-effective in the long run. Therefore an abstention was recommended.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because I think the Commission should introduce guidelines on simplifications for Member States to be aware of their tasks, and provide them with information for simplifying control, monitoring, reporting activities and beneficiaries.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The existing over-regulation under the reformed cohesion policy for the 2014-2020 programming period – including in the transposition of rules into national law – acts as a brake and determines indirect costs for potential beneficiaries seeking EU funding, thereby reducing the impact on investment of Union funds and creating obstacles for beneficiaries, citizens and businesses in the EU , in particular for small and medium-sized enterprises. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution, which calls on the Commission and the Member States to promote the simplification of the rules governing financial instruments under the European Structural and Investment Funds, in order to bring them closer to the needs of beneficiaries and, ultimately, to improve their use.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The Resolution calls on the Commission and the Member States to establish and implement, in coordination with Member States and in accordance with the principle of proportionality, a soft approach to data and information requirements from beneficiaries during the application and reporting process on EU funding in the context of shared management, as well as to encourage the exchange of good practices. The Commission and the Member States are asked to increase the use of the multi-facility approach, taking into account the needs of beneficiaries. We de facto support the resolution.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure, because there is considerable progress that the EU institutions have made towards simplification, adopting several measures including the programme to simplify the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework. Despite the focus on simplification methods under the reformed cohesion policy for the 2014-2020 programming period, the submission of applications, management, reporting and control under the EIS Funds remain complex for both beneficiaries and managing authorities. Parliament considered that the Commission should introduce detailed guidelines on simplification in order to make Member States and regions aware of their task of significantly reducing administrative burdens and over-regulation at national and local level in the framework of procurement procedures, the selection of proposed projects and monitoring and control activities, for example by avoiding frequent regulatory changes , simplifying language and normalising procedures, as well as making the EU budget tangible. It also called on the Commission to enter into a structured and permanent dialogue with Parliament, the Committee of the Regions and other stakeholders on all aspects of the simplification process.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ This report is regarding a simplification of the procedure in cohesion policy. In simple terms Parliament thinks that there are many faults in the current system that have many negative effects, i.e. the language is too complicated and also lost in translation, the procedure for allocation of cash is too slow and the process of transposition is too slow. This in turn has created a system that is not cost effective. This motion for a resolution essentially asks for digitalisation of this process and calls for e-cohesion. Even though we are against the Commission distributing money and the processes involved with that, this resolution is essentially asking for a simplification of the current procedure which would make things more cost-effective in the long run. Therefore an abstention was recommended.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite the considerable progress made by the European institutions towards simplifying legislation and administrative procedures in the field of cohesion policy, there are still many bureaucratic obstacles that undermine the proper functioning of the allocation of European Structural and Investment Funds. In particular, it highlights the difficulty on the part of both beneficiaries and fund management authorities in the application, management, reporting and investment control procedures. The complexity of the procedures and the existing over-regulation are the main causes of this criticality. Administrative simplification should be balanced with the detection and prevention of irregularities and fraud through the rationalisation and structured organisation of control, monitoring and reporting activities. In this regard, Member States should commit themselves to significantly reducing the administrative and bureaucratic burden at national and local level on citizens and small and medium-sized enterprises and to overseeing the procedures for awarding contracts and projects. I welcome the motion for a resolution tabled as it aims to simplify the rules of cohesion policy by making financial instruments more accessible to beneficiaries and improving their use.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ Cities and urban areas should play a stronger role in cohesion policy in the 2014-2020 programming period. Initiatives and guidelines relating to simplification, based on best practice and the recommendations of the high-level group, need to be shared with Member States and regions in order to stimulate a reduction in administrative burden and to make our cohesion policy more effective both at EU and national level. We need a structured and permanent dialogue with Parliament, the Committee of the Regions and other stakeholders.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution because it is an official position of the European Parliament to ask the Commission and member states to work together to lighten administrative burdens as well as to simplify the rules on cohesion policy funds. This concern expressed by Parliament concerns, inter alia, the relatively high percentage of programmes which are ultimately not carried out, due not only to budgetary constraints linked to the impact of the crisis and austerity policies, but also to delays in payments, the bureaucratic burden or the contradiction of rules. However, such simplification of the rules should not serve as an excuse for, on the one hand, letting your guard down from account control and the use of allocated budget items, or on the other hand, to leave the door open to financing instruments that are already beginning to participate actively in operational programmes, such as private credit institutions or venture capital funds.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a particularly sensitive and complex issue, which will be at the heart of both the 2014-2020 implementation and the post-2020. The Council and the Committee recognise that good governance and administrative capacity are among the main prerequisites for achieving the objectives of cohesion policy and that the responsibility for improving administrative capacity lies with the Member States and their regions, however much they are supported by the Commission. However, a dangerous prospect must be avoided, in which small and rich countries – which have reduced financial allocations – converge on a concept of simplification strongly linked to proportionality, which is translated into: the financial dimension of resources, the quality of governance, programme management, the level of risk of regularity of investments. So the danger to be avert is a two-size world: all simple and light for the group of small and good, vice versa, multiplied controls for those who have so many resources and a weak management capacity. Simplification means paying more attention to content and less to pieces of paper and, above all, ensuring equal treatment between Member States and correctly interpreting the principle of proportionality.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The resolution highlights that the Commission should introduce detailed guidelines on simplification in order to make the Member States and their regions aware of their task of eliminating, or at least significantly reducing, the administrative burden and gold-plating arising at national and local level in the processes of procurement, project proposal selection, and monitoring and control activities, including avoiding frequent changes in rules, simplifying language and standardising procedures, as well as focusing the EU budget on tangible results. As I am completely in favour of facilitating such processes for our citizens and those involved I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this motion for a resolution calling for simplification and a move towards a more performance orientated approach in EU regional funding. Any effort to cut red tape is welcome, particularly in this hugely burdensome area, although we obviously need to strike the right balance between simplification and ensuring effective and reliable financial controls.  As this resolution makes clear, there is much more that can be done to simplify and improve the current system of managing regional spending. A ʽone-stop-shopʼ approach remains our ultimate goal, and in the meantime with more support for online applications and language simplification, we can help speed up application-to-grant times and reduce the administrative burden on local authorities and small businesses in managing regional spending. All of this will deliver a better pound-for-pound return to taxpayers on money invested in regional development.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 Although the reform of cohesion policy for the 2014-2020 programming period - in which the methods of simplification, application, management, reporting and control in relation to the European Structural and Investment Funds are addressed - is still cumbersome, both for beneficiaries and for managing authorities, in particular those with less administrative and financial capacity, I believe that the simplification of the rules on financial instruments under the ESI Funds should be promoted, I believe that simplification of the rules on financial instruments under the ESI Funds should be promoted , with a view to aligning them more closely with the needs of beneficiaries and, finally, improving their use.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This resolution calls for greater simplification and efficiency in cohesion policy, despite efforts already made through improved regulation and policy reform in the 2014-2020 programme. In particular, the European Parliament points to the existing over-regulation, including in the process of transposing European rules by national authorities, and the administrative burden caused by complex procedures that discourage applicants for EU funds.  The resolution calls on the European Commission to provide Member States and regions with detailed guidelines, as well as a roadmap to streamline and simplify monitoring, monitoring and reporting activities, including for beneficiaries. Supporting the objectives of this report and convinced of the importance of European funds in supporting economic and social development projects at the local level, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 Serious progress has already been made in the area of cohesion policy in order to reduce administrative burdens and simplify them, but the administrative obligations imposed on the european structural and investment fund's end-leaver are still extremely significant. This is particularly difficult for SMEs, non-public organisations and municipalities, as these organisations and institutions desperately need EU funding, but do not have the financial and human resources capacity to successfully apply and manage the resources they receive. Against this background, further simplification is essential for the effective use of resources. Frequent changes to the rules should be avoided, procedures should be standardised, language used simplified, e-cohesion should be promoted, dissemination and one-stop shop should be promoted. The motion for a resolution on the simplification and performance orientation of cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020 sets out a number of useful ideas on the subject, so I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution in the plenary vote in Strasbourg on 26 November.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 The simpler access to European funds, the greater the chance that my country will be able to absorb most of the European funds allocated to it. I hope that this will happen after the adoption of this resolution, even more so that two of my compatriots are involved in its drafting. In many respects, the European administration is cumbersome and complex, and that is why I always support such documents that make it easier to apply for European projects. Of course, these facilities should not lead to bad practices, failure to comply with the rules and even abuse. I support this motion for a resolution, but I ask the responsible authorities to respect and punish with all rigour all offenders.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The introduction of detailed simplification directives is important because it guides Member States and regions to eliminate and/or drastically reduce management burdens, especially in cases of action control, project selection and public expenditure. This simplification extends proportionately to the control and reporting of activities, to the application and reporting of expenditure linked to European financial programmes and to the reduction of application times - allocation of funds, through the use of electronic applications and digital platforms.

text: in writing. – This report is regarding a simplification of the procedure in cohesion policy. In simple terms Parliament thinks that there are many faults in the current system that have many negative effects, i.e. the language is too complicated and also lost in translation, the procedure for allocation of cash is too slow and the process of transposition is too slow. Therefore an abstention was recommended.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament recognises the importance of significant measures taken by the EU institutions towards simplification, such as the simplification agenda for the multiannual financial framework 2014-2020. However, the Commission should provide detailed guidelines on simplification in order to raise awareness among Member States and their regions of their task of eliminating or at least significantly reducing the administrative burden and over-regulation generated at national and local level in procurement processes, selection of project proposals and monitoring and control activities.  I voted in favour.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This motion for a resolution follows an oral question at the second plenary session in October on this same subject. It wishes to recognise the importance of what has already been done with regard to the simplification of the procedures for the preparation of applications, the presentation of results and the various moments of evaluation of projects, in the implementation of the Directives for such simplification. The issue of administrative simplification and capacity building for meeting the requirements of the EU Structural and Cohesion Funds is crucial. In many realities, take the Portuguese as an example, the existing rules and the bureaucratic web involved in mobilising EU funds in general (cohesion unfortunately does not escape the rule), constitute an impediment to the eligibility of projects and, consequently, determine, in practice, the lack of access to cohesion funds. This issue affects, in particular, the popular-based associative movement, non-governmental organisations, micro, small and medium-sized enterprises and local authorities.  In this sense, further simplification will result in greater potential for access to funds by these agents. The report stresses that simplification should be balanced with prevention and detection of irregularities, i.e. safeguarding that facilitation does not mean laxity, which could benefit fraudulent processes. We voted in favour.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 In the 2014-2020 programming period, cohesion policy reform was carried out, which dealt with simplification methods, yet it is still the case that the application, management, reporting and control of the European Structural and Investment Funds are still difficult for both funding beneficiaries and managing authorities, especially if they have less administrative and financial capacity. The European Commission must provide Member States and their regions with a roadmap for the implementation to rationalise and simplify control, monitoring and reporting activities, including for beneficiaries, in order to remove obstacles to the smooth operation of activities. In the future, the European Commission and the Member States must also support the simplification of the rules governing financial instruments under the European Structural and Investment Funds in order to better align them with the needs of beneficiaries and ultimately improve their use.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this resolution which aims to simplify and make Member States and regions aware of their task of eliminating, or at least reducing, administrative burdens in the context of procurement procedures, the selection of proposed projects and monitoring and control activities.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The introduction of detailed simplification directives is important because it guides Member States and regions in eliminating and/or drastically reducing management burdens, especially in cases of action control, project selection and public expenditure. This simplification extends proportionately to the control and reporting of activities, to the application and reporting of expenditure linked to European financial programmes and to the reduction of application times - allocation of funds through the use of electronic applications and digital platforms. For the above reasons I am voting against the report.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Despite the reformed cohesion policy for the 2014-2020 programming period, in which simplification methods are addressed, application, management, reporting and control with respect to the European Structural and Investment Funds are still cumbersome for both beneficiaries and managing authorities. Complicated procedures can place a significant burden on beneficiaries. I therefore believe that the Commission should introduce detailed guidelines on simplification in order to make the Member States and their regions aware of their task of eliminating, or at least significantly reducing, the administrative burden and gold-plating arising at national and local levels. Moreover, the Commission should provide the Member States and their regions with a roadmap for streamlining and simplifying control, monitoring and reporting activities.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution on the simplification of cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020 provides for a number of useful ideas. That's why I voted in favour. SMEs, non-governmental organisations and municipalities desperately need EU funding, but do not have the financial and human resources capacity to successfully apply and manage the resources they receive. Against this background, further simplification is essential for the effective use of resources. Frequent changes to the rules should be avoided, procedures should be standardised, language used simplified, e-cohesion should be promoted, dissemination and one-stop shop should be promoted.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the need to simplify cohesion policy to make it less cumbersome for both beneficiaries and management authorities, especially those with lower administrative and financial capacities. We must also address the problems posed by the current over-regulation, in particular in the process of transposing rules into national legislation, which causes delays and leads to longer market exclusion time and indirect costs for potential beneficiaries of EU funding, reducing the investment impact of EU funds.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution that calls for the simplification of procedures to access and manage EU funding in order to reduce administrative burden on beneficiaries, in particular small and medium-size businesses and municipalities. I welcome this report that also asks the Commission to introduce guidelines on simplification for managing authorities and to encourage the sharing of good practices.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this simplification. The general cohesion policy has, right now, many overlapping spaces and spaces on which it is difficult to decide what would be its best fit. We understand that a simplification in the respective policy would allow greater ease in understanding the usefulness of the policy, as well as greater chances that citizens would be aware of the existence of it.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my Labour Party colleagues, I voted in favour of the resolution as it calls on the Commission to provide Member States and their regions with a roadmap for streamlining and simplifying control, monitoring and reporting activities, including for beneficiaries, in order to do away with the current bottlenecks in funding.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ Despite the reformed cohesion policy for the 2014-2020 programming period, in which simplification methods are addressed, application, management, reporting and control with respect to the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIF) are still cumbersome for both beneficiaries and managing authorities, in particular those with fewer administrative and financial capacities, and should be simplified.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution because the complicated procedures can place a significant burden on beneficiaries, in particular small and medium-sized businesses, NGOs and municipalities which are in need of EU funding. In general these entities do not have the financial and human resources nor the expertise to successfully apply for and manage EU grants. Simplification through new measures can help cut obstacles and increase the overall investment impact of EU funding.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on simplification in cohesion policy. Although the results of cohesion policy are encouraging and lead to real development and investment, I am convinced that these effects could be further enhanced if administrative barriers reducing the effectiveness of cohesion policy were removed. The source of many problems is undoubtedly the lack of trust between all beneficiary actors, managing authorities and the European Commission. I am convinced that increasing flexibility, based on mutual trust between the various actors, would allow us to respond quickly and effectively to the needs that have arise, thereby unlocking the additional potential of cohesion policy. Incomprehensible guidelines and regulations, as well as the formulation of expectations from beneficiaries, also often require refinement and simplification. These factors, which are not due to the bad will of the beneficiaries, are often later the cause of the irregularities detected at the audit stage.  I am convinced that the resolution voted on today is an important step towards the implementation of much-needed simplifications, and I hope that they will be implemented soon.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Serious progress has already been made in the area of cohesion policy in order to reduce administrative burdens and simplify them. However, the administrative obligations imposed on the european structural and investment fund's end-leaver are still extremely significant. This is particularly difficult for SMEs, non-governmental organisations and municipalities. It is known that these organisations and institutions desperately need EU funding, but do not have the financial and human resources to successfully apply and manage the resources they receive. The motion for a resolution on the simplification and performance orientation of cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020 sets out a number of useful ideas on the subject, so I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution in the plenary vote in Strasbourg on 26 November.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: in writing. ‒ As a local Member of the European Parliament, I have never visited any of the many wonderful EU projects in my East of England constituency without hearing questions and concerns about the bureaucratic complexity of claiming European Union funding. Today’s vote represents our next efforts to act on those concerns. Further moves towards full online applications and monitoring, introducing standard scales of unit costs, ending the duplication of audits, combating the tendency of Member States to ‘gold-plate European Union regulations, avoiding frequent changes in rules and simplifying language and standardising procedures, these can all contribute to making it easier for smaller businesses and voluntary organisations to access the funding. I commend the work of the ‘Europe Connects’ advisers in the East of England, who helped to identify project proposals and assisted project applicants. Sadly their once-free service has been hit by insufficient budgetary resources and now has to be paid for. If the proposals in this report go through, their work will be made easier and the European Union money will be enabled to go further.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly agree with the Commission providing the Member States with a roadmap for simplifying control, monitoring and reporting activities. Moreover, what is very needed is a simplification of the rules governing financial instruments within ESI Funds.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the motion for a Resolution - According to the simplified impact-oriented Cohesion Policy for the period 2014-2020, given that as a former prefect of Istria County who has achieved excellent results in the field of European funds, I know well the problems of preparing, nominating and implementing EU projects. All phases of the management of EU programmes, from European to national and regional levels, as well as all phases of the project cycle faced by beneficiaries of European funds, need to be simplified. In doing so, models should be found that will enable the simple application of European programmes, improve absorption of funds and focus on results. It is necessary to pay attention that such simplified rules also prevent possible abuses and fraud when using EU funds. In this regard, I support the Commission's efforts to simplify cohesion policy, but on the other hand it should be noted that such a process itself becomes quite complicated for beneficiaries, given that different funds have different rules. The solution may be in the preparation of cohesion policy in the next programming period taking into account the experience of the simplification process and the unease of rules and modes of operation with all EU funds.

This in turn has created a system that is not cost-effective. This motion for a resolution essentially asks for digitalisation of this process and calls for e-cohesion. Even though we are against the Commission distributing money and the processes involved with that, this resolution is essentially asking for a simplification of the current procedure which would make things more cost-effective in the long run. My colleagues and I therefore abstained.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the search for simplification and efficiency in cohesion policy because I believe that there is an urgent need to act so that project owners who claim European funds are no longer discouraged by the complexity of the procedures. Indeed, management costs, the number of supporting documents or processing times are all factors that discourage potential beneficiaries and especially the "smallest".  If controls are necessary and legitimate, a better balance must be found to reduce the share of European funds absorbed by bureaucracy. Much progress remains to be made to simplify the rules that apply to beneficiaries and fund managers, both on the side of the European Commission and on the side of the Member States, which too often add administrative layers by transposing European texts. In my view, access to financing for SMEs and the development of online procedures are to be prioritized. This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The streamlining of the effectiveness of cohesion policy is to be welcomed in principle, but the motion for a resolution does not cover the key problems of policy, such as the misuse of funds. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution as it calls on the Commission to provide the Member States and their regions with a roadmap for streamlining and simplifying control, monitoring and reporting activities, including for beneficiaries, in order to do away with the current bottlenecks.
