name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this important motion, which sees my colleague Theresa Reintke as rapporteur. The economic crisis of recent years has, in many cases, forced the Member States to make restrictive budgetary policy choices, which have reduced the financial capacity, particularly of local authorities, by creating disparities between the various regions and municipalities within them. In this case, this Parliament, the Council and the Commission are being asked to mobilise cohesion policy in favour of the city of Rome, which is facing major challenges of change and modernisation, not least the great Jubilee event.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I abstained on this resolution. It is true that administrative procedures need to be simplified. But it advocates strengthening the Union's relations with local authorities at the expense of states.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I have refrained from defending the simplification of the rules, but I do not agree with this policy in principle.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Despite the reform of cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020, which addressed simplification methods, applications, governance, reporting and controls, policies are complicated for beneficiaries and managing authorities, especially for those with fewer administrative and financial capacities.  I supported the European Parliament's resolution, as cohesion policy needs to be simplified and member state governments to assist municipalities and cities with lower fiscal capacity in preparing and co-financing projects. I agree that simplification of the rules for managing ESI Funds' financial resources should be promoted in order to ultimately improve their use. Success auditing is an effective instrument that assesses the effectiveness of the operation and comes up with effective proposals to simplify policies.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution on simplification and performance-oriented orientation in cohesion policy for 2014-2020, because it is complete and documented, and for and for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 27/10/2015.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this resolution which notes that despite the reformed cohesion policy for the 2014-2020 programming period, in which simplification methods are addressed, application, management, reporting and control with respect to the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIF) are still cumbersome for both beneficiaries and managing authorities, in particular those with fewer administrative and financial capacities.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy is the Union's main investment policy, providing the framework and investment strategy needed to invest in agreed growth targets. The European Union aims to achieve five concrete objectives on innovation, employment, education, social inclusion and climate/energy by 2020. Despite the significant progress made by the Union institutions towards simplification, it is still necessary to introduce detailed guidelines on simplification so that Member States and regions can eliminate or drastically reduce the over-regulation of procedures at national and local level.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution deals with the simplification of cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020. In view of the existing over-regulation, including with regard to the transposition of rules into national law, as well as the complexity of the procedures, which can place a heavy burden on small and medium-sized enterprises, NGOs and municipalities in need of EU funding, I feel I must support the position of my fellow authors of the proposal. It calls on the Commission to introduce guidelines on simplification, in order to urge Member States to reduce the burden at national and local level within the framework of various administrative procedures, such as procurement procedures, the selection of proposed projects and monitoring and control activities.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. In principle, streamlining the effectiveness of cohesion policy must be favoured, but the motion for a resolution does not address the central problems of cohesion policy, such as misuse of funds, etc. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. On the assumption that the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESI Funds) are still too complex for both beneficiaries and management authorities, the report proposes to simplify the rules. It is true that small and medium-sized enterprises, NGOs and municipalities, which need EU funding, often do not have the financial and human resources or the skills to successfully apply for and manage EU subsidies. The report therefore proposes to "simplify the language" or to establish a one-stop shop for regional funding.  But it also calls on the Commission to urge states to "significantly reduce the administrative burden and over-regulation" which include "contracting procedures, the selection of project proposals and monitoring and monitoring activities". On the contrary, I believe that strict controls are essential when it comes to public money. I abstain on this report.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution - Towards simplification and performance orientation in the framework of cohesion policy for 2014-2020.  It is essential that the EU institutions move towards simplification, such as the simplification agenda for the multiannual financial framework 2014-2020, the establishment of a high-level Group of independent experts on monitoring simplification for beneficiaries of the European Structural and Investment Funds, the revised financial regulation and the Common Provisions Regulation. The European Commission should raise awareness among Member States and their regions to make efforts to eliminate or substantially reduce the administrative burden and excessive regulation created at national and local level in procurement processes, selection of project proposals and monitoring and control activities. It will also be important for the Commission to establish a permanent dialogue with the European Parliament, the Committee of the Regions and other stakeholders on all aspects of this simplification process.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this resolution as it highlights the need for the Commission to put a strategy in place to lift the administrative burden on Member States. Due to regional differences within the European Union and within Member States the effectiveness of the cohesion policy may be asymmetric due to these different regional characteristics. This resolution strives to reduce unnecessary bureaucracy in the procedure.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I support the motion for a resolution to reduce the administrative burden on cohesion policy for 2014-2020. Simplifying control activities would save beneficiaries a heavy administrative burden. Generally, entities applying for subsidies do not have the opportunity to successfully manage EU subsidies. Therefore, it goes without saying that burdening them will penalize them all the more. In addition, there are direct costs to beneficiaries, thereby reducing the impact on investments of EU funding.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. \u2012 Even after the reform of cohesion policy aimed at simplifying it, the application, management, reporting and control of the European Structural and Investment Funds remains too complicated for many beneficiaries and managing authorities. I am particularly concerned about the unnecessary addition of new obligations during transposition at Member State level, which goes beyond the requirements of EU acts and which create additional obstacles for beneficiaries and, in particular, municipalities and small and medium-sized enterprises with less administrative and financial capacity. I therefore appeal to the Member States to avoid complex procedures, because they only create an unnecessary burden for their own actors, such as municipalities in particular, which thus come to develop with European funds earmarked specifically for the development of the regions.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on simplification and performance orientation in cohesion policy 2014-2020 because I agree that the Commission should introduce detailed guidelines on simplification in order to make the Member States and their regions aware of their task of eliminating, or at least significantly reducing, the administrative burden and gold-plating arising at national and local levels in the processes of procurement, project proposal selection, and monitoring and control activities, including avoiding frequent changes in rules, simplifying language and standardising procedures, as well as focusing the EU budget on tangible results.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Committee on Regional Development has tabled a motion for a parliamentary resolution urging the simplification of cohesion policy. It points out that the application, management, reporting and control of the European Structural and Investment Funds remain difficult for both beneficiaries and managing authorities. It notes that the current over-regulation, including the process of transposing the rules into national law, causes delays and that complex procedures can place a significant burden on beneficiaries. In view of all this, it recommends that the Commission take appropriate action. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite the reform of cohesion policy for the 2014-2020 programming period, which addresses simplification methods, implementation, management, reporting and control with regard to ESI Funds, obstacles remain for beneficiaries and managing authorities, in particular those with fewer administrative and financial capacities. I support the Commission's proposal on simplification, raising member states' awareness of drastically reducing or eliminating administrative burden and excessive regulation in procurement procedures, selection of project proposals and monitoring and control activities. I would argue that the Commission should provide a guide for streamlining and simplifying information control, monitoring and reporting activities. At the same time, it should outline, in coordination with the Member States, a simple view of the data and information requirements imposed on beneficiaries in the application process and in the reporting of EU funds under shared management, as well as to encourage the sharing of good practices. I believe that the simplification of the rules governing financial instruments within the ESI Funds should meet the real needs of beneficiaries and thereby improve their absorption and implementation.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 Although it acknowledges the progress made by the European institutions towards simplifying the EIS fund system, the procedural rules on the submission of applications, management, control and reporting still define a particularly complex system for both managing and awarding authorities. Over-regulation, partly caused by the legislative redundancy created when Community legislation is transposed, leads to an extension of the time which, in turn, increases indirect costs for beneficiaries and reduces the effect of investments. The complexity of procedures and administrative delays are a deterrent to small and medium-sized enterprises, small local authorities and smaller NGOs.  In view of the facts, I can therefore only welcome a resolution promoting a simplification process that takes particular account of small and medium-sized enterprises and smaller local realities. I am particularly in favour of the call for the Commission to draw up simplification guidelines for national administrative authorities responsible for managing EIS funds.  Furthermore, the reduction in the financial burden on beneficiaries and the establishment of a one-stop shop meet with my strongest support.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. I was not able to vote for this report, but I fully support the position of the EPP Group and the French delegation to adopt this report. In particular, this resolution stresses that over-regulation is a hindrance for potential beneficiaries of EUROPEAN funds. Similarly, the complexity of the procedures affects SMEs or small municipalities even harder. The report calls for a reduction in administrative burden at all levels, a simplification of control activities or the development of online procedures. This is an essential objective to ensure that these funds are used to the best of their ability by citizens.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. Cohesion policy is one of the EU's most effective and powerful tools for economic growth, sustainable development and the creation of new jobs. However, due to complicated administrative and bureaucratic procedures and high control costs, it is very difficult to access the resources provided by cohesion policy, which in many cases discourages investors from launching different projects and applying for grants, leading to the loss of valuable ideas. It is therefore essential to reform our cohesion policy. It needs to be more transparent and simpler than it is today. This will also increase the chances of small and medium-sized enterprises and the catch-up of poorer regions.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for a reformed cohesion policy that will reduce the burden of complicated procedures on beneficiaries, particularly small and medium-sized businesses, NGOs and municipalities, which are in need of EU funding.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. ‒ There is a wide consensus across the European Union that the level of bureaucratic hurdles, administrative burdens and lack of access to information are severe enough to deeply hinder the implementation of the cohesion policy. We have a wide number of reports, from grass-root organisations to administration officials, that there are problems with its transparency, with its language, with its accessibility for all stakeholders. That is why I voted for this motion for a resolution and I sincerely hope its recommendations will be taken into account.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: in writing. \u2012 The main objective of the resolution to reduce red tape in EU funding is to reduce the documents, time and resources that are lost when applying, managing and reporting projects under operational programmes in the EU.  The document sets as important objectives the transition to full electronic communication with the beneficiaries of EU funds, as well as the reduction of the requirements for the provision of data and information by project contractors. At the same time, the EP is pushing for the introduction of a single audit and standardised public procurement in the EU, the use of accessible language, an end to frequent changes to the rules on application, management and reporting of projects.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. The European Union's cohesion policy is one of the EU's largest policy areas and is generously funded. Combating abuses and increasing the efficiency of the use of funds is therefore absolutely necessary – after all, it is also about taxpayers' money. However, this report does not go far enough, and I do not, in particular, miss the clear wording of past misconduct. That is why I abstained.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy must be results-oriented. Therefore, in order to ensure the success of this policy, its effective impact on smart, sustainable and inclusive growth and to bring it closer to its citizens, it is necessary to simplify the rules governing cohesion policy. Existing over-regulation and complex procedures prevent the receipt of EU support and create excessive administrative costs and burdens. It is therefore essential that the procedures for implementing financial instruments are as close as possible to business practices and do not create additional burdensome procedures. In this context, the Commission should provide detailed simplification guidelines to ensure an appropriate balance between simplification and detection and prevention of irregularities, including fraud. In addition, the principle of good governance, which is essential for the effective implementation of cohesion policy and a successful contribution to smart, sustainable and inclusive economic growth, should be implemented.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ This report is regarding a simplification of the procedure in cohesion policy. In simple terms Parliament thinks that there are many faults in the current system that have many negative effects, i.e. the language is too complicated and also lost in translation, the procedure for allocation of cash is too slow and the process of transposition is too slow. This in turn has created a system that is not cost-effective. This motion for a resolution essentially asks for digitalisation of this process and calls for e-cohesion. Even though we are against the Commission distributing money and the processes involved with that, this resolution is essentially asking for a simplification of the current procedure which would make things more cost-effective in the long run. Therefore an abstention was recommended.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I have always tried to support, through my parliamentary work, the need to make European funds more accessible to potential beneficiaries, in particular by simplifying participation procedures and making the parameters and evaluation mechanisms of the projects submitted more transparent. Administrative burdens and over-regulation are, in my view, an obstacle to the effective and effective use of European funding by beneficiaries, particularly by small and medium-sized enterprises. We therefore need to move quickly towards simplifying the matter, and this legislative proposal is along these lines; I would therefore have voted in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ Cohesion Policy is the EU's main policy of growth and investment development aligned with the objectives of the 'Smart, Sustainable and Inclusive Growth Strategy - Europe 2020' and aimed at reducing the gap between regions and promoting convergence, with a budget of EUR 351.8 billion by the end of 2020. Unfortunately, despite all efforts, excessive bureaucracy, especially at regional and local level, hinders the effective management of ESI funds in the EU by Member States, regional and local self-government. Changing the rules, or designing new ones, all with the aim of bureaucraising the necessary control procedures that do not bring real impacts in reducing errors and better targeting of European funding should be prevented. Like most MPs, I wonder until when like that? This is why I support the questions raised by the European Commission. It is necessary to find the right ratio between responsibility and simplification. The solution is simple - fewer controls, and tougher sanctions for violators, especially those who deliberately violate the rules.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ Complex application procedures for funds and their withdrawal can place a significant burden on beneficiaries, in particular SMEs, NGOs and municipalities in need of EU funds, and that most often these entities have neither the financial and human resources nor the expertise to successfully apply for and manage EU grants. Despite the reformed cohesion policy for the 2014-2020 programming period, which identifies methods of simplification, application, governance, reporting and control with regard to the ESI Funds, they still present some difficulties for beneficiaries and managing authorities, in particular those with fewer administrative and financial capacities. For all of the above, I join the Commission's calls to propose as soon as possible detailed simplification guidelines so that Member States and their regions are aware of their task in eliminating or at least significantly reducing administrative burden and over-regulation at national and local level in public procurement procedures, selecting project proposals and monitoring and control activities, including frequent changes in regulations, simplifying languages and standardised procedures, and focusing the EU budget on tangible results.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Balanced development meeting cohesion policy objectives requires a specific simplified approach to development towards small and medium-sized enterprises, NGOs and municipalities that would provide funding, build human capacities and improve their level of expertise.  In my view, the applications themselves for cohesion policy programmes must therefore allow those most in need to apply to them. Therefore, with mandatory requests from applicants of all data that can detect and prevent irregularities and fraud, it is important to take into account that assistance is most needed for those whose human and other capacities cannot meet the requirements of complex cohesion policy procedures. If these procedures are not simplified by addressing all the problems observed in previous programming periods, we may be at risk of increasing inequality among beneficiaries even further by implementing cohesion policy.  Also, as development needs to be addressed in a holistic way and different beneficiaries use different cohesion policy programmes, the procedures of the different implementing authorities need to be agreed. In this regard, I support all activities aimed at simplifying all cohesion policy procedures.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite the progress made by the EU institutions towards simplifying cohesion policy, the submission of applications, the management, reporting and control of EIS funds remain complex, both for beneficiaries and for managing authorities, in particular for those with less administrative and financial resources. All this leads to significant indirect costs for potential beneficiaries of EU funding. I therefore believe that it is necessary to simplify the existing regulations, language and procedures, in order to achieve tangible results. That is why I am voting in favour today.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I strongly support efforts to simplify burdensome financial procedures and management and reporting procedures in the framework of the implementation of the European Structural and Investment Funds, which were part of the reformed cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020, while stressing that a reasonable balance must be struck between simplification and the provision of effective financial control measures. I also support the creation of a new group of high-level independent experts on simplification monitoring and the European Commission's strategy for better regulation, as these are positive steps towards greater simplification. However, much remains to be done to improve law-making, support the e-cohesion system, identify good practices and, in the long term, simplify the structures and processes associated with the European Structural and Investment Funds. Areas under shared management, including implementation, management, reporting and control activities, continue to place an undue burden on both managing authorities and beneficiaries, including municipalities and small enterprises, and may have negative effects in terms of investment and absorption of funds.  I therefore supported the motion for a resolution.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider reducing the administrative burden throughout the process of providing European funds to be one of the priorities of all European integration. In the vast majority of cases, European money helps where it should, but the whole process often suffers from excessive complexity. The pursuit of efficiency is therefore really spot on.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the search for simplification and efficiency in cohesion policy for 2014-2020. Urgent action is needed to ensure that project owners who claim European funds are no longer discouraged by the complexity of the procedures. I am campaigning to remove barriers in international trade. I find in the cohesion policy some of these obstacles. Management costs, number of supporting documents, processing times are all factors that discourage potential beneficiaries. Some people give up filing files because of the bureaucracy. However, access to finance for SMEs remains a priority. We must now act.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: In writing. Today, due to overly complicated procedures and over-regulation, and particularly in the context of the transposition of the directives, many SMEs, NGOs and micro-enterprises are facing inequities in access to public orders and subsidies. The joint lack of skills and financial resources penalizes them in certain administrative procedures such as public procurement or grant applications. The motion for a resolution on the search for simplification and efficiency in cohesion policy for 2014-2020 aims to provide solutions to this complexity. That is why I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims in particular to reduce the administrative burden which is essentially and arbitrarily borne by the smaller structures. In particular, this text encourages Member States to simplify the regulation of public procurement by standardising procedures and to streamline and simplify control activities.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I have supported this resolution, which calls for a simplification and greater effectiveness of cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020. Procedures under the European Structural and Investment Funds remain complex for both beneficiaries and management authorities. This complexity needs to be reduced, which particularly penalizes small beneficiaries such as SMEs or municipalities. This includes eliminating administrative burden and over-regulation in contracting procedures, the selection of project proposals, and monitoring and monitoring activities. For example, there needs to be a stability of the rules and a standardization of procedures. In addition, timelines for the transition to the e-cohesion system must be met, the sharing of best practices must be encouraged and the use of the multi-fund approach should be increased.  Cohesion policy is an essential instrument to support our territories and their populations in their development and the enhancement of their wealth. So we need to use all the levers we can to improve their operation.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. The EU institutions have taken important steps to address the issue of simplification. Despite the efforts made, excessive formalities remain an obstacle to the efficient management of the EIE Funds.  This motion for a Resolution calls on the Commission, inter alia, to share simplification initiatives and guidelines, to strike an optimal balance between accountability and simplification, to fully implement electronic cohesion in the management of the EIE Funds, to adopt and implement a flexible approach to beneficiaries' data and information facilitation obligations , and participate in a structured and permanent dialogue with the European Parliament and other partners. For all this, I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. In the resolution on simplifying and improving the effectiveness of the cohesion policy for 2014-2020, which I supported, the European Parliament calls on the Commission to introduce detailed directives on simplification in order to better target red tape. In this context, MEPs call on the Commission to publish a roadmap for Member States with a view to streamlining and simplifying monitoring, monitoring and reporting activities, particularly for beneficiaries. This was a request that had been addressed by the ministers responsible for regional policy earlier this month. In the Member States, the adopted text calls for meeting the deadline of 31 December 2015 under the terms of the regulation with common provisions (Article 122, '3) to adopt e-cohesion, which allows information to be exchanged electronically between beneficiaries and authorities in charge of regional programmes, with a view to shortening the time between applying and obtaining grants. Finally, another emblematic demand, we called for an increased use of the multi-fund approach, which allows beneficiaries to combine several funds in the same project, according to the arrangements set up in the cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Following an oral question, this motion for a resolution was tabled in order to alert to the need to adopt administrative simplification methodologies with regard to compliance with the requirements directly related to the implementation of the Cohesion Fund and the other European Structural and Investment Funds. Similarly, it is absolutely essential to raise awareness among Member States and their regions of the task of eliminating or substantially reducing the administrative burden inherent in applications for structural funding, procurement procedures or selection of proposals, given the obstacle that such bureaucratic bottlenecks already pose in the already heavy administrative machinery of the Member States. To this end, I am fully in favour of this motion for a resolution which is strife for further simplification and direction towards better performance in cohesion policy 2014-2020.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. The demand, management, reporting and controls of the Structural Funds are still too complex despite the European Union's desire to simplify. Indeed, there are many obstacles to follow for beneficiaries, particularly SMEs, which need European funding.  I therefore voted in favour of this text, which makes a clear observation and on which all the players agree. It the for example calls on the Commission to provide Member States and their regions with a roadmap to streamline and simplify monitoring, monitoring and reporting activities, including for beneficiaries, in order to eliminate the difficulties currently faced. There is an urgent need for everyone to benefit from European funds without hindrance.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure on simplifying cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020 as I believe that the procedures for accessing the European Structural and Investment Funds need to be further streamlined. Member States must work to significantly reduce the administrative burden and over-regulation at national and local level in the framework of procurement procedures, the selection of proposed projects and monitoring and control activities.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this simplification. The general cohesion policy has, right now, many overlapping spaces and spaces on which it is difficult to decide what would be its best fit. We understand that a simplification in the respective policy would allow greater ease in understanding the usefulness of the policy, as well as greater chances that citizens would be aware of the existence of it.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution because it is an official position of the European Parliament to ask the Commission and member states to work together to lighten administrative burdens as well as to simplify the rules on cohesion policy funds. This concern expressed by Parliament concerns, inter alia, the relatively high percentage of programmes which are ultimately not carried out, due not only to budgetary constraints linked to the impact of the crisis and austerity policies, but also to delays in payments, the bureaucratic burden or the contradiction of rules. However, such simplification of the rules should not serve as an excuse for, on the one hand, letting your guard down from account control and the use of allocated budget items, or on the other hand, to leave the door open to financing instruments that are already beginning to participate actively in operational programmes, such as private credit institutions or venture capital funds.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this motion due to it wishing to change the way the Commission handles its money. I do not wish to see the Commission in charge of any UK money but, while saying that, I do not want to stand in the way of process simplifications that could lead to a more cost-effective system.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Many adjustments have been added to structural and investment funds in the new programming period, which contribute to simplifying the bureaucratic burden on applicants. This problem is also heavily addressed by the Commission through a group of independent experts, which was set up precisely to monitor and improve simplification procedures. Moreover, the various legislative texts have finally been consolidated and today all funds are subject to the same common provisions.  I welcome all these Commission initiatives, but on the other hand, it must be acknowledged that reporting and control concerning the Structural Funds is still too difficult for many beneficiaries. I also supported the resolution because it underlines the fact that complicated procedures and some complex rules can place a significant burden on beneficiaries, especially for entities that do not always have sufficient administrative capacity, such as small and medium-sized enterprises, non-profit organisations or municipalities. In addition, national authorities are adding obligations beyond those resulting from EU acts, thereby creating a brake on pumping when transferring European standards to national rules. But we're already going through a lot of problems. A good example is the digitisation of the whole process, which will allow the applicant access to all documents and administrative steps through a centralised website. I believe that this will significantly reduce the time between the submission of the application and the disbursment of funds.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the resolution entitled ‘Towards simplification and performance orientation in cohesion policy 2014-2020’. I believe that, despite the considerable steps towards more clarity and coherence in European Structural and Investment Fund management in the 2014-2020 multiannual financial framework, there is still room for simplifying the application, implementation and reporting tasks for beneficiaries. In my view, this would especially require more guidance by the Commission towards Member States on administrative streamlining and promotion of best practices. Nevertheless, simplification should never be carried out to the detriment of the safe use of ESI Funds and ultimately of the EU budget. This is why I believe that there is a need to ensure a proper balance between simplification and the detection and prevention of irregularities and fraud through the use of operational tools like the ARACHNE database.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 It is important to support the reform of cohesion policy in terms of rationalisation and simplification. Complicated procedures can create a significant burden, such as for small and medium-sized enterprises or municipalities that need EU funding but lack financial and human resources, as well as expertise for successfully applying for EU resources.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒I support this motion for a resolution, as Parliament recognises the importance of significant steps taken by the EU institutions towards simplifying procedures. Complicated provisions cause barriers and stays out of the market for a long time, as well as many indirect costs for potential beneficiaries seeking EU funds. This reduces the impact of funding investments and creates barriers for beneficiaries, citizens and businesses in the EU, especially for SMEs. I support this proposal because a complicated procedure can place a significant burden on beneficiaries, in particular small and medium-sized enterprises, NGOs and municipalities, which are in need of EU funding. There are entities that do not have the financial and human resources or expertise to successfully apply for EU governance and support.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ This resolution proposes to reduce red tape, especially for medium and small businesses, NGOs and municipalities, which seek support from EU funds. These entities do not have sufficient financial or human resources to enable them to successfully apply for them. For these reasons, the Commission and the Member States are required to continue their already started efforts to simplify applications, and to fight in detecting and preventing irregularities and various fraud attempts.  Also, the resolution proposes 31.12.2015. as the date by which the Commission and the Member States should move to the so-called E-connectivity, as a precondition for a significant reduction in the total time required to apply. I support this resolution because it provides all those who want to apply for incentives with greater opportunities and a simpler process to obtain them. I believe that by submitting as many correctly submitted applications as much as can, there will be more payouts, which means more investment in various sectors of society, job creation, and economic growth.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution towards a simplified and performance-oriented cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020. Despite the reform of cohesion policy for the 2014-2020 programming period, we are still facing too many complex and bureaucratic procedures, both for beneficiaries and for administrative authorities. I would like to draw attention to small and medium-sized enterprises, which are particularly important in the European Union, as they represent 99% of all businesses in the European Union and provide two thirds of private sector jobs.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this motion for a resolution on cutting red tape for local authorities and EU funding beneficiaries. I welcome all efforts to simplify the implementation of the European Structural and Investment Funds, on the proviso that a sensible balance is struck between simplification and effective financial controls. I also support the creation of the new High Level Group of Independent Experts on Monitoring Simplification and the Commission’s Better Regulation Strategy, both positive steps towards the greater simplification mentioned in this resolution.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The introduction of detailed simplification directives is important because it guides Member States and regions to eliminate and/or drastically reduce management burdens, especially in cases of action control, project selection and public expenditure. This simplification extends proportionately to the control and reporting of activities, to the application and reporting of expenditure linked to European financial programmes and to the reduction of application times - allocation of funds through the use of electronic applications and digital platforms.

name: József SZÁJER
text: Writing. \u2012 Serious progress has already been made in the area of cohesion policy in order to reduce administrative burdens and simplify them, but the administrative obligations imposed on the european structural and investment fund's end-leaver are still extremely significant. This is particularly difficult for SMEs, non-public organisations and municipalities, as these organisations and institutions desperately need EU funding, but do not have the financial and human resources capacity to successfully apply and manage the resources they receive. Against this background, further simplification is essential for the effective use of resources. Frequent changes to the rules should be avoided, procedures should be standardised, language used simplified, e-cohesion should be promoted, dissemination and one-stop shop should be promoted.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU institutions have taken significant steps towards simplifying the MNT for the period 2014-2020. However, I agree with the motion's finding that, despite simplification, the application, management, reporting and control of the European Structural and Investment Funds remains difficult for both beneficiaries and managing authorities, in particular those with lower administrative and financial capacity. Further simplification will therefore be necessary.  I support the Commission's implementation of detailed guidelines on simplification in order to make Member States and their regions aware of their responsibilities in relation to public procurement procedures, the selection of project applications and the elimination or at least reduction of administrative burdens and over-regulation at national and local level in monitoring and control activities.  I voted in favour of this motion precisely because it is feared that in some Member States the situation caused by simplification changes will be a hotbed of trickery and corruption.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Despite the reform of cohesion policy and its significant simplification, the application, supervision and management of funds remains problematic for both beneficiaries and managing authorities. Complex procedures may, as a result, discourage potential beneficiaries from benefiting from EU aid schemes.  In its resolution, the European Parliament rightly pointed out the need to promote the simplification of the rules on financial instruments under the ESI Funds, in order to better adapt to the needs of beneficiaries, which can therefore contribute to increasing their use. That is why I decided to vote in favour of the EP resolution.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Effective implementation of EU cohesion policy requires simplification of current procedures and orientation towards achieving tangible results. Important steps have so far been taken to simplify the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework Agenda. Despite these steps, however, the application, management, reporting and control of the Structural and Investment Funds remain cumbersome processes for beneficiaries and implementing authorities. The most important impact is felt by small and medium-sized enterprises, non-governmental organisations and municipalities, which need European funding the most. This significantly reduces the impact of European funds on the development of Member States' regions. At the same time, duplication and differences in audit work and methodology require a unification of practices and a greater focus on efficiency and results. From this point of view, the Commission should draw up detailed guidelines on simplifying administrative procedures at Member State level and developing common practices at European level in order to avoid bottlenecks that arise. The digitisation and simplification of enforcement procedures by providing all relevant information may be useful for this purpose if an increased emphasis is placed on the needs of beneficiaries. The current resolution is a first step in the right direction.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted for it. Indeed, I am in favour of the Commission introducing detailed directives on simplification to raise awareness among Member States and their regions of the need to eliminate, or at least significantly reduce, the administrative burden and over-regulation at national and local levels on procurement procedures, the selection of project proposals and monitoring and monitoring activities. , including avoiding frequent changes to applicable rules, simplifying language and standardising procedures, and focusing the EU budget on tangible results.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The cohesion policy is the biggest investment tool at our disposal to achieve the Europe 2020 goals. I voted in favour of this resolution which sets out recommendations to the Commission and the Member States on how to maximise the use and the efficiency of the fund. Up to now and although there were previous attempts to simplify it, the procedures remained too cumbersome for both the managing authorities and the beneficiaries, preventing, in particular, SMEs and NGOs from making full use of it. The resolution calls on the Commission to develop guidelines on simplification and provide the Member States with a roadmap for monitoring and reporting activities. Lastly the Commission and the Member States should work closer together with the beneficiaries to make sure the procedures’ rules match their needs.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. I consider Simplification and focus on results as one of the essential elements of a successful cohesion policy, and therefore I wholeheartedly welcome this issue. I consider the establishment of common rules in the structural and investment funds - the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund - as crucial for further development of the Union's regional development policy. In addition, I welcome the establishment of a High Group of Independent Experts in supersing simplification for beneficiaries of the European Structural and Investment Funds within the Commission, the scrutiny of financial regulation and the provisions on common rules. The fact is that complicated procedures can place a significant burden on the backs of fund beneficiaries, in particular small and medium-sized enterprises, NGOs and municipalities, which need the funds precisely the most, as they themselves do not have sufficient human and financial resources, nor expertise, to be able to successfully fulfil all stages in achieving EU support. In this regard, I consider it commendable and necessary to call on the Commission and the Member States to make further efforts to simplify the ARACHNE risk assessment system, as it must achieve a balance between simplification on the one hand and detecting and preventing irregularities, including fraud, on the other.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the european Parliament's motion for a resolution on the road to a simplified and performance-oriented cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020, as I believe that it is necessary to provide Member States with a good plan to unify and simplify the management, monitoring, reporting and control activities of the European Structural and Investment Funds, as these are now too complex, both for beneficiaries and for public authorities.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this simplification. The general cohesion policy has, right now, many overlapping spaces and spaces on which it is difficult to decide what would be its best fit. We understand that a simplification in the respective policy would allow greater ease in understanding the usefulness of the policy, as well as greater chances that citizens would be aware of the existence of it.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission should introduce detailed guidelines on simplification in order to make Member States and their regions aware of their tasks of eliminating or at least reducing the administrative burden and over-regulation at national and local level in the course of public procurement procedures, the selection of project applications and monitoring and control activities. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this simplification. The general cohesion policy has, right now, many overlapping spaces and spaces on which it is difficult to decide what would be its best fit. We understand that a simplification in the respective policy would allow greater ease in understanding the usefulness of the policy, as well as greater chances that citizens would be aware of the existence of it.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. "U2012 Following the adoption of the Cohesion Policy Legislative Package for the period 2014-2020, this motion for a Resolution aims to highlight the need to simplify and guide cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020 to results. It is thus intended to move towards a more effective and efficient cohesion policy, which contributes more to smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, making the Union closer to its citizens. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution because it is an official position of the European Parliament to ask the Commission and member states to work together to lighten administrative burdens as well as to simplify the rules on cohesion policy funds. This concern expressed by Parliament concerns, inter alia, the relatively high percentage of programmes which are ultimately not carried out, due not only to budgetary constraints linked to the impact of the crisis and austerity policies, but also to delays in payments, the bureaucratic burden or the contradiction of rules. However, such simplification of the rules should not serve as an excuse for, on the one hand, letting your guard down from account control and the use of allocated budget items, or on the other hand, to leave the door open to financing instruments that are already beginning to participate actively in operational programmes, such as private credit institutions or venture capital funds.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution because it urges the Commission and the Member States to promote the simplification of the rules governing financial instruments within ESI Funds in order to align them more closely to the beneficiaries’ needs, aiming at their improved use. It is important at this time that we use cohesion funds in the most effective and sustainable way possible, without allowing parts of our Union to be left behind. In the interests of use and transparency it is important that there is a standardisation of procedures across the EU to allow citizens a greater understanding. This policy area is too important to the wellbeing of European Union citizens to be allowed to continue with its current bottlenecks.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this report because it calls for greater simplification and efficiency of cohesion policy. As a liberal, I am, of course, in favour of removing the numerous bureaucratic obstacles and administrative burdens. This will only benefit cohesion policy and any beneficiaries.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Following an oral question at the second session in October, this report aims to recognise the importance of what has already been done in relation to the simplification of the procedures for the preparation of applications, presentation of results and the various moments of evaluation of projects, in the implementation of the Directives for such simplification. The report stresses that simplification and prevention and detection of irregularities should be balanced, i.e. safeguarding that facilitation does not mean laxity, which could benefit fraudulent processes. This issue mainly affects popular-based associations and NGOs, SMEs and municipalities. The issue of administrative simplification and capacity building for meeting the requirements associated with the EU Structural and Cohesion Funds is, for many realities, an impediment to project eligibility and, consequently, to the lack of access to cohesion funds. In this sense, further simplification will result in greater potential for access to funds by these agents.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. In principle, streamlining the effectiveness of cohesion policy must be favoured, but the motion for a resolution does not address the central problems of cohesion policy, such as misuse of funds, etc. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Writing. I voted against this proposal because, while it facilitates the administrative apparatus, it at the same time restricts national rights and severely restricts the self-determination of the Member States. Proposals such as these clearly show how the EU is trying to ignore the participation of its Member States and how national law is being further curtailed. This cannot and must not be the aim of a European Community!

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on the focus of cohesion policy 2014-2020 on simplification and performance. Reducing bureaucracy is a noble goal. Once the EU is prepared to do its bit here, I will be happy to support it as it does here. Irrespective of this, I believe that cohesion policy itself is a great evil. The diversity and disparities in Europe should not be reduced by promoting projects from Brussels from a blurred bird's-eye view and on the basis of the watering can principle. As a result, I consider this to be a huge waste of money.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution of the Committee on Regional Development which improves the mechanisms to enhance the effectiveness of cohesion policy in the EU for the 2014-2020 programming period.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I strongly support this resolution, which aims to encourage both the Commission and the Member States to simplify the process of drawing on European money. Although some simplification efforts have been made, I think that drawing down money is very difficult for both beneficiaries and managing authorities, especially if they have lower administrative and financial capacities. Through this resolution, I call on the Commission to introduce detailed guidelines to simplify the whole process at national and local level in the context of public procurement processes, the selection of proposals for projects and monitoring and control. In my opinion, in addition to simplifying the absorption process, it is necessary to simplify follow-up by introducing a 'single audit principle' and a greater focus on performance audits, which can better assess the effectiveness and effectiveness of operations and lead to simplification proposals.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this European Parliament resolution. It is true that the requirements for various requests for funding from the European Structural and Investment Funds are often too complicated, and this alone will deter many candidates. Others then have a problem with the fact that the opaque conditions will not be fulfilled, despite their efforts. These complicated procedures represent the most significant burden for small and medium-sized enterprises or municipalities that need EU funding but do not have sufficient resources and expertise to make a successful application. Simplifying applications and removing whether a significant reduction in the administrative burden is therefore, in my opinion, the right step for a more efficient use of EU funds.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 This motion for a resolution seeks to recognise the importance of what has already been done with regard to the simplification of the procedures for the preparation of applications, the presentation of results and the various moments of evaluation of projects, in the implementation of the Directives for such simplification. The issue of administrative simplification and capacity building for meeting the requirements associated with the EU Structural and Cohesion Funds is, for many realities, an impediment to project eligibility and, consequently, to the lack of access to cohesion funds. This issue mainly affects popular-based associations and NGOs, SMEs and municipalities.  In this sense, further simplification will result in greater potential for access to funds by these agents. We voted for it.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. I supported the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the road to a simplified and performance-oriented cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020, as I believe that implementation, management, reporting and supervision in relation to the European Structural and Investment Funds is still too complex for both beneficiaries and administrative authorities, especially those with smaller administrative and financial capacities.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, am I right in saying that this is your first time chairing plenary? I certainly cannot recall seeing you here before. So I would like to compliment you. I thought you did a very good job. You got through the votes very efficiently. Moreover, the political right were not accusing you of going too fast and the political left were not accusing you of going too slowly. So you struck the perfect balance. Well done!

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: I declare the session of the European Parliament adjoined. (The sitting was closed at 1 p.m.)
